('21', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 1
('21', 0, 1, 2, 43) 1. “PATH OF TRUTH FOR THE BRAVE ALONE” 1
('21', 0, 2, 3, 84) July, 1920 “The path of truth is for the brave alone, never for a coward.” I realize the significance of this poem 2 more and more as days pass.
('21', 0, 2, 4, 229) I also see that it is not for grown ups only to put the idea of this verse into practice; children and students, too, can do so.
('21', 0, 2, 5, 358) If we try to know and follow the path of truth right from childhood, then alone, on growing up, shall we be saved from following the path of untruth.
('21', 0, 2, 6, 508) Just as a disease, if neglected, becomes chronic and incurable, so also untruth, if permitted to take rot in us from childhood, will later grow into a serious disease and, becoming incurable, gradually ruin our health.
('21', 0, 2, 7, 727) It is for this reason that we find untruth increasing in us.
('21', 0, 2, 8, 788) So the highest lesson to be learnt during one’s student life is that one should know truth and act on it.
('21', 0, 2, 9, 894) This path has always been for the brave because a much greater effort is required to go up the steep slope of truth than to climb the Himalayas.
('21', 0, 2, 10, 1039) If at all, therefore, we want to work in this direction and serve ourselves, we should give the first place to truth and march forward with unshakable faith in it.
('21', 0, 2, 11, 1203) Truth is God.
('21', 0, 3, 12, 1217) MOHANDAS

('21', 1, 1, 2, 1463) 2. LETTER TO THE PRESS ON REPATRIATION OF SOUTH AFRICAN INDIANS
('21', 1, 2, 3, 1527) July 1, 1920 1
('21', 1, 3, 4, 1542) I have just read the interim report 2 of the South African Commission 3 published in Indian Opinion recently received.
('21', 1, 3, 5, 1661) As it reads, the report seems to be harmless.
('21', 1, 3, 6, 1707) Even the word “Repatriation” does not occur in it.
('21', 1, 3, 7, 1758) It is a cautiously worded document.
('21', 1, 3, 8, 1794) And as there seems to be no opposition to the recommendation from the resident Indian population, I am not inclined to oppose the proposal of the Commission.
('21', 1, 3, 9, 1952) At the same time there is no mistaking its intention.
('21', 1, 3, 10, 2006) Indeed they have not even attempted to conceal it, for, they ask His Excellency the Governor of South Africa “to appoint an official well acquainted with the Indian mind and their methods to act in a sympathetic manner and lay before the Indians the advantages of immediately returning to India”.
('21', 1, 3, 11, 2303) The case for the scheme is that the Indians are anxious to return and that the scheme satisfies that anxiety whereas the anxiety seems to be all on the part of the Commission and their return is to be stimulated by placing its advantages before our sorely tried countrymen.
('21', 1, 3, 12, 2577) The working of the scheme will, however, require ceaseless watching.
('21', 1, 3, 13, 2646) There should be no compulsion of any kind whatsoever and no forfeiture of rights of domicile.
('21', 1, 3, 14, 2740) I was pleased to notice absence of any reference to such forfeiture in the interim report.
('21', 1, 3, 15, 2831) One however never knows what undertaking may not be taken from the poor returning Indians against the grant of a free passage.
('21', 1, 3, 16, 2958) If the scheme is benevolently intended to relieve the present distress the Union Government will simply facilitate the return of those who are unable to support themselvs in South Africa, without bargaining for the forfeiture of domicile.
('21', 1, 3, 17, 3197) To insist upon the loss of that valuable right would be to take a mean advantage of the distressful condition on some of our countrymen in South Africa.
('21', 1, 4, 18, 3350) Young India, 7 7 1920
('21', 1, 5, 19, 3372) 1 Released on this date through the Associated Press of India; vide The Bombay Chronicle, 2 7 1920
('21', 1, 6, 20, 3471) 2 It contained a scheme of voluntary repatriation of Indians from South Africa to be carried out under Section 6 of the Indians’ Relief Act, 1914; vide “Uncanny”, 14 7 1920. 3 Appointed by the South African Government to enquire into the question of Asiatics trading and holding land in South Africa.
('21', 1, 6, 21, 3772) The Commission was assisted by Sir Benjamin Robertson on behalf of the Government of India.

('21', 4, 0, 1, 7355) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 5
('21', 4, 1, 2, 7398) 4. NON CO OPERATION
('21', 4, 2, 3, 7418) Since there is no reason to hope that, before August 1, either the khilafat issue will have been satisfactorily solved or a revision of the peace terms promised, we must get ready to start non co operation.
('21', 4, 2, 4, 7625) The Committee is making preparations in this behalf.
('21', 4, 2, 5, 7678) Meantime, the following can be done : 1. Not to subscribe to new loans.
('21', 4, 2, 6, 7750) 2. Not to register one’s name for recruitment in military or civil service.
('21', 4, 2, 7, 7826) The Government has no right to occupy Mesopotamia.
('21', 4, 2, 8, 7877) Mandate is in fact nothing but occupation.
('21', 4, 2, 9, 7920) Moreover, according to newspaper reports, the Arabs do not like even the sight of Indian soldiers there.
('21', 4, 2, 10, 8025) Whether or not this is true, it is the duty of every Indian not to join such service.
('21', 4, 2, 11, 8111) Those who go to Mesopotamia will be doing so merely for money.
('21', 4, 2, 12, 8174) We must refuse to do this, if we do no more.
('21', 4, 2, 13, 8219) Not only can it never be our duty to rule by force over the Arabs, but we, who do not wish to remain in slavery, cannot wish to make others slaves.
('21', 4, 2, 14, 8367) Thus it behoves us not to subscribe to new loans and to refuse, from this very day, to offer ourselves as new recruits for service under the Government, especially for service which requires us to go to Mesopotamia.
('21', 4, 2, 15, 8583) In addition, it is hoped that the following things will be done from August I onwards : 1. Titles and honorary positions will be renounced.
('21', 4, 2, 16, 8723) 2. Legislatures will be boycotted.
('21', 4, 2, 17, 8758) 3. Parents will withdraw their children from Government schools.
('21', 4, 2, 18, 8823) 4. Lawyers will give up practice and help people to settle their civil disputes among themselves.
('21', 4, 2, 19, 8921) 5. Invitations to Government functions, parties, etc., will be politely refused, non co operation being given as the sole reason for doing so.
('21', 4, 2, 20, 9064) It is likely that this programme will be adopted from August 1, if the khilafat question is not settled.
('21', 4, 2, 21, 9169) Lala Lajpat Rai 1 has announced non co operation in the form of
('21', 4, 3, 22, 9233) 1 1865 1928; social reformer and journalist; president, Calcutta session of the Indian National Congress, 1920; founder of Servants of the People Society
('21', 5, 0, 1, 9387) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 5, 1, 2, 9427) boycott of legislatures if justice is not done in the matter of the Punjab.
('21', 5, 1, 3, 9503) So we can now take it that the Punjab too has joined the khilafat agitation.
('21', 5, 1, 4, 9580) Just as on this issue Muslims should take the lead, in the matter of the Punjab the Punjabis themselves should take the lead.
('21', 5, 1, 5, 9706) If they do not adopt non co operation, one may say that the other parts of India cannot do so either.
('21', 5, 1, 6, 9808) We shall hope that Lalaji will not stop with boycott of legislatures.
('21', 5, 1, 7, 9878) Until we win, we shall have to go on extending the scope of non co operation, and be ready to take the four steps suggested earlier.
('21', 5, 1, 8, 10011) I am convinced, however, that we would win if the whole nation joins in boycotting legislatures.
('21', 5, 1, 9, 10108) Three different views on the question of [boycotting] legislatures have been expressed : 1. Not to start non co operation at all; 2. to adopt non co operation after election to legislatures; 3. to boycott legislatures from the very start.
('21', 5, 2, 10, 10347) The first position is entirely opposed to non co operation.
('21', 5, 2, 11, 10407) The second alone needs to be examined.
('21', 5, 2, 12, 10446) I am convinced that it will be a waste of effort to try to enter legislatures and then to refrain from attending their sessions.
('21', 5, 2, 13, 10575) It is a waste of money and time alike.
('21', 5, 2, 14, 10614) I do not at all see the point of doing this.
('21', 5, 2, 15, 10659) What if unworthy people get elected because we do not come forward?
('21', 5, 2, 16, 10727) If such people enter the legislatures, the Government will not be able to run the government of an awakened people and it will be laughed at.
('21', 5, 2, 17, 10869) Moreover, if we join in the elections, we shall not be able to show what real boycott can be.
('21', 5, 2, 18, 10963) Our duty is so to educate public opinion—opinion of the voters—that it will be impossible for anybody to get elected to legislatures as their representatives.
('21', 5, 2, 19, 11122) So long as there is lack of understanding between the king and the subject, to attend the king’s council is to strengthen his hands.
('21', 5, 2, 20, 11255) A king cannot govern at all if he is not able to carry any section of his subjects with him.
('21', 5, 2, 21, 11348) It follows from this that the fewer the subjects who co operate with him, the less will be his authority.
('21', 5, 2, 22, 11454) Hence, for those who accept non co operation, the total boycott of legistatures is the only right course.
('21', 5, 2, 23, 11560) And so I hope that those who are busy trying to get elected to legislatures will give up the attempt for the present and address themselves to the more important work, that of educating public opinion on the khilafat and the Punjab issues, and so serve the people that, when the time for entering legislatures comes, they will be better qualified in virtue of their service.
('21', 5, 2, 24, 11935) Now remain the other two suggestions which are likely to be
('21', 6, 0, 1, 11995) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 7
('21', 6, 1, 2, 12038) severely criticized.
('21', 6, 1, 3, 12059) The lawyers should, for the time being, give up practice and intending litigants or those who find themselves dragged into litigation should boycott the courts and get their disputes settled through arbitration boards.
('21', 6, 1, 4, 12278) It is my confirmed belief that every Government masks its brute force and maintains its control over the people through civil and criminal courts, for it is cheaper, simpler and more honourable, for a ruler that instead of his controlling the people through naked force, they themselves, lured into slavery through courts, etc., submit to him of their own accord.
('21', 6, 1, 5, 12642) If people settle their civil disputes among themselves and the lawyers, unmindful of self interest, boycott the courts in the interest of the people, the latter can advance in no time.
('21', 6, 1, 6, 12827) I have believed for many years that every State tries to perpetuate its power through lawyers.
('21', 6, 1, 7, 12922) Hence, though fully aware that I will be criticized for making this suggestion, I have no hesitation in putting it forward.
('21', 6, 1, 8, 13046) What is true of lawyers is true of schools.
('21', 6, 1, 9, 13090) Even without such momentous issues as those of the khilafat and the Punjab, I would certainly, if I could, see to it that the present schools were completely abandoned and would provide the right kind of education for children on whom the future of India rests.
('21', 6, 1, 10, 13352) But my purpose at present in calling for a boycott of the schools is different; I want to show the Government by rendering the schools idle that, so long as justice is not done in regard to the Punjab and the khilafat, co operation with it is distasteful.
('21', 6, 1, 11, 13608) I know that this suggestion will be visited with a good deal of ridicule.
('21', 6, 1, 12, 13682) But, with the passing of time, people will realize that if they refused to crowd the Government schools, it would be impossible to run the administration.
('21', 6, 1, 13, 13837) Look where we will all over the world, we shall find that the education imparted to the children is intended to facilitate smooth running of the Government.
('21', 6, 1, 14, 13994) Where the Government is concerned solely with public welfare, so is the educational system; where the Government is of a mixed kind—as in India—the educational system is also calculated to confuse the intellect and is positively harmful.
('21', 6, 1, 15, 14232) While making this suggestion I do not wish that the youth should be left altogether unprovided with education.
('21', 6, 1, 16, 14343) Not for a moment do I wish people’s education to stop.
('21', 6, 1, 17, 14398) But I believe that, even when the schools have been deserted, we can look after people’s education all right.
('21', 6, 1, 18, 14508) I know that the suggestions I have made are quite serious and I do not expect to be able to convince readers all at once.
('21', 6, 1, 19, 14630) I shall take up these subjects time and again and place my arguments before the public.
('21', 6, 1, 20, 14718) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 4 7 1920
('21', 7, 0, 1, 14754) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 7, 1, 2, 14794) 5. KHILAFAT AND SWADESHI
('21', 7, 2, 3, 14819) Pathan Alamkhan Jivakhan writes 1 from Damnagar 2. This is really a heartening letter.
('21', 7, 2, 4, 14906) It is plain that the khilafat agitation will benefit the cause of swadeshi.
('21', 7, 2, 5, 14982) But the resolve not to use articles made in Europe only so long as the khilafat issue remained unsolved does not seem to me proper.
('21', 7, 2, 6, 15114) Muslims ought not to use European goods even if they get full justice on the khilafat question.
('21', 7, 2, 7, 15210) It is, moreover, not enough to boycott European goods alone.
('21', 7, 2, 8, 15271) No foreign goods, including Japanese goods, should be used.
('21', 7, 2, 9, 15331) The swadeshi movement is intended as a permanent change.
('21', 7, 2, 10, 15388) No matter how justly Europe deals with us, it is our duty to use only swadeshi goods so that India may ever get perfect justice.
('21', 7, 2, 11, 15517) The country, thus, can prosper only through the spinning wheel and the handloom.
('21', 7, 2, 12, 15598) Lakhs of Muslims have given up spinning and lakhs of Muslim weavers have given up weaving.
('21', 7, 2, 13, 15689) If Hindu and Muslim women again take to spinning and Hindu and Muslim weavers to weaving, within a short time the country will be able to produce all the cloth it needs.
('21', 7, 2, 14, 15859) I wish, therefore, to draw the attention of all, specially of women, to the example that Damnagar has set.
('21', 7, 2, 15, 15966) But what can women do about it, so long as men do not provide them with spinning wheels and slivers of cotton by getting cotton carded by the local carders?
('21', 7, 2, 16, 16123) I trust, therefore, that at least a few public spirited men will come forward in every village, who at a little trouble to themselves, will undertake to procure cotton, get it carded and turned into cotton rolls and supply them to women who may be prepared to spin.
('21', 7, 2, 17, 16389) This is a business in which no loss is possible.
('21', 7, 2, 18, 16438) Only last week we saw the instance of Dhasa 3 where men and women not only spin and weave but for the most part use cloth made in their own village and send out the surplus, if any, to other villages.
('21', 7, 2, 19, 16639) There is no starvation, there cannot be any, in that village.
('21', 7, 2, 20, 16701) With a little effort, things can be planned in a similar way in every village in India.
('21', 7, 2, 21, 16789) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 4 7 1920

('21', 8, 1, 2, 17192) 6. HOW “NAVAJIVAN” SHOULD BE RUN
('21', 8, 2, 3, 17225) A correspondent, who does not give his name and address but describes himself as “one who regards Navajivan as his own”, says: 1
('21', 8, 3, 4, 17354) I have often pointed out that letters containing serious statements should never be anonymous.
('21', 8, 3, 5, 17449) It seems to me that we, Indians, are more in the habit of writing such letters than foreigners.
('21', 8, 3, 6, 17545) We seem afraid or ashamed of expressing our views openly.
('21', 8, 3, 7, 17603) Why should one be afraid of expressing one’s honest views?
('21', 8, 3, 8, 17662) Or be ashamed of them?
('21', 8, 3, 9, 17685) I repeat my advice to anonymous correspondents to give up this habit of anonymity.
('21', 8, 3, 10, 17768) We have no right to express views or use language for which we are not prepared to accept responsibility.
('21', 8, 4, 11, 17874) This letter is reproduced almost literally.
('21', 8, 4, 12, 17918) Had the writer signed it, perhaps he would not have made the language as bitter as he has.
('21', 8, 4, 13, 18009) One who claims that he regards Navajivan “as his own” would put his views quite differently.
('21', 8, 4, 14, 18102) A friend had placed before me the very same views, but there was sweetness and politeness in his way of complaining.
('21', 8, 4, 15, 18219) I put it to “one who regards Navajivan as his own” that he could have used more polite language, if he had but cared to.
('21', 8, 4, 16, 18340) It is our duty to speak out our views, if we think them right and conducive to public interest, but we are never free to dispense with politeness.
('21', 8, 4, 17, 18487) Lack of politeness is a sign of anger.
('21', 8, 4, 18, 18526) The people are at present in an angry mood and boiling over, and therefore, pleased with nothing.
('21', 8, 4, 19, 18624) They are labouring under a mistaken feeling of helplessness, that they are powerless to do anything which may end their suffering.
('21', 8, 4, 20, 18755) And so they cling to anything that can make them forget their grief for a while, to anything which may provide them with an intoxicant in place of that of anger.
('21', 8, 4, 21, 18917) That is why we see nowadays an excess of sensational writing in newspapers.
('21', 8, 4, 22, 18993) Then, again, the craze for reading has increased and with that has grown the habit of reading long articles.
('21', 8, 4, 23, 19102) All these are signs of a state of intoxication.
('21', 8, 4, 24, 19150) Some people in Europe are so addicted to reading something or other that they cannot bear being without a book even for a while.
('21', 8, 4, 25, 19279) It being impossible to go on reading instructive literature the whole day, the plague of “shilling shockers” is on the increase.
('21', 8, 4, 26, 19408) A “shilling shocker” is a hair raising
('21', 8, 5, 27, 19447) 1 The letter which is not given here, complained that Navajivan had not fulfilled the hopes it had raised when it was started but, on the contrary, it had been deteriorating day by day.
('21', 9, 0, 1, 19633) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 9, 1, 2, 19674) novel, costing 8 annas.
('21', 9, 1, 3, 19698) Novels written in restrained language cannot be thrilling.
('21', 9, 1, 4, 19757) So writers and publishers, whose sole object is to make money, tempt readers with impossible stories written in language which no decent man can stand.
('21', 9, 1, 5, 19909) Reading“shilling shockers” has thus become a disease which has affected hundreds of thousands of men and women.
('21', 9, 1, 6, 20021) Even we in India are now in danger of catching this disease.
('21', 9, 1, 7, 20082) It is Navajivan’s effort, among other things, to protect the people against this danger.
('21', 9, 1, 8, 20171) It will never lose sight of this aim and so the writer of this letter has but to have patience.
('21', 9, 1, 9, 20267) All the same, I must admit that there is some substance in the complaint of this correspondent.
('21', 9, 1, 10, 20363) Our hope of being able to give better articles and getting them better printed has not been fully realized.
('21', 9, 1, 11, 20471) Though we have the money for it, we have not yet been able to procure a printing machine which can print a large number of copies.
('21', 9, 1, 12, 20602) Money cannot secure honesty.
('21', 9, 1, 13, 20631) There has been difficulty in getting honest workers.
('21', 9, 1, 14, 20684) The prices of paper have gone sky high while, when Navajivan was started, some people feared that they would fall.
('21', 9, 1, 15, 20799) All these difficulties were unavoidable.
('21', 9, 1, 16, 20840) With all that, we do not feel any shame in presenting Navajivan to the public.
('21', 9, 1, 17, 20919) Not one thoughtless statement appears in it.
('21', 9, 1, 18, 20964) Anyone who keeps in mind the purpose which Navajivan exists to serve, will never desert it so long as the paper remains loyal to that aim.
('21', 9, 1, 19, 21103) This aim has been to shed a new light on current affairs, to place before the people new ideas which have passed the test of experience, and to state whatever we think to be right, without fear of the Government or the public.
('21', 9, 1, 20, 21330) From this pledge, Navajivan has not departed in the slightest degree and, therefore, it is certainly not “wallowing in the dust,” nor is it “a helpless orphan”.
('21', 9, 1, 21, 21491) 1 There are, indeed, many obstacles in its path but it has always been, and will always be, struggling to surmount them The printing mistakes are to be regretted.
('21', 9, 1, 22, 21654) Sometimes it happens that good articles intended for publication come too late and others of an inferior quality have to be put in.
('21', 9, 1, 23, 21786) But from all this it cannot be argued that the aim with which Navajivan was started re mains unfulfilled.
('21', 9, 1, 24, 21892) One may also regret the reduction in the number of its
('21', 9, 2, 25, 21947) 1 As alleged in the letter under comment

('21', 10, 1, 3, 22159) There is no need, moreover, to jump to the conclusion that, because the pages are fewer, the matter published is necessarily less than before.

('21', 10, 1, 6, 22814) Navajivan’s prestige cannot be kept up by defending it.

('21', 11, 7, 10, 24416) 8. LETTER TO THE PRESS ON NON CO OPERATION
('21', 11, 8, 11, 24459) [Before July 7, 1920]
('21', 11, 9, 12, 24481) Mr. Gandhi writes to the Press : Needless to say that I am in entire accord with Lala Lajpat Rai on the question of the boycott of the reformed councils.
('21', 11, 9, 13, 24635) For me it is but one step in the campaign of non co operation and as I feel equally keenly on the Punjab question as on the khilafat, Lala Lajpat Rai’s suggestion is doubly welcome.
('21', 11, 9, 14, 24817) I have seen the suggestion made in more quarters than one that non co operation on the reforms should commence after the process of election has been through.
('21', 11, 9, 15, 24976) I cannot help saying that it is a mistake to go through the election farce and the expense of it when we clearly do not intend to take part in the proceedings of these Legislative councils.
('21', 11, 9, 16, 25166) Moreover, a great deal of educative work has to be done among the people.
('21', 11, 9, 17, 25240) And if I could I would not have the best attention of the country frittered away in electioneering.
('21', 11, 9, 18, 25340) The populace will not under stand the beauty of non co operation if we seek election and then resign.
('21', 11, 9, 19, 25442) But it would be a fine education for them if the electors are not to elect anybody and unanimously to tell whosoever may seek their suffrage that he would not represent them if he so sought election so long as the Punjab and khilafat questions were not satisfactorily settled.
('21', 11, 9, 20, 25719) I hope, however, that Lala Lajpat Rai does not mean to end with the boycott of the reformed councils.
('21', 11, 9, 21, 25821) We must take if necessary every one of the four stages of non co operation if we are to be regarded as a self respecting nation.
('21', 11, 9, 22, 25950) The issue is clear.
('21', 11, 9, 23, 25970) Both the khilafat terms and the Punjab affairs show that Indian opinion counts for little in the councils of the Empire.
('21', 11, 9, 24, 26091) It is a humiliating position, we shall make nothing of the reforms if we quietly swallow the humiliation.
('21', 11, 9, 25, 26197) In my humble opinion therefore the first condition of real progress is the removal of these
('21', 12, 0, 1, 26289) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 13
('21', 12, 1, 2, 26333) difficulties in our path.
('21', 12, 1, 3, 26359) And unless some better course of action is devised nolens volens non co operation must hold the field.
('21', 12, 2, 4, 26462) Young India, 7 7 1920
('21', 12, 3, 5, 26484) 9. STATEMENT BY NON CO OPERATION COMMITTEE
('21', 12, 4, 6, 26527) [Before July 7, 1920 ]
('21', 12, 5, 7, 26550) The following is a statement issued by the Non co operation Committee for public information and guidance : Many question have been asked of the Non co operation Committee as to its expectation and the methods to be adopted for beginning non co operation.
('21', 12, 5, 8, 26806) The Committee wish it to be understood that whilst they expect every one to respond to their recommendation to the full, they are desirous of carrying the weakest members also with them.
('21', 12, 5, 9, 26993) The Committee want to enlist the passive sympathy, if not the active co operation, of the whole of the country in the method of non co operation.
('21', 12, 5, 10, 27139) Those, therefore, who cannot undergo physical sacrifice will help by contributing funds or labour to the movement.
('21', 12, 5, 11, 27254) Should non co operation become necessary, the Committee has decided upon the following as part of the first stage: 1. Surrender of all titles of honour and honorary offices.
('21', 12, 5, 12, 27428) 2. Non participation in Government loans.
('21', 12, 5, 13, 27470) 3. Suspension by lawyers of practice and settlement of civil disputes by private arbitration.
('21', 12, 5, 14, 27564) 4. Boycott of Government schools by parents.
('21', 12, 5, 15, 27609) 5. Boycott of the reformed councils.
('21', 12, 5, 16, 27646) 6. Non participation in Government parties, and such other functions.
('21', 12, 5, 17, 27716) 7. Refusal to accept any civil or military post, in Mesopotamia, or to offer as Units for the army especially for service in the Turkish territories now being administered in violation of pledges.
('21', 12, 5, 18, 27913) PROPAGATE SWADESHI 8. Vigorous prosecution of swadeshi inducing the people at the time of this national and religious awakening, to appreciate their primary duty to their country, by being satisfied with its own
('21', 13, 0, 1, 28125) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 13, 1, 2, 28166) productions and manufactures.
('21', 13, 1, 3, 28196) Swadeshi must be pushed forward without waiting for the 1st of August, for it is an eternal rule of conduct not to be interrupted even when the settlement arrives.
('21', 13, 1, 4, 28360) In order not to commit themselves, people will refrain now from taking service either civil or military.
('21', 13, 1, 5, 28465) They will also suspend taking Government loans, new or old.
('21', 13, 1, 6, 28525) For the rest, it should be remembered that non co operation does not commence before 1st August next.
('21', 13, 1, 7, 28627) Every effort is being, and will still be, made to avoid resort to such a serious breach with the Government by urging His Majesty’s Ministers to secure the revision of a treaty which has been so universally condemned.
('21', 13, 1, 8, 28845) Those who realize their responsibility and gravity of the cause will not act independently, but in concert with the committee.
('21', 13, 1, 9, 28972) Success depends entirely upon disciplined and concerted non co operation and the latter is dependent upon strict obedience to instructions, calmness and absolute freedom from violence.
('21', 13, 1, 10, 29157) Young India, 7 7 1920
('21', 13, 2, 11, 29179) 10. NOTES
('21', 13, 3, 12, 29189) PURE CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE 1
('21', 13, 4, 13, 29215) All the readers of Young India may not know that Ahmedabad came under a heavy fine for the misdeeds of the April of last year.
('21', 13, 4, 14, 29342) The fine was collected from the residents of Ahmedabad but some were exem pted at the discretion of the collector.
('21', 13, 4, 15, 29457) Among those who were called upon to pay the fines were income tax payers.
('21', 13, 4, 16, 29531) They had to pay a third of the tax by them.
('21', 13, 4, 17, 29575) Mr. V.J. Patel 2, noted barrister, and Dr. Kanuga, a leading medical practitioner, were among those who were unable to pay.
('21', 13, 4, 18, 29699) They had admittedly helped the authorities to quell disturbance.
('21', 13, 4, 19, 29764) No doubt they were satyagrahis but they had endeavoured to still the mob fury even at some risk to their own persons.
('21', 13, 4, 20, 29882) But the authorities would not exempt them.
('21', 13, 4, 21, 29925) It was a difficult thing for them to use discretion in individual cas es.
('21', 13, 4, 22, 29999) It was equally
('21', 13, 5, 23, 30014) 1 This note is unsigned.
('21', 13, 5, 24, 30039) 2 Vallabhbhai Patel (1875 1950); Congress leader from Gujarat; first Deputy Prime Minister of free India
('21', 14, 0, 1, 30144) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 15
('21', 14, 1, 2, 30188) difficult for these two gentlemen to pay any fine when they were not to blame at all.
('21', 14, 1, 3, 30274) They did not wish to embarrass the autho rities and yet they were anxious to preserve their self respect.
('21', 14, 1, 4, 30380) They carried on no agitation but simply notified their inability to pay the fines in the circumstances set forth above.
('21', 14, 1, 5, 30500) Therefore an attachment was issued.
('21', 14, 1, 6, 30536) Dr. Kanuga is a very busy practitioner and his box is always full.
('21', 14, 1, 7, 30603) The watchful attaching official attached his cash boxand extracted enough money to discharge the writ of execution.
('21', 14, 1, 8, 30719) A lawyer’s business cannot be conduc ed on these lines.
('21', 14, 1, 9, 30775) Mr. Patel sported no cash box.
('21', 14, 1, 10, 30806) A sofa of his sitting room was therefore attached and advertised for sale and duly sold.
('21', 14, 1, 11, 30895) Both these satyagrahis thus completely saved their consciences.
('21', 14, 1, 12, 30959) Wiseacres may laugh at the folly allowing writs of attachment and paying for the collection of fines.
('21', 14, 1, 13, 31061) Multiply such instances and imagine the consequence to the authorities of executing thousands of writs.
('21', 14, 1, 14, 31165) Writs are possible when they are confined to a few recalcitrants.
('21', 14, 1, 15, 31231) They are troublesome when they have to be executed against many high souled persons who have done no wrong and who refuse payment to vindicate a principle.
('21', 14, 1, 16, 31387) They may not attract much notice when isolated individuals resort to this method of protest.
('21', 14, 1, 17, 31480) But clean examples have a curious method of multiplying themselves.
('21', 14, 1, 18, 31548) They bear publicity and the sufferers instead of incurring odium receive congratulations.
('21', 14, 1, 19, 31638) Men like Thoreau 1 brought about the abolition of slavery by their personal examples.
('21', 14, 1, 20, 31724) Says Thoreau, I know this well that if one thousand, if one hundred, if ten men whom I could name, —if ten honest men only— aye, if one honest man, in this State of Massachusetts ceasing to hold slaves were actually to withdraw from this co partnership and be locked up in the country gaol therefor, it would be the abolition of slavery in America.
('21', 14, 1, 21, 32073) For it matters not how small the beginning may seem to be, what is once well done is done for ever.
('21', 14, 1, 22, 32173) Again he says, I have contemplated the imprisonment of the offender rather than seizure of his goods—though both will serve the same purpose, because they who assert the purest right and consequently are most dangerous to a corrupt State, commonly have not spent much time in accumulating property.
('21', 14, 1, 23, 32472) We, therefore, congratulate Mr. Patel and Dr. Kanuga on the excellent example set by them in an excellent spirit and in an excellent cause.
('21', 14, 2, 24, 32612) Young India, 7 7 1920
('21', 14, 3, 25, 32634) 1 Henry David Thoreau (1817 1862); American recluse, naturalist and writer
('21', 15, 0, 1, 32709) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 15, 1, 2, 32750) 11. CRITICISM OF MUSLIM MANIFESTO
('21', 15, 2, 3, 32784) The khilafat representation 1 addressed to the Viceroy and my letter 2 on the same subject have been severely criticized by the Anglo Indian Press.
('21', 15, 2, 4, 32932) The Times of India which generally adopts an impartial attitude has taken strong exception 3 to certain statements made in the Muslim manifesto and had devoted a paragraph of its article to an adverse criticism of my suggestion that His Excellency should resign if the peace terms are not revised.
('21', 15, 2, 5, 33230) The Times of India excepts to the submission that the British Empire may not treat Turkey like a departed enemy.
('21', 15, 2, 6, 33343) The signatories have, I think, supplied the best of reasons.
('21', 15, 2, 7, 33404) They say :
('21', 15, 3, 8, 33415) We respectfully submit that in the treatment of Turkey the British Government
('21', 15, 4, 9, 33493) are bound to respect Indian Muslim sentiment in so far as it is neither unjust nor
('21', 15, 5, 10, 33576) unreasonable.
('21', 15, 5, 11, 33590) If the seven crore Mussulmans are partners in the Empire, I submit that their wish must be held to be all sufficient for refraining from punishing Turkey.
('21', 15, 5, 12, 33745) It is beside the point to quote what Turkey did during the war.
('21', 15, 5, 13, 33809) It has suffered for it.
('21', 15, 5, 14, 33833) The Times inquires wherein Turkey has been treated worse than the other Powers.
('21', 15, 5, 15, 33913) I thought that the fact was self evident.
('21', 15, 5, 16, 33955) Neither Germany nor Austria and Hungary has been treated in the same way that Turkey has been.
('21', 15, 5, 17, 34050) The whole of the Empire has been reduced to the retention of a portion of its capital, as it were to mock the Sultan and that too has been done under terms so humiliating that no self respecting person, much less a reigning sovereign can possibly accept.
('21', 15, 5, 18, 34305) The Times has endeavoured to make capital out of the fact that the representation does not examine the reason for Turkey not joining the Allies.
('21', 15, 5, 19, 34450) Well, there was no mystery about it.
('21', 15, 5, 20, 34487) The fact of Russia being one of the Allies was enough to warn Turkey against joining them.
('21', 15, 5, 21, 34578) With Russia knocking at the gate at the time of the war it was not an easy matter for Turkey to join the Allies.
('21', 15, 5, 22, 34691) But Turkey had cause to suspect Great Britain herself.
('21', 15, 5, 23, 34746) She knew that England had done no friendly turn to her during the Bulgarian War.
('21', 15, 5, 24, 34827) She was hardly well served at the time of the war with Italy.
('21', 15, 5, 25, 34889) It was still no doubt a bad
('21', 15, 6, 26, 34917) 1 Of 22 6 1920; vide “Muslim Leaders’ Representation to Viceroy”, 22 6 1920. 2 vide “Letter to Viceroy”, 22 6 1920.

('21', 16, 1, 2, 35110) choice.

('21', 16, 1, 7, 35455) Britain may not do it and retain the loyalty of the awakened Mussulmans of India.

('21', 16, 1, 18, 36375) They may not like Turkish rule but they like the present arrangements less.
('21', 16, 1, 19, 36451) They could have made their own honourable terms with Turkey but these self determining people will now be held down by the “matchless might” of the Allies, i.e., British forces.
('21', 16, 1, 20, 36629) Britain had the straight course open to her of keeping the Turkish Empire intact and taking sufficient guarantees for good government.
('21', 16, 1, 21, 36764) But her Prime Minister chose the crooked course of secrect treaties, duplicity and hypocritical subterfuges.
('21', 16, 1, 22, 36873) There is still a way out.
('21', 16, 1, 23, 36899) Let her treat India as a real partner.
('21', 16, 1, 24, 36938) Let her call the true representatives of the Mussulmans.
('21', 16, 1, 25, 36995) Let them go to Arabia and the other parts of the Turkish Empire and let her devise a scheme in concert with them—a scheme that would not humi liate Turkey, that would satisfy the just Muslim sentiments and that will secure honest self determination for the races composing that Empire.
('21', 16, 1, 26, 37281) If it was Canada, Australia or South Africa that had to be placated, Mr. Lloyd George 1 would not have dared to ignore them.
('21', 16, 1, 27, 37406) They have the power to secede.
('21', 16, 1, 28, 37437) India has not.
('21', 16, 1, 29, 37452) Let him no more insult India by calling her a partner, if her feelings count for naught.
('21', 16, 1, 30, 37541) I invite The

('21', 17, 1, 2, 37650) Times of India to reconsider its position and join an honourable agitation in which a high souled people are seeking nothing but justice.

('21', 17, 2, 8, 38553) 12. THE PRINCE
('21', 17, 3, 9, 38568) Mr. Baptista 1 has written to The Bombay Chronicle on the forth coming visit of His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales and has com bated views he imputes to me.
('21', 17, 3, 10, 38729) Much as I should like for the present to observe silence on this delicate subject I cannot allow it to be said of me that I would “visit the sins of ministers on the Prince”.
('21', 17, 3, 11, 38904) I entirely agree with Mr. Baptista that the Prince has no voice in the Government and that he is not concerned with the acts of the ministers of the Crown much less with their blunders.
('21', 17, 3, 12, 39090) I am just as keen as anyone could be to give a royal reception to the Prince and it is because I appreciate the constitution and its working that I would boycott the visit under present conditions.
('21', 17, 3, 13, 39288) It is because I know that the Royalty is above politics that I would not allow the ministers or the Government of India, if I can help it, to use the Prince for their own political purposes.
('21', 17, 3, 14, 39479) If I can do nothing else, at least I must not become a tool in the hands of the ministers and the Government of India and allow them, under cover of the Prince’s visit, to make their hold of India tighter and to demonstrate to the world that under their benign administration the whole of India is happy and contented.
('21', 17, 3, 15, 39798) For let there be no mistake that such will be the result if we remained silent and, under a mistaken sense of loyalty of constitution, gave any re 
('21', 17, 4, 16, 39946) 1 Joseph Baptista; Congress leader from Bombay
('21', 18, 0, 1, 39993) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 19
('21', 18, 1, 2, 40037) ception to the Prince.
('21', 18, 1, 3, 40060) On the contrary, I hope that our loyalty requires us to make it clear to His Majesty’s ministers that if they send the Prince to India, we shall be in no mood to join any receptions they might arrange.
('21', 18, 1, 4, 40262) I would tell them in no language that we are sick at heart over the khilafat and the Punjab questions and that whilst we are fighting them for very life, we must not be expected to co operate with them in giving receptions to His Royal Highness.
('21', 18, 1, 5, 40508) We would be doing a wrong to the public, if we neglected our clear duty of educating them to a truer perception of the meaning of the proposed Royal visit.
('21', 18, 1, 6, 40664) Let it be known that the Prince will arrive by and with the advice of the ministers, and consent and approval of the Government of India.
('21', 18, 1, 7, 40802) The visit therefore will be not an act of the Prince but that of the ministers and in boycotting the visit at this juncture we would be visiting their sins upon themselves and not on the Prince.
('21', 18, 1, 8, 40997) In other words we would not be playing into their hands.
('21', 18, 1, 9, 41054) Supposing the ministers sent Sir Michael O’ Dwyer 1 to replace Lord Chelmsford and he arranged the reception, would Mr. Baptista have us to fall into Sir Michael’s trap!
('21', 18, 1, 10, 41224) Suppose further that he insulted the Punjab under the Prince’s nose by ignoring the Punjab leaders, should the Punjab pocket the insult and join the reception because Royalty is above politics!
('21', 18, 1, 11, 41418) To say so would be to betray a woeful display of ignorance of the meaning of loyalty and politics.
('21', 18, 1, 12, 41517) I venture to suggest that if the Australian people were intensely dissatisfied with the acts, or the blunders of the ministers in the sense we are, they would boycott the visit without the slightest hesitation.
('21', 18, 1, 13, 41728) The ministers want to make political capital out of the proposed visit.
('21', 18, 1, 14, 41800) It is our duty to refuse to let them do so.
('21', 18, 1, 15, 41844) Mr. Baptista says and I agree that we are in mourning.
('21', 18, 1, 16, 41899) He there fore hopes that the Prince would not be sent but if he is, Mr. Baptista says, we should give him a welcome in spite of the mourning.
('21', 18, 1, 17, 42041) I want the Prince to come and therefore I would try to remove the cause of mourning and not take it as a settled fact.
('21', 18, 1, 18, 42160) I would tell the ministers that as we want to give the Prince an enthusiastic welcome, they should remove the khilafat and the Punjab grievances.
('21', 18, 1, 19, 42306) I should further tell them that if they did not do so and still persisted in sending the Prince to India, they would be responsible for placing the people in the awkward position of having to boycott the visit or the reception.
('21', 18, 1, 20, 42534) Young India, 7 7 1920
('21', 18, 2, 21, 42556) 1 Lieutenant Governor of the Punjab, 1913 9
('21', 19, 0, 1, 42600) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 19, 1, 2, 42641) 13. SWADESHI IN THE PUNJAB
('21', 19, 2, 3, 42668) The joint secretaries of the Bharat Stri Maha Mandal, Punjab Branch, send a report of the swadeshi activities of Shrimati Saraladevi Chaudhrani 1 ever since her return to Lahore from Bombay.
('21', 19, 2, 4, 42859) Miss Roy and Mrs. Roshanlal, the secretaries, state that meetings of women were held respectively on the 23rd, 24th and 25th June at three different places in Lahore.
('21', 19, 2, 5, 43026) All the meetings were attended by hundreds of women who were deeply interested in what Shrimati Saraladevi had to say.
('21', 19, 2, 6, 43145) The burden of her discourses was India’s deep poverty.
('21', 19, 2, 7, 43200) She traced the causes and proved that our poverty was primarily due to the abandonment of swadeshi by the people.
('21', 19, 2, 8, 43314) The remedy therefore lay in reverting to swadeshi.
('21', 19, 2, 9, 43365) Saraladevi herself writes to say that her khaddar sari impressed her audiences more than her speeches, and her songs came next, her speeches last.
('21', 19, 2, 10, 43512) The good ladies of Lahore flocked round her and felt her coarse but beautifully white sari and admired it.
('21', 19, 2, 11, 43619) Some took pity on her that she who only the other day was dressed in costly thin silk saris now decked herself in hand woven swadeshi khaddar.
('21', 19, 2, 12, 43762) Saraladevi wanted no pity and retorted that their thin foreign scarves lay heavier on their shoulders with the weight of their helpless dependence on foreign manufacture whereas her coarse khaddar lay light as a feather on her body with the joy of the knowledge that she was free because she wore garments in the manufacture of which her sisters and her brothers had laboured.
('21', 19, 2, 13, 44139) This statement so pleased her audience that most of the women present resolved to discard foreign clothes.
('21', 19, 2, 14, 44246) Saraladevi has now been charged by these ladies to open a shop where they could buy swadeshi goods.
('21', 19, 2, 15, 44346) She has since addressed more audiences.
('21', 19, 2, 16, 44386) She spoke at the District Conference at Sialkot and to a meeting exclusively devoted to ladies numbering over one thousand.

('21', 21, 1, 2, 47348) 14. MADNESS IN JUNAGADH
('21', 21, 2, 3, 47372) Junagadh is a Moslem State in Kathiawad so named for its having been once the land of brave Kathis 1. It posesses a well regulated college called after its founder the Vazeer Bahauddin.
('21', 21, 2, 4, 47558) The college had attracted a good many Sindhi scholars mostly Mohammedans.
('21', 21, 2, 5, 47632) This college has the unique distinction of giving free tuition.
('21', 21, 2, 6, 47696) Suddenly the new Nawab a few days ago issued a ukase expelling all non Kathiawadi students within twenty four hours.
('21', 21, 2, 7, 47813) The poor bewildered students were forcibly entrained the same day and packed away to Sind.
('21', 21, 2, 8, 47904) No one knows the crime committed by the students.
('21', 21, 2, 9, 47954) Rumour has it that the khilafat agitaion is at the back of this mad order.
('21', 21, 2, 10, 48029) The Hindu students have been thrown in to cover the shame of the deed.
('21', 21, 2, 11, 48100) Personally I welcome this expulsion.
('21', 21, 2, 12, 48137) The barefaced injustice of it would show the people the true nature of the subtly hostile forces arraigned against the khilafat agitation.
('21', 21, 2, 13, 48276) These States are themselves subjects of the Imperial State and therefore when the latter errs violently they are really worse off than the subjects who possess no sovereign powers.
('21', 21, 2, 14, 48457) Having much to lose—both power and riches—they become willing instruments of injustice, and the nakedness of the injustice of the Imperial State is better reflected in the acts of Native States than in its own direct act.
('21', 21, 2, 15, 48679) The subjects of Native States and those who live under their temporary protection therefore often become double sufferers.
('21', 21, 2, 16, 48802) But I do not wish to diagnose the condition of Native States under British suzerainty.
('21', 21, 2, 17, 48889) My purpose is to show an easy way out of the impasse.
('21', 21, 2, 18, 48943) The Principal of the college is reported to have resigned by way of protest against the extraordinary order.
('21', 21, 2, 19, 49052) He deserves the warmest congratulations of those who want to see justice and purity in the Empire.
('21', 21, 2, 20, 49151) But have not the Kathiawadi students a duty by the State and their comrades?
('21', 21, 2, 21, 49228) In my opinion they should leave the college in a body after loding a respectful protest.
('21', 21, 2, 22, 49317) They will buy their free education at too dear a price if they have not the manliness to show their sympathy to their fellow students by leaving the college.
('21', 21, 2, 23, 49475) The Nawab Saheb may not still come to his senses.
('21', 21, 2, 24, 49525) That is a matter of no concern to them.
('21', 21, 2, 25, 49565) They will have done their duty by withdrawing from the college.
('21', 21, 3, 26, 49629) 1 Members of a community of Saurashtra
('21', 22, 0, 1, 49668) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 23
('21', 22, 1, 2, 49712) To the expelled students, I would say : “Do not lose heart.
('21', 22, 1, 3, 49772) You will not beg to be readmitted to a college whose owner has so insulted you.
('21', 22, 1, 4, 49852) You may even return the little compensation money and the travelling expenses the Nawab Saheb has given you.
('21', 22, 1, 5, 49961) Accepting any such compensation would be compromising with the wrong.
('21', 22, 1, 6, 50031) You can get all the education you need in Sindh itself, without having to go to any college.
('21', 22, 1, 7, 50124) There is too much idolatry about the education received in our schools and colleges.
('21', 22, 1, 8, 50209) We must learn to be men before we learn to read and write.
('21', 22, 1, 9, 50268) Nature has endowed men with the ability to overcome all difficulties in way of their progress literary or otherwise.
('21', 22, 2, 10, 50385) Young India, 7 7 1920
('21', 22, 3, 11, 50407) 15. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, BOMBAY 1
('21', 22, 4, 12, 50447) July 7, 1920 Mr. M. K. Gandhi asked the assembly to read the Congress Sub committee’s report 2 on the Punjab atrocities carefully.
('21', 22, 4, 13, 50578) He dwelt upon some of the happenings revealed in that report, and said the women of Bombay might perhaps wonder and enquire what he was trying to talk about for they might argue that here in Bombay they could move about with perfect freedom but those who argued in that fashion lost sight of this, that things which had come to pass in the Punjab might happen in Bombay provided circumstances became identical.
('21', 22, 4, 14, 50989) Besides their duty should not be confined merely to preservation of their own safety but taking a broader view of it, they should try to ensure the safety of others as well.
('21', 22, 4, 15, 51163) They should feel the wrongs done to their sisters and brothers of the Punjab as if they themselves had been subjected to those wrongs, and it was their duty to protest with all the emphasis at their command, so that a repetition of the Punjab atrocities might be rendered impossible either in that Province or any other part of India.
('21', 22, 4, 16, 51498) If they wished to maintain their pride in India’s supreme civilization they would have to show to the world that the soul power of India’s womanhood was greater than the physical strength of those officials who had perpetrated the atrocities in the Punjab.
('21', 22, 4, 17, 51755) They must stand by the side of their husbands, brothers and sons and insist on their getting the punjab wrongs redressed.
('21', 22, 5, 18, 51877) The Bombay Chronicle, 8 7 1920
('21', 22, 6, 19, 51908) 1 Under the presidentship of Mrs. Jaiji J. Petit, wife of Jehangir B. Petit of Bombay; vide “Duty of Women”, 18 7 1920. 2 Published on March 25, 1920; vide “Congress Report on the Punjab Disorders”, 25 3 1920.

('21', 23, 2, 3, 52223) BHAISHRI NARAHARI 2, Experience has convinced me that one cannot pay too much attention to students’ handwriting.

('21', 23, 2, 6, 52457) Why does one fall ill?

('21', 23, 2, 10, 52742) It was a vaidya 4 from Baroda who gave these ideas to me.

('21', 23, 3, 13, 52936) and techniques like neti 7, dhauti 8, etc., must be of great help in maintaining the internal cleanliness of the body.
('21', 23, 3, 14, 53055) My only point in saying all this is that you should make your body [as strong] as steel.
('21', 23, 3, 15, 53144) In order to be able to get up early, go to bed, if necessary, at eight sharp.
('21', 23, 3, 16, 53222) I say this because I put the highest value on early rising.

('21', 26, 6, 11, 58255) 19. GUJARAT’S DUTY
('21', 26, 7, 12, 58274) Many difficult problems are now coming up for the whole of India.
('21', 26, 7, 13, 58340) The future of the country will largely depend on how these are solved.
('21', 26, 7, 14, 58411) If, at this juncture, we betrary, we shall invite a curse upon ourselves.
('21', 26, 7, 15, 58485) I have deliberately given to this article the heading “Gujarat’s Duty”.
('21', 26, 7, 16, 58557) Not only is Navajivan addressed to Gujarati speaking readers, but I have been developing before Gujaratis those ideas of which I am especially enamoured and translating them into practice to the limits of my capacity.
('21', 26, 7, 17, 58775) And so a special duty arises for Gujaratis.
('21', 26, 7, 18, 58819) I come into close contact with large numbers of them.
('21', 26, 7, 19, 58873) I discusss my ideas with them
('21', 26, 8, 20, 58903) 1 Vide the preceding item
('21', 26, 9, 21, 58929) 2 G. V. Mavlankar, (1888 1956); a political worker of Gujarat, the first Speaker of the Lok Sabha after independence
('21', 27, 0, 1, 59046) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 27, 1, 2, 59087) very freely and they can examine my life very minutely.
('21', 27, 1, 3, 59143) From them I cannot and do not try to conceal my weaknesses.
('21', 27, 1, 4, 59203) I claim that the ideas which I place before the people are no product of an undeveloped brain but have taken shape on the anvil of thirty years of ever vigilant experience of life and are, therefore, fully mature.
('21', 27, 1, 5, 59417) Even so, there may be errors in them.
('21', 27, 1, 6, 59455) They may even be alto gether wrong.
('21', 27, 1, 7, 59491) There are many errors coming down for generations but, even after sufficient experience, we are unable to recognize them as such.
('21', 27, 1, 8, 59621) It is possible that obtuseness prevents me from seeing my own errors.
('21', 27, 1, 9, 59691) Hence, all I wish is that my ideas should not be rejected before they have been tried out.
('21', 27, 1, 10, 59782) It is the especial duty of Gujaratis to test them as, being nearer to me, it is easier for them to measure their worth.
('21', 27, 1, 11, 59902) It is a sign of cowardice to dismiss these ideas by saying that I have renounced the world, that I have turned a sadhu, that my ideas are good but impracticable.
('21', 27, 1, 12, 60064) I do not accept the charge of being a sadhu and a man ignorant of the world.
('21', 27, 1, 13, 60141) Comparing myself with my co workers, I see my imperfections.
('21', 27, 1, 14, 60202) I believe myself to be a man of the world.
('21', 27, 1, 15, 60245) Personally, I think I am a practical man.
('21', 27, 1, 16, 60287) I am happier, more contented and fearless than my neighbours but with no fewer concerns than they.
('21', 27, 1, 17, 60386) My neighbours shudder when they see my worries.
('21', 27, 1, 18, 60434) And yet I remain healthy enough to be able to carry on with my work.
('21', 27, 1, 19, 60503) I too have a wife and children, like other people.
('21', 27, 1, 20, 60554) I have not disowned my responsibilities towards them; on the contrary, I have thought carefully over them and have not renounced any of them.
('21', 27, 1, 21, 60696) I do not live in a forest, but seem to be establishing ever new contacts.
('21', 27, 1, 22, 60770) I fail to understand how anyone else can be more engrossed than I in this world.
('21', 27, 1, 23, 60851) To dismiss me as a sadhu is to be unfair to me and to deprive Gujarat of my services.
('21', 27, 1, 24, 60937) The present Government is immoral, unjust and arrogant beyond description.
('21', 27, 1, 25, 61012) It defends one lie with other lies.
('21', 27, 1, 26, 61048) It does most things under a threat of force.
('21', 27, 1, 27, 61093) If the people tolerate all these things and do nothing, they will never progress.
('21', 27, 1, 28, 61175) If a man, when hungry, merely keeps wailing about his hunger and makes no great effort to procure food, prepared even to die in the attempt, then we shall doubt whether he is at all hungry.
('21', 27, 1, 29, 61365) The Times of India commented a few days ago that, if our public men were right in all the adjectives they employed when speaking on
('21', 28, 0, 1, 61497) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 29
('21', 28, 1, 2, 61541) the Punjab and other issue, with their feelings so excited the people would surely seek a remedy [for the wrongs].
('21', 28, 1, 3, 61656) There is a saying in English, “Necessity is the mother of invention.” Memons have a saying among them, “With a crisis, the hero”; that is, a crisis produces the hero.
('21', 28, 1, 4, 61823) A crisis means a moment of pressing difficulty.
('21', 28, 1, 5, 61871) Such a moment shows a man the way out and so makes him a man indeed.
('21', 28, 1, 6, 61940) If we really feel the pressure, if the adjectives we use truly describe our feelings, why should we not be able to find the remedy?
('21', 28, 1, 7, 62072) Countless times have we sung that the sufferings of the Punjab are intolerable.
('21', 28, 1, 8, 62152) What does a man suffering unbearable pain do?
('21', 28, 1, 9, 62198) One who is stung by a scorpion tries all manner of remedies and, if they fail to relieve the pain, he dies.
('21', 28, 1, 10, 62306) We, on the contrary, have lost even the strength to die, though we say that our pain is unbearable.
('21', 28, 1, 11, 62406) Why should The Times, then, not pour ridicule on us?
('21', 28, 1, 12, 62459) Shastras advise that the company of the evil should be shun ned.
('21', 28, 1, 13, 62524) We do not have enough courage even to turn our back on the evil Mr. O’Brien, the evil Mr. Smith and the evil Mr. Shri Ram.
('21', 28, 1, 14, 62647) Withdrawing co operation from a government which breaks its promises is a course followed from immemorial times.
('21', 28, 1, 15, 62760) The history of our country provides instance after instance of subjects oppressed by a king leaving the kingdom.
('21', 28, 1, 16, 62873) The subjects have a right to show that they are displeased.
('21', 28, 1, 17, 62933) In Europe, they kill a wicked king.
('21', 28, 1, 18, 62969) In India, the subjects leave the territory of the king when they find things unbearable.
('21', 28, 1, 19, 63058) The non co operation I have suggested is a mild way of boycotting.
('21', 28, 1, 20, 63125) Total boycott is the ultimate stage in non co operation.
('21', 28, 1, 21, 63182) We have even forgotten how to show that we are displeased.
('21', 28, 1, 22, 63241) If that is true, it betokens the depth of our degradation.
('21', 28, 1, 23, 63300) When the slave forgets that he is a slave, there is no way left to help him win his freedom.
('21', 28, 1, 24, 63393) There can hardly be an injustice greater than the two which the Government is obstinately defending today.
('21', 28, 1, 25, 63500) If we do not find them unbearable, then no blame will attach to the Government; on the contrary, it will be said, to use the language of the rustic, that we deserved all this.
('21', 28, 1, 26, 63676) It is the duty of the people of Gujarat, at this difficult time, to examine closely the forms of non co operation which I place before them.
('21', 28, 1, 27, 63817) I hope that in this matter Gujarat will not follow others’ example, but will take the lead and be an example for others to follow.

('21', 29, 1, 2, 63989) A little reflection will show that renouncing titles, boycotting legislatures, leaving Government schools and giving up practice are not very difficult tasks.
('21', 29, 1, 3, 64148) For the present, however, we have to make up our mind to boycott legislatures.

('21', 29, 1, 12, 65646) Those to whom their path is clear need not at all wait till the Congress session is over; rather, they should put their decision into effect and, thereby, show to the Congress the direction and intensity of public opinion.
('21', 29, 1, 13, 65869) It is not likely that in a great venture like this all will be of one mind on the instant.

('21', 29, 1, 15, 66021) We shall succeed in changing their views by showing our dislike of them or boycotting them; we shall have to win them over to our view with argument and gentle persuasion.

('21', 30, 1, 2, 66355) 20. VISIT OF THE PRINCE OF WALES
('21', 30, 2, 3, 66388) Mr. Baptista has asked in The [Bombay ] Chronicle whether, in our present suffering, we are in a position to accord a cordial reception to the eldest son of King Emperor George V when he visits India.
('21', 30, 2, 4, 66589) He has spoken of my views and, therefore, I think it my duty to state them.
('21', 30, 2, 5, 66665) I believe that we cannot drag tha Prince or any other member of the Royal family into politics.
('21', 30, 2, 6, 66761) If our differences with the Government are of an ordinary nature, we should welcome the Prince’s visit and receive him with all respect.
('21', 30, 2, 7, 66898) When, however, the people are in grief and their feeling have been deeply hurt, the Prince’s visit will be ill timed and the people have the right to express their displeasure at the action of the authorities, if the latter arrange the visit without ascertaining their feelings.
('21', 30, 2, 8, 67177) The Prince is in no way insulted by such action.
('21', 30, 2, 9, 67226) To deny this is to demonstrate ignorance of the British Constitution.
('21', 30, 2, 10, 67296) It should be remembered that the Prince is not coming of his own accord.
('21', 30, 2, 11, 67369) If he did, he would be acting contrary to the Constitution.
('21', 30, 2, 12, 67429) He can come only if the British Cabinet requests him to, after consulting the Indian Government.
('21', 30, 2, 13, 67526) The Prince is not free to follow his own inclination in meeting Indians or making speeches.
('21', 30, 2, 14, 67618) His visit, therefore, is not to be considered his own act but that of the Government.
('21', 30, 2, 15, 67704) Moreover, if the Government arranges a visit by the Prince to India, it will be to serve its own purpose.
('21', 30, 2, 16, 67810) So long as there is no great difference dividing the Government and the people, it may be said that the interests of the one are those of the other.
('21', 30, 2, 17, 67959) If there is such a difference, however, what is in the interest of the Government may be against that of the people.
('21', 30, 2, 18, 68076) If the Prince comes at this time and if we receive him warmly, the Government will conclude that, in fact, the people have not been hurt and that all this talk of their having been hurt is only the work of a few disgruntled men.
('21', 30, 2, 19, 68305) It would not be strange if it came to this conclusion.
('21', 30, 2, 20, 68360) If, therefore, the Government does arrange a visit by the Prince of Wales at this juncture, I would look upon the visit as a trap and it would be the duty of the people not to walk into it.
('21', 30, 2, 21, 68550) What is the position of the people today?
('21', 30, 2, 22, 68592) The British Cabinet

('21', 31, 2, 16, 70154) 21. PURE SWADESHI
('21', 31, 3, 17, 70172) A brief report of Shrimati Saraladevi’s work in the Punjab appeared in Navajivan last week.
('21', 31, 3, 18, 70264) From a telegram received later, it appears that even at the Khilafat Conference which she attended at Jhelum, she spoke on swadeshi.
('21', 31, 3, 19, 70397) As Muslims are fast taking to swadeshi, it is easy to propagate swadeshi from a khilafat platform.
('21', 31, 3, 20, 70496) At this juncture, it is very necessary to understand thoroughly some fundamental principles of swadeshi.
('21', 31, 3, 21, 70601) Will it advance the cause of swadeshi if Muslims take the swadeshi vow in their hundreds of thousands?
('21', 31, 3, 22, 70704) I think it will, provided that either there is an increase in the production of swadeshi goods to meet their needs or they and others reduce requirements of cloth.
('21', 32, 0, 1, 70868) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 33
('21', 32, 1, 2, 70912) The cloth which our cotton mills produce is not enough for India’s needs and the mills are not in a position to increase the production of cloth in the immediate future.
('21', 32, 1, 3, 71082) Their weaving capacity is greater than their spinning capacity.
('21', 32, 1, 4, 71146) If, therefore, we use mill yarn for handloom cloth, it will mean that the mills will produce less correspondingly and not that there will be an increase in the total production of cloth.
('21', 32, 1, 5, 71333) The result will be large imports, not of cloth, but of yarn.
('21', 32, 1, 6, 71394) That will leave us just where we are.
('21', 32, 1, 7, 71432) We need not believe that we shall be saving on weaving for yarn will cost more.
('21', 32, 1, 8, 71512) This is not swadeshi.
('21', 32, 1, 9, 71534) The swadeshi of our conception safeguards both dharma and artha 1. Not to be able to serve our own neighbours, our own kith and kin—to wrest a morsel from their mouths and put it into those of strangers, surely this would not be serving the higher end of life, this would not be compassion.
('21', 32, 1, 10, 71825) That would only mean our deserting our own field of duty.
('21', 32, 1, 11, 71883) We are therefore, morally bound to encourage our sisters who spin and our weavers.
('21', 32, 1, 12, 71966) In the process, we shall be sending 60 crores of rupees to the homes of our starving millions and this will safeguard artha.
('21', 32, 1, 13, 72091) The swadeshi dharma is thus the royal road for safeguarding both our dharma and artha.
('21', 32, 2, 14, 72178) We can follow this only if we take to hand spinning and hand weaving.
('21', 32, 2, 15, 72248) The true and genuine swadeshi movement, therefore, con sists in increasing the production of yarn, getting the yarn woven and then marketing the cloth thus produced.
('21', 32, 2, 16, 72414) It is, therefore my suggestion to all lovers of swadeshi and to all owners of swadeshi stores that they should get women to spin and should popularize the cloth woven out of the yarn they produce.
('21', 32, 2, 17, 72611) I know that this work is difficult and heart breaking.
('21', 32, 2, 18, 72666) But no progress is ever possible without our venturing on a path beset with difficulties.
('21', 32, 2, 19, 72756) The way to the Dhaulagiri peak 2 is strewn with the bones of countless travellers.
('21', 32, 2, 20, 72839) The weak of heart lose their enthusiasm right at the foot; there is no way, though, except through hills and valleys.
('21', 32, 2, 21, 72957) If, therefore, those who take up the swadeshi cause do so after fully understanding the basic principle of swadeshi, they will save themselves from disappointment.
('21', 32, 2, 22, 73121) It does not matter if every worker does no more than spin and infects a few with his zeal; but there will be great harm, if the swadeshi movement does not make

('21', 39, 2, 5, 85517) Mr. M. K. Gandhi moved the following resolution :
('21', 39, 3, 6, 85567) (a) That this meeting views with alaram and grave apprehensions the growing agitation in the East African Protectorate against the British Indian settlers residing in that Protectorate and hopes that, in view especially of the fact that the Imperial Government has directed control over the Protectorate and that the Indians emigrated to East Africa before the European advent, the Government of India will guard the Indians against any encroachment upon their rights whether by legislative or administrative measures and that the Government will secure complete equality of status for them by requiring the Protectorate to remove all legal and administrative inequality at present existing.
('21', 39, 4, 7, 86259) (b) This meeting emphatically protests against the undesirable authority placed in the hands of the administrator of the occupied territory empowering him to deport persons without trial, being power virtually aimed against Indians; and views with great concern the other grievances of Indians resident therein, such as want of police protection, artificial financial disabilities due to the invalidity of pre war interim German currency notes, the exchange imbroglio, travelling restrictions, and the like.
('21', 39, 4, 8, 86767) In the opinion of this meeting these disabilities make the position of British Indian settlers worse than during the German regime, and this meeting trusts that the Government of India will secure early relief of the Indian situation from the grievances complained of.

('21', 41, 3, 22, 92970) The Mahratta has pronounced against it in a well reasoned article.

('21', 42, 1, 5, 93851) Must they participate in the harmbecause moderates will not refrain?
('21', 42, 1, 6, 93920) Or, is it contended that the harm can be avoided only if all join the boycott?
('21', 42, 1, 7, 93999) If the last is the contention it betrays ignorance of the principles of boycott.
('21', 42, 1, 8, 94080) We boycott an institution because we do not like it or because we do not wish to co operate with its conductors.
('21', 42, 1, 9, 94193) In the matter of the Councils the latter is the deciding reason.
('21', 42, 1, 10, 94258) And I submit that in a sense we co operate by joining even though the object is obstruction.
('21', 42, 1, 11, 94351) Most institutions, and a British legislative council most of all, thrive upon obstruction.
('21', 42, 1, 12, 94442) The disciplined obstruction of the Irish members made practically no impression upon the House of Commons.
('21', 42, 1, 13, 94549) The Irishmen have not got the Home Rule they wanted.
('21', 42, 1, 14, 94602) The Mahratta argues that obstruction would be active and aggressive non co operation.
('21', 42, 1, 15, 94688) I venture to deny it.
('21', 42, 1, 16, 94710) In my opinion it shows want of faith in yourself, i.e., in your doctrine.
('21', 42, 1, 17, 94784) You doubt and you perish.
('21', 42, 1, 18, 94810) I do not believe that either the English or the moderate leaders can possibly contemplate with equanimity a nationalist boycott of the Councils.
('21', 42, 1, 19, 94955) We are now face to face with the reality.
('21', 42, 1, 20, 94997) Will a single moderate leader care to enter any council if more than half his electorate disapprovd of his offering himself as a candidate at all?
('21', 42, 1, 21, 95144) I hold that it would be unconstitutional for him to do so, because he will not represent his constituency.
('21', 42, 1, 22, 95251) Boycott contemplated by me presupposes a most active discipline and watchful propaganda and it is based on the assumption that the electors themselves will prefer complete to an incomplete boycott in the form of obstruction.
('21', 42, 1, 23, 95476) If it is assumed that the people themselves do no want a complete boycott it would be the duty of those who believe in it to educate the electorates to appreciate the superiority of boycott over obstruction.
('21', 42, 1, 24, 95684) To enter the councils is to submit to the vote of the majority, i.e., to co operate.
('21', 42, 1, 25, 95769) If then we want to stop the machinery of Government, as we want to, until we get justice in the khilafat and the Punjab matters, we must put our whole weight against the Government and refuse to accept the vote of the majority in the council, because it will neither represent the wish of the country nor our own which is more to the point on a matter of principle.

('21', 44, 2, 7, 98626) My speech was in Gujarati and may have suffered at the hands of the translating reporter.
('21', 44, 2, 8, 98716) I shall endeavour to explain my own position independently of the reports of my speech.

('21', 44, 2, 10, 98913) I have often been charged with having an unyielding nature.
('21', 44, 2, 11, 98973) I have been told that I would not bow to the decision of the majority.
('21', 44, 2, 12, 99044) I have been accused of being autocratic.
('21', 44, 2, 13, 99085) Now on the occasion of the Punjab meeting, I was pressed to move a resolution which did not commend itself to me.
('21', 44, 2, 14, 99199) I undertook to do so reserving to myself the right to expressing emphatic opinion to the contrary.
('21', 44, 2, 15, 99298) And I did so.
('21', 44, 2, 16, 99312) I have never been able to subscribe to the charge of obstinacy or autocracy.
('21', 44, 2, 17, 99389) On the contrary I pride myself on my yielding nature in non vital matters.
('21', 44, 2, 18, 99464) I detest autocracy.
('21', 44, 2, 19, 99484) Valuing my freedom and independence I equally cherish them for others.
('21', 44, 2, 20, 99555) I have no desire to carry a single soul with me, if I cannot appeal to his or her reason.
('21', 44, 2, 21, 99645) My unconventionality I carry to the point of rejecting the divinity of the oldest Shastras if they cannot convince my reason.
('21', 44, 2, 22, 99771) But I have found by experience that if I wish to live in society and still retain my independence, I must limit the points of utter independence to matters of first rate importance.
('21', 44, 2, 23, 99953) In all others which do not involve a departure from one’s personal religion or moral code, one must yield to the majority.
('21', 44, 2, 24, 100076) In the case in question I had an opportunity of illustrating my position.

('21', 46, 2, 5, 102633) And yet somehow or other I cannot help feeling that General Dyer is by no means the worst offender.

('21', 46, 2, 9, 102967) He believes himself to be the saviour of the Punjab in that he was able to shoot down like rabbits men who were penned in an enclosure.
('21', 46, 2, 10, 103103) Such a man is unworthy of being considered a soldier.
('21', 46, 2, 11, 103157) There was no bravery in his action.
('21', 46, 2, 12, 103193) He ran no risk.
('21', 46, 2, 13, 103209) He shot without the slightest opposition and without warning.
('21', 46, 2, 14, 103271) This is not an “error of judgment”.
('21', 46, 2, 15, 103307) It is paralysis of it in the face of fancied danger.
('21', 46, 2, 16, 103360) It is proof of criminal incapacity and heartlessness.
('21', 46, 2, 17, 103414) But the fury that has been spent upon General Dyer is, I am sure, largely misdirected.
('21', 46, 2, 18, 103501) No doubt the shoot ing was “frightful”, the loss of innocent life deplorable.
('21', 46, 2, 19, 103579) But the slow tor ture, degradation and emasculation that followed was much worse, more calculated, malicious and soul killing, and the actors who performed the deeds deserve greater condemnation than General Dyer for the Jallianwala Bagh massacre.
('21', 46, 2, 20, 103827) The latter merely destroyed a few bodies but the others tried to kill the soul of a nation.
('21', 46, 2, 21, 103919) Who ever talks of Colonel Frank Johnson 2 who was by far the worst offender?
('21', 46, 2, 22, 103996) He terrorized guiltless Lahore, and by his merciless orders set the tone to the whole of the martial law officers.

('21', 46, 2, 25, 104324) They are still retained in the service.
('21', 46, 2, 26, 104364) Their guilt is as much proved as that of General Dyer.
('21', 46, 2, 27, 104419) We shall have failed in our duty if the condemnation pronounced upon General Dyer produces a sense of satisfaction and the obvious duty of

('21', 47, 2, 6, 105321) 31. UNCANNY
('21', 47, 3, 7, 105333) There is something uncanny about the repatriation scheme of Sourth Africa.
('21', 47, 3, 8, 105408) 1 I had never dreamt that the interim report had the slightest connection with the Indians’ Relief Act of 1914 2. I have now read the full text of that Act and had a discussion with Mr. Andrews also.
('21', 47, 3, 9, 105608) Till the latter drew my attention to the fact, I had even forgotten that there was a section 3 in the Act itself regarding the granting of free passages against forfeiture of domicile.
('21', 47, 3, 10, 105793) The Government communique 4 confirms Mr. Andrews’ information.
('21', 47, 3, 11, 105856) What puzzles me is the fact that it has been found at all necessary to have an interim report in order to enforce the free passage section of the Relief Act.
('21', 47, 3, 12, 106014) That section takes the place of the several sections of different Acts of the Natal legislation repealed by the Act.
('21', 47, 3, 13, 106131) These sections provided for the grant of free passage to those who were under liability to pay the £3 tax, if the latter wanted to escape the payment of the tax or re indenture.
('21', 47, 3, 14, 106309) The section in question though designed to affect these people was made generally applicable.
('21', 47, 3, 15, 106403) But the debate in the Assembly made perfectly clear the scope of the section.
('21', 47, 3, 16, 106481) The contention at the time was that those who paid the £3 tax really did not become domiciled, and if after they ceased to pay the tax, they wanted to take advantage of the free passage section, they should forfeit the right of domicile which was at that time considered to be an equitable settlement of the very hotly debated question of the removal of a tax which had been in vogue for nearly twenty years.
('21', 47, 4, 17, 106890) 1 Vide “Letter to the Press on Repatriation of South African Indians”, 1 7 1920. 2 Vide “The Indian’s Relief Act, 1914”, before 30 6 1914.
('21', 47, 5, 18, 107029) 3 Section 6 4 Reproduced in Young India, 14 7 1920
('21', 48, 0, 1, 107080) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 49
('21', 48, 1, 2, 107124) The interim report somewhat alters the scope of the section, but I am personally not afraid because the section requires a written application for a free passage which is a difficult thing to obtain from any Indian in Natal, and it can only happen in the case of those indentured Indians who having become free are at the present moment unable to support themselves.
('21', 48, 1, 3, 107491) Not many Indians are likely to take advantage of the section and forfeit their domicile; at the same time I cannot help feeling that an illegitimate use is being attempted to be made of the section that was designed not to meet cases of poverty but to meet cases of doubtful domicile.
('21', 48, 1, 4, 107776) It is against my idea of right that a Government should take advantage of distress of men and seek to deprive them of a precious right.
('21', 48, 1, 5, 107912) It would be better not to issue the scheme under unequal conditions.
('21', 48, 1, 6, 107981) However I derive satisfaction from the fact that in spite of the machinery that is being set up not many Indians would take the doubtful advantage of the scheme.

('21', 48, 2, 8, 108166) 32. A SUPERINTENDENT’S ORDER 1
('21', 48, 3, 9, 108197) Mr. Gandhi writes to the Press : The Hon’ble Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya has handed to me an order signed by Mr. F. A. Heron, the Superintendent of Police, Gujranwala (Punjab).

('21', 48, 3, 11, 108567) The order is dated the 5th June, 1919. It may be recalled that Superintendent Heron it was who directed the firing when one of the railway bridges was set fire to by a Gujranwala crowd on the 14th April, 1919. Here is the order in question :
('21', 48, 4, 12, 108809) June 5, 1919

('21', 51, 6, 8, 113839) 1919. Whilst he said he wanted to emphasize that the people were also in the wrong,
('21', 51, 7, 9, 113923) even as the authorities had been, the difference being one of degree.
('21', 51, 7, 10, 113993) Whilst they had
('21', 51, 8, 11, 114009) committed a few pound of wrong the authorities were guilty of tons of wrong.

('21', 51, 13, 19, 114514) Speaking of the Punjab, Mr. Gandhi said he could not but confess to a sense of feeling that, however noted the Punjabis were for their bravery, they had not played well their part in April last.
('21', 51, 13, 20, 114709) They were terrified, their spirit was broken.
('21', 51, 13, 21, 114755) He had not the slightest doubt about this.
('21', 51, 13, 22, 114798) For how else could they consent to such inhumanities as crawling like reptiles rubbing their noses against the ground.
('21', 51, 13, 23, 114917) 3 How, if they had any sense of self respect, if they felt that they were men, could they thus consent to be pulled down from man’s state.
('21', 51, 13, 24, 115056) If they had a sense of their manhood, of their self respect and honour they should have willingly faced death rather than tamely accept such dishonours.
('21', 51, 13, 25, 115209) But he was not there to cavil at the Punjab.
('21', 51, 13, 26, 115254) His mortal frame was made of the same stuff as that of Punjabis.
('21', 51, 13, 27, 115319) He was not sure that his spirit would remain unbroken under similar circumstances.
('21', 51, 13, 28, 115402) He would only pray that he should never submit to such indignities even if he was faced with death as the only alternative.
