('21', 134, 2, 14, 306410) India considers herself to be powerless and paralysed before the machineguns, the tanks and the aeroplanes of the English.
('21', 134, 2, 15, 306533) And she takes up non co operation out of her weakness.
('21', 134, 2, 16, 306588) It must still serve the same purpose, namely, bring her delivery from the crushing weight of British injustice if a sufficient number of people practise it.
('21', 134, 3, 17, 306745) I isolate this non co operation from Sinn Feinism, for, it is so conceived as to be incapable of being offered side by side with violence.

('21', 136, 1, 2, 308387) 92. COURTS AND SCHOOLS
('21', 136, 2, 3, 308410) The Non co operation Committee has included, in the first stage, boycott of law courts by lawyers and of Government schools and colleges by parents or scholars as the case may be.
('21', 136, 2, 4, 308590) I know that, it is only my reputation as a worker and fighter, which has saved me from an open charge of lunacy for having given the advice about boycott of courts and schools.
('21', 136, 2, 5, 308767) I venture however to claim some method about my madness.
('21', 136, 2, 6, 308824) It does not require much reflection to see that it is through courts that a government establishes its authority and it is through schools that it manufactures clerks and other employees.
('21', 136, 2, 7, 309012) They are both healthy institutions when the government in charge of them is on the whole just.
('21', 136, 2, 8, 309107) They are death traps when the government is unjust.

('21', 139, 4, 13, 316822) August 12, 1920
('21', 139, 5, 14, 316838) A representative of this journal 2 called on Mr. M. K. Gandhi yesterdaay.
('21', 139, 5, 15, 316912) Mr. Gandhi, who has come to Madras on a tour to some of the principal Muslim centres in Southern India, was busy with a number of workers discussing his programme; but he expressed his readiness to answer questions on the chief topic which is agitating Muslims and Hindus.
('21', 139, 6, 16, 317185) [REPRESENTATIVE :] After your experience of the satyagraha agitation last year, Mr. Gandhi, are you still hopeful and convinced of the widsom of advising non co operation?
('21', 139, 6, 17, 317357) [GANDHIJI :] Certainly.
('21', 139, 7, 18, 317381) How do you consider conditions have altered since the satyagraha movement of last year?
('21', 139, 7, 19, 317469) I consider that people are better disciplined now than they were
('21', 139, 8, 20, 317534) 1 This appeared in The Madras Mail, 13 8 1920, under the captions : “A Talk with Mr. Gandhi/Non co operation Explained”, and, along with these and the introductory paragraph, was reproduced in Young India.
('21', 139, 8, 21, 317740) 2 The Madras Mail
('21', 140, 0, 1, 317758) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 141
('21', 140, 1, 2, 317803) before.
('21', 140, 1, 3, 317811) In this I include even the masses whom I have had opportu nities of seeing in large numbers in various parts of the country.
('21', 140, 2, 4, 317936) And you are satisfied that the masses understand the spirit of saytagraha?
('21', 140, 3, 5, 318011) And that is why you are pressing on with the programme of non co operation?
('21', 140, 3, 6, 318087) Moreover, the danger that attended the civil disobedience part of satyagraha does not apply to non co operation, because in non co operation we are not taking up civil disobedience of laws as a mass movement.
('21', 140, 3, 7, 318296) The result hitherto has been most encouraging.
('21', 140, 3, 8, 318343) For instance, people in Sind and Delhi, in spite of the irritating restrictions upon their liberty by the authorities, have carried out the committee’s instructions in regard to the Seditious Meetings Proclamation and to the prohibition of posting placards on the walls which we hold to be inoffensive but which the authorities consider to be offensive.
('21', 140, 4, 9, 318697) What is the pressure which you expect to bring to bear on the authorities if co operation is withdrawn?
('21', 140, 4, 10, 318801) I believe, and everybody must grant, that no Government can exist for a single moment without the co operation of the people, willing or forced, and if people suddenly withdraw their co operation in every detail, the Government will come to a standstill.
('21', 140, 5, 11, 319056) But is there not a big “if” in it?
('21', 140, 5, 12, 319091) Certainly, there is.
('21', 140, 6, 13, 319112) And how do you propose to succeed against the big “if”?
('21', 140, 6, 14, 319168) In my plan of campaign, expediency has no room.
('21', 140, 6, 15, 319216) If the khilafat movement has really permeated the masses and the classes, there must be adequate response from the people.
('21', 140, 7, 16, 319339) But are you not begging the question?
('21', 140, 7, 17, 319377) I am not begging the question, because so far as data before me go, I believe that the Muslims keenly feel the khilafat grievance.
('21', 140, 7, 18, 319508) It remains to be seen whether their feeling is intense enough to evoke in them the measure of sacrifice adequate for successful non co operation.
('21', 140, 8, 19, 319654) That is, your survey of the conditions, you think, justifies your advising non co operation in the full conviction that you have behind you the support of the vast masses of the Mussulman population?
('21', 140, 9, 20, 319854) This non co operation, you are satisfied, will extend to complete severance of co operation with the Government?
('21', 141, 0, 1, 319967) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 141, 1, 2, 320009) No; nor is it the present moment my desire that it should.
('21', 141, 1, 3, 320068) I am simply practising non co operation to the extent that is necessary to make the Government realize the depth of popular feeling in the matter and the dissatisfaction with the Government that all that could be done has not been done either by the Government of India or by the Imperial Government whether on the khilafat question or on the Punjab question.
('21', 141, 2, 4, 320428) Do you, Mr. Gandhi, realize that even amongst Mohammedans there are sections of people who are not enthusiastic over non co operation however much they may feel the wrong that has been done to their community?
('21', 141, 2, 5, 320638) But their number is smaller than those who are prepared to adopt non co operation.
('21', 141, 3, 6, 320721) And yet does not the fact that there has not been an adequate response to your appeal for resignation of titles and offices and for boycott of elections of the councils indicate that you may be placing more faith in their strength of conviction than is warranted?
('21', 141, 3, 7, 320985) I think not; for the reason that the stage has only just come into operation and our people are always most cautious and slow to move.
('21', 141, 3, 8, 321120) Moreover, the first stage largely affects the uppermost strata of society, who represent a microscopic minority though they are undoubtedly an influential body of people.
('21', 141, 4, 9, 321291) This upper class, you think, has sufficiently responded to your appeal?
('21', 141, 4, 10, 321363) I am unable to say either one way or the other at present.
('21', 141, 4, 11, 321422) I shall be able to give a definite answer at the end of this month.
('21', 141, 5, 12, 321490) Do you think that without one’s loyalty to the King and the royal family being questioned, one can advocate non co operation in connection with the royal visit?
('21', 141, 5, 13, 321651) Most decidedly; for the simple reason that if there is any disloyalty about the proposed boycott of the Prince’s visit, it is disloyalty to the Government of the day and not to the person of His Royal Highness.
('21', 141, 6, 14, 321862) What do you think is to be gained by promoting this boycott in connection with the royal visit?
('21', 141, 6, 15, 321958) Because I want to show that the people of India are not in sympathy with the Government of the day and that they strongly disapprove of the policy of the Government in regard to the Punjab and khilafat, and even in respect of other important adminis trative measures.
('21', 141, 6, 16, 322226) I consider that the visit of the Prince of Wales is a singularly
('21', 142, 0, 1, 322291) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 143
('21', 142, 1, 2, 322336) good opportunity to the people to show their disapproval of the present Government.
('21', 142, 1, 3, 322420) After all, the visit is calculated to have tremen dous political results.
('21', 142, 1, 4, 322494) It is not to be a non political event, and seeing that the Government of India and the Imperial Government want to make the visit a political event of first class importance, namely, for the purpose of strengthening their hold upon India, I for one, consider that it is the bounden duty of the people to boycott the visit which is being engineered by the two Governments in their own interest which at the present moment is totally antagonistic to the people.
('21', 142, 2, 5, 322954) Do you mean that you want this boycott promoted because you feel that the
('21', 142, 3, 6, 323028) strengthening of the hold upon India is not desirable in the best interests of the
('21', 142, 4, 7, 323111) country?
('21', 142, 4, 8, 323120) The strengthening of the hold of a Government so wicked as the present one is not desirable for the best interests of the people.
('21', 142, 4, 9, 323250) Not that I want the bond between England and India to become loosened for the sake of loosening it but I want that bond to become strengthened only in so far as it adds to the welfare of India.
('21', 142, 5, 10, 323444) Do you think that non co operation and the non boycott of the legislative
('21', 142, 6, 11, 323518) councils [are] consistent?
('21', 142, 6, 12, 323545) No; because a person who takes up the programme of non co operation cannot consistently stand for councils.
('21', 142, 7, 13, 323653) Is non co operation, in your opinion, an end in itself or a means to an end, and if so, what is the end?
('21', 142, 7, 14, 323758) It is a means to an end, the end being to make the present Government just, whereas it has become mostly unjust.
('21', 142, 7, 15, 323871) Co operation with a just government is a duty; non co operation with an unjust government is equally a duty.
('21', 142, 8, 16, 323980) Will you look with favour upon the proposal to enter the councils and to carry on either obstructive tactics or to decline to take the oath of allegiance as consistent with your non co operation?
('21', 142, 8, 17, 324176) No; as an accurate student of non co operation, I consider that such a proposal is inconsistent with the true spirit of non co operation.
('21', 142, 8, 18, 324314) I have often said that a Government really thrives on obstruction, and so far as the proposal not to take the oath of allegiance is concerned, I can really see no meaning in it; it amounts to a useless waste of valuable time and money.
('21', 142, 9, 19, 324550) In other words, obstruction is no stage in non co operation?
('21', 143, 0, 1, 324611) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 143, 2, 2, 324653) Are you satisfied that all efforts at constitutional agitation have been exhausted and that, non co operation is the only course left us?
('21', 143, 2, 3, 324791) I do not consider non co operation to be unconstitutional, but I do believe that of all the constitutional remedies now left open to us, non co operation is the only one left for us.
('21', 143, 3, 4, 324974) Do you consider it constitutional to adopt it with a view merely to paralyse Government?
('21', 143, 3, 5, 325063) Certainly, it is not unconstitutional, but a prudent man will not take all the steps that are constitutional if they are otherwise undesirable, nor do I advise that course.
('21', 143, 3, 6, 325236) I am resorting to non co operation in progressive stages because I want to evolve true order out of untrue order.
('21', 143, 3, 7, 325350) I am not going to take a single step in non co operation unless I am satisfied that the country is ready for that step, namely, non co operation will not be followed by anarchy or disorder.
('21', 143, 4, 8, 325540) How will you satisfy yourself that anarchy will not follow?
('21', 143, 4, 9, 325600) For instance, if I advise the police to lay down their arms, I shall have satisfied myself that we are able by voluntary assistance to protect ourselves against thieves and robbers.
('21', 143, 4, 10, 325782) That was precisely what was done in Lahore and Amritsar last year by the citizens by means of volunteers when the military and the police had withdrawn.
('21', 143, 4, 11, 325935) Even where Government had not taken such measures in a place, for want of adequate force, I know people have successfully protected themselves.
('21', 143, 5, 12, 326079) You have advised lawyers to non co operate by suspending their practice.
('21', 143, 5, 13, 326152) What is your experience?
('21', 143, 5, 14, 326177) Has the lawyers’ response to your appeal encouraged you to hope that you will be able to carry through all stages of non co operation with the help of such people?
('21', 143, 5, 15, 326341) I cannot say that a large number has yet responded to my appeal.
('21', 143, 5, 16, 326406) It is too early to say how many will respond.
('21', 143, 5, 17, 326452) But I may say that I do not rely merely upon the lawyer class or highly educated men to enable the Committee to carry out all the stages of non co operation.
('21', 143, 5, 18, 326610) My hope lies more with the masses so far as the later stages of non co operation are concerned.

('21', 144, 1, 2, 326774) 94. SPEECH ON NON CO OPERATION, MADRAS 1
('21', 144, 2, 3, 326815) August 12, 1920
('21', 144, 3, 4, 326831) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, Like last year, I have to ask your forgiveness that I should have to speak being seated.
('21', 144, 3, 5, 326946) Whilst my voice has become stronger than it was last year, my body is still weak; and if I were to attempt to speak to you standing, I could not hold on for very many minutes before the whole frame would shake.
('21', 144, 3, 6, 327157) I hope, therefore, that you will grant me permission to speak seated.
('21', 144, 3, 7, 327227) I have sat here to address you on a most important question, probably a question whose importance we have not measured up to now.
('21', 144, 3, 8, 327357) But before I approach that question on this dear old beach of Madras, you will expect me—you will want me to offer my tribute to the great departed, Lokamanya Tilak Maharaj.
('21', 144, 3, 9, 327531) (Loud and prolonged cheers.) I would ask this great assembly to listen to me in silence.
('21', 144, 3, 10, 327620) I have come to make an appeal to your heart and to your reason and I could not do so unless you were prepared to listen to whatever I have to say in absolute silence.
('21', 144, 3, 11, 327787) I wish to offer my tribute to the departed patriot and I think that I cannot do better than say that his death, as his life, has poured new vigour into the country.
('21', 144, 3, 12, 327952) If you were present as I was present at that great funeral procession, you would realize with me the meaning of my words.
('21', 144, 3, 13, 328074) Mr. Tilak lived for his country.
('21', 144, 3, 14, 328107) The inspiration of his life was freedom for his country which he called swaraj; the inspiration of his deathbed was also freedom for his country.
('21', 144, 3, 15, 328253) And it was that which gave him such marvellous hold upon his countrymen; it was that which commanded the adoration not of a few chosen Indians belonging to the upper strata of society but of millions of his countrymen.
('21', 144, 3, 16, 328472) His life was one long sustained piece of self sacrifice.
('21', 144, 3, 17, 328529) He began that life of discipline and self sacrifice in 1879 and he continued that life up to the end of his day, and that was the secret of his hold upon his country.
('21', 144, 3, 18, 328696) He not only knew what he wanted for his country but also how to live for his country and how to die for his country.
('21', 144, 3, 19, 328813) I hope then that whatever I say this evening to this vast mass of people, will bear fruit in that same sacrifice for which the life of Lokamanya Tilak Maharaj stands.
('21', 144, 3, 20, 328980) His life, if it teaches us anything whatsoever, teaches one supreme lesson; that if we want to do anything whatsoever for our country, we can do so not by speeches,
('21', 144, 4, 21, 329145) 1 At a public meeting, on the beach opposite the Presidency College
('21', 145, 0, 1, 329213) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 145, 1, 2, 329255) however grand, eloquent and convincing they may be, but only by sacrifice at the back of every word and at the back of every act of our life.
('21', 145, 1, 3, 329397) I have come to ask everyone of you whether you are ready and willing to give sufficiently for your country’s sake, for your country’s honour and for religion.
('21', 145, 1, 4, 329556) I have boundless faith in you, the citizens of Madras, and the people of this great presidency, a faith which I began to cultivate in the year 1893 when I first made acquaintance with the Tamil labourers in South Africa; and I hope that, in these hours of our trial, this province will not be second to any other in India, and that it will lead in this spirit of self sacrifice and will translate every word into action.
('21', 145, 2, 5, 329977) NEED FOR NON CO OPERATION What is this non co operation about which you have heard much, and why do we want to offer this non co operation?
('21', 145, 2, 6, 330117) I wish to go for the time being into the why.
('21', 145, 2, 7, 330163) There are two things before this country.
('21', 145, 2, 8, 330205) The first and the foremost is the khilafat question.
('21', 145, 2, 9, 330258) On this the heart of the Mussulmans of India has become lacerated.
('21', 145, 2, 10, 330325) British pledges, given after the greatest deliberation by the Prime Minister of England in the name of the English nation, have been dragged into the mire.
('21', 145, 2, 11, 330481) The promises given to moslem India, on the strength of which the consideration that was accepted by the British nation was exacted, have been broken and the great religion of Islam has been placed in danger.
('21', 145, 2, 12, 330689) The Mussulmans hold—and I venture to think they rightly hold—that so long as British promises remain unfulfilled so long is it impossible for them to tender whole hearted fealty and loyalty to the British connection; and if it is to be a choice for a devout Mussulman between loyalty to the British connection and loyalty to his Code and Prophet, he will not require a second to make his choice and he has declared his choice.
('21', 145, 2, 13, 331116) The Mussulmans say frankly, openly and honourably to the whole world that if the British ministers and the British nation do not fulfil the pledges given to them and do not wish to regard with respect the sentiments of 70 millions of the inhabitants of India who profess the faith of Islam, it will be impossible for them to retain Islamic loyalty.
('21', 145, 2, 14, 331465) It is a question, then, for the rest of the Indian population to consider whether they want to perform a neighbourly duty by their Mussulman countrymen and if they do, they have an opportunity of a lifetime which will not occur for another hundred years, to show their goodwill, fellowship and
('21', 145, 3, 15, 331759) 1 Up to this, the report is from The Hindu.
('21', 146, 0, 1, 331803) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 147
('21', 146, 1, 2, 331848) friendship and to prove what they have been saying for all these long years that the Mussulman is the brother of the Hindu.
('21', 146, 1, 3, 331972) If the Hindu regards that before the connection with the British nation comes his natural connection with his Moslem brother, then I say to you that if you find that the Moslem claim is just, that it is based upon real sentiment, and that at its background is this great religious feeling, you cannot do otherwise than help the Mussulmans through and through so long as their cause remains just and the means for attaining the end remains equally just, honourable and free from harm to India.
('21', 146, 1, 4, 332465) These are the plain conditions which the Indian Mussulmans have accepted and it was when they saw that they could accept the proferred aid of the Hindus, that they could always justify the cause and the means before the whole world, that they decided to accept the proferred hand of fellowship.
('21', 146, 1, 5, 332760) It is then for Hindus and Mussulmans to offer a united front to the whole of the Christian powers of Europe and tell them that weak as India is, India has still got the capacity of preserving her self respect.
('21', 146, 1, 6, 332970) That is the khilafat in a nutshell; but you have also got the Punjab.
('21', 146, 1, 7, 333040) The Punjab has wounded the heart of India as no other question has for the past century.
('21', 146, 1, 8, 333129) I do not exclude from my calculation the Mutiny of 1857. Whatever hardships India had to suffer during the Mutiny, the insult that was attempted to be offered to her during the passage of the Rowlatt legislation, and that which was offered after its passage, were unparalleled in Indian history.
('21', 146, 1, 9, 333425) It is because you want justice from the British nation in connection with the Punjab atrocities, you have to devise ways and means as to how you can get this justice.
('21', 146, 1, 10, 333592) The House of Commons, the House of Lords, Mr. Montagu, the Viceroy of India, everyone of them knows what the feeling of India is on this khilafat question and on that of the Punjab; the debates in both the Houses of Parliament, the action of Mr. Montagu and that of the Viceroy have demonstrated to you completely that they are not willing to give the justice which is India’s due and which she demands.
('21', 146, 1, 11, 333996) I suggest that our leaders have got to find a way out of this great difficulty and unless we have made ourselves even with the British rulers in India, and unless we have gained a measures of self respect at the hands of the British rulers in India, no connection and no friendly intercourse is possible between them and ourselves.
('21', 146, 1, 12, 334328) I, therefore venture to suggest this beautiful
('21', 147, 0, 1, 334375) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 147, 1, 2, 334417) unanswerable method of non co operation.
('21', 147, 2, 3, 334458) IS IT UNCONSTITUTIONAL?
('21', 147, 2, 4, 334482) I have been told that non co operation is unconstitutional.
('21', 147, 2, 5, 334542) I venture to deny that it is unconstitutional.
('21', 147, 2, 6, 334589) On the contrary, I hold that non co operation is a just and religious doctrine; it is the inherent right of every human being and it is perfectly constitutional.
('21', 147, 2, 7, 334751) A great lover of the British Empire has said that under the British Constitution, even a successful rebellion is perfectly constitutional and he quotes historical instances which I cannot deny in support of his claim.
('21', 147, 2, 8, 334969) I do not claim any constitutionality for a rebellion successful or otherwise so long as that rebellion means in the ordinary sense of the term what it does mean, namely, wresting justice by violent means.
('21', 147, 2, 9, 335174) On the contrary, I have said it repeatedly to my countrymen that violence, whatever end it may serve in Europe, will never serve us in India.
('21', 147, 2, 10, 335316) My brother and friend Shaukat Ali believes in methods of violence; and if it was in his power to draw the sword against the British Empire, I know that he has got the courage of a man and he has got also the wisdom to see that he should offer that battle to the British Empire.
('21', 147, 2, 11, 335594) But because he recognizes as a true soldier that means of violence are not open to India, he sides with me accepting my humble assistance and pledges his word that so long as I am with him and so long as he believes in the doctrine so long will he not harbour even the idea of violence against any single Englishman or any single man on earth.
('21', 147, 2, 12, 335938) I am here to tell you that he has been as true as his word and has kept it religiously.
('21', 147, 2, 13, 336026) I am here to bear witness that he has been following out this plan of non violent non co operation to the very letter and I am asking India to follow this non violent non co operation.
('21', 147, 2, 14, 336211) I tell you that there is not a better soldier living in our ranks in British India than Shaukat Ali.
('21', 147, 2, 15, 336312) When the time for the drawing of the sword comes, if it ever comes, you will find him drawing that sword and you will find me retiring to the jungle of Hindustan.
('21', 147, 2, 16, 336475) As soon as India accepts the doctrine of the sword, my life as an Indian is finished.
('21', 147, 2, 17, 336561) It is because I believe in a mission special to India, and it is because I believe that the ancients of India, after centuries of experience, have found out that the true thing for any human being on earth is not justice based on violence but justice based on sacrifice of self, justice based on yajna 1 and kurbani 2—I cling to that doctrine and I shall cling to it for
('21', 147, 3, 18, 336932) 1 Sacrifice 2 ibid
('21', 148, 0, 1, 336951) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 149
('21', 148, 1, 2, 336996) ever—it is for that reason I tell you that whilst my friend believes also in the doctrine of violence and has adopted the doctrine of non violence as a weapon of the weak, I believe in the doctrine of non violence as a weapon of the strongest.
('21', 148, 1, 3, 337240) I believe that a man is the strongest soldier for daring to die unarmed with his breast bare before the enemy.
('21', 148, 1, 4, 337351) So much for the non violent part of non co operation.
('21', 148, 1, 5, 337405) I, therefore, venture to suggest to my learned countrymen that so long as the doctrine of non co operation remains non violent so long there is nothing unconstitutional in the doctrine.
('21', 148, 1, 6, 337591) I ask further, is it unconstitutional for me to say to the British Government, “I refuse to serve you” ?
('21', 148, 1, 7, 337696) Is it unconstitutional for our worthy chairman to return with every respect all the titles that he has ever held from the Government?
('21', 148, 1, 8, 337830) Is it unconstitutional for any parent to withdraw his children from a Government or aided school ?
('21', 148, 1, 9, 337929) Is it unconstitutional for a lawyer to say, “I shall no longer support the arm of the law so long as that arm of law is used not to raise me but to debase me” ?
('21', 148, 1, 10, 338090) Is it unconstitutional for a civil servant or for a judge to say, “I refuse to serve a Government which does not wish to respect the wishes of the whole people”?
('21', 148, 1, 11, 338252) I ask, is it unconstitutional for a policeman or for a soldier to tender his resignation when he knows that he is called to serve a Government which traduces its own countrymen?
('21', 148, 1, 12, 338430) Is it unconstitutional for me to go to the “krishak”, to the agriculturist, and say to him, “It is not wise for you to pay any taxes, if these taxes are used by the Government not to raise you but to weaken you”?
('21', 148, 1, 13, 338643) I hold and I venture to submit that there is nothing unconstitutional in it.
('21', 148, 1, 14, 338720) What is more, I have done everyone of these things in my life and nobody has questioned the constitutional character of it.
('21', 148, 1, 15, 338844) I was in Kaira working in the midst of seven lakhs of agriculturists.
('21', 148, 1, 16, 338914) They had all suspended the payment of taxes and the whole of India was at one with me.
('21', 148, 1, 17, 339001) Nobody considered that it was unconstitutional.
('21', 148, 1, 18, 339049) I submit that in the whole plan of non co operation there is nothing unconstitutional.
('21', 148, 1, 19, 339136) But I do venture to suggest that it will be highly unconstitutional in the midst of this unconstitutional Government—in the midst of a nation which has built up its magnificent constitution—for the people of India to become weak and to crawl on their belly—it will be highly unconstitutional for the people of India to pocket every insult that is offered to them; it is highly unconstitutional for the 70 millions of Mohammedans of India to submit to a violent wrong done to their religion; it is highly unconstitu tional for the whole of India to sit still and co operate with
('21', 149, 0, 1, 339714) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 149, 1, 2, 339756) an unjust Government which has trodden under its feet the honour of the Punjab; I say to my countrymen : “So long as you have a sense of honour and so long as you wish to remain the descendants and defenders of the noble traditions that have been handed to you for generations after generations, it is unconstitutional for you not to non co operate and unconstitutional for you to co operate with a Government which has become so unjust as our Government has become.
('21', 149, 1, 3, 340223) I am not anti English; I am not anti British; I am not anti any government; but I am anti untruth—anti humbug and anti injustice.
('21', 149, 1, 4, 340353) So long as the Government spells injustice, it may regard me as its enemy, implacable enemy.
('21', 149, 1, 5, 340446) I had hoped at the Congress at Amritsar—I am speaking God’s truth before you—when I pleaded on knees before some of you for co operation with the Government, I had full hope that the British ministers, who are wise as a rule, would placate the Mussulman sentiment, that they would do full justice in the matter of the Punjab atrocities, and, therefore, I said : Let us return goodwill to the hand of fellowship that has been extended to us, which, I then believed, was extended to us through the Royal Proclamation.
('21', 149, 1, 6, 340962) It was on that account that I pleaded for co operation.
('21', 149, 1, 7, 341018) But today that faith having gone and [been] obliterated by the acts of the British ministers, I am here to plead not for futile obstruction in the legislative council but for real substantial non co operation which would paralyse the mightiest government on earth.
('21', 149, 1, 8, 341283) That is what I stand for today.
('21', 149, 1, 9, 341315) Until we have wrung justice and until we have wrong our self respect from unwilling hands and from unwilling pens, there can be no co operation.
('21', 149, 1, 10, 341460) Our Shastras say and I say so with the greatest deference to all the greatest religious preceptors of India but without fear of contradiction that our Shastras teach us that there shall be no co operation between injustice and justice, between an unjust man and a justice loving man, between truth and untruth.
('21', 149, 1, 11, 341771) Co operation is a duty only so long as Government protects your honour, and non co operation is an equal duty when the Government, instead of protecting robs you of your honour.
('21', 149, 1, 12, 341949) That is the doctrine of non co operation.
('21', 149, 1, 13, 341991) NON CO OPERATION AND THE SPECIAL CONGRESS I have been told that I should have watied for the declaration of the special Congress which is the mouthpiece of the whole nation.
('21', 149, 1, 14, 342165) I know that it is the mouthpiece of the whole nation.
('21', 149, 1, 15, 342219) If it was for me, individual Gandhi, to wait, I would have waited for eternity.
('21', 149, 1, 16, 342299) But I had in my hands a sacred trust.
('21', 149, 1, 17, 342337) I was advising my Mussulman countrymen and for the time being I hold their honour in my hands.

('21', 152, 1, 5, 348361) LAWYERS AND NON CO OPERATION I have suggested another difficult matter, viz, that the lawyers should suspend their practice.

('21', 156, 9, 19, 359319) 97. DOCTRINE OF THE SWORD
('21', 156, 10, 20, 359345) I have no dearth of advisers.
('21', 156, 10, 21, 359375) They send me letters, signed and unsigned, and some visit me to proffer their advice in person.
('21', 156, 10, 22, 359471) Some write to me to say that I am a coward, afraid of the sword, and, therefore, I shall achieve nothing in this world; that it is my fear which makes me prate about non violence without knowing what it means.
('21', 156, 10, 23, 359681) Some others tell me that I have violence enough in my heart, that I approve of killing, but that I am such a “shrewd fellow” and so “cunning” that I do not let people know what I think and, though talking about non violence, at heart want to instigate violence.
('21', 156, 10, 24, 359943) Besides these, there is another class of men who think that I am not a rogue but am only waiting for my opportunity and, when it comes, I shall advise people to use the sword.
('21', 156, 10, 25, 360119) These people think that the time for
('21', 156, 11, 26, 360156) 1 Gandhiji was in Ambur on this date which fell on a Saturday.
('21', 157, 0, 1, 360219) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 157, 1, 2, 360261) this is ripe and that now I should wait no longer.
('21', 157, 1, 3, 360312) Ordinarily, it should not be necessary for me to occupy myself with answering the points these advisers make.
('21', 157, 1, 4, 360422) Where is the harm, or what is there to be exercised about, if some people think me cunning?
('21', 157, 1, 5, 360514) What right, besides, have I to take up the time of Navajivan’s readers with a defence of my saintliness or a rebuttal of the charge of being “cunning”?
('21', 157, 1, 6, 360666) Certainly, I ought not to enter into any discussion of this matter with a view to defending myself, but I know that, my present position being what it is, the common people are eager to know my views and I know, further, that my actions proceed from my views.
('21', 157, 1, 7, 360926) I think it necessary, for the sake of these, to clarify my position and so I take the liberty to place once again before readers my views on brute force.
('21', 157, 1, 8, 361080) Sword force is brute force.
('21', 157, 1, 9, 361108) Killing people requires no intelligence.
('21', 157, 1, 10, 361149) We may, indeed, by misdirecting our intelligence employ it in the service of brute force but, though aided by intelligence, brute force remains brute force and the law of the sword remains the law of the beast.
('21', 157, 1, 11, 361360) In the latter, the self is in a state of nescience and can have no knowledge of itself.
('21', 157, 1, 12, 361448) That is why we know the animal world as enveloped in darkness.
('21', 157, 1, 13, 361511) The activities of eating, drinking, sleeping, feeling afraid, etc., are common to man and beast.
('21', 157, 1, 14, 361608) But man has the power of distinguishing between good and evil and can also know the self.
('21', 157, 1, 15, 361698) One animal subdues another simply by its physical might.
('21', 157, 1, 16, 361755) Its world is ruled by that law, but not so the human world.
('21', 157, 1, 17, 361815) The law which is most in harmony with human nature is that of winning over others by the power of love—by soul force.
('21', 157, 1, 18, 361933) When, therefore, a man wins over an enemy through love, he simply follows the law of his nature.
('21', 157, 1, 19, 362030) He has not become a god in doing so.
('21', 157, 1, 20, 362067) Gods have no physical body.
('21', 157, 1, 21, 362095) They behave sometimes like beasts and sometimes like men.
('21', 157, 1, 22, 362153) There are white gods as also black gods.
('21', 157, 1, 23, 362194) Man is, at times, seen acting like an animal.
('21', 157, 1, 24, 362240) He is endowed with brute force as well, and, so long as he has not developed awareness of his spiritual nature he remains an intelligent animal.
('21', 157, 1, 25, 362385) Though human in body, instead of obeying the law of his kind he follows the law of the animal.
('21', 157, 1, 26, 362480) This, however, should not be regarded as his true nature.
('21', 157, 1, 27, 362538) I believe, therefore, that if we wake up to the consciousness of our true nature, we would, that very moment, renounce the law of the jungle.
('21', 157, 1, 28, 362680) But the sages saw that the passions of the beast had not died out in most persons, though they possessed human bodies.
('21', 158, 0, 1, 362799) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 159
('21', 158, 1, 2, 362844) recognized, therefore, that there was scope for the use of brute force even by human beings and showed under what circumstances it could be employed.
('21', 158, 1, 3, 362994) When a man submits to another through fear, he does not follow his nature but yields to brute force.
('21', 158, 1, 4, 363095) He who has no desire to dominate others by brute force will not himself submit to such force either.
('21', 158, 1, 5, 363196) Recognizing, therefore, that a man who fears brute force has not attained self knowledge at all, our Shastras allowed him the use of brute force while he remains in this state.
('21', 158, 1, 6, 363373) A Pathan made a murderous attack on me in 1908. My eldest son 1 was not present then.
('21', 158, 1, 7, 363459) He possessed fairly good physical strength.
('21', 158, 1, 8, 363503) I did not have the Pathan prosecuted since I held the same views then as I do now.
('21', 158, 1, 9, 363586) I was educating my sons too in the ideas of forgiveness and love, and so at our very first meeting [after the assault], my son said to me : “I want to know what my duty would have been if I had been with you at the time.
('21', 158, 1, 10, 363807) You have taught us that we may not strike back nor tamely submit to the other man.
('21', 158, 1, 11, 363890) I understand this principle but I have not the strength to act upon it.
('21', 158, 1, 12, 363962) I could not remain a silent spectator while you were being beaten to death.
('21', 158, 1, 13, 364038) I would consider it my duty to protect you if you should be assaulted.
('21', 158, 1, 14, 364109) But I could not do this by laying down my own life [instead of striking back].
('21', 158, 1, 15, 364188) I must, therefore, either protect you by attacking the man who would strike you, or be passive witness to the attack on you, or run away.” I told him : “It would be a sign of cowardice if you ran away or did nothing to protect me.
('21', 158, 1, 16, 364419) If you could not protect me by taking the danger upon yourself, you should undoubtedly do so by attacking the other man.

('21', 161, 1, 2, 369778) 98. COURTS AND SCHOOLS
('21', 161, 2, 3, 369801) The Khilafat Non co operation Committee has, under my advice, called upon lawyers to give up practice, parents to withdraw their children from schools and college students to leave their colleges.

('21', 161, 2, 9, 370466) Let us first consider the case of lawyers.
('21', 161, 2, 10, 370509) The power of a government depends on its courts.
('21', 161, 2, 11, 370558) Through courts it punishes the guilty and it is through them that civil disputes are settled and in this way the Government acquires control over the people.
('21', 161, 2, 12, 370716) Since the courts cannot run without lawyers, the latter, too, are deemed officials of the courts.
('21', 161, 2, 13, 370814) When the Government rules justly, the courts and lawyers are perhaps of some service but, when the Government resorts to injustice, helping its courts to run is to further the injustice.
('21', 161, 2, 14, 371001) It is almost impossible to run courts without the co operation of lawyers.
('21', 161, 2, 15, 371076) When I call upon the lawyers to give up practice, my intention is not that they should sit idle at home; it is rather that they should start working whole time for the cause of the khilafat or the Punjab, and also that they influence their clients and prevail upon them not to go to the courts.
('21', 161, 2, 16, 371371) These lawyers should set up panchas 1 and help their clients to settle their disputes among themselves.
('21', 161, 2, 17, 371475) In this way, the courts will be left without work and the people will learn to become independent of the State.

('21', 161, 2, 21, 372016) At such times, therefore, the lawyers too are put to a test.

('21', 168, 1, 5, 386974) On the slightest pretext, the labourer goes in for strikes.
('21', 168, 1, 6, 387034) My own experience of the last six months is that many strikes have done harm to labour rather than good.
('21', 168, 1, 7, 387139) I have studied in so far as I could the strike in Bombay, the strike at the Tata Iron Works, the strike in Gorakhpur twice, and the celebrated strike of the Railway labourers in the Punjab.
('21', 168, 1, 8, 387329) In all these four strikes I was more or less in connection with the labourers and what I am about to tell is derived from the labourers themselves.
('21', 168, 1, 9, 387477) There was partial failure in all these strikes.
('21', 168, 1, 10, 387525) Labour was not able to make good its points to the fullest extent.
('21', 168, 1, 11, 387592) What was the reason?
('21', 168, 1, 12, 387613) Labour was badly led.
('21', 168, 1, 13, 387635) I want you to distinguish between two classes of leaders, you have leaders derived from yourselves and they are in their turn advised and led by those who are not themselves labourers, but who are in sympathy or expected to be in sympathy with labour.
('21', 168, 1, 14, 387887) You do not require me to tell you that unless there is correspondence between yourselves, your own leaders, and those who are above you, unless there is perfect correspondence between these three there is bound to be failure.
('21', 168, 1, 15, 388113) Now in all these four strikes, that perfect correspondence was lacking.
('21', 168, 1, 16, 388185) There is another substantial reason which I discovered.
('21', 168, 1, 17, 388241) The labourers looked at pecuniary support from their unions for the maintenance.
('21', 168, 1, 18, 388322) No labour can prolong a strike indefinitely so long as labour depends upon the resources of its union.
('21', 168, 1, 19, 388425) No strike can absolutely succeed which cannot be indefinitely prolonged.
('21', 168, 1, 20, 388498) In all the strikes that I have ever conducted, I have laid down one indispensable rule, that labourers must find their own support.
('21', 168, 1, 21, 388630) Therein lies the secret of success.
('21', 168, 1, 22, 388666) And therein consists your education.
('21', 168, 1, 23, 388703) You should be able to perceive that if you are able to serve one master and command a particular wage your labour must be worth and must be fit to receive that wage anywhere else.
('21', 168, 1, 24, 388883) Strikers therefore cannot be expected to be idlers and to succeed.
('21', 168, 1, 25, 388950) Your demands must be just and there should be no pressure exerted upon those whom you call blacklegs, any force of this kind exerted against your own fellow labourers is bound to react upon yourselves.
('21', 168, 1, 26, 389152) I think your advisers will tell you that these three conditions being fulfilled no strike need ever fail.
('21', 168, 1, 27, 389258) That at once demonstrates to you the necessity of thinking a hundred times, before undertaking a strike.
('21', 168, 1, 28, 389363) So much for your rights and the method of enforcing it.
('21', 168, 1, 29, 389419) you on this point any further
('21', 169, 0, 1, 389449) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 169, 1, 2, 389491) But as labour becomes organized, strikes must become few and far between and as your mental development progresses further you will find immediately that the principle of arbitration replaces the principle of strikes.
('21', 169, 1, 3, 389709) Time has now arrived when we should reach this stage.
('21', 169, 1, 4, 389763) I will not detain I would now venture to say a few words in connection with your national responsibilities.
('21', 169, 1, 5, 389871) Just as you have to understand obligations amongst yourselves with reference to your own masters, so also it is necessary to understand your obligations to the nation to which you belong.
('21', 169, 1, 6, 390059) Then your primary education is complete.
('21', 169, 1, 7, 390100) If you sufficiently realize the dignity of labour, you will realize that you have a duty to discharge by your country.
('21', 169, 1, 8, 390219) You must therefore find out the affairs of our country in the best manner you can.
('21', 169, 1, 9, 390302) You must find it out without having to wade through a cartful of books, who are your governors, what are your duties in relation to them, what they can do to you and what you can do to them.
('21', 169, 1, 10, 390493) I do not propose to go into the existing conditions.
('21', 169, 1, 11, 390546) I have not come here to give you a long address.
('21', 169, 1, 12, 390595) It is impossible for me to interest you in the intricate questions that are now agitating the country.
('21', 169, 1, 13, 390698) It is enough for me to tell you that it is your bounden duty to understand your responsibilities and your duties as citizens of this great land.
('21', 169, 1, 14, 390843) In my humble opinion it is not possible for you to live up to your religion fully until you undertake to understand these things.
('21', 169, 1, 15, 390973) My task this evening is finished, if I have stimulated your desire after a knowledge of the affairs of your country and I hope that you will not rest content until you have found out through your advisers and leaders—the principal affairs of this country.
('21', 169, 1, 16, 391229) I thank the controllers of labour here for extending this invitation to me and I thank you all for having come and given me patient hearing.
('21', 169, 1, 17, 391370) I wish to give you my assurance that whenever you find that, you need any advice from me, it is yours.
('21', 169, 1, 18, 391473) It therefore grieves me very much that when you invited me at one time to come to Madras, I was unable, because I was preoccupied, to respond to your invitation to come to Madras.
('21', 169, 1, 19, 391653) But you will accept my assurance that it was not due to want of will, it was due to want of ability.
('21', 169, 1, 20, 391754) I wish you all the prosperity that you may deserve and I hope that you will discharge yourselves as good citizens of this country.

('21', 170, 1, 2, 392012) 101. SPEECH ON NON CO OPERATION, KUMBAKONAM
('21', 170, 2, 3, 392056) August 16, 1920
('21', 170, 3, 4, 392072) Messrs Gandhi and Shaukat Ali spoke in English and Urdu respectively, their speeches being rendered into Tamil sentence by sentence.
('21', 170, 3, 5, 392205) Acknowledging address of welcome presented at Kumbakonam and addressing a huge mass meeting, Mahatma Gandhi while regretting his insufficient knowledge of Tamil exhorted the people to learn the national lingua franca, Hindi or Urdu, as an essential condition of national progress and wished some of the addresses had been presented in Tamil instead of English.
('21', 170, 3, 6, 392566) He next asked the country to remember that the khilafat cause cannot thrive without large funds and though money in itself was neither of high importance nor of as much consequence as self sacrifice, appealed to people to contribute their mite to the Khilafat Fund, especially those who could not actively take part in non co operation.
('21', 170, 3, 7, 392903) He emphasized the time for speeches and mere deliberations or demonstrations had gone and the time had now come for organized, continuous and sustained work.
('21', 170, 3, 8, 393061) Action must be the watchword of the people.
('21', 170, 3, 9, 393105) It had become the imperative duty of the people, obligatory on everyone of them to withdraw co operation from the wicked, immoral and unjust Government, as khilafat and the Punjab questions had proved the present Government to be.
('21', 170, 3, 10, 393336) If the Turkish Terms really affronted Islam it was a religious duty of Muslims to take up non co operation in all its stages.
('21', 170, 3, 11, 393462) Hindus considered Muslims to be their brethren as sons of Mother India and they wish to be true to their religion and preserve their self respect and honour.
('21', 170, 3, 12, 393620) They must also resort to non violent non co operation as laid down by him.
('21', 170, 3, 13, 393695) Ordinary methods of agitating as memorializing, etc., have failed.
('21', 170, 3, 14, 393762) The principle of non co operation was the only course open to them and whosover approved of it in principle must also recognize that surrender of titles, boycott of proposed visit of Prince of Wales and vigorous prosecution of swadeshi, were the chief essentials of any effective programme of non co operation.
('21', 170, 3, 15, 394073) All Government managed, aided or recognized educational institutions must be emptied as they were mainly manufacturing clerks and servants for the Government.
('21', 170, 3, 16, 394232) As regards councils the policy of co operating to the extent of securing seats in councils, with a view to obstruct Government might be half non co operation but not a full one.
('21', 170, 3, 17, 394410) In the present situation where they wanted to offer non co operation to an insolent and strong Government which was able to protect itself well against popular will and persist in its unjust policy, no half measures will suffice.
('21', 170, 3, 18, 394640) Candidates must refuse to stand for election and constituencies to send any representatives.
('21', 170, 3, 19, 394733) Mr. Gandhi next explained why lawyers must suspend their practice and the Prince’s visit must be boycotted and said several steps which he had enumerated and which formed the first stage in Central Khilafat Committee’s non co operation programme were so arranged as to enable men in higher rungs of society to lead in the matter by practising self 
('21', 171, 0, 1, 395082) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 171, 1, 2, 395124) sacrifice on their own part.
('21', 171, 1, 3, 395153) The last stage would give opportunity to the masses for practice of non co operation.
('21', 171, 1, 4, 395239) Holders of titles must unhesitatingly renounce them now that they have become badges of dishonour.
('21', 171, 1, 5, 395338) Concluding with impassioned appeal to the audience Mr. Gandhi said the Jain Sabha in their welcome address have wrongly described him as a Jain.
('21', 171, 1, 6, 395483) He was a Vaishnavite and Prahlad who non co operated with his own father was the prince of non co operators showing by his conduct the paramount duty of man if he believed God to be greater than all men to non co operate with even one’s own father.
('21', 171, 1, 7, 395732) All Vaishnavites cannot at this critical juncture fail to non co operate without failing to act up to their religion.
('21', 171, 1, 8, 395850) As Thoreau has said, loss of liberty, wealth and intense suffering were the only course of honourable conduct under unjust government.
('21', 171, 1, 9, 395985) Mr. Shaukat Ali was whole heartedly co operating with him in non violent non co operation because he thought India was weak to offer armed resistance but it was his (Mr. Gandhi’s) firm conviction that it required greater strength to offer non violent resistance as the proposed non co operation.
('21', 171, 2, 10, 396281) Mr. Shaukat Ali next addressing the meeting .
('21', 171, 2, 11, 396327) appealed for Hindus’ support and pointed to the Muslim choice of Gandhiji as their leader as the greatest triumph of Hindu Muslim unity.
('21', 171, 2, 12, 396464) For Muslims, if it was good to kill in the cause of Islam, it was equally good to be killed and to invite self suffering.
('21', 171, 3, 13, 396586) The Hindu, 18 8 1920

('21', 172, 1, 2, 397193) 103. SPEECH AT TRICHINOPOLY
('21', 172, 2, 3, 397221) August 17, 1920 1
('21', 172, 3, 4, 397239) I thank you on behalf of my brother Shaukat Ali and myself for the magnificent reception that the citizens of Trichinopoly have given to us.
('21', 172, 3, 5, 397380) I thank you also for the many addresses that you have been good enough to present to us, but I must come to business.
('21', 172, 3, 6, 397498) It is a great pleasure to me to renew your acquaintance for reasons that I need not give you.
('21', 172, 3, 7, 397592) I expect great things from Trichinopoly, Madura and [a] few places I could name.
('21', 172, 3, 8, 397673) I take it that you have read my address on the Madras Beach on non co operation.
('21', 172, 3, 9, 397754) Without taking up your time in this great assembly, I wish to deal with one or two matters that arise out of Mr. S. Kasturi Ranga Iyengar’s2 speech.
('21', 172, 3, 10, 397903) He says in effect that I should have waited for the Congress mandate on non co operation.
('21', 172, 3, 11, 397993) That was impossible, because the Mussulmans had and still have a duty, irrespective of the Hindus, to perform in reference to their own religion.
('21', 172, 3, 12, 398139) It was impossible for them to wait for any mandate, says the mandate of their own religion, in a matter that vitally concerned the honour of Islam.
('21', 172, 3, 13, 398287) It is therefore possible for them only to go to the Congress on bended knees with a clear cut programme of their own and ask the Congress to pronounce its blessing upon that programme and if they are not so fortunate as to secure the blessings of the national assembly, without meaning any disrespect to that assembly, it is their bounden duty to go on with their programme, and so it is the duty of every Hindu, who considers his Mussulman brother as a brother who has a just cause which he wishes to vindicate, to throw in his lot with his Mussulman brother.
('21', 172, 3, 14, 398848) Our leader does not quarrel with the principle of non co operation by itself, but he objects to the three principal details of non co operation.
('21', 172, 3, 15, 398993) He considers that it is our duty to seek election to the councils and fight our battle on the floor of the council hall.
('21', 172, 3, 16, 399114) I do not deny the possibility of a fight and a royal fight on the council floor.
('21', 172, 3, 17, 399195) We have done it for the last 35 years, but I venture to suggest to you and to him, with all due respect, that it is not non co operation and it is not half as successful as non co operation can be.
('21', 172, 3, 18, 399393) You cannot go to a class of people with a view to convince them by any fight—call it even
('21', 172, 4, 19, 399483) 1 The source has August 18 but Gandhiji visited Trichinipoly the provious day; vide “Madras Tour”, 29 8 1920. 2 Editor, The Hindu, Madras
('21', 173, 0, 1, 399621) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 173, 1, 2, 399663) obstruction—who have got a settled conviction and a settled policy to follow.
('21', 173, 1, 3, 399741) It is in medical language an incompatible mixture out of which you can gain nothing, but if you totally boycott the council, you create a public opinion in the country with reference to the khilafat wrong and the Punjab wrong, which feeling will become tota lly irresistible.
('21', 173, 1, 4, 400017) The first advantage of going to the councils must be goodwill on the part of the rulers.
('21', 173, 1, 5, 400106) It is absolutely lacking.
('21', 173, 1, 6, 400132) In the place of goodwill, you have got nothing but injustice, but I must move on.
('21', 173, 1, 7, 400214) I come now to the second objection of Mr. Kasturi Ranga Iyengar with reference to the suspension by lawyers of their practice.
('21', 173, 1, 8, 400341) Milk is good in itself, but it becomes absolutely poisonous immed iately a little bit of arsenic is added to it.
('21', 173, 1, 9, 400454) Law courts are similarly good when justice is distilled through them on behalf of a sovereign power, which wants to do justice to its people.
('21', 173, 1, 10, 400596) Law courts are one of the greatest symbols of power and in the battle of non co operation, you may not leave law courts untouched and claim to offer non co operation, but if you will read that objection carefully, you will find in that objection the great fear that the lawyers will not respond to the call that the country makes upon them, and it is just there that the beauty of non co operation comes in.
('21', 173, 1, 11, 401004) If one lawyer alone suspends practice, it is so much to the good of the country and so if we are sure to deprive the Government of the power that it possesses through its law courts, whether one lawyer takes it up or many, we must adopt that step.
('21', 173, 1, 12, 401252) He objects also to the plan of boycotting Government schools.
('21', 173, 1, 13, 401314) I can only say what I have said with reference to lawyers that if we mean non co operation, we may not receive any favours from the Government, no matter how advantageous by themselves they may be.
('21', 173, 1, 14, 401512) In a great struggle like this, it is not open to us to count how many schools will respond and how many parents will respond and just as a geometrical problem is difficult, because it does not admit of easy proof, so also because a certain stage in national evolution is difficult, you may not avoid that step without making the whole of that evolution a farce.
('21', 173, 2, 15, 401874) At this stage there was some disturbance in one part of the assembly and after a few minutes pause the Mahatma continued.
('21', 173, 2, 16, 401996) We have had a great lesson in non co operation and co operation.
('21', 173, 2, 17, 402061) (laughter.) We had a lesson in non co operation when some young men began to fight there, and it is a dangerous weapon.
('21', 174, 0, 1, 402181) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 175
('21', 174, 1, 2, 402226) I have not the slightest doubt about it.
('21', 174, 1, 3, 402267) One man with a determined will to non co operate can disturb a whole meeting (Laughter.) and we had a physical demonstration of it to night (Renewed laughter.) but ours is non violent non co operation in which there can be no mistake whatsoever if the fundamental conditions are observed.
('21', 174, 1, 4, 402556) If non co operation fails, it will not be for want of any inherent strength in it, but it will fail because there is no response to it, or because people have not sufficiently grasped its simple principles.
('21', 174, 1, 5, 402763) You had also a practical demonstration of co operation just now.
('21', 174, 1, 6, 402828) (Laughter.) That heavy chair went over the heads of so many people, because all wanted to lift their little hand to move that chair away from them and so was that heavier dome also removed from our sight by the co operation of man, woman and child.
('21', 174, 1, 7, 403077) Everybody believes and knows that this Government of ours exists only by the co operation of the people and not by the force of arms it can wield (“Hear, hear!”) and every man with a sense of logic will tell you that the converse of that also is equally true (Laughter.) that Government cannot stand if this co operation on which it exists is withdrawn.
('21', 174, 1, 8, 403431) Difficulties undoubtedly there are, we have hitherto learned how to sacrifice our voice and make speeches.
('21', 174, 1, 9, 403538) We must also learn to sacrifice ease, money, comfort and that we may learn from the Englishmen themselves.
('21', 174, 1, 10, 403645) Everyone who has studied English history know that we are now engaged in a battle with a nation which is capable of great sacrifice and the three hundred millions of India cannot make their mark upon the world, or gain their self respect without any adequate measure of sacrifice.
('21', 174, 1, 11, 403926) Our friend has suggested the boycott of British or foreign goods.
('21', 174, 1, 12, 403992) Boycott of all foreign goods is another name for swadeshi.
('21', 174, 1, 13, 404051) He thinks that there will be a greater response in the boycott of all foreign goods.
('21', 174, 1, 14, 404136) With the experience of years behind me and with an intimate knowledge of the merchantile classes, I venture to tell you that boycott of foreign goods, or boycott of merely British goods is more impracticable than any of the steps I have suggested, whereas in all the steps that I have ventured to suggest there is practically no sacrifice of money involved.
('21', 174, 1, 15, 404494) In the boycott of British or foreign goods you are inviting your merchant princes to sacrifice their millions.
('21', 174, 1, 16, 404605) It has got to be done, but it is an exceedingly slow process.
('21', 174, 1, 17, 404667) The same may be said of the steps that I have ventured to suggest, I know, but boycott of goods is conceived as punishment and punishment is only effective when it is inflicted.
('21', 174, 1, 18, 404845) What I have ventured to suggest is not a punishment, but the performance of a
('21', 175, 0, 1, 404923) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 175, 1, 2, 404965) sacred duty, a measure of self denial from ourselves, and therefore it is effective from its very inception when it is undertaken even by one man and a substantial duty performed even by one single man lays the foundation of a nation’s liberty.
('21', 175, 1, 3, 405210) I am most anxious for my nation, for my Mussulman brethren also to understand that if they want to vindicate national honour, or the honour of Islam, it will be vindicated without a shadow of doubt, not by conceiving a punishment or a series of punishments, but by an adequate measure of self sacrifice.
('21', 175, 1, 4, 405514) I wish to speak of all our leaders in terms of the greatest respect, but whatever respect we wish to pay to them may not stop or arrest the progress of the country, and I am most anxious that the country at this very critical period of its history should make its choice.
('21', 175, 1, 5, 405786) The choice clearly does not lie before you and me in wresting by force of arms the sceptre from the British nation, but the choice lies in suffering this double wrong of the khilafat and the Punjab, in pocketing humiliation and in accepting national emasculation or vindication of India’s honour by sacrifice today by every man, woman and child and those who feel convinced that this is the only choice left open to us may not wait for the verdict of the Congress, of for any other verdict save the verdict of their own conscience.
('21', 175, 1, 6, 406318) You and I may not wait till the nation itself has made the choice, but if we are convinced of the rightness of things, we should make that choice to night.
('21', 175, 1, 7, 406474) So, citizens of Trichinopoly, you may not wait for the whole of India but you can enforce the first step of non co operation and begin your operations even from tomorrow, if you have not done so already.
('21', 175, 1, 8, 406678) You can surrender all your titles tomorrow; (Cheers.) all the lawyers may surrender their practice tomorrow; those who cannot sustain body and soul by any other means can be easily supported by the Kilafat Committee, if they will give their whole time and attention to the work of that Committee, and if the lawyers will kindly do that, you will find that there is no difficulty in settling your disputes by private arbitration.
('21', 175, 1, 9, 407107) You can nationalize your schools from tomorrow if you have got the will and the determination.
('21', 175, 1, 10, 407202) It is difficult, I know, when only a few of you think these things.
('21', 175, 1, 11, 407270) It is as easy as we are sitting here when the whole of this vast audience is of one mind and as it was easy for you to carry that chair, so is it easy for you to enforce this programme from tomorrow if you have one will, one determination and love for your country, love for the honour of your country and religion.
('21', 175, 1, 12, 407586) (Loud and prolonged cheers.) The Hindu, 19 8 1920

('21', 176, 1, 2, 407681) 104. MORE OBJECTIONS ANSWERED
('21', 176, 2, 3, 407711) Swadeshamitran is one of the most influential Tamil dailies of Madras.
('21', 176, 2, 4, 407782) It is widely read.
('21', 176, 2, 5, 407801) Everything appearing in its coloums is entitled to respect.
('21', 176, 2, 6, 407861) The editor has suggested some practical difficulties in the way of non co operation.
('21', 176, 2, 7, 407946) I would therefore like, to the best of my ability, to deal with them.
('21', 176, 2, 8, 408016) I do not know where the information has been derived from that I have given up the last two stages of non co operation.
('21', 176, 2, 9, 408136) What I have said is that they are a distant goal.
('21', 176, 2, 10, 408186) I abide by it.
('21', 176, 2, 11, 408201) I admit that all the stages are fraught with some danger, but the last two are fraught with the greatest—the last most of all.
('21', 176, 2, 12, 408328) The stages have been fixed with a view to running the least possible risk.
('21', 176, 2, 13, 408403) The last two stages will not be taken up unless the Committee has attained sufficient control over the people to warrant the beliefs that the laying down of arms or suspension of taxes will, humanly speaking, be free from an outbreak of violence on the part of the people.
('21', 176, 2, 14, 408676) I do entertain the belief that it is possible for the people to attain the discipline necessary for taking the two steps.
('21', 176, 2, 15, 408798) When once they realize that violence is totally unnecessary to bend an unwilling Government to their will and that the results can be obtained with certainty by dignified non co operation, they will cease to think of violence even by way of retaliation.
('21', 176, 2, 16, 409052) The fact is that hitherto we have not attempted to take concerted and disciplined action from the masses.
('21', 176, 2, 17, 409158) Some day, if we are to become truly a self governing nation, that attempt has to be made.
('21', 176, 2, 18, 409248) The present, in my opinion, is a propitious movement.
('21', 176, 2, 19, 409302) Every Indian feels the insult to the Punjab as a personal wrong, every Mussulman resents the wrong done to the khilafat.
('21', 176, 2, 20, 409423) There is therefore a favourable atmosphere for expecting cohesive and restrained movement on the part of the masses.
('21', 176, 2, 21, 409540) So far as response is concerned, I agree with the editor that the quickest and the largest response is to be expected in the matter of suspension of payment of taxes, but as I have said, so long as the masses are not educated to appreciate the value of non violence even whilst their holdings are being sold, so long must it be difficult to take up the last stage into any appreciable extent.
('21', 176, 2, 22, 409933) I agree too that a sudden withdrawal of the military and the police will be a disaster if we have not acquired the ability to protect ourselves against robbers and thieves.
('21', 176, 2, 23, 410106) But I suggest that when we are ready to call out the military and the police on an extensive scale, we
('21', 177, 0, 1, 410209) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 177, 1, 2, 410251) would find ourselves in a position to defend ourselves.
('21', 177, 1, 3, 410307) If the police and the military resign from patriotic motives, I would certainly expect them to perform the same duty as national volunteers, not as hirelings but as willing protectors of the life and liberty of their countrymen.
('21', 177, 1, 4, 410536) The movement of non co operation is one of automatic adjustment.
('21', 177, 1, 5, 410601) If the Government schools are emptied, I would certainly expect national schools to come into being.
('21', 177, 1, 6, 410702) If the lawyers as a whole suspended practice, they would devise arbitration courts and the nation will have expeditious and cheaper method of settling private disputes and awarding punishment to the wrongdoer.
('21', 177, 1, 7, 410912) I may add that the Khilafat Committee is fully alive to the difficulty of the task and is taking all the necessary steps to meet the contingencies as they arise.
('21', 177, 1, 8, 411074) Regarding the leaving of civil employment, no danger is feared, because no one will leave his employment, unless he is in a position to find support for himself and family either through friends or otherwise.
('21', 177, 1, 9, 411283) Disapproval of the proposed withdrawal of students betrays, in my humble opinion, lack of appreciation of the true nature of non co operation.
('21', 177, 1, 10, 411426) It is true enough that we pay the money wherewith our children are educated.
('21', 177, 1, 11, 411503) But when the agency imparting the education has become corrupt, we may not employ it without partaking of the agent’s corruption.
('21', 177, 1, 12, 411633) When students leave schools or colleges I hardly imagine that the teachers will fail to perceive the advisability of themselves resigning.
('21', 177, 1, 13, 411772) But even if they do not, money can hardly be allowed to count where honour or religion are at stake.
('21', 177, 1, 14, 411873) As to the boycott of the councils, it is not the entry of the Moderates or any other persons that matters so much as the entry of those who believe in non co operation.
('21', 177, 1, 15, 412042) You may not co operate at the top and non co operate at the bottom.
('21', 177, 1, 16, 412110) A councillor cannot remain in the council and ask the gumasta who cleans the council table to resign.
