('21', 178, 1, 2, 412280) 105. SWADESHI
('21', 178, 2, 3, 412294) In criticizing my article entitled “The Music of the Spinning Wheel” 1, the Leader the other day attributed to me the ideas that I have never entertained.
('21', 178, 2, 4, 412449) And it is necessary for the purpose of understanding the true value of swadeshi, to correct some of the current fallacies.
('21', 178, 2, 5, 412572) The Leader considers that I am putting back the hands of the clock of progress by attempting to replace mill made cloth and mill spun yarn by hand woven and hand spun yarn.
('21', 178, 2, 6, 412745) Now, I am making no such attempt at all.
('21', 178, 2, 7, 412786) I have no quarrel with the mill.
('21', 178, 2, 8, 412819) My views are incredibly simple.
('21', 178, 2, 9, 412851) India requires nearly 13 yards of cloth per head per year.
('21', 178, 2, 10, 412910) She produces, I believe, less than half the amount.
('21', 178, 2, 11, 412962) India grows all the cotton she needs.
('21', 178, 2, 12, 413000) She exports several million bales of cotton to Japan and Lancashire and receives much of it back in manufactured calico although she is capable of producing all the cloth and all the yarn necessary for supplying her wants by hand weaving and hand spinning.
('21', 178, 2, 13, 413257) India needs to supplement her main occupation, agriculture, with some other employment.
('21', 178, 2, 14, 413345) Hand spinning is the only such employment for millions.
('21', 178, 2, 15, 413401) It was the national employment a century ago.
('21', 178, 2, 16, 413447) It is not true to say that economic pressure and modern machinery destroyed hand spinning and hand weaving.
('21', 178, 2, 17, 413555) This great industry was destroyed or almost destroyed by extraordinary and immoral means adopted by the East India Company.
('21', 178, 2, 18, 413679) This national industry is capable of being revived by exertion and a change in the national taste without damaging the mill industry.
('21', 178, 2, 19, 413813) Increase of mills is no present remedy for supplying the deficiency.
('21', 178, 2, 20, 413882) The deficiency can be easily supplied only by hand spinning and hand weaving.
('21', 178, 2, 21, 413960) If this employment were revived, it would prevent sixty million rupees from being annually drained from the country and distribute the amount among lakhs of poor women in their own cottages.
('21', 178, 2, 22, 414151) I therefore consider swadeshi as an automatic, though partial, solution of the problem of India’s grinding poverty.
('21', 178, 2, 23, 414267) It also constitutes a ready made insurance policy in times of scarcity of rain.
('21', 178, 2, 24, 414347) But two things are needful to bring about the needed revival—to create a taste for khaddar and to provide an organization for the distribution of carded cotton and collection of yarn against payment.
('21', 178, 2, 25, 414547) In one year, by the silent labour of a few men, several thousands rupees have been distributed in Gujarat among several thousand poor
('21', 178, 3, 26, 414681) 1 Of July 21, 1920
('21', 179, 0, 1, 414700) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 179, 1, 2, 414742) women who are glad enough to earn a few pice per day to buy milk for their children, etc.
('21', 179, 1, 3, 414832) The argument does not apply to the sugar industry as the Leader has attempted.
('21', 179, 1, 4, 414911) There is not sufficient cane grown in India to supply India’s wants.
('21', 179, 1, 5, 414980) Sugar was never a national and supplementary industry.
('21', 179, 1, 6, 415035) Foreign sugar has not supplanted Indian sugar.
('21', 179, 1, 7, 415082) India’s wants of sugar have grown and she therefore imports more sugar.
('21', 179, 1, 8, 415154) But this importation does not institute a drain in the sense in which importation of foreign cloth does.
('21', 179, 1, 9, 415259) Production of more sugar means more scientific agriculture, more and better machinery for crushing and refining.
('21', 179, 1, 10, 415372) The sugar industry therefore stands on a different platform.
('21', 179, 1, 11, 415433) Swadeshi in sugar is desirable, swadeshi in cloth is an urgent necessity.
('21', 179, 1, 12, 415507) Young India, 18 8 1920
('21', 179, 2, 13, 415530) 106. SPEECH AT CALICUT
('21', 179, 3, 14, 415553) August 18, 1920
('21', 179, 4, 15, 415569) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, On behalf of my brother Shaukat Ali and myself I wish to thank you most sincerely for the warm welcome you have extended to us.
('21', 179, 4, 16, 415723) Before I begin to explain the purpose of our mission I have to give you the information that Pir Mahboob Shah who was being tried in Sind for sedition has been sentenced to two years’ simple imprisonment.
('21', 179, 4, 17, 415928) I do not know exactly what the offence was with which the Pir was charged.
('21', 179, 4, 18, 416003) I do not know whether the words attributed to him were ever spoken by him.
('21', 179, 4, 19, 416078) But I do know that the Pir Saheb declined to offer any defence and with perfect resignation he has accepted his penalty.
('21', 179, 4, 20, 416199) For me it is a matter of sincere pleasure that the Pir Saheb who exercises great influence over his followers has understood the spirit of the struggle upon which we have embarked.
('21', 179, 4, 21, 416380) It is not by resisting the authority of Government that we expect to succeed in the great task before us.
('21', 179, 4, 22, 416486) But I do expect that we shall succeed if we understand the spirit of non co operation.
('21', 179, 4, 23, 416573) The Lieutenant Governor of Burma himself has told us that the British retain their hold on India not by the force of arms but by the force of co operation of the people.
('21', 179, 4, 24, 416743) Thus he has given us the remedy for any wrong that the Government may do to the people, whether knowingly or unknowingly.
('21', 179, 4, 25, 416865) And so long as we co operate with the Government,
('21', 180, 0, 1, 416915) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 181
('21', 180, 1, 2, 416960) so long as we support that Government we become to that extent sharers in the wrong.
('21', 180, 1, 3, 417045) I admit that in ordinary circumstances a wise subject will tolerate the wrongs of a Government, but a wise subject never tolerates a wrong that a Government imposes on the declared will of a people.
('21', 180, 1, 4, 417244) And I venture to submit to this great meeting that the Government of India and the Imperial Government have done a double wrong to India, and if we are a nation of self respecting people conscious of its dignity, conscious of its right, it is not just and proper that we should stand the double humiliation that the Government has heaped upon us.
('21', 180, 1, 5, 417591) By shaping and by becoming a predominant partner in the Peace Terms imposed on the helpless Sultan of Turkey, the Imperial Government have intentionally flouted the cherished sentiment of the Mussulman subjects of the Empire.
('21', 180, 1, 6, 417817) The present Prime Minister gave a deliberate pledge after consultation with his colleagues when it was necessary for him to conciliate the Mussulmans of India.
('21', 180, 1, 7, 417977) I claim to have studied this khilafat question in a special manner.
('21', 180, 1, 8, 418045) I claim to understand the Mussulman feeling on the khilafat question and I am here to declare for the tenth time that on the khilafat matter the Government has wounded the Mussulman sentiment as they had never done before.
('21', 180, 1, 9, 418268) And I say without fear of contradiction that if the Mussulmans of India had not exercised great self restraint and if there was not the gospel of non co operation preached to them and if they had not accepted it, there would have been bloodshed in India by this time.
('21', 180, 1, 10, 418536) I am free to confess that spilling of blood would not have availed their cause.
('21', 180, 1, 11, 418616) But a man who is in a state of rage whose heart has become lacerated does not count the cost of his action.
('21', 180, 1, 12, 418724) So much for the khilafat wrong.
('21', 180, 1, 13, 418756) I propose to take you for a minute to the Punjab, the northern end of India.
('21', 180, 1, 14, 418833) And what have both Governments done for the Punjab?
('21', 180, 1, 15, 418885) I am free to confess again that the crowds in Amritsar went mad for a moment.
('21', 180, 1, 16, 418963) They were goaded to madness by a wicked administration.
('21', 180, 1, 17, 419019) But no madness on the part of a people can justify the shedding of innocent blood, and what have they paid for it?
('21', 180, 1, 18, 419134) I venture to submit that no civilized Government could ever have made the people pay the penalty and retribution that they have paid.
('21', 180, 1, 19, 419268) Innocent men were tried through mock tribunals and imprisoned for life.
('21', 180, 1, 20, 419340) Amnesty granted to them after; I count of no consequence.
('21', 180, 1, 21, 419398) Innocent, unarmed men, who knew nothing of what was to happen, were butchered in cold blood without the slightest notice.
('21', 180, 1, 22, 419520) Modesty of women in Manianwala, women who had done no wrong to any individual, was outraged by
('21', 181, 0, 1, 419615) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 181, 1, 2, 419657) insolent officers.
('21', 181, 1, 3, 419676) I want you to understand what I mean by outrage of their modesty.
('21', 181, 1, 4, 419742) Their veils were opened with his stick by an officer.
('21', 181, 1, 5, 419796) Men who were declared to be utterly innocent by the Hunter Committee were made to crawl on their bellies.
('21', 181, 1, 6, 419902) And all these wrongs totally undeserved remain unavenged.
('21', 181, 1, 7, 419960) If it was the duty of the Government of India to punish those who were guilty of incendiarism and murder, as I hold it was their duty, it was doubly their duty to punish officers who insulted and oppressed innocent people.
('21', 181, 1, 8, 420183) But in the face of these official wrongs we have the debate in the House of Lords supporting official terrorism.
('21', 181, 1, 9, 420296) It is this double wrong, the affront to Islam and the injury to the manhood of the Punjab, that we feel bound to wipe out by non co operation.
('21', 181, 1, 10, 420439) We have prayed, petitioned, agitated, we have passed resolutions.
('21', 181, 1, 11, 420505) Mr. Mahomed Ali supported by his friends is now waiting on the British public.
('21', 181, 1, 12, 420584) He has pleaded the cause of Islam in a most manful manner, but his pleading has fallen on deaf ears and we have his word for it that whilst France and Italy have shown great sympathy for the cause of Islam, it is the British ministers who have shown no sympathy.
('21', 181, 1, 13, 420847) This shows which way the British ministers and the present holders of office in India mean to deal by the people.
('21', 181, 1, 14, 420961) There is no goodwill, there is no desire to placate the people of India.
('21', 181, 1, 15, 421034) The people of India must therefore have a remedy to redress the double wrong.
('21', 181, 1, 16, 421112) The method of the West is violence.
('21', 181, 1, 17, 421148) Wherever the people of the West have felt a wrong either justly or unjustly, they have rebelled and shed blood.
('21', 181, 1, 18, 421260) As I have said in my letter to the Viceroy of India, half of India does not believe in the remedy of violence.
('21', 181, 1, 19, 421371) The other half is too weak to offer it.
('21', 181, 1, 20, 421411) But the whole of India is deeply hurt and stirred by this wrong, and it is for that reason that I have suggested to the people of India the remedy of non co operation, I consider it perfectly harmless, absolutely constitutional and yet perfectly efficacious.
('21', 181, 1, 21, 421670) It is a remedy in which, if it is properly adopted, victory is certain, and it is the age old remedy of self sacrifice.
('21', 181, 1, 22, 421790) Are the Mussulmans of India who feel the great wrong done to Islam ready to make an adequate self sacrifice?
('21', 181, 1, 23, 421899) All the scriptures of the world teach us that there can be no compromise between justice and injustice.
('21', 181, 1, 24, 422003) Co operation on the part of a justice loving man with an unjust man is a crime.
('21', 181, 1, 25, 422083) And if we desire to compel this great Government to the will of the people, as we must, we must adopt this great remedy of non co operation.
('21', 181, 1, 26, 422224) And if the Mussulmans of India offer non co operation to Government in order to secure justice in the khilafat matter, I believe it is the duty of the Hindus to
('21', 182, 0, 1, 422385) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 183
('21', 182, 1, 2, 422430) help them so long as their means are just.
('21', 182, 1, 3, 422473) I consider the eternal friendship between the Hindus and Mussulmans is more important than the British connection.
('21', 182, 1, 4, 422588) I would prefer any day anarchy and chaos in India to an armed peace brought about by the bayonet between the Hindus and Mussulmans.
('21', 182, 1, 5, 422720) I have therefore ventured to suggest to my Hindu brethren that if they wanted to live at peace with Mussulmans, there is an opportunity which is not going to recur for the next hundred years.
('21', 182, 1, 6, 422912) And I venture to assure you that if the Government of India and the Imperial Government come to know that there is a determination on the part of the people to redress this double wrong they would not hesitate to do what is needed.
('21', 182, 1, 7, 423144) But the Mussulmans of India will have to take the lead in the matter.
('21', 182, 1, 8, 423214) You will have to commence the first stage of non co operation in right earnest.
('21', 182, 1, 9, 423294) And if you may not help this Government, you may not receive help from it.
('21', 182, 1, 10, 423369) Titles which were the other day titles of honour are today in my opinion badges of our disgrace.
('21', 182, 1, 11, 423466) We must therefore surrender all titles of honour, all honorary offices.
('21', 182, 1, 12, 423538) It will constitute an emphatic demonstration of the disapproval by the leaders of the people of the acts of the Government.
('21', 182, 1, 13, 423662) Lawyers must suspend their practice and must resist the power of the Government which has chosen to flout public opinion.
('21', 182, 1, 14, 423784) Nor may we recieve instruction from schools controlled by the Government and aided by it.
('21', 182, 1, 15, 423874) Emptying of the schools will constitute a demonstration of the will of the middle class of India.
('21', 182, 1, 16, 423972) It is far better for the nation even to neglect the literary instruction of the children than to co operate with a Government that has striven to maintain an injustic and untruth on the khilafat and Punjab matters.
('21', 182, 1, 17, 424187) Similary have I ventured to suggest a complete boycott of reformed councils.
('21', 182, 1, 18, 424264) That will be an emphatic declaration on the part of the representatives of the people that they do not desire to associate with the Government so long as the two wrongs continue.
('21', 182, 1, 19, 424443) We must equally decline to offer ourselves as recruits of the police or military.
('21', 182, 1, 20, 424525) It is impossible for us to go to Mesopotamia or to offer to police that country or to offer military assistance and to help the Government in that blood guiltiness.
('21', 182, 1, 21, 424690) The last plank in the first stage is swadeshi.
('21', 182, 1, 22, 424737) Swadeshi is intended not so much to bring pressure upon the Government as to demonstrate the capacity for sacrifice on the part of the men and women of India.
('21', 182, 1, 23, 424896) When one fourth of India has its religion at stake and when the whole of India has its honour at stake, we can be in no mood to bedeck ourselves with French calico or silks from Japan.
('21', 182, 1, 24, 425081) We must resolve to be satisfied with cloth woven
('21', 183, 0, 1, 425130) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 183, 1, 2, 425172) by the humble weavers of India in their own cottages out of yarn spun by their sisters in their own homes.
('21', 183, 1, 3, 425279) When a hundred years ago our tastes were not debased and we were not lured by all the fineries from the foreign countries, we were satisfied with the cloth produced by the men and women in India, and if I could but in a moment revolutionize the tastes of India and make it return to its original simplicity, I assure you that the Gods would descend to rejoice at the great act of renunciation.
('21', 183, 1, 4, 425673) That is the first stage in non co operation.
('21', 183, 1, 5, 425718) I hope it is as easy for you as it is easy for me to see that if India is capable of taking the first step in anything like a full measure that step will bring the redress we want.
('21', 183, 1, 6, 425899) I therefore do not intend to take you to the other stages of non co operation.
('21', 183, 1, 7, 425978) I would like you to rivet your attention upon the plans in the first stage.
('21', 183, 1, 8, 426054) You will have noticed that but two things are necessary in going through the first stage: (1) Perfect spirit of non violence is indispensable for non co operation, (2) only a little self sacrifice.
('21', 183, 1, 9, 426252) I pray to God that He will give the people of India sufficient courage and wisdom and patience to go through this experiment of non co operation.
('21', 183, 1, 10, 426398) I thank you for the great reception that you have given us.
('21', 183, 1, 11, 426458) And I also thank you for the great patience and exemplary silence with which you have listened to my remarks.

('21', 183, 3, 13, 426590) 107. SPEECH AT MANGALORE
('21', 183, 4, 14, 426615) August 19, 1920
('21', 183, 5, 15, 426631) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, To my brother Shaukat Ali and me it was a pleasure to go to this beautiful garden of India.
('21', 183, 5, 16, 426749) The great reception that you gave us this afternoon, and this great assembly are most welcome to us, if they are a demonstration of your sympathy with the cause which you have the honour to represent.
('21', 183, 5, 17, 426950) I assure you that we have not undertaken this incessant travelling in order to have receptions and addresses, no matter how cordial they may be.
('21', 183, 5, 18, 427095) But we have undertaken this travelling throughout the length and breadth of this dear motherland to place before you the position that faces us today.
('21', 183, 5, 19, 427246) It is our privilege, as it is our duty, to place that position before the country and let her make the choice.
('21', 184, 0, 1, 427357) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 185
('21', 184, 1, 2, 427402) Throughout our tour we have received many addresses, but in my humble opinion no address was more truly worded than the address that was presented to us at Kasargod.
('21', 184, 1, 3, 427568) It addressed both of us as “dear revered brothers”.
('21', 184, 1, 4, 427620) I am unable to accept the second adjective “revered”.
('21', 184, 1, 5, 427674) The word “dear” is dear to me I must confess.
('21', 184, 1, 6, 427720) But dearer than that is the expression “brothers”.
('21', 184, 1, 7, 427771) The signatories to that address recognized the true significance of this travel.
('21', 184, 1, 8, 427852) No blood brothers can possibly be more intimately related, can possibly be more united in one purpose, one aim than my brother Shaukat Ali and I. And I considered it a proud privilege and honour to be addressed as blood brother to Shaukat Ali.
('21', 184, 1, 9, 428096) The contents of that address were as equally significant.
('21', 184, 1, 10, 428154) It stated that in our united work was represented the essence of the unity between the Mussulmans and Hindus in India.
('21', 184, 1, 11, 428273) If we two cannot represent that very desirable unity, if we two cannot cement the relation between the two communities, I do not know who can.
('21', 184, 1, 12, 428416) Then without any rhetoric and without any flowery language the address went on to describe the inwardness of the Punjab and the khilafat struggle; and then in simple and beautiful language it described the spiritual significance of satyagraha and non co operation.
('21', 184, 1, 13, 428681) This was followed by a frank and simple promise.
('21', 184, 1, 14, 428730) Although the signatories to the address realized the momentous nature of the struggle on which we have embarked, and although they sympathize with the struggle with their whole heart, they wound up by saying that even if they could not follow non co operation in all its details, they would do as much as they could to help the struggle.
('21', 184, 1, 15, 429068) And lastly, in eloquent, and true language, they said, “if we cannot rise equal to the occasion it will not be due to want of effort but to want of ability”.
('21', 184, 1, 16, 429226) I can desire no better address, no better promise, and if you, the citizens of Mangalore, can come up to the level of the signatories, and give us just the assurance that you consider the struggle to be right and that it commands your entire approval, I am certain you will make all sacrifice that lies in your power.
('21', 184, 1, 17, 429544) For we are face to face with a peril greater than plagues, greater than influenza, greater than earthquakes and mighty floods, which sometimes overwhelm this land.
('21', 184, 1, 18, 429708) These physical calamities can rob us of so many Indian bodies.
('21', 184, 1, 19, 429771) But the calamity that has at the present moment over taken India touches the religious honour of a fourth of her children and the self respect of the whole nation.
('21', 184, 1, 20, 429935) The khilafat wrong affects the Mussulmans of India, and the Punjab calamity very nearly overwhelms the manhood of India.
('21', 184, 1, 21, 430056) Shall we in the face of this danger
('21', 185, 0, 1, 430092) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 185, 1, 2, 430134) be weak or rise to our full height?
('21', 185, 1, 3, 430170) The remedy for both the wrongs is the spiritual solvent of non co operation.
('21', 185, 1, 4, 430247) Icall it a spiritual weapon, because it demands discipline and sacrifice from us.
('21', 185, 1, 5, 430329) It demands sacrifice from every individual irrespective of the rest.
('21', 185, 1, 6, 430398) And the promise that is behind this performance of duty, the promise given by every religion that I have studied, is sure and certain.
('21', 185, 1, 7, 430533) It is that there is no spotless sacrifice that has been yet offered on earth, which has not carried with it its absolute adequate reward.
('21', 185, 1, 8, 430671) It is a spiritual weapon, because it waits for no mandate from anybody except one’s own conscience.
('21', 185, 1, 9, 430771) It is a spiritual weapon because it brings out the best in the nation and it absolutely satisfies national honour if the whole nation takes it up.
('21', 185, 1, 10, 430918) And therefore it is that I have called non co operation—in opposition to the opinion of many of my distinguished countrymen and leaders—a weapon that is infallible and absolutely practicable.
('21', 185, 1, 11, 431110) It is infallible and practicable, because it satisfies the demands of individual conscience.
('21', 185, 1, 12, 431203) God above cannot, will not expect Maulana Shaukat Ali to do more than he has been doing, for he has surrendered and placed at the disposal of God whom he believes to be the Almighty ruler of everyone, he has delivered all in the service of God.
('21', 185, 1, 13, 431448) And we stand before the citizens of Mangalore and ask them to make their choice either to accept this precious gift that we lay at their feet or to reject it.
('21', 185, 1, 14, 431607) And after having listened to my message if you come to the conclusion that you have no other remedy than non co operation for the conservation of Islam and the honour of India, you will accept that remedy.
('21', 185, 1, 15, 431813) I ask you not to be confused by so many bewildering issues that are placed before you, not to be shaken from your purpose because you see divided counsels amongst your leaders.
('21', 185, 1, 16, 431990) This is one of the necessary limitations of any spiritual or any other struggle that has ever been fought on this earth.
('21', 185, 1, 17, 432111) It is because it comes so suddenly that it confuses the mind if the heart is not tuned properly.
('21', 185, 1, 18, 432208) And we would be perfect human beings on this earth if in all of us was found absolutely perfect correspondence between the mind and the heart.
('21', 185, 1, 19, 432351) But those of you who have been following the newspaper controversy, will find that no matter what division of opinion exists amongst our journals and leaders there is unanimity that the remedy is efficacious if it can be kept free from violence, and if it is adopted on a large scale.
('21', 185, 1, 20, 432636) I admit the difficulty, the virtue however lies in surmounting it.
('21', 185, 1, 21, 432703) We cannot possibly combine violence with a spiri tual weapon like non co operation.
('21', 185, 1, 22, 432787) We do not offer spotless sacrifice it we take the lives of others in offering our own.
('21', 186, 0, 1, 432874) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 187
('21', 186, 1, 2, 432919) Absolute free dom from violence is therefore a condition precedent to non co operation.
('21', 186, 1, 3, 433007) But I have faith in my country to know that when it has assimilated the principle of the doctrine to the fullest extent, it will respond to it.
('21', 186, 1, 4, 433151) And in no case will India make any headway what soever until she has learnt the lesson of self sacrifice.
('21', 186, 1, 5, 433257) Even if this country were to take up the doctrine of the sword, which God forbid, it will have to learn the lesson of self sacrifice.
('21', 186, 1, 6, 433391) The second difficulty suggested is the want of solidarity of the nation.
('21', 186, 1, 7, 433464) I accept it too.
('21', 186, 1, 8, 433481) But that diffficulty I have already answered by saying that it is a remedy that can be taken up by individuals for individual and by the nation for national satisfaction; and therefore even if the whole nation does not take up non co operation, the individual successes, which may be obtained by individuals taking up non co operation, will stand to their own credit as of the nation to which they belong.
('21', 186, 1, 9, 433887) The first stage in my humble opinion is incredibly easy inasmuch as it does not involve any very great sacrifice.
('21', 186, 1, 10, 434001) If your Khan Bahadurs and other title holders were to renounce their titles I venture to submit that whilst the renunciation will stand to the credit and honour of the nation it will involve a little or no sacrifice.
('21', 186, 1, 11, 434218) On the contrary, they will not only have surrendered no earthly riches, but they will have gained the applause of the nation.
('21', 186, 1, 12, 434344) Let us see what it means, this first step.
('21', 186, 1, 13, 434387) The able editor of The Hindu, Mr. Kasturi Ranga Iyengar, and almost every journalist in the country are agreed that the renunciation of titles is a necessary and a desirable step.
('21', 186, 1, 14, 434567) And if these chosen people of the Government were without exception to surrender their titles to Government giving notice that the heart of India is doubly wounded in that the honour of India and of Muslim religion is at stake and that therefore they can no longer retain their titles I venture to suggest that this their step which costs not a single penny either to them or to the nation will be an effective demonstration of the national will.
('21', 186, 1, 15, 435014) Take the second step or the second item of non co operation.
('21', 186, 1, 16, 435075) I know there is strong opposition to the boycott of councils.
('21', 186, 1, 17, 435137) The opposition when you begin to analyse it means not that the step is faulty or that it is not likely to succeed, but it is due to the belief that the whole country will not respond to it and that the Moderates will steal into the councils.
('21', 186, 1, 18, 435379) I ask the citizens of Manglore to dispel that fear from your hearts.
('21', 186, 1, 19, 435448) United, the voters of Mangalore can make it impossible for either a Moderate or an Extremist or any other form of
('21', 187, 0, 1, 435562) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 187, 1, 2, 435604) leader to enter the councils as your representative.
('21', 187, 1, 3, 435657) This step involves no sacrifice of money, no sacrifice of honour but the gaining of prestige for the whole nation.
('21', 187, 1, 4, 435772) And I venture to suggest to you that this one step alone if it is taken with any degree of unanimity even by the Extremists can bring about the desired relief, but if all do not respond the individual need not be afraid.
('21', 187, 1, 5, 435993) He at least will have laid the foundation for true set progress, let him have the comfort that he at least has washed his hands clean of the guilt of the Government.
('21', 187, 1, 6, 436159) Then I come to the members of the profession which one time I used to carry on.
('21', 187, 1, 7, 436239) I have ventured to ask the lawyers of India to suspend their practice and withdraw their support from a Government which no longer stands for justice, pure and unadulterated, for the nation.
('21', 187, 1, 8, 436430) And the step is good for the individual lawyer who takes it and is good for the nation if all the lawyers take it.

('21', 187, 1, 10, 436837) I will not tax your patience by taking you through the other items of non co operation important as they are.
('21', 187, 1, 11, 436947) But I have ventured to place before you four very important and forcible steps any one of which if fully taken up contains in it possibilities of success.
('21', 187, 1, 12, 437102) Swadeshi is prea ched as an item of non co operation, as a demonstration of the spirit of sacrifice and it is an item which every man, woman and child can take up.

('21', 188, 3, 14, 439281) 109. ADDRESS TO STUDENTS OF LAW COLLEGE, MADRAS
('21', 188, 4, 15, 439329) August 21, 1920
('21', 188, 5, 16, 439345) Mr. Gandhi began by saying that he wanted to occupy the students in a heart to heart conversation, that he would explain to them how a pair, composed of Maulana Shaukat Ali and himself, living at opposite poles about some fundamentals of life—particularly in one fundamental of life, inasmuch as to the speaker non violence was the final arbiter and to Shaukat Ali the sword was the final arbiter—how such a pair could engage hand in hand in the struggle in question.
('21', 188, 5, 17, 439813) He could do no better than read to them a letter he had received that very morning from a Christian lady who said among other things that she was convinced by the speaker’s Madras speech of the necessity of non co operation and that though she had no particular sympathy with Turkey she could not help feeling that in a struggle carried on solely for the honour and prestige of Islam, not only the Hindus but the Christians also should render full assistance to the Mussulmans, and that in a matter of conscience, as the one in question, no nation should be called upon to hang its decision on the mandate of its Congress.
('21', 188, 5, 18, 440436) She also expressed her hearty approval of the boycott of councils and of Government and Government aided schools as also other steps in the first stage of non co operation.
('21', 188, 5, 19, 440609) The speaker read out the letter to the audience and said that it was a magnificent letter, and that he read it not to produce a certificate of
('21', 188, 6, 20, 440752) 1 Vide “Our Duty”, 29 8 1920. 2 Priests
('21', 189, 0, 1, 440792) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 189, 1, 2, 440834) non co operation or about his Madras address, but as the testimony of an impartial Christian observer who was convinced of the spirituality of the struggle, and who thought it was therefore a struggle in which Hindus and Christians ought to have their share no less than the Mussulmans.
('21', 189, 2, 3, 441121) Mr. Gandhi next went on to offer his remarks on the Viceroy’s speech at the opening of the legislative council.
('21', 189, 2, 4, 441233) He said that the paragraph on non co operation demonstrated the triumph of non co operation, it involved a confession that the authorities had learnt a lesson, viz, the wisdom of not precipitating violence and to allow a movement to die out by simply ridiculing it.
('21', 189, 2, 5, 441499) That was, said the speaker, the chosen method of Government in its own home, and it was for the people of India to convert that ridicule into approval.
('21', 189, 2, 6, 441651) Lord Chelmsford had said that he was a lawyer, and that as such he was offering advice to the members of the bar, but that took them no step further.
('21', 189, 2, 7, 441801) At the one end was the Viceroy asking the lawyers to hold on to the courts like grim death, at the other end was the speaker, also a lawyer, who had seen several years’ active practice and given it up, who was born of the people and for the people, asking them to shun the law courts, and it was for the legal profession to make their choice.
('21', 189, 2, 8, 442144) Throughout the world, went on the speaker, the Government had their hold on the necks of the people through the agency of the law courts.
('21', 189, 2, 9, 442282) These law courts, in times other than the present, a lesser evil inasmuch as they preserved so called order as opposed to anarchy.
('21', 189, 2, 10, 442413) In times as the present, they were an unmitigated evil, and he had no doubt that if the lawyers boycotted law courts they would paralyse the arm of Government which means force.
('21', 189, 2, 11, 442591) If the lawyers leading public movement in the country were not willing to respond to the call of sacrifice, he, the speaker, would not have the gumption to go and advise the country.
('21', 189, 2, 12, 442774) If the lawyers were not prepared for acts of sacrifice their appeals would fall flat on the masses, indeed they would have to go asking the people not to engage in a struggle of the present nature, in which case they would have to eat their own words and say that the injustice of which they were talking till now was not so glaring or rankling in their breast as to ask them to go beyond the orthodox methods of agitation.
('21', 189, 2, 13, 443198) There may be, said the speaker, governments as diabolical, even more diabolical than the British Government, but for Indians it was the most diabolical.
('21', 189, 2, 14, 443351) It was going downhill.
('21', 189, 2, 15, 443374) What a shocking document was the Viceregal pronouncement!
('21', 189, 2, 16, 443432) The Viceroy said that the Punjab chapter was closed.
('21', 189, 2, 17, 443485) From a Government who could thus add insult to injury, no gifts, however valuable they may be, could be accepted so long as they do not repent for what they had done.
('21', 189, 2, 18, 443652) Khilafat, the Government might say, would kill itself, but it would not kill itself so long as the Indians had not killed themselves.
('21', 189, 2, 19, 443786) It would close only over their ashes.
('21', 189, 3, 20, 443824) The speaker then carried the audience through some of the episodes in his life which revealed how he, a staunch Hindu, who had imbibed the best of Hinduism from his Shastras, from his fore fathers and his studies, how he was brought together with
('21', 190, 0, 1, 444071) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 191
('21', 190, 1, 2, 444116) a man like Shaukat Ali, than whom he knew no more deeply religious man.
('21', 190, 1, 3, 444188) It was the common feeling that the salvation of India lay in the union of hearts between the Hindus and the Mussulmans that brought them together.
('21', 190, 1, 4, 444335) The Mussulmans were not too arrogant, too haughty to do with out the help of the Hindus and others, and there was no alternative before Shaukat Ali to accept the aid offered by the speaker, as a Hindu who had represented the best of what he had assimilated of Hinduism and for no other motive but that of showing the nobility of his faith.
('21', 190, 1, 5, 444675) To illustrate the spirit in which his assistance was accepted the speaker harked back to a meeting that took place between him and Maulana Abdul Bari Saheb, narrating in vivid detail the talk between the Maulana and him.
('21', 190, 1, 6, 444896) The gist of the story was that whilst Mr. Gandhi insisted that he was not going to render aid in any bargaining spirit, the Maulana insisted that it would be the denial of Islam if the Mussulmans accepted the aid without any thought of reciprocating it.
('21', 190, 1, 7, 445150) Thus were two staunch faithful ones, viz, the speaker and Mr. Shaukat Ali, united more than a brother to brother on a mission to save the honour of Islam and India.
('21', 190, 2, 8, 445315) The speaker proceeded to say that the lawyers with their trained minds ought to be able to see the core of the question.
('21', 190, 2, 9, 445436) It meant, in spiritual terms, not a battle between races, but a battle between the forces of light and darkness, between the forces of devil and God.
('21', 190, 2, 10, 445586) The devil was today incarnate in the wretched Western civilization.
('21', 190, 2, 11, 445654) Having given years of study to the Western civilization the speaker had come to the deliberate conclusion that it represented evil clothed in the robes of Satan and that the Indians had to be engaged in fighting the powers of that evil.
('21', 190, 2, 12, 445891) The force that were moulding the masses of Europe were devilry incarnate and Christianity had to grapple with those forces more and more as the evil ever darkened and thickened.
('21', 190, 2, 13, 446069) The speaker would not hesitate to say that God (Truth) was represented by the Indians, by the non co operationists because they approached God in the humblest spirit, they were asking God not to give them arms but a spirit of self sacrifice.
('21', 190, 2, 14, 446311) The British people, said the speaker, whilst they bragged, blustered, whilst they used in turn honeyed phrases and bitter ones, deep down in them was the spirit to appreciate courage.
('21', 190, 2, 15, 446495) But the Viceroy today was coquetting with them.
('21', 190, 2, 16, 446543) He saw that there was an atmosphere of sycophancy and he wanted to avail himself of it.
('21', 190, 2, 17, 446631) He presented to show that he could tolerate opposition.
('21', 190, 2, 18, 446687) It was good enough this cajoling, but it was wicked because behind it were not just motives as the Viceroy represented today a double wrong, as he had heaped insult on insult.
('21', 190, 2, 19, 446863) The khilafat wrong he laid at the door of Europe.
('21', 190, 2, 20, 446913) Well, the Indians were offering non co operation to all the powers, not only to the British powers, they were non co operating with the evil regarding the khilafat and the Punjab in each and every corner of the world wherever it was represented.
('21', 190, 3, 21, 447159) Mr. Gandhi appealed to the audience to leave law courts, emphasizing that nobody served the country and did not serve himself.
('21', 190, 3, 22, 447286) He for one could say that by giving up law he had to sacrifice none of the comforts that he used to enjoy,
('21', 191, 0, 1, 447393) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 191, 1, 2, 447435) because they came multiplied a hundred fold out of the kindness of the people who repaid their services in more than a full measure.
('21', 191, 1, 3, 447568) But they must be prepared to say that they were all for the country, every hour of their time, even their recreation hours, were to be for the country.
('21', 191, 1, 4, 447720) If they wanted to pit themselves against the mighty corporation, i.e., the Government, who had got all the arts and crafts of Government, all the powers of sweet speech, all the powers of bribery and even of sacrifice, they must be prepared for greater powers of sacrifice.
('21', 191, 1, 5, 447994) He wanted them to realize that in going to the law courts they were strengthening the arm of Government which represented evil.
('21', 191, 2, 6, 448122) Incidentally, the speaker said that the reluctance to cast in their lot with Mussulmans was engendered by the craven fear that India would be deluged by the Mussulmans and that the Hindus would be terrorized over by them, in case the latter were victorious.
('21', 191, 2, 7, 448380) This fear, said the speaker was degrading to Hinduism, whose land was dotted, as Col.
('21', 191, 2, 8, 448466) Tod said, with a thousand Thermopaelies.
('21', 191, 2, 9, 448507) The death of a martyr is far more preferable to the death of a coward.

('21', 191, 2, 11, 448726) The nobility of Hinduism consisted in unconditionally going to the aid of the Mussulmans, when they were in peril.
('21', 191, 2, 12, 448841) He would assure them that God would send a fresh command to Islam that Hindus should be regarded as the partners of the Mussulmans and that they might never quarrel with them.
('21', 191, 2, 13, 449017) The speaker was prepared to give the same aid to Christendom in its peril; he would give the same aid to Gen.
('21', 191, 2, 14, 449127) Dyer if he was in danger; but not if he was going on a similar errand as the Jallianwala Bagh.
('21', 191, 2, 15, 449222) He asked them to go out to Islam, trusting not the followers of Islam but trusting goodness, and asking the heavens to witness.
('21', 191, 2, 16, 449350) Every Mussulman would then be their protector, and there would be an imperishable union between the two.
('21', 191, 2, 17, 449455) The Hindu would then offer his prayers with more impunity than he did today.
('21', 191, 2, 18, 449532) Today he did not offer his prayers with impunity as he had to do so with fear of Satan hanging on him in the guise of a saint.
('21', 191, 3, 19, 449659) Mr. Gandhi went on to say that the attempt to revise the Peace Terms was an attempt to revive Islam.
('21', 191, 3, 20, 449760) The Mussulmans adored no Caliph, and none who had a rotten character; they adored Islam and they adored the Caliph as representing the essence of Islam.
('21', 191, 3, 21, 449913) They were not fighting for a Sultan who has signed the Peace Terms; they were fighting for an ideal, pure and simple, and the Hindus had the choice ready before them of defending their hearts and homes, and it would be the eternal disgrace of Hinduism if they could not prepare themselves to stand by Islam.
('21', 191, 3, 22, 450221) The speaker emphasized with the force and humility he could command that in trying to die for Islam, they were trying to die for their own faith, and for their own hearts and homes.

('21', 192, 3, 4, 450544) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, I am glad that I have been able to come in your midst so soon after my visit.
('21', 192, 3, 5, 450648) You will remember, those of you who were present on the last occasion, what I said to you then and I hope that those who listened to my remarks and understood them explained them to those who were not present.
('21', 192, 3, 6, 450858) And if none of you has done it already I would ask you on my behalf to explain those remarks to other friends.
('21', 192, 3, 7, 450969) I told you then what some of your duties were and I told you also that if you performed all those duties you could gain not only your immediate end, namely, a positive relationship with your employers, but you could command.

('21', 192, 4, 9, 451366) But what I said to you on the last occasion had reference only to relation between labour and capital.

('21', 195, 1, 2, 457126) 113. LETTER TO SARALADEVI CHAUDHRANI BEZWADA, August 23, 1920 Either the night or the day has been passed each day in the train.
('21', 195, 1, 3, 457255) The nights have been always disturbed by crowds.
('21', 195, 1, 4, 457304) Thank God we have nearly finished this exhausting tour.
('21', 195, 1, 5, 457360) Considering everything I have kept remarkably fit and strong.
('21', 195, 1, 6, 457422) Your letters have your usual self.
('21', 195, 1, 7, 457457) Some of them decidedly despondent and sceptical and suspicious.
('21', 195, 1, 8, 457521) You still do not understand Mathuradas 1. He and the others who surround me are superior to us, if you will allow me to include you.
('21', 195, 1, 9, 457654) They are certainly superior to me.
('21', 195, 1, 10, 457689) And it is as should be.
('21', 195, 1, 11, 457713) It is my claim that I have selected as my companions my superiors in character, superiors, that is to say, in their possibility.
('21', 195, 1, 12, 457842) My progress can only be little.
('21', 195, 1, 13, 457874) Theirs is still illimitable.
('21', 195, 1, 14, 457903) They are jealous of their ideal which is my character.
('21', 195, 1, 15, 457958) I and (if you are mine in the purest sense of the term) you must give everything to retain or deserve their love and affection.
('21', 195, 1, 16, 458086) There can be no yielding only on principle.
('21', 195, 1, 17, 458130) For that we must forsake all and everything.

('21', 195, 1, 19, 458250) Their love uplifts me and keeps me on the square.
('21', 195, 1, 20, 458300) They are my sheet anchor as I am theirs.
('21', 195, 1, 21, 458341) You should be proud of their jealousy and watchfulness.
('21', 195, 1, 22, 458397) They want to run no risks and they are right.
('21', 195, 1, 23, 458443) You and I are in duty bound to satisfy every lawful requirement.
('21', 195, 1, 24, 458508) And we shall have well met.

('21', 196, 1, 2, 459404) 114. SPEECH AT BEZWADA
('21', 196, 2, 3, 459427) August 23, 1920
('21', 196, 3, 4, 459443) Proceedings of the meeting held in connection with the visit of Messrs M. K. Gandhi and Maulana Shaukat Ali, on the evening of 23rd August 1920 at Bezwada in the compound of the Municipal Travellers’ Bungalow : India will commit suicide if we do not appreciate and understand the forces that are arrayed against us.
('21', 196, 3, 5, 459759) We have got a mighty Government, with all the power, with all the forces of arms arrayed against us.
('21', 196, 3, 6, 459860) It is composed of men who are able, courageous, willing and capable of making sacrifices.
('21', 196, 3, 7, 459950) It is a Government which does not scruple to use means fair or foul in order to gain its ends.
('21', 196, 3, 8, 460045) (Cries of “shame!”) No craft is above that Government.
('21', 196, 3, 9, 460100) It resorts to frightfulness, terrorism.
('21', 196, 3, 10, 460140) It resorts to bribery in the shape of titles, honours and high offices.
('21', 196, 3, 11, 460212) (Cries of “shame!”) It administers opiates in the form of reforms.
('21', 196, 3, 12, 460279) In any sense it is autocracy doubly distilled, appearing in the guise of democracy for the greatest gifts of a crafty, cunning man are worthless so long as cunning resides in his heart.
('21', 196, 3, 13, 460465) It is a Government which represents a civilization which is purely material and godless.
('21', 196, 3, 14, 460554) (Cries of “shame!”) I have given to you these qualities of this Government not in order to excite your angry passions but in order that you may appreciate fully the forces that are matched against you.
('21', 196, 3, 15, 460756) Anger will serve no purpose.
('21', 196, 3, 16, 460785) But we shall have to meet the godlessness by godliness.
('21', 196, 3, 17, 460841) We shall have to meet their untruth by truth.
('21', 196, 3, 18, 460887) We shall have to meet terrorism, their frightfulness by bravery, and it is an unbending bravery which is, today, demanded from every man, woman and child.
('21', 196, 3, 19, 461042) And I ask you, the citizens of Bezwada, to consider well before you set your eyes upon the loaves and fishes that are ready for you in Government employment, set them in one scale and set your religious and national honours in the other and make your choice.
('21', 196, 3, 20, 461301) It passes my comprehension how we, who have known this Government, who have read the Viceregal pronouncement, who have understood the determination of this Government not to grant justice either in the matter of the Punjab or in the matter of the khilafat; it passes my comprehension how can we expect any real blessing, any real freedom for India from any association, constructive or obstructive, with this Government.
('21', 196, 3, 21, 461722) Moderates believe in the possibility of justice being obtained at the hands of this Government.
('21', 196, 3, 22, 461818) Nationalists with firmness, on the other
('21', 197, 0, 1, 461859) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 197, 1, 2, 461901) hand, have wrung with denunciation unadulterated of this Government and of its measures.
('21', 197, 1, 3, 461990) How can a Nationalist ever hope to gain anything by entering into these councils holding people that they do.
('21', 197, 1, 4, 462100) But if they really represent popular will and if they want to retain their hold on the popular mind, I venture to suggest to them that it is their business to remain out of the councils, consolidate public opinion and wring justice from unwilling hands.
('21', 197, 2, 5, 462354) N.A.I. : Home : Political : December, 1920 : Nos.
('21', 197, 2, 6, 462404) 210 16A
('21', 197, 3, 7, 462412) 115. LETTER TO SARLADEVI CHAUDHRANI
('21', 197, 4, 8, 462448) ON THE WAY TO MANMAD FOR BOMBAY, August 24, 1920
('21', 197, 5, 9, 462497) MY DEAREST S., Your letters have caused me distress.
('21', 197, 5, 10, 462550) You do not like my sermons.
('21', 197, 5, 11, 462578) And yet so long as you remain a school girl, what should I do except giving you sermons?
('21', 197, 5, 12, 462667) If my love is true it must express itself in sermons so long as you do not realize the ideal accepted by you as worthy.
('21', 197, 5, 13, 462787) I do not at all like your doubting the necessity of the life adopted by you or the life you are trying to adopt.
('21', 197, 5, 14, 462900) What can be the reward of always speaking and doing Truth even at the peril of one’s life?
('21', 197, 5, 15, 462991) What can be the reward of dying for one’s country?
('21', 197, 5, 16, 463042) What is the reward of your having given years to acquiring perfection in piano playing?
('21', 197, 5, 17, 463130) You give all for the cause you represent because you cannot do otherwise.
('21', 197, 5, 18, 463204) Your satisfaction must depend upon complete surrender.
('21', 197, 5, 19, 463259) A surrender that gives not satisfaction is compulsory surrender, unworthy of a self respecting person.
('21', 197, 5, 20, 463362) And if your association with me does not teach you this simple truth, I must be unworthy of your love.
('21', 197, 5, 21, 463465) For, if my life has not taught you this much, I am a worthless being.
('21', 197, 5, 22, 463535) There is no worth in me except the capacity for unlimited self surrender and truthfulness.
('21', 197, 5, 23, 463626) All have noticed these two qualities in me and there must be something wrong in me if you who have penetrated my life so deeply have failed to notice them.
('21', 197, 5, 24, 463782) And what can I give you to share except my richest possessions?
('21', 197, 5, 25, 463846) And so, you must not resent my giving you sermons but receive them in the same loving manner in which they are delivered.
('21', 197, 5, 26, 463968) If I am your Law giver and if I do not always lay down the law, surely I must at least reason with you on things of eternity or supreme importance for the country for which we live and which we love so well.
('21', 198, 0, 1, 464176) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 199
('21', 198, 1, 2, 464221) But this does not mean that you must not write nasty things if you think them.
('21', 198, 1, 3, 464300) My plea is that you must cease to think nasty thoughts.
('21', 198, 1, 4, 464356) With love,
('21', 198, 2, 5, 464367) Yours, L. G.
('21', 198, 3, 6, 464380) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('21', 198, 3, 7, 464426) Courtesy : Narayan Desai
('21', 198, 4, 8, 464451) 116. RELIGIOUS AUTHORITY FOR NON CO OPERATION
('21', 198, 5, 9, 464497) It is not without the greatest reluctance that I engage in a controversy with so learned a leader like Sir Narayan Chandavarkar.
('21', 198, 5, 10, 464626) But in view of the fact that I am the author of the movement of non co operation, it becomes my painful duty to state my views even though they are opposed to those of the leaders whom I look upon with respect.
('21', 198, 5, 11, 464837) I have just read during my travels in Malabar Sir Narayan’s rejoinder to my answer to the Bombay Manifesto against non co operation.
('21', 198, 5, 12, 464970) I regret to have to say that the rejoinder leaves me unconvinced.
('21', 198, 5, 13, 465036) He and I seem to read the teachings of the Bible, the Gita and the Koran from different standpoints or we put different interpretations on them.
('21', 198, 5, 14, 465181) We seem to understand the words ahimsa, politics and religion differently.
('21', 198, 5, 15, 465256) I shall try my best to make clear my meaning of the common terms and my reading of the different religions.
('21', 198, 5, 16, 465364) At the outset let me assure Sir Narayan that I have not changed my views on ahimsa.
('21', 198, 5, 17, 465448) I still believe that man not having been given the power of creation does not possess the right of destroying the meanest creature that lives.
('21', 198, 5, 18, 465591) The prerogative of destruction belongs solely to the Creator of all that lives.
('21', 198, 5, 19, 465671) I accept the interpret ation of ahimsa, namely, that it is not merely a negative state of harmlessness but it is a positive state of love, of doing good even to the evil doer.
('21', 198, 5, 20, 465847) But it does not mean helping the evil doer to continue the wrong or tolerating it by passive acquiescence—on the contrary, love, the active state of ahimsa, requires you to resist the wrong doer by dissociating yourself from him even though it may offend him or injure him physically.
('21', 198, 5, 21, 466132) Thus if my son lives a life of shame, I may not help him to do so by continuing to support him; on the contrary, my love for him requires me to withdraw all support from him although it may mean even his death.
('21', 198, 5, 22, 466343) And the same love imposes on me the
('21', 199, 0, 1, 466379) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 199, 1, 2, 466421) obligation of welcoming him to my bosom when he repents.
('21', 199, 1, 3, 466478) But I may not by physical force compel my son to become good—that in my opinion is the moral of the story of the Prodigal Son.
('21', 199, 1, 4, 466605) Non co operation is not a passive state, it is an intensely active state—more active than physical resistance or violence.
('21', 199, 1, 5, 466728) Passive resistance is a misnomer.
('21', 199, 1, 6, 466762) Non co operation in the sense used by me must be non violent and therefore neither punitive nor vindictive nor based on malice, ill will or hatred.
('21', 199, 1, 7, 466910) It follows therefore that it would be sin for me to serve General Dyer and co operate with him to shoot innocent men.
('21', 199, 1, 8, 467028) But it will be an exercise of forgiveness or love for me to nurse him back to life, if he was suffering from a physical malady.
('21', 199, 1, 9, 467156) I cannot use in this context the word co operation as Sir Narayan would perhaps use it.
('21', 199, 1, 10, 467244) I would co operate a thousand times with this Government to wean it from its career of crime, but I will not for a single moment co operate with it to continue that career.
('21', 199, 1, 11, 467417) And I would be guilty of wrong doing if I retained a title from it or “as service under it or supported its law courts or schools”.
('21', 199, 1, 12, 467549) Better for me a beggar’s bowl than the richest possession from hands stained with the blood of the innocents of Jallianwala.
('21', 199, 1, 13, 467674) Better by far a warrant of imprisonment than honeyed words from those who have wantonly wounded the religious sentiment of my seventy million brothers.
('21', 199, 1, 14, 467826) My reading of the Gita is diametrically opposed to Sir Nara yan’s.
('21', 199, 1, 15, 467893) I do not believe that the Gita teaches violence for doing good.
('21', 199, 1, 16, 467957) It is pre eminently a description of the duel that goes on in our own hearts.
('21', 199, 1, 17, 468035) The divine author has used a historical incident for inculcating the lesson of doing one’s duty even at the peril of one’s life.
('21', 199, 1, 18, 468164) It inculcates performance of duty irrespective of the consequences, for, we mortals, limited by our physical frames, are incapable of controlling actions save our own.
('21', 199, 1, 19, 468332) The Gita distinguishes between the powers of light and darkness and demonstrates their incompatibility.
('21', 199, 1, 20, 468436) Jesus, in my humble opinion, was a prince among politicians.
('21', 199, 1, 21, 468497) He did render unto Caesar that which was Caesar’s.
('21', 199, 1, 22, 468548) He gave the devil his due.
('21', 199, 1, 23, 468575) He ever shunned him and is reported never once to have yielded to his incantations.
('21', 199, 1, 24, 468659) The politics of his time consisted in securing the welfare of the people by teaching them not to be seduced by the trinkets of the priests and the pharisees.
('21', 199, 1, 25, 468817) The latter then controlled and moulded the life of the people.
('21', 199, 1, 26, 468880) Today the system of Government is so devised as to affect every department of our life.
('21', 199, 1, 27, 468968) It threatens our very existence.
('21', 199, 1, 28, 469001) If therefore we want to conserve the welfare of the nation, we must religiously interest ourselves in the
('21', 200, 0, 1, 469107) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 201
('21', 200, 1, 2, 469152) doings of the governors and exert a moral influence on them by insisting on their obeying the laws of morality.
('21', 200, 1, 3, 469264) General Dyer did produce a “moral effect” by an act of butchery.
('21', 200, 1, 4, 469329) Those who are engaged in forwarding the movement of non co operation, hope to produce a moral effect by a process of self denial, self sacrifice and self purification.
('21', 200, 1, 5, 469497) It surprises me that Sir Narayan should speak of General Dyer’s massacre in the same breath as acts of non co operation.
('21', 200, 1, 6, 469618) I have done my best to understand his meaning, but I am sorry to confess that I have failed.
('21', 200, 1, 7, 469711) Young India, 25 8 1920
('21', 200, 2, 8, 469734) 117. KHILAFAT AND SWADESHI
('21', 200, 3, 9, 469761) It was not without much misgiving that I consented to include swadeshi as a plank in non co operation.
('21', 200, 3, 10, 469864) But Maulana Hasrat Mohani by his sheer earnestness bore me down.
('21', 200, 3, 11, 469929) I fear however that his reasons for including swadeshi are different from mine.
('21', 200, 3, 12, 470009) He is a protagonist of boycott of British goods.
('21', 200, 3, 13, 470058) I cannot reconcile myself to the doctrine as I have explained elsewhere in this issue.
('21', 200, 3, 14, 470145) But having failed to popularize boycott, Mohani Saheb has accepted swadeshi as the lesser good.
('21', 200, 3, 15, 470241) It is however necessary for me to explain how I have come to include swadeshi in the programme of non co operation.
('21', 200, 3, 16, 470357) Non co operation is nothing but discipline in self sacrifice.
('21', 200, 3, 17, 470419) And I believe that a nation that is capable of limitless sacrifice is capable of rising to limitless heights.
('21', 200, 3, 18, 470529) The purer the sacrifice the quicker the progress.
('21', 200, 3, 19, 470579) Swadeshi offers man, woman and child an occasion to make a beginning in self sacrifice of pure type.
('21', 200, 3, 20, 470680) It therefore presents an opportunity for testing our capacity for sacri fice.
('21', 200, 3, 21, 470758) It is the measure for gauging the depth of national feeling on the khilafat wrong.
('21', 200, 3, 22, 470841) Does the nation feel sufficiently to move it to go through even the preliminary process of sacrifice?
('21', 200, 3, 23, 470943) Will the nation revise its taste for the Japanese silk, the Manchester calico or the French lace and find all its decoration out of hand spun and hand woven cloth, i.e., khadi?
('21', 200, 3, 24, 471120) If crores of people will refuse to wear or use foreign cloth and be satisfied with the simple cloth that we can produce in our homes, it will be proof of our organizing ability, energy, co operation and self sacrifice that will enable us to secure all we need.
('21', 200, 3, 25, 471381) It will be a striking demonstration of national solidarity.
('21', 200, 3, 26, 471441) Such a consummation cannot be achieved for the mere wish.
('21', 200, 3, 27, 471499) It cannot be achieved by one man, no matter how capable and sincere he
('21', 201, 0, 1, 471570) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 201, 1, 2, 471612) may be.
('21', 201, 1, 3, 471620) It cannot be achieved by dotting India with swadeshi stores.
('21', 201, 1, 4, 471681) It can only be achieved by new production and judicious distribution.
('21', 201, 1, 5, 471751) Production means lakhs of women spinning in their own homes.
('21', 201, 1, 6, 471812) This requires earnest men to be engaged in honestly distributing carded cotton and collecting yarn and paying for it.
('21', 201, 1, 7, 471930) It means manufacture of thousands of spinning wheels.
('21', 201, 1, 8, 471984) It means inducing the hereditary weavers to return to their noble calling and distributing home spun yarn amongst them and setting their manufactures.
('21', 201, 1, 9, 472135) It is thus only as an energizing agent that I can think of swadeshi as a plank in non co operation.
('21', 201, 1, 10, 472235) But it is not to be despised in that capacity.
('21', 201, 1, 11, 472282) And I hope that every worker for the cause, even if he can do nothing else, will have done something if he can advance swadeshi first by increasing production and then distribution.
('21', 201, 1, 12, 472464) He would be simply moving in a circle if he is satisfied with distributing cloth that is already being manufactured in India.
('21', 201, 1, 13, 472590) Young India, 25 8 1920
('21', 201, 2, 14, 472613) 118. BOYCOTT OF GOODS V. NON CO OPERATION PROGRAMME
('21', 201, 3, 15, 472665) Mr. Kasturi Ranga Iyengar was pleased to answer my argument in favour of the details of the first stage of non co operation that I had the honour of explaining at the great Madras Beach meeting.
('21', 201, 3, 16, 472860) He expressed his dissent from all but the renunciation of titles.
('21', 201, 3, 17, 472926) He sugg ested boycott of foreign goods in the place of the other items.
('21', 201, 3, 18, 472998) Even at the risk of repeating arguments familiar to the readers of Young India, I must deal with the question of boycott which has now received the imprimatur of so able a publicist as Mr. Kasturi Ranga Iyengar.
('21', 201, 3, 19, 473210) In the first place, boycott of British goods has been conceived as a punishment and can have no place in non co operation which is conceived in a spirit of self sacrifice and is a matter of sacred duty.
('21', 201, 3, 20, 473413) Secondly, any measure of punishment must be swift, certain and adequate for the effect intended to be produced.
('21', 201, 3, 21, 473525) Resorted to by indi viduals, therefore, boycott is ineffectual, for, it can give no satisfaction unless it is productive of effect, whereas every act of non co operation is its own satisfaction.
('21', 201, 3, 22, 473720) Thirdly, boycott of British goods is thoroughly unpractical, for, it involves sacrifice of their millions by millionaires.
('21', 201, 3, 23, 473843) It is in my opinion infinitely more difficult for a merchant to sacrifice his
('21', 202, 0, 1, 473921) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 203
('21', 202, 1, 2, 473966) millions than for a lawyer to suspend his practice or for a title holder to give up his title, or for a parent to sacrifice, if need be, the literary instruction of his children.
('21', 202, 1, 3, 474145) Add to this the important fact that merchants have only lately begun to interest themselves in politics.
('21', 202, 1, 4, 474250) They are therefore yet timid and cautious.
('21', 202, 1, 5, 474293) But the class, to which the first stage of non co operation is intended to appeal, is the political class which has devoted years to politics and is not mentally unprepared for communal sacrifice.
('21', 202, 1, 6, 474490) Boycott of British goods to be effective must be taken up by the whole country at once or not at all.
('21', 202, 1, 7, 474592) It is like a siege.
('21', 202, 1, 8, 474612) You can carry out a siege only when you have the requisite men and instru ments of destruction.
('21', 202, 1, 9, 474708) One man scratching a wall with his finger nails may hurt his fingers but will produce no effect upon the walls.
('21', 202, 1, 10, 474820) One title holder giving up his title has the supreme satisfaction of having washed his hands clean of the guilt of the donor and is unaffected by the refusal of his fellows to give up theirs.
('21', 202, 1, 11, 475012) The motive of boycott being punitive lacks the inherent practicability of non co operation.
('21', 202, 1, 12, 475104) The spirit of punishment is a sign of weakness.
('21', 202, 1, 13, 475152) A strengthening of that spirit will retard the process of regeneration.
('21', 202, 1, 14, 475224) The spirit of sacrifice is a determination to rid ourselves of our weakness.
('21', 202, 1, 15, 475301) It is therefore an invigorating and purifying process and is therefore also calculated to do good both to us and to those who evoke the spirit of sacrifice in us.
('21', 202, 1, 16, 475464) Above all, if India has a mission of her own, she will not fulfill it by copying the doubtful example of the West and making even her sacrifice materialistically utilitarian instead of offering a sacrifice, spotless and pleasing even in the sight of God.
('21', 202, 1, 17, 475719) Young India, 25 8 1920

('21', 203, 1, 2, 476047) 120. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('21', 203, 2, 3, 476081) SABARMATI, NEAR AHMEDABAD, August 27 [1920]
('21', 203, 3, 4, 476125) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE, I hope you have my letters.
('21', 203, 3, 5, 476174) Jamnadas has sent me a cable asking me in your name to go to Germany to have Just’s cure.
('21', 203, 3, 6, 476264) But it cannot be.
('21', 203, 3, 7, 476282) I have no leisure for anything but the struggle going on here.
('21', 203, 3, 8, 476345) If I was free, I would have run down not for the earth cure but most decidedly to meet you, hug you and once more look you in the face.
('21', 203, 3, 9, 476481) For me you have risen from the dead.
('21', 203, 3, 10, 476518) Not having heard from or of you and all my inquiries having failed, I had decided that you had left this little globe of ours.
('21', 203, 3, 11, 476645) You cannot imagine the joy of the thought I may yet see you in the flesh and meanwhile begin to receive your love letters.
('21', 203, 3, 12, 476768) I know you will not rebuke me when I tell you that like many of my things, your clothes have become moth eaten.
('21', 203, 3, 13, 476880) With all the changes life with me has undergone, I have been unable to overhaul things in my custody.
('21', 203, 3, 14, 476982) For months when we shifted to where we are at present, all the things had to be stored away in a place.
('21', 203, 3, 15, 477086) We were living in tents in what was practically a wilderness.
('21', 203, 3, 16, 477148) So when you come, you will see a skeleton of what at one time used to be a good wardrobe.
('21', 203, 3, 17, 477238) Most of your books remain in a fair condition.
('21', 203, 3, 18, 477285) Our friend Omar has gone through much grief.
('21', 203, 3, 19, 477330) Parsi Rustomji is in Durban and thriving.
('21', 203, 3, 20, 477372) West is his own printer in Durban.
('21', 203, 3, 21, 477407) I am now off to a conference.
('21', 203, 4, 22, 477437) With love,
('21', 203, 5, 23, 477448) Yours, UPPER HOUSE
('21', 203, 6, 24, 477467) From the original : Gandhi Kallenbach Correspondence.
('21', 203, 6, 25, 477521) Courtesy : National Archives of India

('21', 204, 0, 1, 477597) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 205
('21', 204, 1, 2, 477642) 121. SPEECH AT GUJARAT POLITICAL CONFERENCE, AHMEDABAD
('21', 204, 2, 3, 477697) August 27, 1920 I consider it an honour to discharge the duty which has been assigned to me.
('21', 204, 2, 4, 477790) I am not, however, altogether disinterested in the matter.
('21', 204, 2, 5, 477849) Electing a president is easy and yet difficult.
('21', 204, 2, 6, 477897) This is a critical time for India.
('21', 204, 2, 7, 477932) On this occasion, with the eyes of the whole country turned on us, we need to elect as president an old and experienced captain who will steer the ship well.
('21', 204, 2, 8, 478090) Several names were suggested in the meeting of the Reception Committee.
('21', 204, 2, 9, 478162) I voted for Shri Abbas Tyabji.
('21', 204, 2, 10, 478193) I felt that, with him in charge, many of our difficulties would be overcome and that I, too, could help in solving them since I knew Shri Tyabji quite intimately.
('21', 204, 2, 11, 478356) He is advanced in age and weak, but the moment he received my telegram about the Punjab matter he came running to Lahore.
('21', 204, 2, 12, 478478) He was taken ill there; as he was making a list of the people who had suffered, his heart started beating faster.
('21', 204, 2, 13, 478592) He was so ill that, since he looked upon me as his younger brother, he sent for me and made his will.
('21', 204, 2, 14, 478694) We should pay careful attention to what the other side has to say.
('21', 204, 2, 15, 478761) It was difficult for Shri Abbas Tyabji to accept the invitation to be president.
('21', 204, 2, 16, 478842) As he is weak, he will not be able to take full part in the discussion.
('21', 204, 2, 17, 478914) We should, therefore, make his task as easy as we can.
('21', 204, 2, 18, 478969) [From Gujarati] Gujarati, 5 9 1920
('21', 204, 3, 19, 479004) 122. SPEECH ON NON CO OPERATION AT GUJARAT POLITICAL CONFERENCE 1
('21', 204, 4, 20, 479070) August 28, 1920 There has been no occasion in the history of the Congress to move a resolution of this kind.
('21', 204, 4, 21, 479179) Hence all of us should give the most careful consideration to it and hear respectfully what the leaders who oppose it have to say about it.
('21', 204, 4, 22, 479319) If we would have the weapon of non co operation employed in the right manner, we should win over our opponents by love instead of trying to impose our views on them.
('21', 204, 4, 23, 479485) Non co operation is no weapon of coercion.
('21', 204, 4, 24, 479528) In using this beautiful
('21', 204, 5, 25, 479552) 1 On the second day of the Conference; Gandhiji moved the resolution on non co operation.
('21', 205, 0, 1, 479642) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 205, 1, 2, 479684) weapon, there should be no impatience or discourtesy.
('21', 205, 1, 3, 479738) If the resolution is rejected, I would be unhappy but would certainly not lose heart, nor would I give up non co operation.
('21', 205, 1, 4, 479862) We should hear what leaders who have served the people want to say.
('21', 205, 1, 5, 479930) If we refuse to give a hearing to those who wish to warn us, I do not know what work we are fit todo.
('21', 205, 1, 6, 480032) It is our duty to listen with courtesy even to a child’s protest.
('21', 205, 1, 7, 480098) Courtesy is both the first and the last step in non co operation.
('21', 205, 1, 8, 480164) This is not a weapon to be used in anger.
('21', 205, 1, 9, 480206) Maulana Shaukat Ali, who acts in complete unity of purpose with me, has held his anger in check.

RIDICULE REPLACING REPRESSION Had His Excellency the Viceroy not made it impossible by his defiant attitude on the Punjab and the khilafat, I would have tendered him hearty congratulation for substituting ridicule for repression in order to kill a movement distasteful to him.
('21', 221, 1, 3, 516972) For, torn from its context and read by itself His Excellency’s discourse on non co operation is unexceptionable.
('21', 221, 1, 4, 517085) It is a symptom of translation from savagery to civilization.
('21', 221, 1, 5, 517147) Pouring ridicule on one’s opponent is an approved method in civilized politics.
('21', 221, 1, 6, 517227) And if the method is consistently continued, it will mark an important improvement upon the official barbarity of the Punjab.
('21', 221, 1, 7, 517353) His interpretation of Mr. Montagu’s state ment about the movement is also not open to any objection whatsoever.
('21', 221, 1, 8, 517465) Without doubt a government has the right to use sufficient force to put down an actual outbreak of violence.
('21', 221, 1, 9, 517574) But I regret to have to confess that this attempt to pour ridicule on the movement, read in conjunction with the sentiments on the Punjab and the khilafat preceding the ridicule, seems to show that His Excellency has made it a virtue of necessity.
('21', 221, 1, 10, 517822) He has not finally abandoned the method of terrorism and frightfulness, but he finds the movement being conducted in such an open and truthful manner that any attempt to kill it by violent repression would expose him not only to ridicule but contempt of all right thinking men.
('21', 221, 1, 11, 518100) Let us however examine the adjective used by His Excellency to kill the movement by laughing at it.
('21', 221, 1, 12, 518200) It is “futile”, “ill advised”, “intrinsically inane”, “unpractical”, “visionary”.
('21', 221, 1, 13, 518282) He has rounded off the adjectives by describing the movement as “most foolish of all foolish schemes”.
('21', 221, 1, 14, 518385) His Excellency has become so impatient of it that he has used all his vocabulary for showing the magnitude of the ridiculous nature of non co operation.
('21', 221, 1, 15, 518538) Unfortunately for His excellency the movement is likely to grow with ridicule as it is certain to flourish on repression.
('21', 221, 1, 16, 518660) No vital movement can be killed except by the impatience, ignorance or laziness of its authors.
('21', 221, 1, 17, 518756) A movement cannot be “inane” that is conducted by men of action as I claim the members of the Non co operation Committee are.
('21', 221, 1, 18, 518882) It is hardly “unpractical”, seeing that if the people respond, everyone admits that it will achieve the end.
('21', 221, 1, 19, 518991) At the same time it is perfectly true that if there is no response from the people, the movement will be popularly described as “visionary”.
('21', 221, 1, 20, 519132) It is for the nation to return an effective answer by organized non co operation and change ridicule into respect.

('21', 221, 1, 22, 519276) Both give place to respect when they fail to produce the intended effect.

('21', 233, 1, 2, 543742) 138. DEPUTY COMMISSIONER’S ASSASSINATION
('21', 233, 2, 3, 543783) When I heard of the assassination, by a Muslim, of Mr. Wil loughby, a Deputy commissioner, how I wished I had been present on the spot; if it had been possible for me to take that blow upon myself, I would have rendered a service to Islam and to India which I can do in no other way.
('21', 233, 2, 4, 544067) My dying in such circumstances would have had the result of convincing the whole world of the purity of our struggle; in such conviction lie the seeds of our victory.
('21', 233, 2, 5, 544234) This assassination has harmed our cause.
('21', 233, 2, 6, 544275) An element of violence has entered the struggle, which had been peaceful so far.
('21', 233, 2, 7, 544356) The freedom from fear which individual Englishmen enjoyed has in a measure dimini shed.
('21', 233, 2, 8, 544444) This will lead to vindictiveness and severer repression.
('21', 233, 2, 9, 544501) Increase in repression brought on by our own mistakes cannot but harm us.
('21', 233, 2, 10, 544575) In our struggle, nothing is kept secret.
('21', 233, 2, 11, 544616) What we think, we speak out.
('21', 233, 2, 12, 544645) Since we certainly do not want to use violence in our non co operation movement, we should condemn this murder, condemn it not only in newspapers and meetings but in our private conversations too, and even in our thoughts.
('21', 233, 2, 13, 544868) It is not that what I am saying is relevant only to non violence of my conception; I say it from the point of view of the generally accepted principles of moral conduct.
('21', 233, 2, 14, 545038) If we really wish to keep non co operation free from violence, we should realize that it was our first duty to stop violence [if it occurred].
('21', 233, 2, 15, 545181) Welcoming violence, openly or secretly, while claiming to have renounced it, would be nothing but duplicity.
('21', 233, 2, 16, 545290) If violence broke out, the people would not be able to keep up non co operation.
('21', 233, 2, 17, 545371) There would be a reign of terror all over the country and the people themselves would get panicky; no one would then go on with non co operation.
('21', 233, 2, 18, 545517) This is plain enough and those in charge of the movement have realized it; that is why non co operation has generally remained free from violence.
('21', 233, 2, 19, 545664) I know, however, that there are Muslims, and Hindus too, who welcome such assassinations.

('21', 233, 2, 21, 545824) Quite a few believe that, were it not for bomb throwing, the partition of Bengal would not have been undone.

('21', 234, 1, 3, 546251) I regard the victory of the British to be their defeat.
