('21', 235, 1, 2, 548228) non Moslem Indian in every legitimate manner to assist his Mussulman brother in his attempt to remove the religious calamity that has overtaken him : And in view of the fact that in the matter of the events of the April of 1919 both the said Governments have grossly neglected or failed to protect the innocent people of the Punjab and punish officers guilty of unsoldierly and barbarous behaviour towards them and have exonerated Sir Michael O’Dwyer who proved himself directly or indirectly responsible for most of the official crimes and callous to the sufferings of the people placed under his administration, and that the debate in the House of Lords betrayed a woeful lack of sympathy with the people of India and showed virtual support of the systematic terrorism and frightfulness adopted in the Punjab and that the latest Viceregal pronouncement is proof of entire absence of repentance in the matters of the khilafat and the Punjab : This Congress is of opinion that there can be no contentment in India without redress of the two aforementioned wrongs and that the only effectual means to vindicate national honour and to prevent a repetition of similar wrongs in future is the establishment of swarajya.
('21', 235, 1, 3, 549444) This Congress is further of opinion that there is no course left open for the people of India but to approve of and adopt the policy of progressive non violent non co operation until the said wrongs are righted and swarajya is established.
('21', 235, 1, 4, 549684) And inasmuch as a beginning should be made by the classes who have hitherto moulded and represented opinion and inasmuch as Government consolidates its power through titles and honours bestowed on the people, through schools controlled by it, its law courts and its legislative councils, and inasmuch as it is desirable in the prosecution of the movement to take the minimum risk and to call for the least sacrifice compatible with the attainment of the desired object, this Congress earnestly advises (a) surrender of titles and honorary offices and resignation from nominated seats in local bodies; (b) refusal to attend Government levees, durbars, and other official and semi official functions held by Government officials or in their honour; (c) gradual withdrawal of children from schools and colleges owned, aided or controlled by Government and in place of such schools and colleges establishment of national schools and colleges in
('21', 236, 0, 1, 550625) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 237
('21', 236, 1, 2, 550670) the various Provinces; (d) gradual boycott of British courts by lawyers and litigants and establishment of private arbitration courts by their aid for the settlement of private disputes; (e) refusal on the part of the military, clerical and labouring classes to offer themselves as recruits for service in Mesopotamia; (f) withdrawal by candidates of their candidature for election to the reformed councils and refusal on the part of the voters to vote for any candidate who may despite the Congress advice offer himself for election; (g) the boycott of foreign goods.
('21', 236, 1, 3, 551239) And inasmuch as non co operation has been conceived as a measure of discipline and self sacrifice without which no nation can make real progress, and inasmuch as an opportunity should be given in the very first stage of non co operation to every man, woman, and child, for such discipline and self sacrifice, this Congress advises adoption of swadeshi in piece goods on a vast scale, and inasmuch as the existing mills of India with indigenous capital and control do not manufacture sufficient yarn and sufficient cloth for the requirements of the nation, and are not likely to do so for a long time to come, this Congress advises immediate stimulation of further manufacture on a large scale by means of revising hand spinning in every home and hand weaving on the part of the millions of weavers who have aband oned their ancient and honourable calling for want of encouragement.

('21', 240, 2, 13, 561723) It is a struggle between religion and irreligion, powers of light and powers of darkness.

('21', 240, 2, 17, 562058) In reality it is worshipping mammon.

('21', 240, 2, 19, 562232) His so called followers measure their moral progress by their material possessions.

('21', 243, 1, 2, 568385) 144. SWADESHI
('21', 243, 2, 3, 568399) The swadeshi propaganda has been going on in a more or less organized manner now for the past eighteen months.
('21', 243, 2, 4, 568510) Some of its results are surprising and gratifying.
('21', 243, 2, 5, 568561) It has taken a fairly firm hold in the Punjab, Madras and the Bombay Presidency.
('21', 243, 2, 6, 568642) Hand spinning and hand weaving are steadily increasing in these parts.
('21', 243, 2, 7, 568713) Several thousand rupees have been distributed in homes where women never did any work before.
('21', 243, 2, 8, 568807) And if more work of this kind has not been done, it is due to want of workers.
('21', 243, 2, 9, 568886) This is however written more to note the mistakes of the past than to sum up the bright side.
('21', 243, 2, 10, 568980) My observations lead me to the conclusion that whilst the inauguration of the three vows and swadeshi stores have greatly stimulated the swadeshi spirit, it is no longer possible to advocate the taking of any of the three vows or the opening of new swadeshi stores for the sale of mill made cloth.
('21', 243, 2, 11, 569278) The result of the propaganda has been to send up the prices of yarn and cloth rather than increase production.
('21', 243, 2, 12, 569389) It is clear that the purpose of swadeshi is not served until the quantity of yarn and cloth produced is increased.
('21', 243, 2, 13, 569504) The gain therefore is merely moral and not material.
('21', 243, 2, 14, 569557) The people have begun to perceive the desirability of wearing only swadeshi cloth if the real interest of the country is to be advanced.
('21', 243, 2, 15, 569694) But it is clear that we must take practical steps for meeting the growing demand for swadeshi cloth.
('21', 243, 2, 16, 569795) One way, no doubt, is to increase the mills.
('21', 243, 2, 17, 569840) But it is obvious that capitalists do not need popular encouragements.
('21', 243, 2, 18, 569911) They know that India needs much more cloth than is manufactured by our mills.
('21', 243, 2, 19, 569989) But mills do not spring up like mushrooms.
('21', 243, 2, 20, 570032) It is a matter of getting machinery from outside, let alone the difficulty of getting labour.
('21', 243, 2, 21, 570126) And after all, India cannot become truly and economically independent so long as she must rely on the supply of machinery from outside for the manufacture of her cloth.
('21', 243, 2, 22, 570295) The cleanest and the most popular form of swadeshi, therefore, is to stimulate hand spinning and hand weaving and to arrange for a judicious distribution of yarn and cloth so manufactured.
('21', 243, 2, 23, 570484) With a little talent and a little industry this thing is easy.
('21', 243, 2, 24, 570547) Even as each home cooks its own food without difficulty, so may each home weave its own yarn.
('21', 243, 2, 25, 570641) And just as in spite of every home having its own kitchen, restaurants continue to flourish, so will mills continue to supply our additional wants.
('21', 243, 2, 26, 570789) But even as because of our private kitchens we would not
('21', 244, 0, 1, 570846) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 245
('21', 244, 1, 2, 570891) starve if every restaurant was through some accident closed, so would we, by reason of domestic spinning, not have to go naked even if every mill, by a blockade from the West, had to stop work.
('21', 244, 1, 3, 571085) Not long ago, we knew this secret of our own economic independence and it is possible for us to regain that independence by a little effort, a little organizing agency and a little sacrifice.
('21', 244, 1, 4, 571277) Therefore true swadeshi consists in introducing the spinning wheel in every household and every household spinning its own yarn.
('21', 244, 1, 5, 571406) Many a Punjabi woman does it today.
('21', 244, 1, 6, 571442) And though we may not supply our own cloth entirely, we shall be saving yearly crores of rupees.
('21', 244, 1, 7, 571539) In any event there is no other swadeshi than increased manufacture by hand spinning and hand weaving.
('21', 244, 1, 8, 571641) Whether we take up hand spinning and hand weaving or we do not, it is at least necessary to understand what true swadeshi is.
('21', 244, 1, 9, 571767) Young India, 8 9 1920
('21', 244, 2, 10, 571789) 145. DEMOCRACY “VERSUS” MOBOCRACY
('21', 244, 3, 11, 571823) Looking at the surface there is but a thin dividing line between mob law and the people’s law.
('21', 244, 3, 12, 571918) And yet the division is complete and will persist for all time.
('21', 244, 3, 13, 571982) India is today quickly passing through the mob law stage.
('21', 244, 3, 14, 572040) The use of the adverb signifies my hope.
('21', 244, 3, 15, 572081) It may be our misfortune to have to pass through that process even in slow stages.

('21', 244, 3, 19, 572451) It represented undisciplined destruction and therefore it was thoughtless, profitless, wicked and harmful.
('21', 244, 3, 20, 572558) War is disciplined destruction, much more bloody than any yet committed by mobs.
('21', 244, 3, 21, 572639) And yet war has been apostrophized, because we have been deceived by the temporary but brilliant results achieved by some wars.
('21', 244, 3, 22, 572767) So, if India has to achieve her freedom by violence, it will have to be by disciplined and honourable (insofar as it is possible to associate honour with violence) violence, named war.

('21', 249, 1, 2, 582039) 146. THREE NATIONAL CRIES
('21', 249, 2, 3, 582065) During the Madras tour, at Bezwada I had occasion to remark upon the national cries and I suggested that it would be better to have cries about ideals than men.
('21', 249, 2, 4, 582226) I asked the audience to replace “ Mahatma Gandhi ki jai” and “Mahomed Ali Shaukat Ali ki jai” by “ Hindu Mussulman ki jai”.
('21', 249, 2, 5, 582350) Brother Shaukat Ali, who followed, positively laid down the law.
('21', 249, 2, 6, 582415) In spite of the Hindu Muslim unity he had observed that if Hindus shouted “Vandemataram”, the Muslims rang out with “Allah o Akbar” and vice versa.
('21', 249, 2, 7, 582563) This he rightly said jarred on the ear and still showed that the people did not act with one mind.
('21', 249, 2, 8, 582662) There should be therefore only three cries recognized, “Allah o Akbar” to be joyously sung out by Hindus and Muslims showing that God alone was great and no other.
('21', 249, 2, 9, 582826) The second should be “ Vandemataram” (Hail Motherland) or “ Bharat Mata ki jai” (Victory to Mother Hind).
('21', 249, 2, 10, 582932) The third should be “Hindu Mussulman ki jai” without which there was no victory for India, and no true demonstration to the greatness of God.
('21', 249, 2, 11, 583074) I do wish that the newspapers and public men would take up the Maulana’s suggestion and lead the people only to use the three cries.
('21', 249, 2, 12, 583207) They are full of meaning.
('21', 249, 2, 13, 583233) The first is a prayer and a confession of our littleness and therefore a sign of humility.
('21', 249, 2, 14, 583324) It is a cry in which all Hindus and Muslims should join in reverence and prayerfulness.
('21', 249, 2, 15, 583412) Hindus may not fight shy of Arabic words when their meaning is not only totally inoffensive but even ennobling.
('21', 249, 2, 16, 583524) God is no respecter of any particular tongue.

('21', 249, 2, 18, 583696) And I should prefer “Vandemataram” to “Bharat Mata ki jai” as it would be a graceful recognition of the intellectual and emotional superiority of Bengal.
('21', 249, 2, 19, 583850) Since India can be nothing without the union of the Hindu and the Muslim heart, “ Hindu Mussulman ki jai” is a cry which we may never forget.
('21', 249, 2, 20, 583992) There should be no discordance in these cries.

('21', 249, 2, 22, 584168) Those who do not wish to join may refrain, but they should consider it a breach of etiquette to interpolate their own when a cry has already been raised.

('21', 250, 2, 7, 584974) 147. SPEECH ON NON CO OPERATION RESOLUTION, CALCUTTA CONGRESS
('21', 250, 3, 8, 585036) September 8, 1920
('21', 250, 4, 9, 585054) Mr. Gandhi moved his resolution on non co operation with the following speech : I am aware, more than aware, of the grave responsibility that rests on my shoulders in being privileged to move this resolution before this great assembly.
('21', 250, 4, 10, 585290) I am aware that my difficulties, as also yours, increase if you are able to adopt this resolution.
('21', 250, 4, 11, 585389) I am also aware that the adoption of any resolution will mark a definite change in the policy which the country has hitherto adopted for the vindication of the rights that belong to it, and its honour.
('21', 250, 4, 12, 585591) I am aware that a large number of our leaders who have given the time and attention to the affairs of my motherland, which I have not been able to give, are ranged against me.
('21', 250, 4, 13, 585767) They think it a duty to resist the policy of revolutionizing the Government policy at any cost.
('21', 250, 4, 14, 585863) Knowing this I stand before you in fear of God and a sense of duty to put this before you for your hearty acceptance.
('21', 250, 4, 15, 585981) THINK IMPARTIALLY I ask you to dismiss me, for the time being from your consi deration.
('21', 250, 4, 16, 586069) I have been charged of saintliness and a desire for dictator ship.
('21', 250, 4, 17, 586136) I venture to say that I do not stand before you either as a saint or a candidate for dictatorship.
('21', 250, 4, 18, 586235) I stand before you to present to you the results of my many years’ practical experience in non co operation.
('21', 250, 4, 19, 586344) I deny the charge that it is a new thing in the country.
('21', 250, 4, 20, 586401) It has been accepted at hundreds of meetings attended by thousands of men, and has been placed in working order since the first of August by the Mussulmans, and many of the things in the programme are being enforced in a more or less intense form.
('21', 250, 4, 21, 586649) I ask you again to dismiss personalities in the considera tion of this important question,
('21', 251, 0, 1, 586740) 252 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 251, 1, 2, 586782) and bring to bear patient and calm judgment on it.

('21', 260, 2, 11, 611455) 149. INTERVIEW ON INDIANS ABROAD
('21', 260, 3, 12, 611488) [September 9, 1920] 1
('21', 260, 4, 13, 611510) Mr. Gandhi, interviewed on questions of Indians abroad, made a definite
('21', 260, 5, 14, 611582) statement of his views.

('21', 260, 10, 23, 611987) As regards East Africa, Mr. Gandhi said the Government of that place was prejudiced, pro white, and anti Asiatic.
('21', 260, 10, 24, 612101) The Indians in East Africa were numerous and influential.
('21', 260, 10, 25, 612159) They must organize themselves.

('21', 261, 2, 6, 613404) 150. SPEECH AT A.I.C.C. MEETING, CALCUTTA
('21', 261, 3, 7, 613446) September 9, 1920
('21', 261, 4, 8, 613464) In bringing the meeting to a close Pandit Malaviya said .
('21', 261, 4, 9, 613522) that although he had the greatest regard and affection for Mr. Gandhi, it was his most painful duty to differ from him entirely in regard to the resolution of the Congress on non co operation.
('21', 261, 4, 10, 613715) he was therefore determined .
('21', 261, 4, 11, 613745) to pursue a course of action different from that adopted by the Congress .
('21', 261, 4, 12, 613820) to remain in the Congress and at the same time seek election to the Legislative Council.
('21', 261, 5, 13, 613909) Mr. Kasturi Ranga Iyengar said that he felt relieved to hear the statement from the Panditiji because a number of friends who were standing as candidates and who were also Congressmen had doubts as to whether they should continue to be the members of the Congress seeking elections to the councils.
('21', 261, 5, 14, 614208) Panditji’s example would be a precedent to them and may be acted upon by others who were in similar position with regard to the resolution.
('21', 261, 5, 15, 614348) Members would like to hear Mr. Gandhi’s views on the matter.
('21', 261, 6, 16, 614409) Mr. Gandhi said that as he had expressed his opinion in the Press, the Subjects
('21', 261, 7, 17, 614489) Committee and elsewhere, he would state it again that it was perfectly competent for
('21', 261, 8, 18, 614574) the minority to continue to be members of the Congress and to be free to act or not to
('21', 261, 9, 19, 614661) act on the resolution of the Congress according to their convictions and conscience
('21', 261, 10, 20, 614745) and said that he agreed with Mr. Malaviya in the view he took as regards this matter.
('21', 261, 11, 21, 614831) Mrs. Besant observed that as she was totally opposed to non co operation, she as a member of the All India Congress Committee felt she ought not to act in the Committee and she would cease to attend further meetings of the Committee till the next Congress.

('21', 262, 5, 6, 615459) 151. LETTER TO RENUKA MUKERJEE
('21', 262, 6, 7, 615490) [After September 9, 1920] 1
('21', 262, 7, 8, 615518) DEAR MISS MUKERJEE,
('21', 262, 8, 9, 615538) The only advice I can give you is that you should think fifty times before you take any serious step.
('21', 262, 8, 10, 615640) You should argue out the position with your parents and convince them or feel stronger in your own conviction.
('21', 262, 8, 11, 615751) And then you may take the step you may think is best.
('21', 262, 8, 12, 615805) I am not in love with education in England.
('21', 262, 8, 13, 615849) I can understand grown up people with formed ideas going to England to test them.
('21', 262, 8, 14, 615931) The atmosphere in which education is given there tends to endear our own slavery to us in a most insidious manner.
('21', 262, 8, 15, 616046) But you may not act upon these ideas unless they are part of your own being.
('21', 262, 8, 16, 616123) The very fact that you need my advice is a sound reason for your waiting, praying and discussing with those that are near and dear to you.
('21', 262, 9, 17, 616262) From a photostat: S.N. 7248a
('21', 262, 10, 18, 616291) 1 This was in reply to the addressee’s letter of September 9, 1920.
('21', 263, 0, 1, 616359) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 263, 1, 2, 616401) 152. INTERVIEW WITH MOTILAL GHOSE 1
('21', 263, 2, 3, 616437) September 10, 1920
('21', 263, 3, 4, 616456) Mahatma Gandhi was accompanied by Babu Giridhari Lal 2, Mr. Jawaharlal Nehru and Sreemati Saraladevi.
('21', 263, 3, 5, 616558) After mutual greetings Mahatma Gandhi opened the conversation by inquiring if it were a fact that Babu Motilal had written to the president of the special Congress opposing the boycott of councils.
('21', 263, 4, 6, 616756) MOTI BABU : It is not a fact.
('21', 263, 4, 7, 616786) I only sent a message to the Congress and its Subjects Committee through the president suggesting that the non co operation resolution should not be disposed of in a hurry but its consideration should be postponed till the Nagpur Congress was held.
('21', 263, 5, 8, 617035) MAHATMA : What is your opinion about the boyccott of councils and other items in the resolution passed by the Congress?
('21', 263, 6, 9, 617155) I have been a non co operationist for the last fifty years.
('21', 263, 6, 10, 617215) As regards the
('21', 263, 7, 11, 617230) councils I have always regarded them as a farce, a delusion and a snare.
('21', 263, 7, 12, 617303) I myself have
('21', 263, 8, 13, 617317) never sought to enter any of them and have always counselled our public men to do
('21', 263, 9, 14, 617399) the same.
('21', 263, 9, 15, 617409) But I must say both this and other items in the resolution affected only an
('21', 263, 10, 16, 617485) infinitesimally small number of people.
('21', 263, 10, 17, 617525) It mattered little whether the handful of title 
('21', 263, 11, 18, 617574) holders give up their titles or not or the few men, who go to the council, do or do not
('21', 263, 12, 19, 617662) The all important question is how to rouse the masses.
('21', 263, 12, 20, 617717) You must raise a cry which
('21', 263, 13, 21, 617744) the masses will understand.
('21', 263, 13, 22, 617772) Will you kindly be a little more explicit?
('21', 263, 14, 23, 617815) I shall explain my position by citing two instances.
('21', 263, 14, 24, 617868) You have no doubt heard of the great combination of the indigo raiyats of Bengal in 1866 to expel the
('21', 263, 15, 25, 617970) planters from this province?
('21', 263, 15, 26, 617999) Oh yes.
('21', 263, 16, 27, 618007) Do you know how this was effected, the unity of six millions of people in the course of six months which has no parallel in the histroy of any country in the world?
('21', 263, 16, 28, 618172) It was only by raising a cry of a great wrong felt keenly by all the raiyats equally and
('21', 263, 17, 29, 618261) which went straight into the heart of every one of them as soon as it was raised.
('21', 263, 17, 30, 618343) Yes, I have heard of it.
('21', 263, 18, 31, 618368) It happened in this wise.
('21', 263, 18, 32, 618394) The raiyats were groaning under the oppression of
('21', 263, 19, 33, 618444) the planters.
('21', 263, 19, 34, 618458) They came to see that their deliverance lay in not sowing indigo.
('21', 263, 20, 35, 618524) 1 Editor, Amrita Bazar Patrika, Calcutta
('21', 263, 21, 36, 618565) 2 Lala Girdhari Lal; deputy chairman, Punjab Chamber of Commerce; managing director, Amritsar Flour and General Mills
('21', 264, 0, 1, 618683) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 265
('21', 264, 1, 2, 618728) few intelligent among them took a vow in some sacred place that they would have nothing to do with indigo sowing.
('21', 264, 1, 3, 618842) They then persuaded others to take the same vow.
('21', 264, 1, 4, 618891) The cry was “no raiyat should touch the indigo even if he was tortured to death”.
('21', 264, 2, 5, 618973) though they were tortured in a most brutal way by the planters they did not yield.
('21', 264, 2, 6, 619056) When the planters failed, the authorities interfered and coerced them both by threats and entreaties.
('21', 264, 2, 7, 619158) They remained as firm as the rock.
('21', 264, 2, 8, 619193) “Saheb, you say you will put us in jail.
('21', 264, 2, 9, 619234) Do it, but this hand shall never again touch indigo.” “Sow it for this season only and you will be free to do what you like afterwards.” “Saheb, we have taken the vow in the name of God.
('21', 264, 2, 10, 619421) We can never break it.”—that was the bold and spirited reply of the downtrodden and illiterate raiyats.
('21', 264, 3, 11, 619525) Moti Babu next referred to the cry of “land” by Ireland to bring about unity among Irishmen.
('21', 264, 3, 12, 619618) He said, “You know the Irish leaders failed to rouse the Irish masses till Parnell raised the cry of ‘land’ which affected every Irishman.
('21', 264, 3, 13, 619757) The Irish understood it because it was a common grievance.
('21', 264, 3, 14, 619816) And the Land League was the result which formed the nucleus for Irish nationality.”
('21', 264, 4, 15, 619900) Moti Babu addressing the Mahatma said : “Dear friend, you should think of a common cry for the masses which will appeal to their heart directly.
('21', 264, 4, 16, 620045) It seems to me that there are two things which sit like a dread nightmare on the breast of both the masses and the educated class.
('21', 264, 4, 17, 620176) One is the police zulum 1 and the other is the pitiless
('21', 264, 5, 18, 620232) character of the criminal administration.
('21', 264, 5, 19, 620274) Can’t these go to make a common cry?” Mahatma Gandhi said that he would think over the matter.
('21', 264, 6, 20, 620369) Mahatma Gandhi next gave his view on the boycott of councils.
('21', 264, 6, 21, 620431) He said that councils demoralized most of those who went there.
('21', 264, 6, 22, 620495) These our representative men can do greater service outside the council than inside it.
('21', 264, 6, 23, 620583) Moti Babu agreed.
('21', 264, 7, 24, 620601) Next came the question of boycotting British courts.
('21', 264, 7, 25, 620654) Mahatma Gandhi said, that the courts, as much as the councils are the great instrument to keep our people under moral and intellectual domination.
('21', 264, 7, 26, 620801) We must get rid of these evils.
('21', 264, 8, 27, 620833) Moti Babu replied that he agreed with him but the evil must be struck at very root.
('21', 264, 8, 28, 620917) The vast majority of the lawyers won’t give up their practice which enables them to keep motor cars, etc., and indulge in other luxuries.
('21', 264, 8, 29, 621055) You must go to the people and advise them to stop litigation.
('21', 264, 8, 30, 621117) Mahatma Gandhi replied that he knew of many lawyers who were prepared to give up their practice.
('21', 264, 8, 31, 621214) Moti Babu said it was very hard for him to believe that story.
('21', 264, 8, 32, 621277) However, if there be some willing to do it, the great majority will not.
('21', 264, 8, 33, 621350) We are to stop the evil at the very source.
('21', 264, 9, 34, 621394) In regard to the question of the withdrawal of children from schools Mahatma Gandhi said that the boys get their mentality in the school.
('21', 264, 9, 35, 621532) On being pressed to say what the boys would do if they were withdrawn from schools Mahatma Gandhi said
('21', 264, 10, 36, 621635) 1 Repression
('21', 265, 0, 1, 621648) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 265, 1, 2, 621690) that if the boys were withdrawn new schools would be started.
('21', 265, 1, 3, 621752) So long as our boys, who are the makers of the future of the country, continue to be intellectually fed in the present day schools there is little hope for the country.
('21', 265, 2, 4, 621921) Babu Motilal replied that as the existing schools and colleges are maintained by our money and not by money brought from England he did not see why should not our boys avail themselves of the education imparted in those institutions till we have got our national educational institutions established.
('21', 265, 2, 5, 622222) Of course we must be on our guard that our boys are not in any way demoralized in the Government schools and colleges.
('21', 265, 3, 6, 622341) The last question discussed was the deletion of that part of Babu Bipin Chandra Pal’s amendment which contemplated the raising of a fund in the name of Lokamanya Tilak.
('21', 265, 3, 7, 622510) Babu Motilal regretted that this should have been dropped and was not added to Mr. Gandhi’s resolution.
('21', 265, 3, 8, 622614) The first thing we want now is propaganda not only in this country but also in England and America.
('21', 265, 3, 9, 622714) We also need funds for starting national schools and colleges and establish arbitration courts.
('21', 265, 3, 10, 622810) Babu Motilal appealed to the Mahatma to start such a fund at the Nagpur Congress.
('21', 265, 4, 11, 622892) The interview ended by Moti Babu’s warmly embracing Mahatma Gandhi and
('21', 265, 5, 12, 622963) giving him his blessings.
('21', 265, 5, 13, 622989) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 17 9 1920
('21', 265, 6, 14, 623021) 153. THE CONGRESS
('21', 265, 7, 15, 623039) Never has the Congress been called upon to decide an issue so momentous as the one it was called upon to decide at its special session presided over by Lala Lajpatrai.
('21', 265, 7, 16, 623207) Never perhaps has the Congress witnessed such determined opposition as was offered to the non co operation resolution.
('21', 265, 7, 17, 623326) And yet never, within my experience, has a decisive majority listened with such respect and attention to the opposition argument as it did at the last session.
('21', 265, 7, 18, 623486) Again never has there been such united opposition shown to a Subjects Committee resolution by the noted leaders of the people.
('21', 265, 7, 19, 623613) Mrs. Besant has a fine record of service to India.
('21', 265, 7, 20, 623664) Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviyaji is a name to conjure with.
('21', 265, 7, 21, 623721) He has to his credit an unbroken record of many years’ brilliant service to the country and an unblemished character.
('21', 265, 7, 22, 623839) Mr. Das leads a party ever growing in influence and strength.
('21', 265, 7, 23, 623901) I felt the late Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak’s absence most keenly at such a juncture.
('21', 265, 7, 24, 623988) Mr. Baptista led the Deccan.
('21', 265, 7, 25, 624017) Mr. Kasturi Ranga Iyengar, the talented editor of The Hindu, led the Madras Nationalist Party.
('21', 265, 7, 26, 624112) All these and many other leaders
('21', 266, 0, 1, 624145) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 267
('21', 266, 1, 2, 624190) strenuously opposed the non co operation resolution.
('21', 266, 1, 3, 624243) I warned that great audience against accepting my proposal unless they were prepared to suffer and were convinced that true non co operation was possible only through the programme submitted by me.
('21', 266, 1, 4, 624441) But the audience wanted action, wanted suffering.
('21', 266, 1, 5, 624491) The voting was elaborately registered.
('21', 266, 1, 6, 624530) The Congress pandal was cleared for the purpose of voting.
('21', 266, 1, 7, 624589) Lala Lajpatrai personally superin tended the operation.
('21', 266, 1, 8, 624645) It lasted for six hours.
('21', 266, 1, 9, 624670) All the provinces but the Central Provinces and the Berar voted in favour of my resolution.
('21', 266, 1, 10, 624762) The Central Provinces gave for my proposition 30 votes as against 33 for Babu Bipin Chandra Pal’s.
('21', 266, 1, 11, 624861) I give the figures below : For Resolution For Amendment Bombay 243 93 Madras 161 135 Bengal 551 395 U.P. 259 28 Punjab 254 92 Andhra 59 12 Sind 36 16 Delhi59 9 Behar 184 28 Burma 14 4 C.P. 30 33 Berar 5 28
('21', 266, 2, 12, 625067) –––––––––––– ––––––––––– 1855 873
('21', 266, 3, 13, 625101) My resolution adopted the principle of the whole of the khilafat programme, even non payment of taxes, and advised for immediate adop tion, boycott of titles and honorary offices, law courts by litigants, scho ols and colleges and reformed councils.
('21', 266, 3, 14, 625351) Babu Bipin Chandra Pal proposed a mission to England to present our demands and meanwhile to establish national schools, formulate arbitration courts and not to boycott the councils.
('21', 266, 3, 15, 625534) His resolution would have meant in effect seeking election to the councils and these probably adopting obstructive tactics.
('21', 266, 3, 16, 625658) This meant a virtual postponement of the real struggle to the next general election.
('21', 266, 3, 17, 625743) The opposition therefore chiefly centred on the boycott of councils.
('21', 266, 3, 18, 625812) And the Congress has decided by an overwhelming majority that the councils must be abandoned.
('21', 266, 3, 19, 625906) I hope that those who do not believe that boycott of
('21', 267, 0, 1, 625959) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 267, 1, 2, 626001) councils would postpone the attainment of swarajya (let alone hastening it) will work with all their might to advance the purpose of the Congress.
('21', 267, 1, 3, 626148) An analysis of the votes shows that the country wants non co operation.
('21', 267, 1, 4, 626220) Mrs. Besant who consistently, fearlessly and frankly opposed it had very few adherents.
('21', 267, 1, 5, 626308) I do not propose to examine the merits of the case at the present moment.
('21', 267, 1, 6, 626382) My argument is before the country in favour of boycott of councils, schools and courts.
('21', 267, 1, 7, 626470) Nothing I heard on the Congress platform has shaken my belief in the necessity or the efficacy of these steps.
('21', 267, 1, 8, 626581) But I would respectfully address a few words to the majority and to the minority.
('21', 267, 1, 9, 626663) To the majority I would say : The hour of the greatest triumph is the hour of the greatest humility.
('21', 267, 1, 10, 626764) The majority has taken upon its shoulders a tremendous responsibility.
('21', 267, 1, 11, 626835) Every individual voter in favour of my proposal has certainly bound himself, if he is a parent, to withdraw his children from schools or colleges subject in any way to Government control.
('21', 267, 1, 12, 627023) Every voter being a lawyer is bound at the earliest opportunity to suspend his practice and promote the cause of settlement of disputes by private arbitration.
('21', 267, 1, 13, 627183) Every candidate for the councils, who has voted with the majority, has undertaken to withdraw his candidature, every such voter to refrain from voting at the elections.
('21', 267, 1, 14, 627352) Every delegate voting with the majority has bound himself to stimulate hand spinning and hand weaving and in his own person to use only hand spun and hand woven cloth.
('21', 267, 1, 15, 627520) Everyone of the majority having accepted the principle of non violence, self sacrifice and discipline in regard to non co operation is bound to treat the minority with respect and fairness.
('21', 267, 1, 16, 627710) We may not use physical or wordy violence against them.
('21', 267, 1, 17, 627766) We must endeavour by our intensive practice and by scrupulously honourable methods to convert it to our views.
('21', 267, 1, 18, 627877) Those who voted with the minority were either weak or not ready.
('21', 267, 1, 19, 627942) Some few doubted the rightness of withdrawing children from schools for instance.
('21', 267, 1, 20, 628024) But when they see schools being emptied, national schools springing into being, lawyers suspending practice and yet not starving, and the councils deserted at least by the best of nationalists, they will soon begin to believe in the programme, lose their weakness and be themselves ready to adopt it.
('21', 267, 1, 21, 628325) We need not therefore be impatient with the minority because it does not see eye to eye with us.
('21', 267, 1, 22, 628422) To the minority I would say, they have lost in a fair fight.
('21', 267, 1, 23, 628483) Unless now therefore it is a matter of conscience with them, they must come
('21', 268, 0, 1, 628559) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 269
('21', 268, 1, 2, 628604) forward to prosecute the programme of non co operation in a most vigorous manner.
('21', 268, 1, 3, 628686) Those who think that majority has grievously erred are no doubt entitled to carry on a campaign of conversion of the majority to their views.
('21', 268, 1, 4, 628828) By far the largest number in the minority however have accepted the principle of establishment of private arbitration courts and national schools.
('21', 268, 1, 5, 628975) They wanted only a postponement of the consideration of the boycott of councils.
('21', 268, 1, 6, 629056) I venture to suggest to them that minority should accept the verdict and help to make the programme a success.
('21', 268, 1, 7, 629167) Boycott of foreign goods finds a place in my resolution.
('21', 268, 1, 8, 629224) I am sorry for it.
('21', 268, 1, 9, 629243) I may not state how it came to find a place there.
('21', 268, 1, 10, 629294) But as it did not conflict with my conscience, and in order to show my reasonableness, I undertook to move a resolution whose musical harmony was marred by a false note.
('21', 268, 1, 11, 629464) Boycott of foreign cloth is included in swadeshi.
('21', 268, 1, 12, 629514) Boycott of all other foreign goods is a senseless proposition if only because it is a virtual impossibility.
('21', 268, 1, 13, 629623) But if the introduction of the addendum stimulates us to sacrifice our luxuries and superfluities, it would have served a good purpose.
('21', 268, 1, 14, 629759) It is certainly our right and duty to discard everything foreign that is superfluous and even everything foreign that is necessary if we can produce or manufacture it in our country.
('21', 268, 1, 15, 629942) Young India, 15 9 1920
('21', 268, 2, 16, 629965) 154. A FOREWORD 1
('21', 268, 3, 17, 629983) [About September 15, 1920] 2
('21', 268, 4, 18, 630012) It is not [an] easy thing for me to write a foreword to a life sketch of Mr. Andrews between whom and me there exists a tie closer than between blood brothers.
('21', 268, 4, 19, 630172) But if I may say without presumptions, I would like to note down my conviction that there does not exist in India a more truthful, more humble and more devoted servant of hers than C. F. Andrews.
('21', 268, 4, 20, 630368) May the lesson of his life prove to the youth of India an encouragement for greater devotion to the motherland.

('21', 269, 1, 2, 630824) 155. LETTER TO N. C. SINHA 1
('21', 269, 2, 3, 630853) BOLPUR, [Before September 17, 1920] 2
('21', 269, 3, 4, 630891) DEAR MR. SINHA 3,
('21', 269, 4, 5, 630909) I am glad you have written about the lawyers.
('21', 269, 4, 6, 630955) We shall never fight our way to swaraj without taking any risks and without causing some distrubance in the ordinary life.
('21', 269, 4, 7, 631078) I agree with you that we lawyers have been the bete noir of the magistracy, but that was when in their opinion, we caused the greatest trouble.
('21', 269, 4, 8, 631222) But you will see that when we ourselves abandon the courts, the process will not be relished by the bureaucracy.
('21', 269, 4, 9, 631335) What does it matter if temporarily the Santhal Parganas and such other districts are deprived of the assistance the lawyers have only just begun to render to them, and I can conceive hundreds of ways of helping them without pleading their cause before biased or ignorant magistrates.
('21', 269, 4, 10, 631619) The lawyers today lead public opinion, and conduct all political activity.
('21', 269, 4, 11, 631694) This they do during the few leisure hours they get from their tennis and billiards.
('21', 269, 4, 12, 631778) I do not expect that by dividing their leisure hours between billiards and politics, lawyers will bring us substantially near swaraj.
('21', 269, 4, 13, 631912) I want at least the public workers among them to be whole timers, and when that happy day comes, I promise a different outlook before the country.
('21', 269, 5, 14, 632059) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI The Hindu, 29 9 1920

('21', 270, 7, 10, 632641) 157. SPEECH TO INMATES OF SHANTINIKETAN
('21', 270, 8, 11, 632681) September 17, 1920
('21', 270, 9, 12, 632700) SISTERS AND BROTHERS, The happiness I have found in your company these few days is beyond words.
('21', 270, 9, 13, 632797) I came here to improve my broken health and you will be glad to know that I shall be returning from here, though not altogether restored to health, much improved.
('21', 270, 9, 14, 632960) It is a painful thought to me that I cannot speak to you in Bengali.
('21', 270, 9, 15, 633029) Though my hope to be able, one day, to talk with you in Bengali may be a forlorn one, I think I am not unjustified in hoping that you will come to understand my Hindustani.
('21', 270, 9, 16, 633202) Your education will be incomplete till Hindustani has become a compulsory subject in your school and you pick up the language.
('21', 270, 9, 17, 633329) There is another thing, moreover, which I should not like to keep back from you and that is that I want to see your school, by and by, become a beautiful hive swarming with most industrious bees.
('21', 270, 9, 18, 633525) The life we live will not be a real life until a beautiful harmony between our hearts and hands has been established.
('21', 270, 9, 19, 633643) I think the meaning of the work in which I am at present absorbed can be explained even to young children, though, of course, what I am going to say is not meant for them alone.
('21', 270, 9, 20, 633821) I have kept back nothing from my own children or, in South Africa, from children whom I regarded as my own.
('21', 270, 9, 21, 633929) For me, personally, there is only one religion and that is
('21', 271, 0, 1, 633988) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 271, 1, 2, 634030) Hinduism.
('21', 271, 1, 3, 634040) I take pride in calling myself a Hindu, but I am no dogmatic, ritual bound Hindu.
('21', 271, 1, 4, 634122) As I understand Hinduism, it is an extremely comprehensive faith.
('21', 271, 1, 5, 634188) It has tolerance and respect for other faiths.
('21', 271, 1, 6, 634235) That is why you see me engaged in defending Islam with the same energy and passion with which I would defend my faith.
('21', 271, 1, 7, 634354) Defending Islam is a great happiness to me since I feel that in the process I am acquiring fitness to defend my religion.
('21', 271, 1, 8, 634476) The European Powers, which rely on brute force, pose a threat to Hinduism as much as they do to Islam.
('21', 271, 1, 9, 634579) Today, it is Islam’s turn, tomorrow it may be that of Hinduism.
('21', 271, 1, 10, 634643) I think the threat to Hinduism has been there, a very subtle threat, ever since British power was established in this land.
('21', 271, 1, 11, 634767) I have seen that Western influences have shaken the very foundations of our thinking.
('21', 271, 1, 12, 634853) Western civilization is the work of Satan.
('21', 271, 1, 13, 634896) For many years now, we have been under a strange spell.
('21', 271, 1, 14, 634952) My eyes really opened only last year.
('21', 271, 1, 15, 634990) When the Allies declared war, it was ostensibly for the defence of weak nations but under cover of this aim they practised no end of scheming.
('21', 271, 1, 16, 635133) Even then, at the last Congress at Amritsar, I pleaded earnestly and sincerely with the country to extend co operation to the Government, for till then it was my faith that the British people would feel penitent for their misdeeds and that the British [Prime] Minister would honour his promises.
('21', 271, 1, 17, 635429) But the closing of the Punjab chapter and the announcement of Peace Terms with Turkey destroyed all my faith.
('21', 271, 1, 18, 635539) I came to the conclusion that every man is faced, once in his life, with a choice between God and Satan.
('21', 271, 1, 19, 635644) From my experience of co operation with the British Government for these many years, I have seen that association with the British rulers has a demoralizing effect.
('21', 271, 1, 20, 635809) I am convinced that until India realizes her mission and the whole nation is awakened to a consciousness of their equality with the British, the continuation of the British connection will only mean our continued degradation.
('21', 271, 1, 21, 636035) I also saw that unity with the Muslims was of far greater value than keeping up the British connection.
('21', 271, 1, 22, 636139) This unity would be difficult to maintain if we did not help them in their hour of need.
('21', 271, 1, 23, 636228) Moreover, with one fourth of the body politic suffering from paralysis, development of the spirit of patriotism among us would be impossible.
('21', 271, 1, 24, 636370) Hence, I cultivated friendship with Shaukat Ali and became a brother to him.
('21', 271, 1, 25, 636447) My association with him is a source of joy and pride to me.
('21', 271, 1, 26, 636507) We have differences on some matters.
('21', 271, 1, 27, 636544) I believe in the principle of non violence.
('21', 271, 1, 28, 636588) He seems to believe in violence.
('21', 271, 1, 29, 636621) He believes that in certain circumstances a man may be another’s enemy and that killing
('21', 272, 0, 1, 636709) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 273
('21', 272, 1, 2, 636754) one’s enemy is justified.
('21', 272, 1, 3, 636780) If, nonetheless, I continue to work with him, the reason is that I have seen in him some qualities of sterling worth.
('21', 272, 1, 4, 636898) He is a man of his word, is a perfectly loyal friend and is extraordinarily brave.
('21', 272, 1, 5, 636981) He has great faith in God.
('21', 272, 1, 6, 637008) I immediately saw that only a devoted man could have all these qualities and I sought association with him, attracted only by his devoutness.
('21', 272, 1, 7, 637150) I have, besides, always trusted that my success in employing non violence will convince him of its beauty.
('21', 272, 1, 8, 637257) No other English term can express all the meanings of ahimsa whi ch the word innocence expresses.
('21', 272, 1, 9, 637355) Hence ahimsa and innocence may be re garded as equivalents.
('21', 272, 1, 10, 637415) It is my faith that everything will be well with the man who follows the path of non violence.
('21', 272, 1, 11, 637510) The weapons at the disposal of the votary of non violence are much more potent than those available to the votary of violence.
('21', 272, 1, 12, 637637) I may describe organized violence as a barbar ous thing.
('21', 272, 1, 13, 637694) It is most certainly beastly.
('21', 272, 1, 14, 637724) Only a perfect practitioner of non violence can display perfect courage.
('21', 272, 1, 15, 637797) Even one man ready to live a life of non violence to perfection will be able to subdue the entire world.
('21', 272, 1, 16, 637902) Let me say, in all humility, that, if I have, with this broken body of mine, some little strength to conduct a struggle of such great magnitude, it is because of my practice of non violence.
('21', 272, 1, 17, 638093) If the Hindus understand their religion and follow it, they are bound to produce an impact on the world.
('21', 272, 1, 18, 638198) The day on which India accords primacy to violence, my life will have been emptied of its meaning.
('21', 272, 1, 19, 638297) But my faith remains unshaken.
('21', 272, 1, 20, 638328) And you, children of Hindu parents, if you understand your duty as Hindus, you will never co operate with the unjust and the wicked.
('21', 272, 1, 21, 638461) The immortal verses of Tulsidas in which he advises against association with the wicked are beautiful beyond comparison.
('21', 272, 1, 22, 638582) For India to hope for any good from British rule as it is today is like trying to hug empty space.
('21', 272, 1, 23, 638681) I, for one, have offered my closest co operation to this Government for a number of years and, at the end of it all, I had some bitter experiences.
('21', 272, 1, 24, 638829) It is owing to them that I have undertaken this terrible, but noble and glorious fight and have been trying to induce you all to join it.
('21', 272, 1, 25, 638967) In this holy temple, I only ask you to pray that, in my struggle for spiritual growth, God may grant me good health and wisdom and for ever keep me from error and cowardice.

('21', 273, 0, 1, 639178) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 273, 1, 2, 639220) 158. PURE SWADESHI
('21', 273, 2, 3, 639239) I grow more convinced every day that swadeshi can mean only one thing.
('21', 273, 2, 4, 639310) I have declared open swadeshi stores and formulated vows of swadeshi; this may have served some purpose and developed the spirit of swadeshi, but I do not think India has gained any economic benefits thereby.
('21', 273, 2, 5, 639519) The swadeshi movement has benefited to the extentthat hand woven cloth has been produced out of hand spun yarn and that such cloth has been popularized.
('21', 273, 2, 6, 639672) The mills need no incentives.
('21', 273, 2, 7, 639702) They are able to market all their production.
('21', 273, 2, 8, 639748) They are hardly in a position to spin the yarn they need.
('21', 273, 2, 9, 639806) In this situation, producing hand woven cloth with mill yarn is of no benefit to the country; on the contrary, it increases the burden on the poor.
('21', 273, 2, 10, 639954) One disadvantage of doing so is that it will increase the price of yarn and cloth and the other is that, whereas now the poor content themselves with wearing cloth produced by our mills, they will by and by start wearing foreign cloth.
('21', 273, 2, 11, 640190) The latter will prove more harmful, for once the poor have fallen into the habit of using foreign cloth it will be difficult to bring them back to the use of swadeshi cloth.
('21', 273, 2, 12, 640364) Hence I put down here some rules and principles of the swadeshi movement : 1. Only hand spun yarn and hand woven cloth should be used.
('21', 273, 2, 13, 640499) 2. The utmost efforts should be made to promote the spinning and weaving of such yarn.
('21', 273, 2, 14, 640586) 3.All possible improvements should be effected in the spining wheel and the handloom.
('21', 273, 2, 15, 640672) 4.We should find out where hand spinning and hand weaving are carried on.
('21', 273, 2, 16, 640746) 5.At present, the main variety of cloth so produced is khadi.
('21', 273, 2, 17, 640808) We should work to popularize it.
('21', 273, 2, 18, 640841) 6.Steps should be taken to promote love of simplicity among the people.
('21', 273, 2, 19, 640913) 7.Stores should be opened for selling hand spun yarn and hand woven cloth made from such yarn.
('21', 273, 2, 20, 641008) In the course of my tours, I have been observing that swadeshi of this type is being quietly but steadily propagated in many places.
('21', 273, 2, 21, 641141) In a village in Madras Province, Shri Hanumant Rao of the Servants of India Society has been working very hard with the help of friends.
('21', 273, 2, 22, 641278) A widow is helping him with money and also by working herself.
('21', 273, 2, 23, 641341) His own wife, too, has joined in the effort.
('21', 273, 2, 24, 641386) There is a technical school in
('21', 274, 0, 1, 641417) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 275
('21', 274, 1, 2, 641462) Masulipattam, where also work is going on.
('21', 274, 1, 3, 641505) I saw some yarn, very much finer and of better texture than what we get in Gujarat.
('21', 274, 1, 4, 641589) This fine yarn was spun by some rich women for the love of the thing.
('21', 274, 1, 5, 641659) I saw some dhotis, too, made of such yarn.
('21', 274, 1, 6, 641702) The people also succeed well in dyeing clothes with swadeshi material.
('21', 274, 1, 7, 641773) Thus, in some isolated spots, even without capital the enterprise is making progress.
('21', 274, 1, 8, 641859) To open a khadi store requires hardly five hundred rupees.
('21', 274, 1, 9, 641918) It can be managed by one person provided he is hard working.
('21', 274, 1, 10, 641979) He may have a small shop, just large enough to hold what he can afford to stock.
('21', 274, 1, 11, 642060) Till he has acquired enough custom for khadi, he should go round hawking.
('21', 274, 1, 12, 642134) In this way, with a small capital a large number ofpeople can subsist and pure swadeshi will be popularized.
('21', 274, 1, 13, 642243) The main purpose of this article, how ever, is to warn those who take the vow of wearing [Indian] mill cloth and those who open stores for such cloth.
('21', 274, 1, 14, 642394) It may not be necessary to close down all the stores which exist, but their owners should gradually stock them with khadi.
('21', 274, 1, 15, 642517) They may, if they wish, invest money in other swadeshi goods besides cloth but it is clear that the country will not profit at all by their storing mill made cloth or cloth woven by hand from mill yarn.
('21', 274, 1, 16, 642720) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 19 9 1920
('21', 274, 2, 17, 642757) 159. NOTES
('21', 274, 3, 18, 642768) THEFT ON RAILWAYS I have been receiving complaints from many poor people that the goods they send by railway are stolen in transit.
('21', 274, 3, 19, 642900) A person sends yarn and it is stolen.
('21', 274, 3, 20, 642938) There is no end to the pilfering of fruits.
('21', 274, 3, 21, 642982) Who is to blame for this?
('21', 274, 3, 22, 643008) Certainly not the Government.
('21', 274, 3, 23, 643038) We have no regard for honesty, no contempt for dishonesty.
('21', 274, 3, 24, 643097) I do not know how much Navajivan is read among railway servants.
('21', 274, 3, 25, 643162) I would, however, request those who read it to see that others read this article.
('21', 274, 3, 26, 643244) Railway servants should realize that they are the servants of the public.
('21', 274, 3, 27, 643318) They must not steal.
('21', 274, 3, 28, 643339) If they are not paid enough for their living, they should try for an increase in pay, but on no account should they steal.
('21', 274, 3, 29, 643462) Railway workers have formed their own unions.
('21', 274, 3, 30, 643508) I put it to their leaders that it is as much their duty to bring about internal reform as to secure rights in regard to their wages.
('21', 274, 3, 31, 643641) If we merely insist on our rights and fail in our duties, we shall lose whatever rights we secure.
('21', 275, 0, 1, 643740) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 275, 1, 2, 643782) No very profound principle of honesty is involved in this.
('21', 275, 1, 3, 643841) If we do not display even practical honesty, public administration just cannot be carried on.
('21', 275, 1, 4, 643935) I place a simple idea before the railway workers: “You, too, take interest in the national movement; you, too, raise your voice against the injustice of British rule.
('21', 275, 1, 5, 644102) But how are people to protest against the injustice you do by stealing?
('21', 275, 1, 6, 644174) Has an unjust man any right to demand justice?
('21', 275, 1, 7, 644221) To the extent you are dishonest, you strengthen British rule, for people will lose faith in you.
('21', 275, 1, 8, 644318) You will make them say, by your behaviour, that British administration is better, such as it is.” So long as a subject people do not make themselves better than their rulers in point of moral strength, they cannot shake off subjection.
('21', 275, 1, 9, 644554) Therefore, if the railway workers wish well both of themselves and the people, they must resolve to shake off this immoral practice of stealing.
('21', 275, 2, 10, 644699) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 19 9 1920

('21', 277, 14, 16, 647903) 164. SWARAJ IN ONE YEAR
('21', 277, 15, 17, 647927) Much laughter has been indulged in at my expense for having told the Congress audience at Calcutta that if there was sufficient response to my programme of non co operation, swaraj would be attained in one year.
('21', 277, 15, 18, 648139) Some have ignored my condition and laughed because of the impossibility of getting swaraj anyhow within one year.
('21', 277, 15, 19, 648253) Others have spelt the “if” in capitals and suggested that if “ifs” were permissible in argument, any absurdity could be proved to be a possibility.
('21', 277, 15, 20, 648401) My proposition however is based on a mathematical calculation.
('21', 277, 15, 21, 648464) And I venture to say that true swaraj is a practical
('21', 277, 16, 22, 648517) 1 This was in reply to Shaukat Ali’s telegram of September 21, 1920, from Bombay regarding the trial of the editor of Zamindar.
('21', 277, 16, 23, 648645) It read : “Khilafat Lahore wires trial begins today, Section 124 A 153 A Special Magistrate Maulana cheerful offence Hazro speeches.
('21', 277, 16, 24, 648778) Zafar Ali Khan case fixed 27 Prosecution evidence about twenty witnesses including Pirgolra.
('21', 277, 16, 25, 648871) Wire advice about Defence.
('21', 277, 16, 26, 648898) Kindly wire Khilafat Lahore direct send me copy.” 2 The draft is in Gandhiji’s hand.
('21', 277, 16, 27, 648983) 3 Vide the preceding item.
('21', 278, 0, 1, 649010) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 279
('21', 278, 1, 2, 649055) impossibility without due fulfilment of my conditions.
('21', 278, 1, 3, 649110) Swaraj means a state such that we can maintain our separate existence without the presence of the English.
('21', 278, 1, 4, 649217) If it is to be partnership, it must be a partnership at will.
('21', 278, 1, 5, 649279) There can be no swaraj without our feeling and being the equals of Englishmen.
('21', 278, 1, 6, 649358) Today we feel that we are dependent upon them for our internal and external security, for an armed peace between the Hindus and the Mussulmans, for our education and for the supply of daily wants, nay, even for the settlement of our religious squabbles.
('21', 278, 1, 7, 649612) The rajas are dependent upon the British for their powers and the millionaires for their millions.
('21', 278, 1, 8, 649711) The British know our helplessness and Sir Thomas Holland cracks jokes quite legitimately at the expense of non co operationists.
('21', 278, 1, 9, 649840) To get swaraj then is to get rid of our helplessness.
('21', 278, 1, 10, 649894) The problem is no doubt stupendous even as it is for the fabled lion who having been brought up in the company of goats found it impossible to feel that he was a lion.
('21', 278, 1, 11, 650062) As Tolstoy used to put it, mankind often laboured under hypnotism.
('21', 278, 1, 12, 650129) The British themselves cannot be expected to help us out of it.
('21', 278, 1, 13, 650193) On the contrary, they din into our ears that we shall be fit to govern ourselves only by slow educative processes.
('21', 278, 1, 14, 650308) The Times suggested that if we boycott the councils we shall lose the opportunity of a training in swaraj.
('21', 278, 1, 15, 650415) I have no doubt that there are many who believe what the Times says.
('21', 278, 1, 16, 650484) It even resorts to a falsehood.
('21', 278, 1, 17, 650516) It audaciously says that Lord Milner’s mission listened to the Egyptians only when they were ready to lift the boycott of the Egyptian council.
('21', 278, 1, 18, 650660) For me the only training in swaraj we need is the ability to defend ourselves against the whole world and to live our natural life in perfect freedom even though it may be full of defects.
('21', 278, 1, 19, 650849) Good govern ment is no substitute for self government.
('21', 278, 1, 20, 650904) The Afghans have a bad Government but it is self Government.
('21', 278, 1, 21, 650965) I envy them.
('21', 278, 1, 22, 650978) The Japanese learnt the art through a sea of blood.
('21', 278, 1, 23, 651030) And if we today had the power to drive out the English by superior brute force, we would be counted their superiors, and in spite of our inexperience in debating at the council table or in holding executive offices, we would be held fit to govern ourselves.
('21', 278, 1, 24, 651288) For brute force is the only test the West has hitherto recognized.
('21', 278, 1, 25, 651355) The Germans were defeated not because they were necessarily in the wrong, but because the allied Powers were found to possess greater brute strength.
('21', 278, 1, 26, 651505) In the end therefore India must either learn the art of war which the British will not teach her or, she must follow her own way of discipline and self sacrifice through non co operation.
('21', 278, 1, 27, 651693) It is as amazing as it is humiliating that less than one hundred thousand white men should be able to rule three
('21', 279, 0, 1, 651806) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 279, 1, 2, 651848) hundred and fifteen million Indians.
('21', 279, 1, 3, 651885) They do so somewhat undoubtedly by force but more by securing our co operation in a thousand ways and making us more and more helpless and dependent on them as time goes forward.
('21', 279, 1, 4, 652064) Let us not mistake reformed councils, mere law courts and even governorships for real freedom or power.
('21', 279, 1, 5, 652168) They are but subtler methods of emasculation.
('21', 279, 1, 6, 652214) The British cannot rule us by mere force.
('21', 279, 1, 7, 652256) And so they resort to all means, honourable and dishonourable, in order to retain their hold on India.
('21', 279, 1, 8, 652359) They want India’s billions and they want India’s manpower for their imperialistic greed.
('21', 279, 1, 9, 652448) If we refuse to supply them with men and money, we achieve our goal, namely, swaraj, equality, manliness.
('21', 279, 1, 10, 652554) The cup of our humiliation was filled during the closing scenes in the Viceregal council.
('21', 279, 1, 11, 652644) Mr. Shastri could not move his resolution on the Punjab.
('21', 279, 1, 12, 652701) The Indian victims of Jallianwala [Bagh] received Rs. 1250, the English victims of mob frenzy received lakhs.
('21', 279, 1, 13, 652811) The officials who were guilty of crimes against those whose servants they were, were reprimanded.
('21', 279, 1, 14, 652909) And the councillors were satisfied.
('21', 279, 1, 15, 652945) If India were powerful, India would not have stood this addition of insult to her injury.
('21', 279, 1, 16, 653035) I do not blame the British.
('21', 279, 1, 17, 653063) If we were weak in numbers as they are, we too would perhaps have resorted to the same methods as they are now employing.
('21', 279, 1, 18, 653185) Terrorism and deception are weapons not of the strong but of the weak.
('21', 279, 1, 19, 653256) The British are weak in numbers, we are weak in spite of our numbers.
('21', 279, 1, 20, 653326) The result is that each is dragging the other down.
('21', 279, 1, 21, 653378) It is common experience that Englishmen lose in character after residence in India and that Indians lose in courage and manliness by contact with Englishmen.
('21', 279, 1, 22, 653536) This process of weakening is good neither for us, two nations, nor for the world.
('21', 279, 1, 23, 653618) But if we Indians take care of ourselves the English and the rest of the world would take care of themselves.
('21', 279, 1, 24, 653728) Our contribution to the world’s progress must therefore consist in setting our own house in order.
('21', 279, 2, 25, 653827) Training in arms for the present is out of the question.
('21', 279, 2, 26, 653884) I go a step further and believe that India has a better mission for the world.
('21', 279, 2, 27, 653963) It is within her power to show that she can achieve her destiny by pure self sacrifice, i.e., self purification.
('21', 279, 2, 28, 654076) This can be done only by non co operation.
('21', 279, 2, 29, 654119) And non co operation is possible only when those who commenced to co operate begin the process of withdrawal.
('21', 279, 2, 30, 654229) If we can
('21', 280, 0, 1, 654239) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 281
('21', 280, 1, 2, 654284) but free ourselves from the threefold maya 1 of Government controlled schools, Government law courts and legislative councils, and truly control our own education, regulate our disputes and be indifferent to their legislation, we are ready to govern ourselves and we are only then ready to ask the Government servants, whether civil or military, to resign and the tax payers to suspend payment of taxes.
('21', 280, 1, 3, 654688) And is it such an impracticable proposition to expect parents to withdraw their children from schools and colleges and establish their own institutions or to ask lawyers to suspend their practice and devote their whole time and attention to national service against payment, where necessary, of their maintenance, or to ask candidates for councils not to enter councils and lend their passive or active assistance to the legislative machinery through which all control is exercised?
('21', 280, 1, 4, 655171) The movement of non co operation is nothing but an attempt to isolate the brute force of the British from all the trappings under which it is hidden and to show that brute force by itself cannot for one single moment hold India.
('21', 280, 1, 5, 655400) But I frankly confess that, until the three conditions mentioned by me are fulfilled, there is no swaraj.
('21', 280, 1, 6, 655506) We may not go on taking our college degrees, taking thousands of rupees monthly from clients for cases which can be finished in five minutes and taking the keenest delight in wasting national time on the council floor and still expect to gain national self respect.
('21', 280, 1, 7, 655772) The last though not the least important part of the maya still remains to be considered.
('21', 280, 1, 8, 655861) That is swadeshi.
('21', 280, 1, 9, 655879) Had we not abandoned swadeshi, we need not have been in the present fallen state.
('21', 280, 1, 10, 655961) If we would get rid of the economic slavery, we must manufacture our own cloth and at the present moment only by hand spinning and hand weaving.
('21', 280, 1, 11, 656106) All this means discipline, self denial, self sacrifice, organizing ability, confidence and courage.
('21', 280, 1, 12, 656206) If we show this in one year among the classes that today count, and make public opinion, we certainly gain swaraj within one year.
('21', 280, 1, 13, 656337) If I am told that even we who lead have not the qualities in us, there certainly will never be swaraj for India, but then we shall have no right to blame the English for what they are doing.
('21', 280, 1, 14, 656528) Our salvation and its time are solely dependent upon us.

('21', 281, 1, 2, 656738) 165. SOME ILLUSTRATIONS
('21', 281, 2, 3, 656762) I promised in my article on “Democracy versus Mobocracy” 1
('21', 281, 3, 4, 656821) to give some illustrations of my meaning out of my own experiences.
('21', 281, 3, 5, 656889) I was however unable, owing to the protracted Congress proceedings, to give those illustrations last week.
('21', 281, 3, 6, 656996) I do so now.
('21', 281, 3, 7, 657009) When we reached Madras, a huge crowd waited us at the station.
('21', 281, 3, 8, 657072) Our compartment was detached and fortunately drawn up in front of a reserved platform.
('21', 281, 3, 9, 657159) What would have happened, if we had to alight together with the other passengers can be better imagined than described.
('21', 281, 3, 10, 657279) But even on the reserved platform we were not able to get out for some time.
('21', 281, 3, 11, 657356) The volunteers were in the way.
('21', 281, 3, 12, 657388) Instead of dispersing themselves among the crowd and keeping it back, they clustered together to do us honour as they thought.
('21', 281, 3, 13, 657515) The result was that the pressure was all directed towards where they and we were standing.
('21', 281, 3, 14, 657606) And “form a ring” has become the usual word of command.
('21', 281, 3, 15, 657662) This forming a ring is a humiliating spectacle and yet it has become such an institution that even when there is no one else but volunteers, “a ring” is formed round the leader to be “honoured”.
('21', 281, 3, 16, 657857) To proceed with my descripiton, the crowd was large, the noises they made were so terrific that the directions given by the volunteers could not be heard at all.
('21', 281, 3, 17, 658019) All was chaos.
('21', 281, 3, 18, 658034) My poor toes were every moment in danger of being crushed to a pulp.
('21', 281, 3, 19, 658103) I often very nearly lost my balance through the jostling of the very volunteers who were trying to protect me.
('21', 281, 3, 20, 658214) And but for the very great care with which they guarded me and the assistance rendered to them by the stalwart Maulana Shaukat Ali, I would have fared much worse than I did.
('21', 281, 3, 21, 658388) The atmosphere was suffocating.
('21', 281, 3, 22, 658420) Thus struggling it took us nearly three quarters of an hour to reach the motor car, whereas ordinarily it need not have taken three minutes to walk out of the station to the porch.
('21', 281, 3, 23, 658601) Having reached the car it was no easy job to get into it.
('21', 281, 3, 24, 658659) I had to be shoved into it in the best manner possible.
('21', 281, 3, 25, 658715) I certainly heaved a sigh of relief when I found myself in the car, and I thought that both the Maulana and I deserved the ovation we received from the crowd after the dangerous exercise we had gone through.
('21', 281, 3, 26, 658923) With a little forethought this mobocracy, for such it was, could have been changed into a splendidly organized and educative demonstration.
('21', 281, 3, 27, 659063) And it could have
('21', 281, 4, 28, 659081) 1 Of September 8, 1920
('21', 282, 0, 1, 659104) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 283
('21', 282, 1, 2, 659149) been rendered free of all risk to life.
('21', 282, 1, 3, 659189) The experience of Madras was typical of many.
('21', 282, 1, 4, 659235) We had an extraordinary experience at Erode on our way to Salem.
('21', 282, 1, 5, 659300) I was fairly fagged out.
('21', 282, 1, 6, 659325) My voice had become hoarse with speaking.
('21', 282, 1, 7, 659367) As at many stations there was here too a surging crowd.
('21', 282, 1, 8, 659423) It was throughly disorganized, though like everywhere else perfectly good humoured and respectful.
('21', 282, 1, 9, 659522) I appealed to them not to make all kinds of unmusical noises, told them to disperse in an orderly manner as they had already seen us.
('21', 282, 1, 10, 659656) I told them too that if they intended to take their share in the khilafat and the Punjab struggle, they were expected to undergo discipline.
('21', 282, 1, 11, 659797) I was able to reach my voice to the most intelligent amongst them.
('21', 282, 1, 12, 659864) I suggested that they should quietly rise, turn towards the station entrance and noiselessly retire.
('21', 282, 1, 13, 659965) They listened, the rest followed and the station was cleared in two minutes’ time.
('21', 282, 1, 14, 660048) If the friends, who heard me, had haggled, argued, objected and insisted on shouting and remaining, the whole crowd would have done likewise and there would have been a pandemonium throughout the long time that the train stopped there.
('21', 282, 1, 15, 660284) I shall finish this description by giving the reverse of our experience at Jalarpet.
('21', 282, 1, 16, 660369) We were travelling to Madras by the night train leaving Bangalore.
('21', 282, 1, 17, 660436) We had been taking meetings at Salem during the day, motoring to Bangalore, a distance of 125 miles from Salem, taking there a meeting in drenching rain and thereafter we had to entrain.
('21', 282, 1, 18, 660623) We needed night’s rest but there was none to be had.
('21', 282, 1, 19, 660676) At almost every station of importance, large crowds had gathered to greet us.
('21', 282, 1, 20, 660754) About midnight we reached Jalarpet junction.
('21', 282, 1, 21, 660799) The train had to stop there nearly forty minutes or stopped that night all those terrible minutes.
('21', 282, 1, 22, 660898) Maulana Shaukat Ali requested the crowd to disperse.
('21', 282, 1, 23, 660951) But the more he argued, the more they shouted “Maulana Shaukat Ali ki Jai”, evidently thinking that the Maulana could not mean what he said.
('21', 282, 1, 24, 661092) They had come from twenty miles’ distance, they were waiting there for hours, they must have their satisfaction.
('21', 282, 1, 25, 661205) The Maulana gave up the struggle, he pretended to sleep.
('21', 282, 1, 26, 661262) The adorers thereuponmounted the footboards to have a peep at the Maulana.
('21', 282, 1, 27, 661337) As the light in our compartment was put out they brought in lanterns.
('21', 282, 1, 28, 661407) At last I thought I would try.
('21', 282, 1, 29, 661438) I rose, went to the door.
('21', 282, 1, 30, 661464) It was a signal for a great shout of joy.
('21', 282, 1, 31, 661506) The noise tore me to pieces.
('21', 282, 1, 32, 661535) I was so tired.
('21', 282, 1, 33, 661551) All my appeals proved fruitless in the end.
('21', 282, 1, 34, 661595) They would stop for a while to renew the noise again.
('21', 282, 1, 35, 661649) I shut the windows.
('21', 282, 1, 36, 661669) But the crowd was not to be baffled.
('21', 282, 1, 37, 661706) They tried to open the windows from outside.
('21', 282, 1, 38, 661751) They must see us both.
('21', 282, 1, 39, 661774) And so the tussle went on till my son took it up.
('21', 282, 1, 40, 661824) He harangued them,
('21', 283, 0, 1, 661843) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 283, 1, 2, 661885) appealed to them for the sake of the other passengers.
('21', 283, 1, 3, 661940) He produced some effect and there was a little less noise.
('21', 283, 1, 4, 661999) Peeping however went on to the last minute.
('21', 283, 1, 5, 662043) It was all well meant, it was all an exhibition of boundless love, yet how cruel, how unreasonable!
('21', 283, 1, 6, 662143) It was a mob without a mind.
('21', 283, 1, 7, 662172) There were no intelligent men of influence among them and so nobody listened to anybody.
('21', 283, 1, 8, 662261) Before we can make real headway, we must train these masses of men who have a heart of gold, who feel for the country, who want to be taught and led.
('21', 283, 1, 9, 662411) But a few intelligent, sincere, local workers are needed, and the whole nation can be organized to act intelligently, and democracy can be evolved out of mobocracy.
('21', 283, 1, 10, 662576) This evolution is really the first step to successful, national non co operation.

('21', 283, 2, 12, 662681) 166. SWADESHI STORES
('21', 283, 3, 13, 662702) In a previous issue 1 I endeavoured to show how stores for the sake of selling mill manufactures did not advance swadeshi in any way whatsoever, but on the contrary tended to send up the price of cloth.
('21', 283, 3, 14, 662905) I propose to show in this article how with a small capital, it is possible to advance true swadeshi and earn a modest live lihood.
('21', 283, 3, 15, 663036) Suppose that there is a family consisting of husband, wife and two children one of whom is ten years old and the other five.
('21', 283, 3, 16, 663161) If they have a capital of Rs. 500, they can manage a khaddar bhandar 2 in a small way.
('21', 283, 3, 17, 663248) They can hire, say in a place with a population of 20,000 inhabitants, a shop with dwelling rooms for Rs. 10 per month.
('21', 283, 3, 18, 663368) If they sell the whole of the stock at 10 per cent profit they can have Rs. 50 per month.
('21', 283, 3, 19, 663458) They have no servants.
('21', 283, 3, 20, 663481) The wife and the children in their spare time would be expected to help in keeping the shop tidy and looking after it when the husband is out.
('21', 283, 3, 21, 663624) The wife and children can also devote their spare time to spinning.
('21', 283, 3, 22, 663692) In the initial stages the khaddar may not sell at the shop.
('21', 283, 3, 23, 663752) In that case the husband is expected to hawk the khaddar from door to door and popularize it.
('21', 283, 3, 24, 663846) He will soon find a custom for it.
('21', 283, 3, 25, 663881) The reader must not be surprised at my suggesting 10 percent profits.
('21', 283, 3, 26, 663951) The khaddar bhandars are not designed for the poorest.
('21', 283, 3, 27, 664006) The use of khaddar saves at least half the cost not necessarily because the
('21', 283, 4, 28, 664082) 1 Vide “Swadeshi”, 8 9 1920.
('21', 283, 5, 29, 664111) 2 Store
('21', 284, 0, 1, 664119) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 285
('21', 284, 1, 2, 664164) khaddar is more durable (though that it certainly is) but because its use revolutionizes our tastes.
('21', 284, 1, 3, 664265) I know what saving of money its use has meant to me.
('21', 284, 1, 4, 664318) Those who buy khaddar from patriotic motives merely can easily afford to pay 10 percent profits on khaddar.
('21', 284, 1, 5, 664426) Lastly the popularizing of khaddar means much care, devotion and labour.
('21', 284, 1, 6, 664499) And the owner of a khaddar bhandar does not buy it at a wholesale shop but he must wander to get the best khaddar, he must meet the local weavers and induce them to weave hand spun yarn.
('21', 284, 1, 7, 664686) He must stimulate in his own district hand spinning among its women.
('21', 284, 1, 8, 664755) He must come in touch with the carders and get them to card cotton.
('21', 284, 1, 9, 664823) All this means intelligence, organization and great ability.
('21', 284, 1, 10, 664884) A man who can exhibit these qualities has a right to take 10 per cent profits.
('21', 284, 1, 11, 664963) And a swadeshi bhandar conducted on these lines becomes a true centre of swadeshi activity.
('21', 284, 1, 12, 665055) I commend my remarks to the attention of the managers of swadeshi stores that are already in existence.
('21', 284, 1, 13, 665159) They may not revolutionize their method at once but I have no doubt that they will advance swadeshi only to the extent that they sell khaddar.

('21', 284, 2, 15, 665325) 167. THE DISTRESS IN PURI
('21', 284, 3, 16, 665351) I invite the attention of the readers to the latest report of the Puri distress.
('21', 284, 3, 17, 665432) The response made hitherto has been generous but not enough to cope with the distress in full.
('21', 284, 3, 18, 665527) Volunteers are becoming scarce owing to the prolongation of the distress.
('21', 284, 3, 19, 665601) They have to be replaced by paid workers.
('21', 284, 3, 20, 665643) The committee 1 has been obliged for want of funds to cut down the number relieved and the Government of Bihar and Orissa will not relieve “economic” distress.
('21', 284, 3, 21, 665803) The committee needs at least Rs. 50,000. I take that the generous readers who see the appeal will not be slow to respond.
('21', 284, 3, 22, 665925) An eyewitness who chanced to go to Puri from Calcutta told me that he saw a hungry man die in his presence.
('21', 284, 3, 23, 666033) He had walked to the place where relief was being given.
('21', 284, 3, 24, 666090) He was too exhausted to live to get relief.
('21', 284, 3, 25, 666134) Only the other day an Oriya was found in the act of committing suicide because he was unable to bear the pangs of hunger.

('21', 285, 1, 2, 666497) What do these incidents teach us?
('21', 285, 1, 3, 666531) Distress is chronic in the land.

('21', 285, 1, 9, 667178) Nor, let me hope, will the death of Mr. Krishnachandra Naik from snake bite discourage volunteers from offering their assistance.

('21', 285, 1, 13, 667633) Mr. Naik will return to the earth with a body better equipped for the work before him.
