('21', 287, 1, 2, 670385) 169. REPORT ON DRAFT INSTRUCTIONS FOR CONGRESS ORGANIZATIONS 1
('21', 287, 2, 3, 670448) September 22, 1920 Report on draft instructions for Congress organizations and those who approve of the resolutions on non co operation of the special Congress Session prepared by the Sub committee appointed by the All India Congress Committee.
('21', 287, 2, 4, 670693) The Congress has advised: (a) boycott of titles and honorary offices, (b)boycott of Government functions such as parties, levees and durbars, (c)gradual boycott of Government or Government controlled schools and colleges and establishment of national schools and colleges, (d)gradual boycott of law courts by lawyers and litigants and establishment by the aid of such lawyers of private arbitration courts, (e) boycott of reformed councils by candidates and electors, (f)boycott of recruiting for soldiers, clerks and labourers for service in Mesopotamia (meaning Turkish dominions) as on the outbreak of the war, (g) boycott of foreign goods, (h)promotion of swadeshi by stimulating manufacture and distribution of hand spun yarn and hand woven cloth out of such yarn.
('21', 287, 2, 5, 671463) The Congress has approved of Mr. Gandhi’s full programme of progressive non violent non co operation but has adopted for immediate use the items above mentioned.
('21', 287, 2, 6, 671625) The question is how to enforce these items.
('21', 287, 2, 7, 671669) BOYCOTT OF TITLES This is the most difficult part of the programme.
('21', 287, 2, 8, 671737) But it is the most necessary part.
('21', 287, 2, 9, 671772) It is difficult because it applies to those who have not as a body hitherto taken part in active public life and have prized their titles or honours as life itself.
('21', 287, 2, 10, 671937) It is a necessary item in non co operation because even this class must be disillusioned and educated to consider gifts from an unrighteous government as a dishonour to
('21', 287, 3, 11, 672106) 1 The original typewritten draft bears corrections in Gandhiji’s hand.

('21', 288, 1, 2, 672222) be religously shunned.

('21', 288, 2, 4, 672598) No undue pressure of any kind whatsoever should be exercised.

('21', 288, 4, 15, 674504) Canvassing should go on for volunteer teachers, and where parents and schoolmasters of schools other than those under direct Government control agree, those schools should give immediate
('21', 289, 0, 1, 674691) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 289, 1, 2, 674733) notice to the Government dispensing with all control or aid by way of inspection or otherwise.
('21', 289, 1, 3, 674828) They should be conducted as national schools with such modification in the training as local circumstances may require.
('21', 289, 1, 4, 674948) If men of education take interest in this movement of truly nationalizing our education, local committees of inspection and guidance may be formed ultimately resulting in provincial or district universities.
('21', 289, 1, 5, 675156) The introduction of the adjective “gradual” in the item regarding schools in the resolution simply means that immediate results are not expected because of the existing infatuation about Government schools.
('21', 289, 1, 6, 675363) It does not mean that propaganda should be so carried out as to bring about only a gradual withdrawal of boys and girls from schools and colleges.
('21', 289, 1, 7, 675510) Lists of parents who have withdrawn their children, of boys who have themselves withdrawn and of school masters who have resigned and lists of local schools established as also of volunteer teachers should be sent to the provincial headquarters and should be published.
('21', 289, 1, 8, 675780) BOYCOTT OF LAW COURTS
('21', 289, 2, 9, 675802) The increase of litigation is an acknowledged evil.
('21', 289, 2, 10, 675854) That litigation keeps pace with the increase of lawyers is also a fairly established fact.
('21', 289, 2, 11, 675945) That a government wields tremendous powers through its law courts and its system of punishments is also equally true.
('21', 289, 2, 12, 676063) When there is a real nati onal awakening amongst the masses it must be reflected in the statistics of crime and civil suits.
('21', 289, 2, 13, 676188) A nation which has set its heart upon gaining self determination can have little time for private quarrels civil or criminal and it must be the duty of everyone and specially of those who are versed in law to bring about such a state of things.
('21', 289, 2, 14, 676433) Moreover, hitherto lawyers have controlled (and that very properly) public agitation in the country.
('21', 289, 2, 15, 676534) If they do not give their whole time and attention to the immediate establishment of swaraj and devote only a portion of their leisure to public affairs, and assuming that the lawyers remained in charge of public movements the establishment of swaraj must be indefinitely postponed.
('21', 289, 2, 16, 676817) Therefore it is absolutely necessary for reaching our goal in the immediate future that lawyers should suspend their practice.
('21', 289, 2, 17, 676944) Those who do so and who require to be supported should be supported by the nation either by utilizing their services for the national schools or in connection with private arbitration or for propaganda work.
('21', 289, 2, 18, 677152) A deputation such as has been suggested for holders of titles, etc., should
('21', 290, 0, 1, 677228) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 291
('21', 290, 1, 2, 677273) also wait upon lawyers and ascertain their wishes.
('21', 290, 1, 3, 677324) Lists of lawyers in each town or district should be prepared marking out those who may suspend their practice and forwarded to the provincial headquarters for publication.
('21', 290, 1, 4, 677496) Lawyers should help in inducing parties not only to refer future disputes to arbitration but also to withdraw cases now pending in the British courts and submit them to the national arbitration courts.
('21', 290, 1, 5, 677698) District Committees should make lists of lawyers and other prominent citizens commanding public confidence who are to preside over arbitration courts.
('21', 290, 1, 6, 677849) As there is at present no machinery to enforce the orders of arbitration courts some kind of social boycott should be imposed on parties who fail to carry out such orders.
('21', 290, 1, 7, 678021) It has been pointed out that certain lawyers who are ready and willing to suspend their practice immediately are not in a position to do so completely at a moment’s notice as they have already entered into engagements from which as honourable men cannot withdraw without the consent of their clients.
('21', 290, 1, 8, 678322) In these cases the lawyers will be expected to attend only to such engagements and to make every endeavour to cease to practice completely at the earliest possible date.
('21', 290, 1, 9, 678492) COUNCILS The boycott of councils is of the greatest moment and the greatest concentration of energy.
('21', 290, 1, 10, 678593) People at large cannot understand the meaning of non co operation if the best workers seek election to the councils.
('21', 290, 1, 11, 678710) The reform act has not been framed so as to grant immediate swaraj.
('21', 290, 1, 12, 678778) Whenever swaraj comes it will not come as a free will offering from the British people but it will come when the demand becomes irresistible.
('21', 290, 1, 13, 678920) A force of an irresistible character, we contend, cannot be generated on the floor of the reformed councils.
('21', 290, 1, 14, 679029) It will have to be generated by an incessant education of the electrorate and those who are outside the electoral rolls.
('21', 290, 1, 15, 679150) Candidates who have already come forward should be approached by deputations requesting them to withdraw their candidature, and electors should be approached to sign the following form : In view and in virtue of the resolution of the special session of the national Congress and the All India Moslem League we being voters in the electoral district of .
('21', 290, 1, 16, 679504) for election to the reformed councils hereby place on record our desire that we do not wish to be represented at the Provincial Legis lative Council (or the Legislative Assembly or the Council of State) and hereby inform all candidates for election that if they seek election in
('21', 291, 0, 1, 679783) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 291, 1, 2, 679825) spite of our wish to the contrary, they will not, represent us.
('21', 291, 1, 3, 679889) We do not desire to be represented in the reformed councils till justice has been granted in the matters of khilafat and the Punjab and swaraj is established in India.
('21', 291, 1, 4, 680057) If more than one half of the number of electors in a particular district can be induced to sign this form we consider that it is impossible for any candidate to persist in his candidature after such an emphatic declaration.
('21', 291, 1, 5, 680281) Lists of those who have withdrawn their candidature and those who persist should be taken to put the pros and cons before the voters prior to asking them to sign the above mentioned form which should be translated in the vernacular of the district concerned.
('21', 291, 1, 6, 680540) RECRUITING FOR LABOUR, ETC., FOR MESOPOTAMIA The least that a nation which feels the cruel wrong of the khilafat and the Punjab can do is to refuse to swell the ranks of recruits as sepoys, clerks and labourers for service in Mesopotamia and the other parts of the Turkish Dominions as they existed on the outbreak of the War.
('21', 291, 1, 7, 680867) Propaganda should be carried by workers among those who are likely to offer themselves for such service placing before them the true situation and then letting them make their choice.
('21', 291, 1, 8, 681051) BOYCOTT OF FOREIGN GOODS This clause was an unfortunate interpolation due to a misap prehension.
('21', 291, 1, 9, 681148) 1 Every non co operator is in duty bound to simplify his or her wants and dispense with all luxuries that are dependent on the use of foreign articles.
('21', 291, 1, 10, 681300) SWADESHI This part of the resolution contains all that is immediately possible in the way of boycott of foreign cloth.
('21', 291, 1, 11, 681419) The use of foreign cloth whether from Lancashire or Japan or France has taken the bread out of millions of mouths, has all but killed the ancient art of home spinning which supplemented the resources of millions of agricult urists and constituted a kind of insurance against famine.
('21', 291, 1, 12, 681702) It has robbed thousands of weavers of an honourable and lucrative occupation.
('21', 291, 1, 13, 681780) Our mills do not manufacture sufficient for our wants.
('21', 291, 1, 14, 681835) Any pressure on mill manufacture by those who are in the habit of using foreign cloths can only result in increasing prices, depriving the
('21', 291, 2, 15, 681974) 1 This sentence is from The Bombay Chronicle, 28 9 1920.
('21', 292, 0, 1, 682031) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 293
('21', 292, 1, 2, 682076) poor of the cloth they buy without in any way promoting swadeshi.
('21', 292, 1, 3, 682142) Resort therefore to hand spinning and hand weaving is at the present day a national necessity and before it becomes fairly universal it will require discipline, sacrifice and organizing ability all of which are qualities also required for gaining swaraj.
('21', 292, 1, 4, 682397) We attach great importance to swadeshi in the form of a revival of hand spinning and hand weaving and distribution of cloth so manufactured.
('21', 292, 1, 5, 682538) Thousands of workers need special training for this work.
('21', 292, 1, 6, 682596) Ladies of high station should be induced to take up hand spinning and to use only such cloth as can be woven out of hand spun yarn.
('21', 292, 1, 7, 682728) Classes should be formed in every street.
('21', 292, 1, 8, 682770) Spinning wheels can be manufactured by any ordinary carpenter if a model is placed before him.
('21', 292, 1, 9, 682865) Those who are desirous of taking up this branch of work should communicate with the manager of Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati, near Ahmedabad.
('21', 292, 1, 10, 683006) SWARAJ FUND It is very necessary that a national fund should be established for the purpose of carrying into effect the Congress resolution.
('21', 292, 1, 11, 683147) Fund will be required for propaganda work, for encouraging swadeshi for establishing national schools and for supporting lawyers who have suspended their practice and are unable to support themselves.
('21', 292, 1, 12, 683348) Provincial with the help of district organizations should therefore make every endeavour to collect funds and submit monthly reports of receipts and expenditure.
('21', 292, 1, 13, 683510) VOLUNTEER CORPS Provincial, district and town organizations should form volunteer corps for the purpose of disciplining the people and maintaining order.
('21', 292, 1, 14, 683664) Finally we would advise that where there is a sufficient number of workers, a batch should specialize in order to make one particular item successful.
('21', 292, 1, 15, 683815) Where the workers are not sufficient, precedence should be given to the boycott of councils because results must be shown in this item of non co operation before the middle of December next.

('21', 295, 1, 2, 687291) 172. LETTER TO EVERY VOTER ON DUTY OF VOTERS 1
('21', 295, 2, 3, 687338) ALL INDIA HOME RULE LEAGUE, MASJID BUNDER ROAD, MANDVI, BOMBAY, [Before September 25, 1920] The special session of the Congress by an overwhelming majority has decided in favour of complete boycott of the reformed councils.
('21', 295, 2, 4, 687562) It is therefore your duty not to vote for any candidate for election to the reformed councils.
('21', 295, 2, 5, 687657) It is however necessary for any candidate who wished to stand in your name to know that you do not wish him or anybody else to represent you.
('21', 295, 2, 6, 687799) For that purpose you should sign the form that has been prepared for your signature.
('21', 295, 2, 7, 687884) It is your duty also to tell your co voters, what they should do.
('21', 295, 2, 8, 687950) You know why it is wrong to enter the councils.
('21', 295, 2, 9, 687998) The Government have declined to grant justice to the Punjab.
('21', 295, 2, 10, 688059) British ministers have broken their pledged word to the Mussulmans and otherwise ignored the deepest Mussulman sentiments regarding the khilafat.
('21', 295, 2, 11, 688205) We must get these wrongs righted and in order to prevent a recurrence of such injustice or bad faith we must obtain full swaraj and must get rid of the badge of inferiority.
('21', 295, 2, 12, 688379) We cannot do this by going to the councils, nor can we gain swaraj by going there.
('21', 295, 2, 13, 688462) On the contrary, although our representatives may vote against unjust Government measures they will still be regarded as authors of those measures and thus be unwilling instruments of injustice.
('21', 295, 2, 14, 688657) The best way therefore for conserving our honour, hastening the advent of swaraj and righting those wrongs is for the voters not to send any representatives to the councils.
('21', 295, 3, 15, 688831) The Bombay Chronicle, 25 9 1920
('21', 295, 4, 16, 688863) 1 According to Bombay Secret Abstracts, 1920, this was issued as a leaflet by Gandhiji and was being freely distributed in Sind in English and vernacular.

('21', 296, 6, 7, 689249) 174. LETTER TO CHAIRMAN, A.I.C.C. 4
('21', 296, 7, 8, 689285) September 25, 1920 THE CHAIRMAN ALL INDIA CONGRESS COMMITTEE CALCUTTA
('21', 296, 8, 9, 689355) SIR, By a resolution of the All India Congress Committee held at Amritsar and dated the 2nd January last the undersigned were appointed a committee to draft amendments to the Congress Constitution and Rules.
('21', 296, 8, 10, 689563) The report was to be presented on or before the 30th June last.
('21', 296, 8, 11, 689627) We regret to say that owing to unforeseen difficulties we were not able to prepare our final draft by that date.
('21', 296, 8, 12, 689740) We now append hereto our final draft of the Constitution.
('21', 296, 8, 13, 689798) We have not been able to meet at any place for mutual discussion but have been obliged to confer with one another only by correspon dence.
('21', 296, 8, 14, 689937) received from various quarters.
('21', 296, 8, 15, 689969) In coming to our conclusions we have carefully considered all the suggestions
('21', 296, 9, 16, 690047) 1 889 1942; whom Gandhiji regarded as his fifth son; treasurer of Indian National Congress for a number of years 2 To accept the presidentship of Nagpur Congress; vide the addressee’s letter to Gandhiji dated September 24, 1920. 3 Aurobindo Ghosh (1872 1950); mystic, poet and philosopher; settled at Pondichery from 1910 onwards 4 The original draft is in Gandhiji’s hand.
('21', 297, 0, 1, 690421) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 297, 1, 2, 690463) We have not been able to agree to the principle of fixing the number of delegates to the Congress.
('21', 297, 1, 3, 690562) Mr. Gandhi is alone responsible for the suggestion.
('21', 297, 1, 4, 690614) The majority of us consider that the Congress will lose its demonstrative and influential character if the number is restricted.
('21', 297, 1, 5, 690743) The majority admit the unwieldy nature of the present Congresses.
('21', 297, 1, 6, 690809) But in their opinion the benefit of having an unlimited number outweighs the difficulty of the problem.
('21', 297, 1, 7, 690913) Mr. Gandhi on the other hand considers that the restriction is essential in order to give the Congress a truly representative character and to make it a proper deliberative body.
('21', 297, 1, 8, 691092) He thinks too that the Congress demands will become irresistible when it scientifically represents the whole people of India with an effective and proportionate voice in its deliberations and when every resolution has been considered with precision.
('21', 297, 1, 9, 691342) He thinks that its demonstrative character will remain unimpaired by reason of the admission of visitors and guests in an unrestricted manner.
('21', 297, 1, 10, 691485) The draft hereto attached embodies Mr. Gandhi’s suggestions.
('21', 297, 1, 11, 691546) If therefore the All India Congress Committee rejects Mr. Gandhi’s proposal the section dealing with the restriction of the number of delegates will have [to] be deleted.
('21', 297, 1, 12, 691717) If Mr. Gandhi’s proposal for restriction is accepted, we approve of the principle of proportional representation known as the single transferable vote.
('21', 297, 1, 13, 691869) The All India Congress Committee will note the change we have made in the Congress creed.
('21', 297, 1, 14, 691959) The most noteworthy change proposed by us is the substi[tu]tion of the adjective constitutional by legitimate and honourable in reference to the methods to be adopted.
('21', 297, 1, 15, 692127) We think that the work constitutional having a double meaning—popular and legal—causes embarrassment.
('21', 297, 1, 16, 692229) We have also removed the clause “a steady reform of the existing system of administration” in order to bring the article more in accordance with the recent resolutions of the Congress on reforms.
('21', 297, 1, 17, 692425) Another noteworthy change we have made is to redistribute the provinces on a linguistic basis.
('21', 297, 1, 18, 692520) We believe that the present distribution made from time to time to meet the exigencies of a conquering power is unscientific and is calculated to retard the political and social progress of the respective communities speaking a common vernacular and therefore the growth of India as a whole.
('21', 297, 1, 19, 692812) We therefore feel that so far as the Congress is concerned, we should re divide India into provinces on a linguistic basis.
('21', 297, 1, 20, 692936) This would also strengthen the movement for securing such a redistribution by the Government.
('21', 298, 0, 1, 693030) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 299
('21', 298, 1, 2, 693075) We have made no special provision for Mussulman represen tation in the Congress.
('21', 298, 1, 3, 693156) In view of the happy relations existing between the two races, we do not consider it necessary to make any special provision for their representation.
('21', 298, 1, 4, 693307) But we wish to state that if the Mussulmans desire any special provision or protection, it should be made or granted for the asking.
('21', 298, 1, 5, 693440) So far as recognition of Urdu is concerned we have used the common term Hindustani which includes both Hindi and Urdu and we have recognized both scripts, Devnagari and Persian.
('21', 298, 1, 6, 693618) We present no separate draft rules.
('21', 298, 1, 7, 693654) We consider that the ordinary recognized procedure for such assemblies like the Congress and its offshoots should be applicable where no special mention to the contrary is made in the Constitution.
('21', 298, 2, 8, 693852) We remain,
('21', 298, 4, 9, 693863) Yours truly,
('21', 298, 5, 10, 693876) From a photostat : G.N. 8228
('21', 298, 6, 11, 693905) 175. UNUSUAL CIRCULAR
('21', 298, 7, 12, 693927) The Education Department has issued a circular which, translated, reads as under : 1
('21', 298, 8, 13, 694012) The reason which has prompted this circular is not difficult to understand.
('21', 298, 8, 14, 694088) It is dated September 1. Even the man who trusts to his rifle must admit that, faced with non co operation, brute force is unavailing and the rifle ineffective.
('21', 298, 8, 15, 694249) When we get the strength for non co operation, rifles will be covered with rust, there will be grass growing over them and our children will play where they lie buried.
('21', 298, 8, 16, 694418) When one side talks of non co operation, the other side has no choice but to talk of co operation.
('21', 298, 8, 17, 694517) There is no doubt of it that the Empire depends on friendship, on co operation.
('21', 298, 8, 18, 694597) It was only when I saw that the friendship was not genuine, that it was a friendship between the strong and the weak, that I advised non co operation.
('21', 298, 8, 19, 694748) Friendship is possible only between equals and, since we want to be friends with the whole world, we wish to be the equals of all; we wish to give up all fear of others and to conquer their brute force by our
('21', 298, 9, 20, 694957) 1 For the text of the circular, vide “The Meaning of the Empire”, 29 9 1920.
('21', 299, 0, 1, 695034) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 299, 1, 2, 695076) moral strength.
('21', 299, 1, 3, 695092) It is our non co operation which will create the basis for friendship.
('21', 299, 1, 4, 695163) The foregoing circular is sheer hypocrisy, no more than make believe.
('21', 299, 1, 5, 695233) The effort will be as futile as trying to make a rope out of sand.
('21', 299, 1, 6, 695300) 1 If the Government really means to treat us as friends, it must undo the injustices, its ways must change and its heart should melt.
('21', 299, 1, 7, 695434) If the heart melts, it will repent for its innumerable sins, do justice to the Punjab, heal the Muslims’ wound, will look upon Tilak Maharaj, not as an enemy, but as a pillar of the Empire and the Viceroy will apologize for the crime of refusing even to mention his name.
('21', 299, 1, 8, 695706) The greatest crime of Tilak Maharaj was that, with his foresight, he saw that, so long as the British officers looked down upon us, associating with them would do us harm.
('21', 299, 1, 9, 695878) It is for this reason that the British officers seem to think that they would be polluted if they so much as mentioned his name.
('21', 299, 1, 10, 696007) So long as, inwardly, they have contempt for us, such circulars for promoting friendship are but a salve for our wounds.
('21', 299, 1, 11, 696128) But we can hope for a change of heart in the officials only when we have conquered their hostility by our strength of character.
('21', 299, 1, 12, 696257) We ourselves credit them with superior strength and want to be what they are.
('21', 299, 1, 13, 696335) The truth of the matter is that acquiring an empire constitutes no superiority.
('21', 299, 1, 14, 696415) It requires brute force and the ability to use cunning methods of persuasion, bribery and coercion and to creat divisions among the opponents.
('21', 299, 1, 15, 696558) This provides no measure of moral worth.
('21', 299, 1, 16, 696599) Superiority can be measured only in terms of moral worth and an empire based on moral strength is the only true empire.
('21', 299, 1, 17, 696719) In adopting non co operation, India has chosen the way which will help it to win such an empire.
('21', 299, 1, 18, 696816) All that the foregoing circular tells us is that even our adversary admits our path to be the right one.
('21', 299, 1, 19, 696921) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 26 9 1920
('21', 299, 2, 20, 696958) 1 A Tamil proverb
('21', 300, 0, 1, 696976) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 301
('21', 300, 1, 2, 697021) 176. GUJARAT’S DUTY
('21', 300, 2, 3, 697041) The question naturally arises what Gujarat will do now.
('21', 300, 2, 4, 697097) Gujarat had decided, even before the Congress session was held, to boycott legislatures, schools and courts and the Congress has now approved this programme; Gujarat is, therefore, under a double obligation now.
('21', 300, 2, 5, 697309) However, it seems to have done nothing of much consequence so far.
('21', 300, 2, 6, 697376) It seems that legislatures will be boycotted by and large.
('21', 300, 2, 7, 697435) But this certainly will not suffice.
('21', 300, 2, 8, 697472) How many schools have we rendered vacant?
('21', 300, 2, 9, 697514) How many lawyers have given up practice?
('21', 300, 2, 10, 697555) How many people have given up wearing foreign cloth entirely?
('21', 300, 2, 11, 697617) How many have taken up, and induced others to take up, hand spinning and hand weaving?
('21', 300, 2, 12, 697704) These are no idle questions.
('21', 300, 2, 13, 697733) We shall be tested by how we answer them.
('21', 300, 2, 14, 697775) Our attending meetings and raising hands for voting will not get us swaraj or justice for the Punjab; nor will it prevent the humiliation of Islam.
('21', 300, 2, 15, 697923) Moreover, the Viceroy has made it clear by his action that we are not to expect any justice.
('21', 300, 2, 16, 698016) Officers have been reprimanded.
('21', 300, 2, 17, 698048) India has demanded not merely that the guilty officers be reprimanded but that they be discharged from service or suitably punished.
('21', 300, 2, 18, 698181) Nothing like this has been done.
('21', 300, 2, 19, 698214) In Fiji, innocent and helpless Indians were subjected to atrocities similar to those in Amritsar.
('21', 300, 2, 20, 698312) Gujaratis must have read the report of an example of arrogance in New Zealand.

('21', 310, 1, 3, 719246) If this principle is accepted, the question whether there are any alternative schools does not arise at all.
('21', 310, 1, 4, 719355) You have, therefore, to consider the issue only from this point of view, whether or not it is your duty now to leave schools and colleges forthwith.
('21', 310, 1, 5, 719504) What should the students do after leaving their institution?
('21', 310, 1, 6, 719565) What should those who are rendered idle during the intervening period do?
('21', 310, 1, 7, 719639) You may ask all these questions.
('21', 310, 1, 8, 719672) The principle is the same that I have put forward.
('21', 310, 1, 9, 719723) I do not put before you the corollaries which follow from this.
('21', 310, 1, 10, 719787) Consistently with this main principle, one may, unwaveringly, follow any course which appeals to one’s heart.
('21', 310, 1, 11, 719897) It is, at the same time, my duty to add that no student is justified in continuing to attend school or college out of weakness, once his doubts have been resolved.
('21', 310, 1, 12, 720061) This is no time for the nation to show weakness.
('21', 310, 2, 13, 720110) Then followed questions by students and Gandhiji’s replies.
('21', 310, 3, 14, 720170) Q: Mahatmaji, what should we do if the Congres meeting in Nagpur postpones the implementation of this resolution?

('21', 310, 5, 21, 720918) Should we, then, give up that which truly belongs to us or should we take back its management in our hands?
('21', 310, 5, 22, 721026) Should a person misuse something that has been entrusted to him, even in law such a person is said to have committed breach of trust.
('21', 310, 5, 23, 721160) If a dhobi puts to some other use garment which has been given to him for washing, he is accused of theft.

('21', 311, 1, 2, 721604) not going to be converted into a zoo.

('21', 311, 1, 9, 722358) Mahatmaji, should one leave schools which are private and not run by the Government?

('21', 313, 1, 2, 726276) 182. THE KACHA GARHI INCIDENT
('21', 313, 2, 3, 726306) My attention has been drawn by Lieutenant Hewett of the 37th Dogras to certain statements which appeared in the issue of this paper on the 28th July last under the heading, “More about the Bulletted Muhajarin.” The report 1 in question which deals with the Kacha Garhi incident was communicated by Mr. H. J. Mohamed as the opening words showed.
('21', 313, 2, 4, 726651) Lieutenant Hewett denies the truth of various statements in the report and complains in particular of the following specific allegations, which he characterizes as false and malicious:
('21', 313, 3, 5, 726836) The officer kneeled upon the body and cut deep in the neck; and
('21', 313, 4, 6, 726900) They (i.
('21', 313, 4, 7, 726909) the British soldiers and the officers) were bent on murder and murder
('21', 313, 5, 8, 726979) in a cruel manner, for this alone could satisfy their lust for blood and appease
('21', 313, 6, 9, 727060) their anger.
('21', 313, 6, 10, 727073) Lieutenant Hewett informs me that he was the only officer travelling by the train referred to in this report or present on the occasion referred to therein, and he denies that there is any truth whatever in these allegations which he says clearly refer to him.
('21', 313, 6, 11, 727334) On another page of the same issue of Young India, there appeared an article 2 by me in which I said that “If the facts set forth in the statement are true they reflect the greatest discredit on the so called soldiers who took wanton delight in killing a man who was endeavouring to protect the honour of women”, but I was careful to advise my readers to suspend their judgement till they had the Government version before them.
('21', 313, 6, 12, 727762) I gladly publish the repudiation by Lieutenant Hewett.
('21', 313, 6, 13, 727817) The public thus have the original statement and a contradiction by the officer concerned.
('21', 313, 6, 14, 727907) There is now all the greater reason for suspension of judgment till the result of the inquiry is before the public.

('21', 314, 1, 2, 728168) 183. REPRESSION IN THE PUNJAB

('21', 316, 3, 16, 734124) 184. THE HALLUCINATION OF SCHOOLS AND COLLEGES
('21', 316, 4, 17, 734171) Much is being said and written against the proposed boycott of Government controlled schools and colleges.
('21', 316, 4, 18, 734278) The proposal has been descibed as “mischievous”, “harmful”, “opposed to the best interest of the country”, etc.
('21', 316, 4, 19, 734390) Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviyaji is among its most uncompromising opponents.
('21', 316, 4, 20, 734464) I have been taxing myself to the best of my capacity in order to discover my error.
('21', 316, 4, 21, 734548) But the effort has resulted in deepening my conviction that it is sinful to receive any education under the control of the present Government, no matter how high its quality may be, even as it would be to take the richest milk when it is tainted with poison.
('21', 316, 4, 22, 734807) I ask myself why some see the truth of the proposition quite clearely whilst others, the accepted leaders, condemn it as an error.
('21', 316, 4, 23, 734938) The answer I have been able to find is that the latter do not consider the present system of Government as an unmixed evil as the former do.
('21', 316, 4, 24, 735079) In other words, the opponents do not sufficiently realize the significance of the Punjab and the khilafat wrongs.
('21', 316, 4, 25, 735193) They do not feel as others do that the activity of the present Government is injurious to national growth.
('21', 316, 4, 26, 735300) I know that this is a serious statement to make.

('21', 317, 1, 5, 735663) I am equally positive that they would not send their children to a school managed, controlled or even influenced by a robber who had robbed them of their possessions.

('21', 318, 2, 9, 738661) 185. THE MEANING OF THE EMPIRE
('21', 318, 3, 10, 738692) The following circular has been issued by the Education Department:
('21', 318, 4, 11, 738760) Teachers and educational officers of this Presidency should be asked to co operate in bringing about a right understanding of the meaning of the Empire and in dispelling the idea that the Empire is based on force and militarism, by encouraging the parties concerned to look upon each other as brethren in advancement of the liberal aims and mutual friendship and sympathy particularly in India where a contrary feeling is gaining ground.

('21', 318, 4, 13, 739236) The circular in my opinion is a triumph of non co operation.
('21', 318, 4, 14, 739297) We have been often told authoritatively that the Empire is based finally on force.
('21', 318, 4, 15, 739380) When an attempt is being made to isolate this force, and to show by not meeting it by force that it is utterly useless when it is not backed by co operation, conscious or unconscious, of the people, we have a circular calling upon the teachers to co operate in showing that the Empire is based not on force or millitarism but that it is based on mutual friendship.
('21', 318, 4, 16, 739745) This I consider a triumph of non co operation because force recedes into the background.
('21', 318, 4, 17, 739834) Sir Michael O’Dwyer flaunted his brute force in the face of the nation, and terrorism reigned supreme for a time.
('21', 318, 4, 18, 739948) It did not answer.

('21', 318, 4, 24, 740212) It is a vain attempt to expect to secure friendship by false

('21', 320, 1, 2, 742261) 186. MR. PENNINGTON’S OBJECTIONS ANSWERED
('21', 320, 2, 3, 742303) I gladly publish Mr. Pennington’s 1 letter 2 with its enclosure 3 just as I have received them.
('21', 320, 2, 4, 742399) Evidently Mr. Pennington is not a regular reader of Young India, or he would have noticed that no one has condemned mob outrages more than I have.
('21', 320, 2, 5, 742546) He seems to think that the article 4 he has objected to was the only thing I have ever written on General Dyer.
('21', 320, 2, 6, 742658) He does not seem to know that I have endeavoured with the utmost impartiality to examine the Jallianwala massacre.
('21', 320, 2, 7, 742773) And he can see any day all the proof adduced by my fellow comissioners and myself in support of our findings on the massacre.
('21', 320, 2, 8, 742899) The ordinary readers of Young India knew all the facts and therefore it was unnecessary for me to support my assertions otherwise.
('21', 320, 2, 9, 743030) But unfortunately Mr. Pennington represents the typical Englishman.
('21', 320, 2, 10, 743098) He does not want to be unjust, nevertheless he is rarely just in his appreciation of world events because he has no time to study them except cursorily and that through a press whose business is to air only party views.
('21', 320, 2, 11, 743318) The average Englishman therefore except in parochial matters is perhaps the least informed though he claims to be well informed about every variety of interest.
('21', 320, 2, 12, 743479) Mr. Pennington’s ignorance is thus typical of the others and affords the best reason for securing control of our own affairs in our own hands.
('21', 320, 2, 13, 743622) Ability will come with use and not by waiting to be trained by those whose natural interest is to prolong the period of tutelage as much as possible.
('21', 320, 2, 14, 743772) But to return to Mr. Pennington’s letter he complains that there has been no “proper trial of anyone”.
('21', 320, 2, 15, 743875) The fault is not ours.
('21', 320, 2, 16, 743898) India has consistently and insistently demanded a trial of all the officers concerned in the crimes against the Punjab.

('21', 323, 1, 2, 749058) 187. SPEECH AT TEACHERS’ MEETING, AHMEDABAD
('21', 323, 2, 3, 749102) September 29, 1920 I was myself a teacher once and can still claim to be one.
('21', 323, 2, 4, 749180) I have had some experience in education, having carried out experiments in it.
('21', 323, 2, 5, 749259) As a result of these experiments, I have come to the conclusion that a nation whose teachers have lost their manhood can never rise.
('21', 323, 3, 6, 749392) Our teachers have indeed lost manhood.
('21', 323, 3, 7, 749431) They do under force what, otherwise, they would not do.
('21', 323, 3, 8, 749487) No physical force is used on them, but they are subjected to a subtle kind of pressure.
('21', 323, 3, 9, 749575) Teachers get frightened by threats from their superiors, by threats or hints of cuts in their salaries or stoppage of increments.
('21', 323, 4, 10, 749705) We are now faced with a situation in which teachers—both men and women—should risk their lives, their belongings and their salaries and, courageously, put the situation before the students as it is.
('21', 323, 4, 11, 749904) If they cannot do so, they should give up teaching as their means of livelihood.
('21', 323, 4, 12, 749985) My task for the day will be done when I have explained this to the teachers.
('21', 323, 4, 13, 750062) A great teacher like Shri Shastriar is in the opposite camp.
('21', 323, 4, 14, 750123) Even Pandit Malaviya, founder of an institution like the [Benares] Hindu University, is of the opinion that I am leading the public on the wrong path.
('21', 323, 4, 15, 750274) Those who belong to the nationalist camp also have their doubts.
('21', 323, 4, 16, 750339) Even so I believe I am right.
('21', 323, 4, 17, 750369) A gentlemen who has come from Baghdad recounted to me his experiences there.

('21', 323, 4, 20, 750528) If I did not think of non co operation all the twenty four hours,—even when I go to bed it is this thought which calms my mind—it would have been impossible for me to live in this country.
('21', 323, 4, 21, 750717) I think the illiterate Arabs of Baghdad are infinitely more advanced than we.

('21', 326, 2, 4, 756764) 188. NEED FOR FIRMNESS AND COURAGE
('21', 326, 3, 5, 756799) Probably, very few people know the signifiance of the war we are fighting.
('21', 326, 3, 6, 756874) A gentleman asked me : “Can our activities be described as war?” I had no hesitation in replying : “Our struggle has all the attributes of a war.” The thing that we want, namely, swaraj, is not to be had without fighting and, therefore, all the means we employ must be those used in a war.
('21', 326, 3, 7, 757164) That is to say, we must suspend our normal work and attend to the duty forced on us by circumstances.
('21', 326, 3, 8, 757266) The only difference, or rather the one great difference, between our struggle and a war is that there is no scope for brute force or armed might in our struggle; in fact, the use of physical force will mean our defeat.
('21', 326, 3, 9, 757485) The other characteristics of our struggle are those of an ordinary war.
('21', 326, 3, 10, 757557) As in the usual kind of war, so in this, too, self sacrifice, training, planning, and so on are indispen sable.
('21', 326, 3, 11, 757669) During a war, people suspend their normal work; in the face of a general threat, people forget their individual misfortunes.
('21', 326, 3, 12, 757794) The immoral becomes moral, the robber gives up robbing, the drunkard, drinking, the debauchee gives up his debauchery and the thief, his thieving.
('21', 326, 3, 13, 757941) There is but one thing on the lips of all : the country’s freedom.
('21', 326, 3, 14, 758008) In a crisis of this kind, people have no time to go to law courts; the students join the struggle for national freedom and look upon their part in it as their studies.
('21', 326, 3, 15, 758176) At such a time, though, the qualities which shine best are firmness and courage.
('21', 326, 3, 16, 758257) These are the qualities needed most.
('21', 326, 3, 17, 758294) Not to go back on one’s decision is firmness.
('21', 326, 3, 18, 758340) To leave a Government school today, torepent the next day and on the third day to seek readmission to the same school is no firmness.
('21', 326, 3, 19, 758474) Such weakness will bring about the downfall of the nation, will not raise it.
('21', 326, 3, 20, 758552) The teacher who submits his resignation today and withdraws it the next day does greater harm to the nation than the one who does not resign at all.
('21', 326, 3, 21, 758701) Courage lies in going ahead with one’s work in the face of difficulties and risks.
('21', 326, 3, 22, 758784) During a war, courage is in greater demand than the shrewdness of a business man.
('21', 326, 3, 23, 758866) This shrewdness is needed during peace time.
('21', 327, 0, 1, 758911) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 327, 1, 2, 758953) things are unsettled, the thing needed is courage : Gujarat is famous for her commercial shrewdness, and it seems quite a natural thing that the commercially inclined should lack courage.
('21', 327, 1, 3, 759141) This supposition is not proper.
('21', 327, 1, 4, 759173) As a nation cannot thrive on just one aptitude, so too an individual cannot.
('21', 327, 1, 5, 759250) Hence, every individual is endowd with the quality of courage.
('21', 327, 1, 6, 759313) It is only when we have no need to use it that we feel we lack it.
('21', 327, 1, 7, 759380) The time has come for Gujarat, for the whole of India, to show her courage.
('21', 327, 1, 8, 759456) “Where is the scope for courage when no physical force is to be used?” I hope no one will raise such vain doubts.
('21', 327, 1, 9, 759570) In truth, courage does not lie in using physical force.
('21', 327, 1, 10, 759626) The elephant does not exhibit courage when he goes along crushing ants underfoot, but he shows it when he fights a lion with all his strength, for in doing so he risks his life.
('21', 327, 1, 11, 759804) The potter exhibits no courage in twisting his donkey’s ear, but the lion hearted man opposing a band of robbers exhibits courage, for it is plain that he puts his life in danger.
('21', 327, 1, 12, 759984) The man who refrains from using physical force and yet, refusing to submit, fights on, shows the highest courage.
('21', 327, 1, 13, 760098) What is courage, indeed?
('21', 327, 1, 14, 760123) India has, in this unarmed war, an opportunity to show such courage.
('21', 327, 1, 15, 760192) The student who leaves his school without thinking of the future or of education shows real courage, while the one who leaves only when another school is provided shows the shrewdness of a business man.
('21', 327, 1, 16, 760395) The pleader who boycotts the Government’s law courts without considering whether or not he will then be able to maintain himself shows courage; the one who boycotts them only after making alternative arrangements for his livelihood may show worldly wisdom but he certainly exhibits no courage.
('21', 327, 1, 17, 760689) To plunge into a thing with faith and without any fear of consequences is courage.
('21', 327, 1, 18, 760772) Where there is timidity, there can be no courage.
('21', 327, 1, 19, 760822) Our people are afflicted with timidity.
('21', 327, 1, 20, 760862) To talk of winning while clinging to this is to indulge in self contradiction.
('21', 327, 1, 21, 760941) We shall need an enterprising spirit and shall have to take risks at every step.
('21', 327, 1, 22, 761022) On a battle field, they often brave dangers under compulsion; in our struggle, we brave them willingly, and can achieve much at a small risk.
('21', 327, 1, 23, 761164) The steps we are to take by way of non co operation are such as involve very little danger.
('21', 327, 1, 24, 761256) And yet, if the people respond well, I am sure we shall be enjoying swaraj in a very short time.
('21', 327, 1, 25, 761353) However, the people will certainly expect the educated classes to show firmness and courage in taking these steps.
('21', 327, 1, 26, 761468) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 3 10 1920
('21', 328, 0, 1, 761505) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 329
('21', 328, 1, 2, 761550) 189. TRUTH AND KHILAFAT
('21', 328, 2, 3, 761574) All dharma culminates in truth.
('21', 328, 2, 4, 761606) Truth is God.
('21', 328, 2, 5, 761620) There is no dharma which is above truth.
('21', 328, 2, 6, 761661) Undoubtedly, truth is difficult to follow.
('21', 328, 2, 7, 761704) If a man can be truthful both in thought and word, he will need nothing more.
('21', 328, 2, 8, 761782) He will find in truth everything else.
('21', 328, 2, 9, 761821) The path of truth is only for the brave.
('21', 328, 2, 10, 761862) “Truth” is a simple word.
('21', 328, 2, 11, 761888) Anyone who fails to follow it in his dealings will lose his honour and his credit.
('21', 328, 2, 12, 761971) If some dirt mixes with a quantity of milk, all of it is considered impure; likewise, the value of words otherwise unblemished is diminished if falsehood mixes with them.
('21', 328, 2, 13, 762142) Thus, it is not only for an ill spoken word that one has to pay; even innocent things are regarded as evil when mixed with evil.
('21', 328, 2, 14, 762271) Maulana Zafar Ali Khan’s case provides an instance of this truth.

('21', 338, 4, 6, 785227) 195. SPEECH TO STUDENTS AND TEACHERS 1, SURAT
('21', 338, 5, 7, 785273) October 6, 1920 You must have read a summary of my speech to students in Ahmedabad.
('21', 338, 5, 8, 785357) I want to talk to you about some of the things I said to them.
('21', 338, 5, 9, 785420) I shall talk to your elders in the evening.
('21', 338, 5, 10, 785464) 2 Wherever I go, I like to keep alive the close contacts which I have established with students.
('21', 338, 5, 11, 785561) Being myself a father of four sons, I understand the son’s duty towards his parents.
('21', 338, 5, 12, 785646) I was myself a son once and some persons whom I respect as elders are still living.
('21', 338, 5, 13, 785730) Hence I know very well the duty that sons owe to fathers.
('21', 338, 5, 14, 785788) A son can be advised to disobey his father, if the occasion demands this.
('21', 338, 5, 15, 785862) I may thus seem to be giving contradictory advice.
('21', 338, 5, 16, 785913) What I am going to say to you, I have already told my sons.
('21', 338, 5, 17, 785973) I have a good many sons, have had quite a few children entrusted to my care and I have brought them up.
('21', 338, 5, 18, 786077) Only yesterday, a couple belonging to one of the untouchable communities expressed their desire to entrust their daughter 3 to my care.
('21', 338, 5, 19, 786213) The girl has stayed with me before now.
('21', 338, 5, 20, 786253) I told her father that he could leave Lakshmi with me only if he gave up all claims on her.
('21', 338, 5, 21, 786345) I did not make this condition with all parents who entrusted their children to me.
('21', 338, 5, 22, 786428) Even so, I regard as my very own the children whom I have brought up.
('21', 338, 5, 23, 786498) I have given my sons advice no less harsh than what I give the students these days.
('21', 338, 5, 24, 786582) On the right occasion, you can rise against me, your parents and the whole world.

('21', 339, 1, 2, 787098) as Prahlad sacrificed his father.

('21', 339, 1, 25, 789069) People do not respect it as they should.

('21', 350, 2, 4, 814197) The man who finds no time during the whole day for prayers and ablutions is a thief stealing what belongs to God.
('21', 350, 2, 5, 814311) Following the same principle, the swarajist who understands that swaraj is to be won through non co operation must keep an account from day to day and ask himself at the end of each day : 1. “How many title holders did I request today to renounce their titles?” 2. If he has not withdrawn his children from schools and colleges, “Why have I delayed so long?
('21', 350, 2, 6, 814669) How many other parents have I persuaded to do this?” 3. “Why have I failed so far to give up legal practice?

('21', 350, 2, 11, 815225) How many weavers did I help by encouragement?” 8. “Since I believe that swaraj is impossible without self sacrifice, selfless work and discipline, what further self sacrifice did I make today?
('21', 350, 2, 12, 815418) How many persons in my own locality or village did I inspire to work for this movement?
('21', 350, 2, 13, 815506) How much of my time and money did I spend in doing so?” Every swarajist must put such questions to himself every day and, if the answers are not satisfactory, he must do some act of penance and increase his efforts the following day.

('21', 351, 3, 16, 817192) Two students of the Grant Medical College, Bombay, who were due for their final examination, left the College without taking the examination.
('21', 351, 3, 17, 817334) Two others were reading for a post graduate course.

('21', 353, 3, 19, 822108) Personally, I am convinced that the present salaries of primary school teachers are very low.

('21', 362, 1, 29, 843690) Had he done injustice only to me, I would not have entered into an argument; but he has done injustice to non co

('21', 363, 0, 1, 843814) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 363, 1, 2, 843856) operation.
('21', 363, 1, 3, 843867) I do not regard anyone as my follower.
('21', 363, 1, 4, 843906) Those who approve of my ideas are followers of those ideas [not of me].
('21', 363, 1, 5, 843978) Those who act contrary to my ideas are followers neither of me nor of the ideas.
('21', 363, 1, 6, 844059) As we may not abandon good work lest someone should see it in a wrong light, so also a movement like non co operation which is otherwise considered essential may not be abandoned for fear that it might lend itself to abuses.
('21', 363, 1, 7, 844284) The Gita is misinterpreted by many people, but this is no reason why it should be condemned or abandoned.
('21', 363, 1, 8, 844390) So called Christians plunder others in the name of Christianity, but this is the fault neither of the Christian religion nor of its founder.
('21', 363, 1, 9, 844531) A misdeed of the Government cannot be concealed simply because its exposure is likely to make people more angry with it.
('21', 363, 1, 10, 844652) There is no virtue in being free from ill will for the blameless.
('21', 363, 1, 11, 844718) Not to entertain ill will even for the guilty—this alone lends lustre to the virtue.
('21', 363, 1, 12, 844803) Hence it is that, though I point to the great evils of the British Empire, I restrain the bitter feelings which they rouse, check violence and show to the people the royal road of bringing about a change of heart in the British or making them leave India through non co operation.
('21', 363, 1, 13, 845084) This will intensify the bitterness for a while.
('21', 363, 1, 14, 845132) There will also be trouble from insane persons, like this “Bolshevism”; if there is, I shall try to cheek it, of course, but I consider it less intolerable than that the British Empire should continue as it is today.

('21', 363, 1, 17, 845613) The candidate who received the letter has said a few things in anger; I entreat him to banish his anger.

('21', 363, 1, 19, 845929) Is it right, out of anger, to harm the country’s interest?
('21', 363, 1, 20, 845988) It would be altogether wrong now to seek election to legislatures in opposition to public opinion.
('21', 363, 1, 21, 846087) What epithet can describe the action of a candidate who enters the legislature, though forbidden by the very voters with whose votes he aspires to be elected?
('21', 363, 1, 22, 846246) We have, therefore, but one golden rule.
('21', 363, 1, 23, 846287) Those who believe

('21', 364, 1, 2, 846350) that the councils will open the gate to freedom and those, like me, who believe them to be a death trap for the country, should patiently explain to the voters the possible benefits and dangers and act as the latter wish.
('21', 364, 1, 3, 846572) If they wish to elect anyone, persons of my view should not hinder them; likewise, if the voters plainly show their opposition, it is the duty of intending candidates not to seek election.
('21', 364, 1, 4, 846761) If the opponents of council entry use coercion, they will be committing a sin; if candidates enter councils against all opposition, they will be committing a heinous sin.
('21', 364, 1, 5, 846932) There is here no problem of conscience for the candidates, for their duty is to enter the legishature only if the voters in their constituency want them to.

('21', 365, 5, 8, 848218) 212. SPEECH AT AMRITSAR
('21', 365, 6, 9, 848242) October 18, 1920
('21', 365, 7, 10, 848259) Mr. Gandhi .
('21', 365, 7, 11, 848272) began his speech in Hindi amid shouts of Allah o Akbar and Sat Sri Akal.
('21', 365, 7, 12, 848345) He said, Mr. Mahomed Ali had told them what was taking place at
('21', 365, 8, 13, 848409) present in England.
('21', 365, 8, 14, 848429) It was being considered how to secure all the approaches to India.
('21', 365, 8, 15, 848496) If the Govern ment was taking possession of Persia and Iraq, it was to ensure the perpetuation of India’s dependence.
('21', 365, 8, 16, 848614) A man could not serve two masters.
('21', 365, 8, 17, 848649) If Indians acknowledged the English as their masters, it meant that they had forgotten their great to whom they had sworn allegiance from their very birth.
('21', 365, 8, 18, 848805) The only alternative before them now was to relinquish their God or to relinquish the Government.
('21', 365, 8, 19, 848903) The only two ways to attain swaraj were the sword and non co operation.
('21', 365, 8, 20, 848975) The Hindus and Mussulmans had already accepted the latter.
('21', 365, 8, 21, 849034) Although some people had confidence in the sword, too, to win swaraj, he had not.
('21', 365, 8, 22, 849116) They could not free India by burning houses and committing murders.
('21', 365, 8, 23, 849184) There were two condi tions precedent to win swaraj, complete unity and sacrifice.
('21', 365, 8, 24, 849266) The latter was only possible if they decided upon non co operation with the Government.
('21', 365, 8, 25, 849354) If they did that they could achieve swaraj in one year.
('21', 365, 8, 26, 849410) They lacked discipline which they must cultivate.
('21', 365, 8, 27, 849460) As long as there was no discipline in towns and villages liberty was impossible.
('21', 365, 8, 28, 849541) There should be unity and confidence.
('21', 365, 8, 29, 849579) They must remember that fear and slavery could live side by side but not fear and love.
('21', 365, 8, 30, 849667) God wanted pure sacrifice.
('21', 365, 8, 31, 849694) They must be pure.
('21', 365, 8, 32, 849713) They must leave Government courts, schools, service, councils, and titles and wear home spun khaddar.
('21', 365, 8, 33, 849815) He asked the Amritsar lawyers with what face they now practised in the courts which had disgraced and humiliated them so much during the martial law days.
('21', 365, 8, 34, 849970) Unless they relinquished practice the salvation of India was impossible through them.
('21', 365, 8, 35, 850056) Could they send their boys to schools where they had been made to walk 16

('21', 367, 2, 5, 853128) 214. SPEECH ON NON CO OPERATION, LAHORE2
('21', 367, 3, 6, 853169) October 19, 1920
('21', 367, 4, 7, 853186) Mahatma Gandhi said that he was glad to find Zafar Ali in jail, because according to him Zafar Ali became free by being put inside the jail.
('21', 367, 4, 8, 853327) The only place for those who did their duty by the people and the Government was the prison house.
('21', 367, 4, 9, 853426) The speaker had read the charges against Zafar Ali.
('21', 367, 4, 10, 853478) Zafar Ali had said that if Government did not do justice on the matter of the khilafat, Government would perish and had asked his audience to repeat that statement after him.
('21', 367, 4, 11, 853653) This was the principal charge against Zafar Ali.
('21', 367, 4, 12, 853702) The speaker said that he would proceed a step further.
('21', 367, 4, 13, 853757) He wanted the audience to repeat after him not only that if the Government would not do justice in the matter of the khilafat, Government could perish but also that they would deem it their duty to destroy it.
('21', 367, 4, 14, 853967) (The audience repeated this after Mahatma Gandhi.) The speaker said that the way to release Zafar Ali was to do their duty loyally by the people and to push on the non co operation propaganda.
('21', 367, 4, 15, 854160) In that event, Government could not send any of their leaders to jail.
('21', 367, 4, 16, 854231) He was glad to be told that that in spite of being kept in a dark narrow cell, being supplied with the jail food though he was yet an under trial prisoner, and in spite of his being in bad health for these reasons, Government was not able to break Zafar Ali and he would not apologize.
('21', 367, 4, 17, 854517) It was not for the people to pray to Government for Zafar Ali’s release.
('21', 367, 4, 18, 854590) It would be a sin to do so.
('21', 367, 4, 19, 854618) They would not ask favours from Government.
('21', 367, 5, 20, 854662) The speaker next referred to the bravery of the Sikhs during the War and said that they had saved the British Empire and had cut the throats of the Turks, the Arabs and the Egyptians at the bidding of their task master.
('21', 367, 5, 21, 854882) What was their reward?
('21', 367, 5, 22, 854905) Let them ask Gohar Singh of Sheikhupura.
('21', 367, 5, 23, 854946) Let them ask the Sikh ladies of Manianwala.
('21', 367, 6, 24, 854990) The speaker emphatically declared that violence was not to be encouraged.
('21', 367, 6, 25, 855064) He was sorry to see the great ovation given to Mr. Mahomed Ali when he said that it

('21', 368, 1, 2, 855325) might be necessary in the future for us to unsheath the sword and proclaim jehad.

('21', 368, 3, 22, 857511) He would be the man who would fear God and love truth and would be impervious to everthing else.

('21', 369, 1, 2, 858240) 215. FROM RIDICULE TO—?
('21', 369, 2, 3, 858264) It will be admitted that non co operation has passed the stage of ridicule.
('21', 369, 2, 4, 858340) Whether it will now be met by repression or respect remains to be seen.
('21', 369, 2, 5, 858412) Opinion has already been expressed in these columns1 that ridicule is an approved and civilized method of opposition.
('21', 369, 2, 6, 858530) The Viceregal ridicule though expressed in unnecessarily impolite terms was not open to exception.
('21', 369, 2, 7, 858629) But the testing time has now arrived.
('21', 369, 2, 8, 858667) In a civilized country when ridicule fails to kill a movement it begins to command respect.
('21', 369, 2, 9, 858759) Opponents meet it by respectful and cogent argument and the mutual behaviour of rival parties never becomes violent.
('21', 369, 2, 10, 858876) Each party seeks to convert the other or draw the uncertain element towards its side by pure argument and reasoning.
('21', 369, 2, 11, 858993) There is little doubt now that the boycott of the councils will be extensive if it is not complete.
('21', 369, 2, 12, 859093) The students have become disturbed.
('21', 369, 2, 13, 859129) Important institutions may any day become truly national.
('21', 369, 2, 14, 859187) Pandit Motilal Nehru’s great renunciation of a legal practice which was probably second to nobody’s is by itself an event calculated to change ridicule into respect.
('21', 369, 2, 15, 859353) It ought to set people thinking seriously about their own attitude.
('21', 369, 2, 16, 859421) There must be something very wrong about our Government—to warrant the step Pandit Motilal Nehru has taken.
('21', 369, 2, 17, 859529) Post graduate students have given up their fellowships.
('21', 369, 2, 18, 859585) Medical students have refused to appear for their final examination.
('21', 369, 2, 19, 859654) Non co operation in these circumstances cannot be called an inane movement.
('21', 369, 2, 20, 859730) Either the Government must bend to the will of the people which is being expressed in no unmistakable terms through non co operation, or it must attempt to crush the movement by repression.
('21', 369, 2, 21, 859920) Any force used by a government under any circumstance is not repression.
('21', 369, 2, 22, 859993) An open trial of a person accused of having advocated methods of violence is not repression.
('21', 369, 2, 23, 860086) Every State has the right to put down violence by force.
('21', 369, 2, 24, 860143) But the trial of Mr. Zafar Ali Khan and two moulvis of Panipat shows that the Government is seeking not to put down or prevent violence but to suppress expression of opinion, to prevent spread of disaffection.
('21', 369, 2, 25, 860353) This is repression.
('21', 369, 2, 26, 860373) The trials are the beginning of it.
('21', 369, 2, 27, 860409) It has not still assumed a virulent form but if these trials do not result in stifling the propaganda, it is highly likely that
('21', 369, 3, 28, 860537) 1 Vide “Ridicule Replacing Respression”, 1 9 1920.
('21', 370, 0, 1, 860588) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 371
('21', 370, 1, 2, 860633) severe repression will be resorted to by the Government.
('21', 370, 1, 3, 860690) The only other way to prevent the spread of disaffection is to remove the causes thereof.
('21', 370, 1, 4, 860780) And that would be to respect the growing response of the country to the programme of non co operation.
('21', 370, 1, 5, 860883) It is too much to expect repentance and humility from a government intoxicated with success and power.
('21', 370, 1, 6, 860986) We must therefore assume that the second stage in the Government programme will be repression growing in violence in the same ratio as the progress of non co operation.
('21', 370, 1, 7, 861155) And if the movement survives repression, the day of victory of truth is near.
('21', 370, 1, 8, 861233) We must then be prepared for prosecutions, punishments even up to deportations.
('21', 370, 1, 9, 861313) We must evolve the capacity for going on with our programme without the leaders.
('21', 370, 1, 10, 861394) That means capacity for self government.
('21', 370, 1, 11, 861435) And as no government in the world can possibly put a whole nation in prison, it must yield to its demand or abdicate in favour of a government suited to that nation.
('21', 370, 1, 12, 861601) It is clear that abstention from violence and persistence in the programme are our only and surest chance of attaining our end.
('21', 370, 1, 13, 861729) The Government has its choice, either to respect the movement or to try to repress it by barbarous methods.
('21', 370, 1, 14, 861837) Our choice is either to succumb to repression or to continue in spite of repression.
('21', 370, 1, 15, 861922) Young India, 20 10 1920
('21', 370, 2, 16, 861946) 216. NECESSITY OF DISCIPLINE
('21', 370, 3, 17, 861975) I have already remarked upon my experiences of want of method and discipline in Madras.
('21', 370, 3, 18, 862063) The same want is being noticed during the tour in the Rohelkhund.
('21', 370, 3, 19, 862129) Everywhere there is chaos and disorder not for want of men but because of volunteers without training.
('21', 370, 3, 20, 862232) They are called upon to handle a situation and crowds that are unprecedented.
('21', 370, 3, 21, 862310) There is more noise and bustle than work.
('21', 370, 3, 22, 862352) Maulana Shaukat Ali is the indefatigable organizer.
('21', 370, 3, 23, 862404) He wants to satisfy all parties and therefore packs too many events in any programme he arranges.
('21', 370, 3, 24, 862502) To take only one instance.
('21', 370, 3, 25, 862529) He accepted for one single day a motor ride from Aligarh to Hathras, thence to Etah and from Etah to Kasgunj with the prospect of a slow night journey from Kasgunj to Cawnpore.
('21', 370, 3, 26, 862706) The motor ride covered a distance of 90 miles.
('21', 370, 3, 27, 862753) After a trying meeting of workers at Aligarh early in the morning, we got into our motors at 9.45 a.m.
('21', 370, 3, 28, 862856) and reached Hathras at
('21', 371, 0, 1, 862879) 372 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 371, 1, 2, 862921) about 11 a.m.
('21', 371, 1, 3, 862935) The sun was burning hot and fierce.
('21', 371, 1, 4, 862971) The inevitable noisy procession was there.
('21', 371, 1, 5, 863014) It was followd by a huge meeting involving an intolerable strain on the voice of the strongest speaker.
('21', 371, 1, 6, 863118) We however got for our pains resignations of three honorary magis tracies.
('21', 371, 1, 7, 863193) We motored thence to Etah.
('21', 371, 1, 8, 863220) There was a little more order there than at Hathras.
('21', 371, 1, 9, 863273) Soon after finishing Etah we motored to Kasgunj.
('21', 371, 1, 10, 863322) We had accidents during the jouney, the cars refusing to move.
('21', 371, 1, 11, 863385) With difficulty we reached Kasgunj, Maulana Shaukat Ali and his companions not reaching in time for the train.
('21', 371, 1, 12, 863496) We had several resignations at Etah.
('21', 371, 1, 13, 863533) The meeting at Kasgunj for its enormous size was well managed but not without difficulty.
('21', 371, 1, 14, 863623) Touching the feet has become an uncontrollable performance causing much waste of time and involving danger when it is resorted to in the midst of a large crowd.
('21', 371, 1, 15, 863784) But the most wretched experience was the night journey from Kas gunj to Cawnpore.
('21', 371, 1, 16, 863866) It was made most uncomfortable by crowds attending at every station.
('21', 371, 1, 17, 863935) They were everywhere insistent and assertive.

('21', 376, 16, 26, 876255) 221. SWARAJYA SABHA
('21', 376, 17, 27, 876275) The “All India Home Rule League” will henceforth be known as “Swarajya Sabha”.
('21', 376, 17, 28, 876354) Its constitution has been changed.
('21', 376, 17, 29, 876389) I must confess that I always disliked the term “Home Rule”.
('21', 376, 17, 30, 876449) If we are to know even our highest ideal under a foreign name, why not have it as our ideal to turn ourselves into foreigners?
('21', 376, 17, 31, 876576) I know some highly educated Indians who believe that India’s salvation is possible only through immitation of Western ways and ideals.
('21', 376, 17, 32, 876711) One of these Indians

('21', 377, 1, 4, 876859) If, in most things, he prefers the Western way, it is not for self interest.
('21', 377, 1, 5, 876936) Somehow he feels that only by turning ourselves into their like shall we be able to meet the English as their equals.
('21', 377, 1, 6, 877054) Some Indians, converts to Christianity, believe that the country’s salvation is impossible until both Hindus and Muslims have become Christians.
('21', 377, 1, 7, 877199) However, just as we would not have it as our ideal to turn ourselves into Englishmen or Christians, so also I did not like the phrase “Home Rule”.
('21', 377, 1, 8, 877346) The meaning, the force, to be found in “swaraj” are not present in “Home Rule”.
('21', 377, 1, 9, 877426) Hindus and Muslims, all—even illiterate people—can understand the term “swaraj”, but not “Home Rule”.
('21', 377, 1, 10, 877528) We have, therefore, dropped Home Rule and given to “swaraj” its rightful place.
('21', 377, 1, 11, 877608) Besides this, there are other important changes which are worth noting.
('21', 377, 1, 12, 877680) The aim, so far, was to secure Home Rule within the British Empire, like what the Colonies enjoy.
('21', 377, 1, 13, 877778) Instead, the aim now will be to strive for swaraj of people’s choice.
('21', 377, 1, 14, 877848) The means have always been a subject of controversy and, therefore, we have limited ourselves to all effective means which are peaceful and legitimate.
('21', 377, 1, 15, 878000) That is to say, the ideal now before us is to achieve swaraj without recourse to violence.
('21', 377, 1, 16, 878091) The Congress is the people’s organ.

('21', 377, 1, 21, 878560) They have been made after much thought and discussion.

('21', 381, 3, 9, 887743) 223. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH
('21', 381, 4, 10, 887771) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, October 25, 1920
('21', 381, 5, 11, 887811) DEAR MR. JINNAH, I have just returned from an exhausting tour.
('21', 381, 5, 12, 887874) I have received the letter addressed to me by you and 19 other friends, tendering your resignation of the membership of the Swaraj Sabha, till lately known as the All India Home Rule League.
('21', 381, 5, 13, 888065) I am exceedingly sorry that you and your co signatories have thought fit to take the very serious step you have.
('21', 381, 5, 14, 888178) The reasons given by you are that the procedure adopted at the meeting at which the change was made was “contrary to the rules and regulations of the League” and that my ruling validating the procedure was both incorrect and arbitrary.
('21', 381, 5, 15, 888414) I venture to think that the procedure adopted was in accordance with the rules and regulations and that my ruling was strictly correct.
('21', 381, 5, 16, 888550) The point you raised was that there was not a three fourths majority.
('21', 382, 0, 1, 888620) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 383
('21', 382, 1, 2, 888665) The regulations cited by you referred to a change in the constitution by the council of the League being legal only if it voted by a majority of three fourths.
('21', 382, 1, 3, 888825) The meeting at which the vote was taken was not a meeting of the council, but it was a general meeting of the League.
('21', 382, 1, 4, 888943) And my ruling was that as there was no rule, whereby the League had bound itself not to change its constitution except by a majority of three fourths, it was competent and proper for the League to alter its consti tution by a bare majority.
('21', 382, 1, 5, 889184) Had I accepted your deductive or inferential interpretation of the rules, I feel that my ruling would have been “illegal and arbitrary”.
('21', 382, 1, 6, 889321) Coming as the challenge did from you, for whose legal knowledge I have high regard, I have since the meeting endeavoured to examine my ruling and every one of the lawyers whom I have consulted tells me that it was not possible for me to give any ruling other than the one I gave.
('21', 382, 1, 7, 889601) Your second objection is that the new constitution omits mention of “British connection”, and that it is permissive of “unconstitutional and illegal activities”.
('21', 382, 1, 8, 889763) So far as British connection is concerned I think you are clearly wrong.
('21', 382, 1, 9, 889836) Because the meaning of the word “swaraj” is deliberately limited by the new constitution so as to keep the Sabha strictly loyal to the Congress creed.
('21', 382, 1, 10, 889987) Let me recall to you the discussion that took place before the important alteration was adopted.
('21', 382, 1, 11, 890084) Speaker after speaker made it clear that the interpretation clause was purposely introduced to keep the affiliation of the Sabha pure and above board.
('21', 382, 1, 12, 890235) In my opinion, you may not allow yourselves to be affected by any sentiments expressed by the speakers, including myself.
('21', 382, 1, 13, 890357) If I could help it I would certainly make it clear in any creed as I have made it clear in my speeches, that I want my country to have swaraj whether with or without the British connection.
('21', 382, 1, 14, 890547) I am not opposed to that connection by itself but I do not wish to make a fetish of it.
('21', 382, 1, 15, 890635) I will not keep India for a single minute under slavery for the sake of that connection.
('21', 382, 1, 16, 890724) But I and those who think with me have limited our ambition in order that we can carry the Congress with us and be thus enabled to remain affiliated to that body.
('21', 382, 1, 17, 890887) I venture to suggest to you that your amendment and the original adopted by the Sabha, do not materially differ, except in so far as the original keeps unadulterated swaraj constantly before the country as an ideal to be worked for.
('21', 382, 1, 18, 891120) I should think, therefore, that your objection to the alteration is not so vital (if at all), as to warrant a separation.
('21', 382, 1, 19, 891242) There now remains for me to consider your objection to the methods.
('21', 382, 1, 20, 891310) I entirely dissent from your interpretation of sub clause 2,
('21', 383, 0, 1, 891371) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 383, 1, 2, 891413) that it permits “unconstitutional or illegal activities”.
('21', 383, 1, 3, 891471) You will admit that the words “unconstitutional” and “illegal” are highly technical terms.
('21', 383, 1, 4, 891562) An ex Advocate General of Madras considers non co operat ion to be unconstitutional.
('21', 383, 1, 5, 891647) If I have understood you correctly you consider it to be perfectly constitutional.
('21', 383, 1, 6, 891730) The president of the special Congress gave it as his considered ruling that my resolution was not unconstitutional.
('21', 383, 1, 7, 891846) As a not indifferent lawyer of 20 years’ unbroken practice, I confess it is difficult for me to conceive an illustration under the British constitution of unconstitutional activity except it be violence.
('21', 383, 1, 8, 892050) And violence has been specifically eschewed from the Sabha’s constitution.
('21', 383, 1, 9, 892125) Similarly, about the word “illegal”.
('21', 383, 1, 10, 892162) Jurists differed on its interpretation.
('21', 383, 1, 11, 892202) A cyclist cycling without a lamp to fetch a doctor acts contrary to law but does not engage in an “illegal” activity.
('21', 383, 1, 12, 892320) He voluntarily pays the fine and thus honours the law.
('21', 383, 1, 13, 892375) To disregard a tyrannical administrative order may be contrary to law but it is not in my opinion an “illegal activity”.
('21', 383, 1, 14, 892496) To make strong speeches amou nting in the opinion of an erratic judge to sedition is not an illegal activity.
('21', 383, 1, 15, 892606) In placing before you for your consideration these homely illustrations my purpose is to show that it is a most dangerous thing for a country, fighting for its very life, its honour and its religion, to tie itself down in a knot of indefinable expressions.
('21', 383, 1, 16, 892863) Surely all public bodies will think out for themselves the methods to be adopted for winning freedom for the country.
('21', 383, 1, 17, 892981) I personally hate unconstitution alism and illegalities, but I refuse to make a fetish of these as I refuse to make a fetish of the British connection.
('21', 383, 1, 18, 893133) I therefore, venture to ask you and friends to reconsider whether you have not hastily severed your connection with a body which you have hitherto nursed with industrious affection.
('21', 383, 1, 19, 893315) If you wish to take your share in the new life that has opened up before the country, and benefit the country by your experience and guidance, and if you do not consider that there is anything fundamentally opposed to your conscience, I invite you and your co signatories to reconsider your resignations.
('21', 383, 1, 20, 893620) But if, unfortunately, you cannot see your way to revise your decision I trust you will acquit the Sabha of any irregular procedure and me of any illegal or arbitrary conduct and base your decision on grounds other than those you have set forth in your letter.

('21', 384, 1, 2, 893972) 224. TO EVERY ENGLISHMAN IN INDIA
('21', 384, 2, 3, 894006) DEAR FRIEND, I wish that every Englishman will see this appeal and give thoughtful attention to it.
('21', 384, 2, 4, 894106) Let me introduce myself to you.
('21', 384, 2, 5, 894138) In my humble opinion, no Indian has co operated with the British Government more than I have for an unbroken period of twenty nine years of public life in the face of circumstances that might well have turned any other man into a rebel.
('21', 384, 2, 6, 894375) I ask you to believe me when I tell you that my co operation was not based on the fear of the punishments provided by your laws or any other selfish motives.
('21', 384, 2, 7, 894533) It was free and voluntary co operation based on the belief that the sum total of the activity of the British Government was for the benefit of India.
('21', 384, 2, 8, 894683) I put my life in peril four times for the sake of the Empire, —at the time of the Boer war when I was in charge of the Ambulance corps whose work was mentioned in General Buller’s dispatches, at the time of the Zulu revolt in Natal when I was in charge of a similar corps, at the time of the commencement of the late War when I raised an Ambulance corps and as a result of the strenuous training had a servere attack of pleurisy, and lastly, in fulfilment of my promise to Lord Chelmsford at the War Conference in Delhi, I threw myself in such an active recruiting campaign in Kaira District involving long and trying marches, that I had an attack of dysentery, which proved almost fatal.
('21', 384, 2, 9, 895372) I did all this in the full belief that acts such as mine must gain for my country an equal status in the Empire.
('21', 384, 2, 10, 895485) So late as last December I pleaded hard for a trustful co operation.
('21', 384, 2, 11, 895554) I fully believed that Mr. Lloyd George would redeem his promise to the Mussulmans and that the revelations of the official atrocities in the Punjab would secure full reparation for the Punjabis.
('21', 384, 2, 12, 895749) But the treachery of Mr. Lloyd George and its appreciation by you, and the condonation of the Punjab atrocities have completely shattered my faith in the good intentions of the Government and the nation which is supporting it.
('21', 384, 2, 13, 895976) But though my faith in your good intentions is gone, I recognize your bravery, and I know that what you will not yield to justice and reason, you will gladly yield to bravery.
('21', 384, 2, 14, 896152) See what this Empire means to India: Exploitation of India’s resources for the benefits of Great
