('21', 389, 3, 14, 907581) 226. ALIGARH
('21', 389, 4, 15, 907594) Aligarh is an old institution—forty five years old.
('21', 389, 4, 16, 907646) It has unique traditions.
('21', 389, 4, 17, 907672) It has a great record behind it.
('21', 389, 4, 18, 907705) It may claim to have given to India the Ali Brothers.
('21', 389, 4, 19, 907759) It is the best known centre of Islamic culture in India.
('21', 389, 5, 20, 907816) Why do I seek to destroy it?
('21', 389, 5, 21, 907845) Some Mussulmans easily think that I mean ill under the pretence of wishing well to Aligarh.
('21', 389, 5, 22, 907937) Little do they know that I am imploring Panditji to do to the Hindu University what I am asking the trustees to do to Aligarh, and I am certainly going to plead with the Benares students as earnestly as I have with the Aligarh boys.
('21', 389, 5, 23, 908170) I have done the same with the Khalsa College.
('21', 389, 5, 24, 908216) The latter is the only centre of Sikh culture.
('21', 389, 5, 25, 908263) I do desire passionately to destroy all these three institutions as they are, and would strive to raise purer and truer ones instead.
('21', 389, 5, 26, 908397) I deny that these institutions are in any way true representatives
('21', 390, 0, 1, 908464) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 391
('21', 390, 1, 2, 908509) of their respective cultures.
('21', 390, 1, 3, 908539) And as much as Islam is in peril at English hands, Hinduism and Sikhism are also in peril.
('21', 390, 1, 4, 908630) I asked an Aligarh professor whether he would preach complete independence for India as her goal if necessary, or if the institution as such could refuse to receive a Governor in his racial capacity.
('21', 390, 1, 5, 908830) He frankly admitted that it was not possible.
('21', 390, 1, 6, 908876) And yet I make bold to say that today the vast majority of the students of India have no regard or respect for British rule.
('21', 390, 1, 7, 909001) They are disgusted with it.
('21', 390, 1, 8, 909029) They have certainly no genuine affection for it.
('21', 390, 1, 9, 909078) I venture to submit that to keep boys in this false atmosphere is to teach them to deny their faith and for us to do violence to their respective cultures.
('21', 390, 1, 10, 909234) We will not make a nation of hypocrites.
('21', 390, 1, 11, 909275) With the knowledge we have of British intentions, it is unmanly—un Indian—for us to accept even a portion of our own money through hands stained with the blood of the innocents at Jallianwala.
('21', 390, 1, 12, 909468) We may as well accept gifts from a robber who has robbed us of our property.
('21', 390, 1, 13, 909545) This Government has robbed us of our honour and put one of our religions in peril.
('21', 390, 1, 14, 909628) In my humble opinion, it is a sin for nation to receive education in schools financed by or under the influence or control of the Government.
('21', 390, 1, 15, 909770) I have therefore no hesitation in advising immediate destruction of these institutions at all cost.
('21', 390, 1, 16, 909870) But if the trustees, the teachers and the parents or the boys will act in unison, there is no cost to be paid and eveything to be gained.
('21', 390, 1, 17, 910008) I am asking for the form to be changed, I do not seek to destroy the soul.
('21', 390, 1, 18, 910083) Even as we leave bodies which we have out grown, so must we leave the institutions which we have out grown, and bring into being others, more in accord with our needs.
('21', 390, 1, 19, 910251) How can scholastic institutions which represent the youth of a nation lag behind when the nation is marching forward?
('21', 390, 1, 20, 910369) Several high schools having a more or less distinguished record have thrown off the yoke of grant and affiliation in Gujarat.
('21', 390, 1, 21, 910495) They are none the worse for it.
('21', 390, 1, 22, 910527) They are all the purer for it.
('21', 390, 1, 23, 910558) The principals and the trustees can train the youth under their charge in a freer atmosphere.
('21', 390, 1, 24, 910652) Financial considerations deter those who do not want to work.
('21', 390, 1, 25, 910714) Our institutions will collapse if the teachers or the trustees are false to their trust, or the nation really does not want them.
('21', 390, 1, 26, 910844) The programme of non co operation is based on the belief that the nation is tired of the present Government and wants to change it without resorting to
('21', 391, 0, 1, 910996) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 391, 1, 2, 911038) methods of violence.
('21', 391, 1, 3, 911059) The experience so far gained shows that the nation does definitely desire the change.
('21', 391, 1, 4, 911145) If there is failure or delay, it will be due to want of workers.

('21', 391, 2, 6, 911234) 227. OUR LATE TOUR
('21', 391, 3, 7, 911253) My experiences are becoming so much enriched by every tour that it is difficult for me to cope with them and give the results to the reader.
('21', 391, 3, 8, 911394) I must therefore content myself with adding to the stock on the necessity of discipline and organization.
('21', 391, 3, 9, 911500) I have dealt with our experiences up to the journey to Cawnpore.
('21', 391, 3, 10, 911565) I was dreading our approach to Cawnpore—the Cawnpore of Maulana Hasrat Mohani and Dr. Murarilal 1. They are both great workers.
('21', 391, 3, 11, 911693) The arrangements at the station were perfect.
('21', 391, 3, 12, 911739) A large crowd awaited us at the station.
('21', 391, 3, 13, 911780) But the discipline observed was so good that we were able to make our way through two solid rows of men without a single member moving before we had taken our seats in the cars.
('21', 391, 3, 14, 911958) What might have meant a waste of thirty minutes was finished within five.
('21', 391, 3, 15, 912032) The procession was happily abandoned.
('21', 391, 3, 16, 912070) The programme was as business like as the reception at the station.
('21', 391, 3, 17, 912138) We reached at about 8 o’clock.
('21', 391, 3, 18, 912169) We had only a day at our disposal, but during that time there was a meeting with the workers, a private interview with Mr. Frazer Hunt of the Chicago Tribune, a visit to the Widows’ Home, opening a national Gujarati school, a meeting of the Gujarati ladies (a crowded ladies’ meeting), opening of a national arbitration court, an open air meeting, and finally private chats with visitors.
('21', 391, 3, 19, 912558) All this was finished without any undue rush and strain.
('21', 391, 3, 20, 912615) There was at first a little confusion at the open air meeting.
('21', 391, 3, 21, 912678) It was discovered that no previous instructions were given to the volunteers.
('21', 391, 3, 22, 912756) But after a little effort, there too perfect silence reigned, and the audience listened to three heavy speeches amid perfect silence.
('21', 391, 3, 23, 912890) It is my conviction that as soon as we have organized and disciplined ourselves, swaraj will be established.
('21', 391, 3, 24, 912999) An organized refusal to be ruled by any foreign power is all that is needed in a country like ours.
('21', 391, 3, 25, 913099) Lucknow was a contrast.
('21', 391, 3, 26, 913123) There was utter confusion at the station and a seething mass of humanity.
('21', 391, 3, 27, 913197) It was a demonstration of undisciplined love.
('21', 391, 3, 28, 913243) All were pressing forward to

('21', 392, 1, 11, 913995) There was at night a vast meeting.

('21', 392, 2, 20, 914666) I must reluctantly omit the stirring events of Amritsar and Lahore and hasten to Bhiwani.
('21', 392, 2, 21, 914756) At Amritsar there was a huge but unorganized crowd at the station.
('21', 392, 2, 22, 914823) We evaded it by alighting at another platform.
('21', 392, 2, 23, 914870) The demonstration at Lahore we evaded by motoring there.
('21', 392, 2, 24, 914927) The night journey to Bhiwani was perfectly restless.
('21', 392, 2, 25, 914980) Crowds insisted on darshan.
('21', 392, 2, 26, 915008) One man suggested that mahatmas needed no rest and that it was their duty to give darshan.
('21', 392, 2, 27, 915099) Some were really angry that we all stolidly refused to move out of beds.
('21', 392, 2, 28, 915172) Another remarked that we must be highly inconsiderate not to respect the wishes of the people and get up to give darshan.
('21', 392, 2, 29, 915294) At length tired and sleepless, we reached Bhiwani.
('21', 392, 2, 30, 915345) Probably fifty thousand people had gathered from surrounding villages.
('21', 392, 2, 31, 915416) I was therefore afraid that we would be crushed to atoms.
('21', 392, 2, 32, 915474) But to my agreeable surprise, I found perfect order there.
('21', 392, 2, 33, 915533) There was no rush or noisy bustle at the station.
('21', 392, 2, 34, 915583) All kept their respective places.
('21', 392, 2, 35, 915617) The procession was comfortably managed in spite of a dense throng.
('21', 392, 2, 36, 915684) Order observed at the pandal was still more striking.

('21', 393, 2, 16, 917171) 228. IN DEFENCE OF MALAVIYAJI AND SHASTRIAR
('21', 393, 3, 17, 917215) TO THE EDITOR YOUNG INDIA
('21', 393, 5, 18, 917241) Mahatma Gandhi in his article headed “The Hallucination of Schools and Colleges” 1 while discussing the non co operation programme regarding the withdrawal of students from schools and colleges, admitting that the movement has been called “harmful” and “opposed to the best interests of the country”, says that Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya is its most uncompromising opponent.
('21', 393, 5, 19, 917617) Then he taxes himself to find out the reasons for this attitude of Panditji.
('21', 393, 5, 20, 917694) We quote Mahatma Gandhi : “The answer I have been able to find is that the latter do not consider the present Government as an unmixed evil as the former do.
('21', 393, 5, 21, 917852) In other words, the opponents do not sufficiently realize the significance of the Punjab and khilafat wrongs.” And
('21', 393, 6, 22, 917967) 1 Dated 29 9 1920
('21', 394, 0, 1, 917985) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 395
('21', 394, 1, 2, 918030) further on he proceeds to say : “It is unthinkable that Malaviyaji and Shastriar cannot feel the wrongs even as I do.
('21', 394, 1, 3, 918148) And yet that is precisely my meaning.” We assure Mahatma Gandhi that we have the most profound and sincere respect for him, but that would not blind us to the claims of others.
('21', 394, 1, 4, 918325) We hold no brief for Messrs Malaviyaji and Shastriar.
('21', 394, 1, 5, 918379) They can take care of themselves.
('21', 394, 1, 6, 918413) Panditji’s brilliant speech in the council, his touching appeal for funds for the “Jallianwala Bagh Memorial” and his recent stirring speech at the Empire Theatre, Bombay, supply an emphatic refutation to the suggestion that Mahatma Gandhi, quite unconsciously no doubt, has made.
('21', 394, 1, 7, 918694) Mr. Shastriar’s articles in the Servant of India 1, and his speeches on the Punjab tragedy also
('21', 394, 2, 8, 918790) reveal the burning patriotism, somewhat softened by the judicial mind of Mr. Gokhale’s worthy successor.
('21', 394, 2, 9, 918895) Both of these great men have sufficiently given vent to expressions of deep feeling in connection with the khilafat wrong.
('21', 394, 3, 10, 919018) Mahatma Gandhi himself has said so much on the question of individual liberty and the importance of following one’s conscience, that we can hardly believe that he would, by any action of his, try to curtail the one, or silence the other.
('21', 394, 3, 11, 919256) But that is what the article indirectly attempts to do.
('21', 394, 3, 12, 919312) That there is ample scope for difference of opinion in the adoption of means to attain the end is conceivable, but that so great an individualist as Mahatma Gandhi should attempt, however remotely, to curtail the expression of different views, is not so easy to imagine.
('21', 394, 4, 13, 919583) In conclusion, we appeal to Mahatma Gandhi not to make such equivocal
('21', 394, 5, 14, 919653) statements, we appeal to the modern Buddha not to excite emotions, to base
('21', 394, 6, 15, 919728) his arguments on reason alone, and trust he will see the impropriety of the
('21', 394, 7, 16, 919804) statements he has made and will hasten to make reparation for the same.
('21', 394, 8, 17, 919876) trust Mahatma Gandhi will allow us the same honesty of conviction and
('21', 394, 9, 18, 919946) freedom of opinion as Mahatma Gandhi claims for himself, though we have
('21', 394, 10, 19, 920018) the misfortune to differ from him.
('21', 394, 11, 20, 920053) Yours, etc.,
('21', 394, 12, 21, 920066) “SWADESHI” I gladly publish this letter.
('21', 394, 12, 22, 920107) I honour the writers for their defence of the two great patriots.
('21', 394, 12, 23, 920173) I wish they had permitted me to publish their names.
('21', 394, 12, 24, 920226) Let me however inform the reader that they are Gujaratis.
('21', 394, 12, 25, 920284) And it is a matter of pride to me that Gujaratis would resent like everyone else any aspersion upon the patriotism of either Malaviyji or Shastriji.
('21', 394, 12, 26, 920433) But I hasten to assure these friends that they will not be able to out do me in the race for honouring the two patriots.
('21', 394, 12, 27, 920554) For the time
('21', 394, 13, 28, 920567) 1 Organ of the Servants of India Society, Poona
('21', 395, 0, 1, 920615) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 395, 1, 2, 920657) being we differ in our views on matters of highest importance.
('21', 395, 1, 3, 920720) I have endeavoured honestly to find out the reason for the difference and have come to conclusion that they cannot feel as strongly as I do the khilafat and the Punjab wrongs.
('21', 395, 1, 4, 920896) Feelings are measured by acts, not by words.
('21', 395, 1, 5, 920941) Their diagnosis is different from mine.
('21', 395, 1, 6, 920981) From the two wrongs I deduce that I am to expect nothing good from this Government.
('21', 395, 1, 7, 921065) Not so they.
('21', 395, 1, 8, 921078) Therefore, whilst for them association with the Government is possible, for me it is impossible unless it repents of its sins.
('21', 395, 1, 9, 921205) Two surgeons may describe a particular disease by the same name and yet one may prescribe mere ointment and the other a dangerous surgical operation.
('21', 395, 1, 10, 921355) There need not be on that account any want of respect ascribed to the one who resorts to an operation.
('21', 395, 1, 11, 921458) And if the other were to seek the cause of difference in the methods of treatment, he would be entitled to say and be justified in saying that the one who prescribed the ointment treatment could not have realized the desperate nature of the disease, though he described it by the same name.
('21', 395, 1, 12, 921749) I wish to assure the writers further that in my statement of the case there is no equivocation.
('21', 395, 1, 13, 921845) Nor is there any desire on my part to curtail any one’s liberty, or silence the voice of conscience, least of the two partiots.
('21', 395, 1, 14, 921973) On the contrary, I have humility enough to own that though I feel sure that my diagnosis and method are both correct, [they] may be wrong.
('21', 395, 1, 15, 922112) And when I find that they are, I shall be quick enough to acknowledge my mistake.
('21', 395, 1, 16, 922194) Lastly, let me assure these friends that I have made it my business in life not to appeal to emotions, that is, excite passions but to put the most abstruse truths in simplest terms, so that the reason even of the illiterate masses may comprehend.

('21', 395, 2, 18, 922466) 229. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, DAKOR
('21', 395, 3, 19, 922503) October 27, 1920 This place where we have gathered is a centre of pilgrimage.
('21', 395, 3, 20, 922581) But India today is in such straits, such a sad plight, that even when we are in a holy place, we fail to realize the meaning of sanctity.
('21', 395, 3, 21, 922719) Moreover, I have not come here to have darshan of Ranchhodji 1. In these days, Ranchhodji has lost the power to set us free from our debt.
('21', 395, 3, 22, 922858) The reason for this is that we, his devotees, have no devotion, we have

('21', 396, 1, 4, 923137) When will God deliver us from this evil, this sin?
('21', 396, 1, 5, 923188) I have often heard that many pilgrims coming to Dakor do not conduct themselves properly.
('21', 396, 1, 6, 923278) On their way, they misbehave at places.
('21', 396, 1, 7, 923318) I do not know whether there is any truth in this talk.
('21', 396, 1, 8, 923373) But, if there is anything that our religion, that of Hindus and of Muslims, teaches us, it is above all to keep our desires or senses under control.
('21', 396, 1, 9, 923522) All religions teach us to look upon every woman in the world, according to her age, as our mother, our sister or our daughter.
('21', 396, 1, 10, 923649) I have heard, and I believe it, that pilgrims to Dakor violate this very first tenet of religion, and yet believe that a dip in the Gomati would purify them.
('21', 396, 1, 11, 923807) Can a dip be of any avail?
('21', 396, 1, 12, 923834) I do not even believe that they wish to be purified by a bath.

('21', 396, 1, 14, 923977) Even for those who accept family life, brahmacharya is a dharma.
('21', 396, 1, 15, 924042) Brahmacharya consists in controlloing all the five sense—hearing, sight, smell, taste and touch.
('21', 396, 1, 16, 924139) This dharma is not for the sannyasi only but also for all good householders.
('21', 396, 1, 17, 924216) One who does not follow these simple rules is none such.
('21', 396, 1, 18, 924273) This then, is our first duty if we would live rightly, remain independent and be no one’s slave—be it in Hindu society or in Muslim.
('21', 396, 1, 19, 924406) Someone told me that there would be many Dharalas 1 in this gathering and that I might address a few words to them.
('21', 396, 1, 20, 924522) What should I tell them?
('21', 396, 1, 21, 924547) This at least I must tell them, that, if they have any idea of religion, they should know that it does not tell them to rob others.
('21', 396, 1, 22, 924679) Rather than live by robbery, it would be better to commit suicide.
('21', 396, 1, 23, 924746) Rather than rob others that one may eat, it is better to starve to death.
('21', 396, 1, 24, 924820) Rather than rob for clothes, it is better to go naked.
('21', 396, 1, 25, 924875) This plea that I am making to the whole of India is not addressed to Vanias and Brahmins alone, but to everyone in the country, to Dheds 2, Bhangis 3, Dharals—to Muslims, Parsis, Christians and others.
('21', 396, 1, 26, 925077) I entreat you all that, if you wish to make India happy, your primary duty is to live in harmony with people of other faiths.
('21', 396, 1, 27, 925203) That is the duty of good neighbours.

('21', 409, 5, 13, 954616) 235. HOW TO CELEBRATE “DIWALI”
('21', 409, 6, 14, 954647) It would be no exaggeration to say that in this Kaliyuga we have no right to celebrate Diwali with so much jubilation.
('21', 409, 6, 15, 954766) Our celebrating Diwali implies that we feel we are living in Ramarajya.
('21', 409, 6, 16, 954838) Do we have Ramarajya in India today?
('21', 409, 6, 17, 954875) A king who is not prepared to listen to his subjects, under whose rule the subjects get no milk to drink, no food to eat and no cloth to wear, a king who massacres his innocent subjects, who trades in wine, hemp and opium, who, by eating pork, hurts the feelings of Muslims and by eating beef the feelings of Hindus, who threatens the very existence of Islam and gambles at horse racing—how can the subjects of such a king celebrate Diwali ?
('21', 409, 6, 18, 955317) Let no one labour under the delusion that this is an exaggerated picture; if there is anyone who has such fear, I shall be only too happy to be able to explain the thing to him in all humility.

('21', 411, 2, 15, 959114) 236. TEA STALLS
('21', 411, 3, 16, 959130) The closing of tea stalls in Gujarat is a change of no ordinary significance.
('21', 411, 3, 17, 959208) I congratulate the workers who took up this task and saw it through.
('21', 411, 3, 18, 959277) I hope this self denial will be permanent.
('21', 411, 3, 19, 959320) There was a time when we always had our meals in our homes and had no need to eat or drink anything outside.
('21', 411, 3, 20, 959429) Nowadays, we generally eat outside.
('21', 411, 3, 21, 959465) In consequence, we do not get good food to eat, and it is dear.
('21', 411, 3, 22, 959529) In this way, we make things dear for the poor.
('21', 411, 3, 23, 959576) Personally, I know of no virtue in tea.
('21', 411, 3, 24, 959616) Moreover, the tea made in shops is boiled and, therefore, harmful.
('21', 411, 3, 25, 959683) The most beneficial result of this movement, however, is that the consumption of milk has been reduced and its price has come down.
('21', 411, 3, 26, 959815) If the people exercise sufficient care, they can have [the consumption and price of] milk under control
('21', 412, 0, 1, 959919) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 413
('21', 412, 1, 2, 959964) and it may then be possible for the poor to have milk and ghee, things which they can now only dream of.
('21', 412, 1, 3, 960069) However, it is one thing to bring about the closure of tea stalls through the force of public opinion and quite another to seek to do so through coercion.
('21', 412, 1, 4, 960224) The attempts being made in Bombay to get them closed forcibly seem dreadful to me at any rate.
('21', 412, 1, 5, 960319) I have even addressed a letter 1 on this subject to the newspapers there.

('21', 412, 1, 7, 960437) I would rather that the teal stalls remained open than that they should be forced to close down.

('21', 412, 1, 9, 960631) It has pained me all the more to see my name used in this movement.
('21', 412, 1, 10, 960699) I can never associate myself with violence in any form whatever.
('21', 412, 1, 11, 960764) To me, vio lence is a denial of dharma.
('21', 412, 1, 12, 960804) I would not like to have even the best thing done under compulsion.
('21', 412, 1, 13, 960872) Even swaraj I would not have through violence.

('21', 413, 1, 2, 962617) 237. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, AHMEDABAD
('21', 413, 2, 3, 962659) October 31, 1920
('21', 413, 3, 4, 962676) Wherever I go in India in the course of my tours, women bless me with their darshan.
('21', 413, 3, 5, 962761) At every place, I meet thousands of them.
('21', 413, 3, 6, 962803) Today, I shall tell you a beautiful story.
('21', 413, 3, 7, 962846) By now there must be hardly any of you who has not heard of Amritsar.
('21', 413, 3, 8, 962916) A few days ago I was in this very town, where there had flowed the blood of thousands of our brethren and General Dyer had killed or wounded a thousand or fifteen hundred innocent people.
('21', 413, 3, 9, 963104) When I was in Amritsar, one day four women came to me early in the morning, at half past six.
('21', 413, 3, 10, 963198) There, the cold is much severer than it is here.
('21', 413, 3, 11, 963247) But the women felt that they ought to caution the man who, they thought, had been doing so much in their service.
('21', 413, 3, 12, 963361) One of them said to me : “Brother, what you are doing is good indeed, but you do not know that our men, and the women too, in some degree, have been deceiving you.” I was simply taken aback.
('21', 413, 3, 13, 963552) I asked them: “Why should they deceive me?
('21', 413, 3, 14, 963595) What can they hope to gain thereby?” She said : “The men are cunning.
('21', 413, 3, 15, 963665) They lie to you.
('21', 413, 3, 16, 963682) We have understood, of course, that you need only pure men and women to help you in your work and this is reason why we, women, follow you everywhere, that we may be filled with your ideals.” The sister then used a Sanskrit word.
('21', 413, 3, 17, 963912) One would not expect to hear a Sanskrit word like this from a Punjabi woman.
('21', 413, 3, 18, 963989) Perhaps you also do not understand its meaning.
('21', 413, 3, 19, 964037) she told me that their men were not jitendriya, and that the women, too, were not so to the extent I wanted them to be or believed they were.
('21', 413, 3, 20, 964179) I understood from this hint what they meant.
('21', 413, 3, 21, 964224) Jitendriya means one who has the senses under control.
('21', 413, 3, 22, 964279) In other words, a man or woman who does not mind hearing evil with the ears or speaking evil with the tongue is not jitendriya.
('21', 413, 3, 23, 964407) In this context, what is specifically meant is that a man who is not loyal to one woman, his wife, or a woman to one man, her husband, is not jitendriya.
('21', 413, 3, 24, 964561) The sister asked me : “You want us to control our anger, but how can one who cannot restrain carnal desire restrain anger?
('21', 413, 3, 25, 964684) And how can one who is unable to restrain anger make sacrifices?” * * * Tulsidas and the Gita teach that association with the wicked is to be shunned.
('21', 413, 3, 26, 964835) The present rule also is a rule of the wicked, of the base.
('21', 413, 3, 27, 964895) Rather than that the children be educated in the schools of this Government, it is better that they should go without education.
('21', 413, 3, 28, 965024) “Who will maintain us if the son is not educated?”—such fears are
('21', 414, 0, 1, 965090) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 415
('21', 414, 1, 2, 965135) unnecessary.
('21', 414, 1, 3, 965148) How do they, who have no sons, maintain themselves?
('21', 414, 1, 4, 965200) It is God who maintains us.
('21', 414, 1, 5, 965228) * * * If you can make only thick rotlas 1 and another woman can make them thin, will you eat your thick ones or beg thin ones from the other?

('21', 414, 1, 7, 965457) By doing so, on the contrary, you will make the poor man’s cloth dear for him.

('21', 414, 1, 14, 966454) Even today, I can show you thousands of Damayantis 4 in the country.
('21', 414, 1, 15, 966523) I once suggested to a woman that she should bathe regularly.
('21', 414, 1, 16, 966584) She replied that she would do so if I gave her another garment to change into.
('21', 414, 1, 17, 966663) Such is the miserable plight of the country today.
('21', 414, 1, 18, 966714) * * * To secure swaraj, to start new schools—this requires money and I cannot collect it from a tree.
('21', 414, 1, 19, 966816) When I started this begging in Dakor, one woman who made her living by working a quern parted with her ring to me.
('21', 414, 1, 20, 966931) Two or three other women gave me rings, necklaces, etc.

('21', 418, 1, 2, 971378) 243. SPEECH AT MEHMEDABAD
('21', 418, 2, 3, 971404) November 1, 1920 I should like to talk to you about a great many things today, but I do not wish to hold forth for long.
('21', 418, 2, 4, 971525) India is passing through a difficult period.
('21', 418, 2, 5, 971570) I can hardly describe the sad plight of the country.
('21', 418, 2, 6, 971623) I have just said, at a women’s meeting, 1 that the present Government is a Satanic Government, a Ravanarajya possessed by a Satanic spirit.
('21', 418, 2, 7, 971763) We have two outstanding instances of this: that of the Punjab and of the khilafat.
('21', 418, 2, 8, 971846) About the khilafat, promises have not been kept; there has been a senseless massacre.
('21', 418, 2, 9, 971932) He alone who is imbued with a demoniac spirit, a Satanic spirit, would act in such a manner.
('21', 418, 2, 10, 972025) Tulsidas has des cribed such a government as a demoniac government.
('21', 418, 2, 11, 972093) Co operation with such a government is not possible, indeed it is one’s duty, one’s dharma, to withhold co operation from it.
('21', 418, 2, 12, 972219) Should we take help from such a government or accept favours from it, we would be a party to its acts of injustice and its sins.
('21', 418, 2, 13, 972348) So long as we share in its sin, the people cannot be happy.
('21', 418, 2, 14, 972408) What can we do to carry out non co operation?
('21', 418, 2, 15, 972454) One way is for all of us to co operate with one another.
('21', 418, 2, 16, 972511) There should be the utmost co operation among all Indians—Hindus, Muslims, Parsis, Christians and others.
('21', 418, 2, 17, 972617) A demon can govern only by setting his subjects against one another.
('21', 418, 2, 18, 972686) This is what our Government has actually done.
('21', 418, 2, 19, 972733) It has set Hindus and Muslims against each other and, in the Madras Presidency, Brahmins and non Brahmins against each other.
('21', 418, 2, 20, 972859) If it could have its way, it would create trouble here as well.
('21', 418, 2, 21, 972923) I have already received a few letters.
('21', 418, 2, 22, 972962) Some Dheds and Bhangis have asked me where they stand in the non co operation movement.
('21', 418, 2, 23, 973050) I see their point and tell you that non co operation is not feasible without unity amongst us.
('21', 418, 2, 24, 973145) Unity cannot be achieved through hypocrisy.
('21', 418, 2, 25, 973189) Unless we are just to one another, there can be no unity.
('21', 418, 2, 26, 973247) For this we must have the strength to make sacrifices, the strength to subordinate self interest; we should be able to lay down our lives.
('21', 418, 2, 27, 973386) We shall not get swaraj by killing people, setting fire to houses, or removing railway tracks.
('21', 418, 2, 28, 973481) To be able to win swaraj, we should become pure, and to be pure is to be self controlled.
('21', 418, 2, 29, 973571) We shall not be able to carry on our work so long as we do not eliminate fraud and dishonesty from us.
('21', 418, 2, 30, 973674) The attempt to stop the

('21', 434, 1, 2, 1009649) 249. TO THE PARENTS OF ALIGARH BOYS
('21', 434, 2, 3, 1009685) GENTLEMEN, I know that the best of my friends are bewildered at many of my doings at the present moment, not the least among which is my advice to the youth of the country.
('21', 434, 2, 4, 1009858) I do not wonder at their bewild erment.
('21', 434, 2, 5, 1009898) I have undergone a complete transformation in my attitude toward the system of Government under which we are labouring.
('21', 434, 2, 6, 1010018) To me it is Satanic even as was the system under Ravana’s rule according to the scriptures of my religion.
('21', 434, 2, 7, 1010125) But my friends are not so convinced as I am of the supreme necessity of ending this rule, unless the system undergoes a radical change and there is definite repentance on the part of the rulers.
('21', 434, 2, 8, 1010320) I share too your concern about your boys who are learning at Aligarh.
('21', 434, 2, 9, 1010390) You will believe me when I tell you that I do not wish to hurt your feelings.
('21', 434, 2, 10, 1010468) I am, myself, the father of four boys whom I have brought up to best of my lights.
('21', 434, 2, 11, 1010551) I have been an extremely obedient son to my parents, and an equally obedient pupil to my teachers.
('21', 434, 2, 12, 1010650) I know the value of filial duty.
('21', 434, 2, 13, 1010683) But I count duty to God above all these.
('21', 434, 2, 14, 1010724) And in my opinion, the time has come for every young man and young woman in this country to make their choice between duty to God and duty to others.
('21', 434, 2, 15, 1010874) I claim to know the yourth of our country in a fairly intimate manner.
('21', 434, 2, 16, 1010945) I know that in the majority of cases the youth of our country have the determining of their higher education in their own hands.
('21', 434, 2, 17, 1011074) I know cases in which parents find it difficult to wean their children from what to them (the parents) appears to be the infatuation of their children about higher education.
('21', 434, 2, 18, 1011249) I am convinced that I am doing no violence to the feelings of parents when I address our young men and ask them to leave their schools or colleges even in spite of their parents.
('21', 434, 2, 19, 1011428) You will not be astonished to learn that, of the parents of hundreds of boys who have left schools or colleges, I have received only one protest and that from a Government servant whose boys have left their college.
('21', 434, 2, 20, 1011644) The protest is based on the ground that they were not even consulted before their boys decided to leave their college.
('21', 434, 2, 21, 1011763) In fact my advice to the boys was even to discuss with their parents the question of leaving before arriving at a decision.
('21', 434, 2, 22, 1011887) I have myself appealed to thousands of parents at scores of meetings at which hardly a parent has objected to the proposition of leaving Government controlled schools.
('21', 434, 2, 23, 1012055) Indeed they have with
('21', 435, 0, 1, 1012077) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 435, 1, 2, 1012119) wonderful unanimity passed resolutions on non co operation including the item on schools.
('21', 435, 1, 3, 1012209) I therefore take leave to think than the parents of the Aligarh boys are no less convinced than the others of the necessity of withdrawing their children from schools and colleges supported or controlled by a Government that has participated in betraying the Mussulmans of India and has wantonly humiliated the nation through its barbarous treatment of the Punjab.
('21', 435, 1, 4, 1012574) I hope you know that I am as eager as any that our boys’ education should not be neglected.
('21', 435, 1, 5, 1012666) But I am certainly more eager that their education is received through clean hands.
('21', 435, 1, 6, 1012750) I hold it to be unmanly for us to continue to receive grants for our education from a Government which we heartily dislike.
('21', 435, 1, 7, 1012874) In my humble opinion that would be even dishonourable and disloyal.
('21', 435, 1, 8, 1012942) Is it not better that our children should receive their education in a free atmosphere, even though it may be given in humble cottages or in the shade of trees and under teachers who, being themselves free, would breathe into our children the spirit of freedom?

('21', 438, 5, 10, 1019596) Now I was present at the meeting and had reason to listen to every word that Maulana Abdul Bari said with the greatest attention, and I must confess that the speech could not possibly provide any occasion for Mr. Douglas’ secession.
('21', 438, 5, 11, 1019829) I deny that the Maulana Saheb either condoned the murder, or by calling Mr. Willoughby a Kafir had any intention of insulting Christians.

('21', 438, 5, 13, 1020013) He never protested at the meeting, he never complained to me.

('21', 438, 5, 15, 1020299) I could not associate myself with an insult to any of the great religions of the world.

('21', 464, 5, 9, 1078767) A half truth is always very dangerous.
('21', 464, 5, 10, 1078806) I do not suggest that Marutirao has deliberately made statements which he knows to be half truths.
('21', 464, 5, 11, 1078905) We often, through misunderstanding, state and act on half truths.
('21', 464, 5, 12, 1078971) Undoubtedly, there are Brahmins in this world who ask others to wash their feet and then drink that water, and among books which pass as holy with the Hindus there are some which play on people’s ignorance; but we should use our reason to distinguish between truth and deception.
('21', 464, 5, 13, 1079251) It would be suicide to hate the entire Brahmin community and keep away from it simply because a few of them have told lies and misled the people with false Shastras.
('21', 464, 5, 14, 1079417) I should like to tell the non Brahmins, on oath, that I have studied the Koran, the Zend Avesta and the Bible according to the best of my ability.

('21', 464, 5, 16, 1079685) I believe, all the same, that no other religion values renunciation and self control, as a form of yajna as much as Hinduism does.
('21', 464, 5, 17, 1079816) I want to tell the Hindus that we owe these ideas of yajna, of self sacrifice, to none other than the Brahmins.

('21', 468, 4, 16, 1089195) 269. WHAT TO DO ON THE 16TH OF NOVEMBER
('21', 468, 5, 17, 1089235) In connection with this, Mr. Gandhi writes in Navajivan 2 as follows: The 16th of November is somewhat of a day of trial for the people, because on that day members for the legislative councils will be elected throughout the Bombay Presidency.
('21', 468, 5, 18, 1089479) What will the voters do on that day?
('21', 468, 5, 19, 1089516) What is their duty?
('21', 468, 5, 20, 1089536) 1. I hope that no voter will go to the polling booth to record his vote.
('21', 468, 5, 21, 1089609) 2. That all the voters will remain indoors.
('21', 468, 5, 22, 1089653) 3. In case a meeting is held away from the polling booth, voters will attend it and express themselves against being represented on the council.

('21', 469, 1, 2, 1089908) 4. The work of canvassing signatures and of asking voters not to vote will cease for 24 hours from the night of the 15th instant.
('21', 469, 1, 3, 1090038) 5. Volunteers too will not do anything on the 16th instant to dissuade voters from voting.
('21', 469, 1, 4, 1090129) 6. In short, those who choose to vote should have the day wholly at their disposal.
('21', 469, 1, 5, 1090213) How can we hope to convert voters whom we have not been able to persuade till the 15th?

('21', 469, 2, 11, 1090582) 270. DIFFICULTIES IN OUR WAY
('21', 469, 3, 12, 1090611) Our difficulties are of two kinds; those that are imposed from without and those that are of our own creation.
('21', 469, 3, 13, 1090722) The latter are far more dangerous, because we often hug them and are therefore reluctant to remove them.
('21', 469, 3, 14, 1090827) Thus, for instance, the disturbance created at Mrs. Besant’s recent meetings at Bombay was of our own making.
('21', 469, 3, 15, 1090937) And it is easier to deal with a seditious meetings proclamation than the disturbance at Mrs. Besant’s meetings.
('21', 469, 3, 16, 1091049) A prohibition of “seditious” meetings gives us strength.
('21', 469, 3, 17, 1091106) Disturbances created by us undoubtedly weaken our cause.
('21', 469, 3, 18, 1091163) The verbal rowdyism at Mrs. Besant’s meeting was a type of violence.
('21', 469, 3, 19, 1091232) It was a distinct departure from the creed of non violent non co operation.
('21', 469, 3, 20, 1091308) It may easily result in physical violence.
('21', 469, 3, 21, 1091351) Those who created the disturbance ought to realize its seriousness for the sacred cause they have at heart.
('21', 469, 3, 22, 1091459) It is the very worst training we can give ourselves in swaraj.
('21', 469, 3, 23, 1091522) Swaraj pressupposes mutual toleration of views, no matter how distasteful they may be to us.
('21', 469, 3, 24, 1091615) If the non co operationists refuse to listen to the other party’s views, they lay themselves open to the same charge as the Government, which they complain comes to decisions without considering their view point.
('21', 469, 3, 25, 1091828) Non co operation against the Government is based on, and is possible with, co operation among ourselves.
('21', 469, 3, 26, 1091933) We must bring about as far as possible and consistently with our creed, harmony among ourselves.
('21', 469, 3, 27, 1092030) Rowdyism is hardly the way to do so.
('21', 469, 3, 28, 1092067) By their action at
('21', 470, 0, 1, 1092086) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 471
('21', 470, 1, 2, 1092131) the meetings in question non co operationists have still further estranged from themselves Mrs. Besant and her friends and followers.
('21', 470, 1, 3, 1092265) The loss is patent enough.
('21', 470, 1, 4, 1092292) They have certainly gained no new adherents by their rowdyism.
('21', 470, 1, 5, 1092355) In so far as the students were concerned in the insult offered to Mrs. Besant, they have discredited themselves at a critical period in their evolution.
('21', 470, 1, 6, 1092508) They are called upon, in the name of religion and country, to disregard the wishes even of their parents, should they dissuade them from leaving schools tainted with Government grant or affiliation.
('21', 470, 1, 7, 1092707) Such disregard is permissible only to sons and daughters who have cultivated the sense of scrupulous respect and obedience towards their parents and elders.
('21', 470, 1, 8, 1092864) That disobedience is a virtue only when it is resorted to in response to a higher call and has not a trace of bitterness, hostility, or resentment in it.
('21', 470, 1, 9, 1093018) It is a positive vice when it becomes thoughtless, insolent and rowdy.
('21', 470, 1, 10, 1093089) The one ennobles, the other degrades.
('21', 470, 1, 11, 1093127) And after all, do we not owe anything to Mrs. Besant’s years, her past brilliant services, and her sex?
('21', 470, 1, 12, 1093231) The rising generation will commit suicide if it becomes ungrateful.

('21', 470, 1, 14, 1093415) She does so from pure motives.

('21', 470, 1, 17, 1093608) And it is our duty respectfully to consider what she says.
('21', 470, 1, 18, 1093667) But I have been told that unless, at her meetings, an emphatic dissent is expressed, she would make capital of our supposed silence, and claim that here is a larger body of Indian opinion at her back than is really the case.
('21', 470, 1, 19, 1093892) Surely rowdyism is not the only way of expressing dissent.
('21', 470, 1, 20, 1093951) The best and the chosen way would be not to attend her meetings, unless we wish to go in order to be convinced.
('21', 470, 1, 21, 1094063) We need not swell her audience when we know that we do not approve of her views.
('21', 470, 1, 22, 1094144) The other way, if we must attend, is to enter our respectful dissent at the end of the meeting, or if we consider her remarks to be offensive to express our dissent by courteously walking out.
('21', 470, 1, 23, 1094337) A noisy demonstration is a sign of our weakness.
('21', 470, 1, 24, 1094386) A dignified withdrawal is a proof of our strength.
('21', 470, 1, 25, 1094437) Rowdyism is, as a rule, intended to cover a minority that wishes to break up a meeting.
('21', 470, 1, 26, 1094525) A majority conscious of its strength produces an eloquent and electrical effect both on the speaker, and his, or her, minority of followers.
('21', 470, 1, 27, 1094666) It is true that this rowdyism is not a result of the movement of non co operation.
('21', 470, 1, 28, 1094749) It is a legacy of our past.
('21', 470, 1, 29, 1094777) We have been,

('21', 471, 1, 3, 1094935) Applause and shouts of dissent are essentially a Western institution.
('21', 471, 1, 4, 1095005) With the, for us, new method of non violent non co operation, the old must go.
('21', 471, 1, 5, 1095084) The two cannot co exist.
('21', 471, 1, 6, 1095109) If we are engaged in a duel between religion and irreligion, and if we truly represent the forces of religion, we shall have to give up even verbal violence and learn dignified ways of dealing with our opponents.

('21', 471, 2, 9, 1095592) 271. IF I AM ARRESTED 1
('21', 471, 3, 10, 1095616) I have been constantly thinking of what the people would do in case I am arrested.
('21', 471, 3, 11, 1095699) My co workers also have been putting this question to me.
('21', 471, 3, 12, 1095757) What would be the plight of India if the people took to the wrong path through love run mad?
('21', 471, 3, 13, 1095850) What would be my own plight in such a case?
('21', 471, 3, 14, 1095894) Rivers of bloodshed by the Government cannot frighten me; but I would be deeply pained even if the people did so much as abuse the Government for my sake or in my name.
('21', 471, 3, 15, 1096063) It would be disgracing me if the people lost their equilibrium on my arrest.
('21', 471, 3, 16, 1096140) The nation can achieve no progress merely by depending upon me.
('21', 471, 3, 17, 1096204) Progress is possible only by their understanding and following the path suggested by me.
('21', 471, 3, 18, 1096293) For this reason,I desire that the people should maintain perfect self control and consider the day of my arrest as a day of rejoicing.
('21', 471, 3, 19, 1096428) I desire that even the weaknesses existing today should disappear at that time.
('21', 471, 3, 20, 1096508) What can be the motive of the Government in arresting me?
('21', 471, 3, 21, 1096566) The Government are not my enemy, for I have not a grain of enmity towards them.
('21', 471, 3, 22, 1096646) But they believe that I am the soul of all this agitation, that, if I am removed, the ruled and the rulers would be left in peace, that the people are blindly following me.
('21', 471, 3, 23, 1096819) Not only the Government but some of our leaders also share this belief.
('21', 471, 3, 24, 1096891) How, then, can the Government put the people to the test?
('21', 471, 3, 25, 1096949) How can the Government ascertain whether the people understand my advice or are simply

('21', 472, 1, 2, 1097190) dazzled by my utterances?

('21', 477, 2, 3, 1106920) November 15, 1920 SISTERS AND BROTHERS, I have done a good many things in my life; some of them I feel proud of, though some others I regret.
('21', 477, 2, 4, 1107062) A few of them were very responsible undertakings.
('21', 477, 2, 5, 1107112) But I should like to state here—I am sure I am guilty of no exaggeration—that nothing I have done so far can stand comparison with what we are about to do today.
('21', 477, 2, 6, 1107274) I am aware of a great risk in this undertaking, but not because I fear that it may prove harmful to the nation; what pains me, or rather the incongruity I feel, is this, that I am not fit for the task I have undertaken.
('21', 477, 2, 7, 1107494) I do not say this as a matter of formality, I speak from the heart.
('21', 477, 2, 8, 1107562) If I knew that the present undertaking related to education in the real sense of the term, this preface would not have been necessary.
('21', 477, 2, 9, 1107697) This Mahavidyalaya is not being established with the sole object of imparting education; it [also] aims at helping the student to acquire a means of livelihood and when, in this respect, I compare it with Gujarat College and other similar institutions, I simply shudder.
('21', 477, 2, 10, 1107968) In this, too, I am not exaggerating.
('21', 477, 2, 11, 1108005) What comparison is possible between Gujarat College and other similar colleges, on the one hand, and this small Mahavidyalaya of ours?
('21', 477, 2, 12, 1108140) To my mind, of course, it is great, but I am afraid that in your eyes, as you compare this Vidyalaya with the colleges you have in India, this Mahavidyalaya 2 probably appears an Anuvidyalaya 3. You are very likely thinking in terms of brick and mortar.
('21', 477, 2, 13, 1108394) Of this, to be sure, I see more in Gujarat College.
('21', 477, 3, 14, 1108446) 1 Literally, an institution of higher learning.
('21', 477, 3, 15, 1108494) The Mahavidyalaya was a constituent college of the Gujarat Vidyapith which had been established as a national university without a Government charter.
('21', 477, 3, 16, 1108645) Gandhiji was appointed chancellor for life.
('21', 477, 3, 17, 1108689) Many more institutions, colleges and schools were afterwards affiliated to or recognized by the Vidyapith, the total number of students in these institutions standing at 30,000 in 1923. The activities of the Vidyapith were interrupted for temporary periods in consequence of the Civil Disobedience Movements of 1930 and 1932 and the Quit India Movement of 1942. It is now one of the national universities with a charter from the Government of India and seeks to promote Gandhiji’s ideal of craft centred and service oriented education.
('21', 477, 3, 18, 1109225) 2 Maha, great; Anu small 3 ibid

('21', 489, 6, 7, 1137202) 279. A TRIUMPH OF NON VIOLENCE
('21', 489, 7, 8, 1137233) The communique 3 issued by the Government of India on the non co operation movement may be regarded as its first triumph of a striking order.
('21', 489, 7, 9, 1137375) For the Government have decided in view of its non violent character to refrain, for the time being at any rate, from repressing by violence what they consider to be an unconstitutional movement.
('21', 489, 7, 10, 1137571) The Government, as well as the people, may be congratulated upon this wise decision; and I have not the slightest doubt that, if the movement continues to be purged of all violence, whether in deed or in word, it would not only be impossible for the Government to resort to repression, but also to resist the ever growing volume of public opinion against it, when that opinion is backed by well directed acts of renunciation of Government patronage or support, on a national scale.

('21', 493, 3, 9, 1148384) 280. BRAHMINS AND NON BRAHMINS
('21', 493, 4, 10, 1148415) When I wrote in Young India on the non Brahmin question in Maharashtra, I little realized that the non Brahmin case was largely, if not entirely, a political matter, and that the complaint was not so much against the Brahmins as a class by the non Brahmins as a class, as by some educated non Brahmins against the Nationalists who were mostly Brahmins.
('21', 493, 4, 11, 1148768) Non Brahmins include the Lingayats, the Marathas, the Jains and the “untouchables”.
('21', 493, 4, 12, 1148852) The latter, however, have a separate grievance against the other non Brahmins, in that they are isolated as much by the non Brahmins.
('21', 493, 4, 13, 1148986) The case for the educated non Brahmins is again not common to all.
('21', 493, 4, 14, 1149053) It may however be stated in the following terms : 1. Educated non Brahmins do not possess the same political power that the Brahmins possess.
('21', 493, 4, 15, 1149195) The latter have the largest number of Government posts, and seats on representative bodies, although the former are numerically by far the strongest.
('21', 493, 4, 16, 1149345) 2. Some Brahmins debar the Lingayats from the inner
('21', 494, 0, 1, 1149397) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 495
('21', 494, 1, 2, 1149442) sanctuary of temples, which the latter claim as their own; and this false (in their estimation) claim is supported by the Brahmins in general.
('21', 494, 1, 3, 1149585) 3. The Brahmins treat all non Brahmins as Shudras, and treat them precisely as the British treat all Indians.
('21', 494, 1, 4, 1149695) In my opinion the non Brahmin case is exceedingly weak and is certain to disappear from the public life of Maharashtra, if the Brahmins of the Nationalist party carry out the Congress non co operation programme in its entirety.
('21', 494, 1, 5, 1149923) The movement owes its vitality, not to the religious or the social disability, but to the political ascendancy of the Brahmins, which the latter undoubtedly enjoy by right of merit.
('21', 494, 1, 6, 1150105) That grievance must vanish if the Nationalist Brahmins, having evolved larger views about swaraj, taboo all Government posts and boycott the councils and nominated seats on municipalities.
('21', 494, 1, 7, 1150294) It is clear to me, that the Government in accordance with its confirmed policy will play the non Brahmins against the Brahmins even without the knowledge of the former, and endeavour to prolong its lease of life by fostering quarrels between the two, and holding out political inducements, to the non Brahmins.
('21', 494, 1, 8, 1150605) It is clear, too, that the Brahmins will take the wind out of the non Brahmin sail, and make that opposition innocuous by a rightrenunciation of every form of Government patronage.
('21', 494, 1, 9, 1150786) The reason why the question has assumed a more acute form is that non Brahmin leaders are trying to influence the electorate in their favour, and are telling the electors that the non Brahmins being weak, they must seek the British alliance.
('21', 494, 1, 10, 1151028) Brahmin leaders are naturally trying to influence the same electors and dissuade them from using their vote.
('21', 494, 1, 11, 1151137) This gives rise to bad blood but not more than when the moderates and the nationalists are fighting.
('21', 494, 1, 12, 1151238) The most painful part of the situation, however, is that the non Brahmin leaders, who claim to represent the masses and to feel for them, by their co operaion with the Government, or by seeking to better their condition by Government aid, will actually tighten the hold of the Government on the masses.
('21', 494, 1, 13, 1151541) And by their countenancing the Government aid they will make more difficult the remedy of the Punjab and the khilafat wrongs.
('21', 494, 1, 14, 1151667) The non Brahmin policy is thus demonstrably suicidal.
('21', 494, 1, 15, 1151721) Whatever their grievance against the Brahmins or the Nationalists, their remedy certainly does not lie through alliance with a Government, whose creed is economic exploitation of the masses, and to that end also their emasculation.
('21', 494, 1, 16, 1151953) For this refusal to right the Punjab, and partly
('21', 495, 0, 1, 1152002) 496 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 495, 1, 2, 1152044) even the khilafat wrong, is based upon the policy of keeping up the British prestige at any cost.
('21', 495, 1, 3, 1152142) One lakh of Englishmen cannot keep under subjection thirty crores of human beings merely by brute force.
('21', 495, 1, 4, 1152247) But it can, and does, consolidate its power, by making them pro gressively helpless, in a most subtle manner.
('21', 495, 1, 5, 1152357) I venture therefore to warn the non Brahmin leaders against the danger of the co operation with the Government which is bound to hurt the very cause which they seek to espouse.
('21', 495, 1, 6, 1152534) They will not better the economic condition of the masses by gaining a few Government posts, or by being elected legislative councillors.
('21', 495, 1, 7, 1152672) Judged by the economic standard, thirty five years of our political activity have resulted in disaster.
('21', 495, 1, 8, 1152776) The masses of India today are less able to stand the ravages of famine and disease than they were fifty years ago.
('21', 495, 1, 9, 1152891) They are less manly than they were at any period in the history of the nation.
('21', 495, 1, 10, 1152970) The impending calamity of the non Brahmin leaders running into the arms of the Government for the supposed betterment of their political condition can easily be averted by the great Brahmin party.
('21', 495, 1, 11, 1153167) It is intelligent, it is strong, it has the traditional prestige of authority.

('21', 495, 1, 14, 1153377) But it is not enough.
('21', 495, 1, 15, 1153399) Bitterness will still remain, unless the Brahmins extend the hand of fellowship to those who feel weak and injured.

('21', 496, 1, 2, 1154177) 281. THE GUJARAT NATIONAL COLLEGE
('21', 496, 2, 3, 1154211) Never have I felt my position as embarrassing as I felt it at the time of inaugurating the Gujarat National College.
('21', 496, 2, 4, 1154328) 1 I knew that it marked a silent and peaceful revolution which my audience might not understand or appreciate.
('21', 496, 2, 5, 1154439) I felt too that the National College would suffer in comparison, if brick and mortar or academic distinction were to be the test.
('21', 496, 2, 6, 1154569) It was hardly possible to have a national building, when a Government, which claimed to be the ultimate proprietor of all our earthly possessions, had ceased to be the mouthpiece of the nation, and had even forfeited its confidence—yet the new college has in it possibilities which it is impossible to forecast.
('21', 496, 2, 7, 1154881) May it be the seed of national freedom!
('21', 496, 2, 8, 1154921) Its success will depend upon the combined efforts of the teachers and the scholars.
('21', 496, 2, 9, 1155005) Without any literary merit, I have accepted the office of chancellor, and performed the inauguration ceremony, because I believe in non co operation being the only remedy for national regeneration, and because I believe that the staff of the College and members of the senate are truly imbued with the same belief.
('21', 496, 2, 10, 1155320) I have approached my task in prayerful humility.
('21', 496, 2, 11, 1155369) May God protect the new University and the College!

('21', 498, 6, 7, 1159275) As to protesting at the meeting, I left the meeting in a state of disgust, and judging from the present mood of audiences at political meetings, it is open to serious doubt whether I would have obtained a hearing if I had got up to take exception to the speeches of the learned Maulanas.
('21', 498, 6, 8, 1159563) As to complaining to Mr. Gandhi, the matter concerned me and my future conduct, not merely as a non co operator but as a Christian, and however great a respect I may have for Mr. Gandhi, I refuse to admit him as my guide and to take counsel with him as to my conduct as a Christian.
('21', 498, 7, 9, 1159846) Mr. Gandhi further complains to having been misreported in one respect, but that obviously refers to the report of his speech by Mr. Mahadev Desai, and not by me, as the juxtaposition of the context is somewhat unfair to me.

('21', 500, 5, 11, 1164870) 284. SATYAGRAHA AND THE SUPPRESSED CLASSES
('21', 500, 6, 12, 1164913) TO THE EDITOR YOUNG INDIA
('21', 500, 8, 13, 1164939) In commenting on my letter in your leading article 1 of the 27th October, you have virtually admitted my principal contention that “we Hindus should wash our own blood stained hands before we ask the English to wash theirs” to borrow your own powerful phraseology.
('21', 500, 8, 14, 1165204) But are you not practically asking the English to do so?
('21', 500, 8, 15, 1165261) You admit that mine is “a proper question seasonably put”.
('21', 500, 8, 16, 1165320) Does it not strike you, then, that the present political movement which you have started is, to say the least, a bit premature?
('21', 500, 8, 17, 1165448) You further say, “that we have become the Pariahs of the Empire which is, in Gokhale’s language, the retributive justice meted out to us by a just God.” If that is so, does it not follow that we cannot permanently achieve our political ideals unless and until we remove the root cause or causes of that same “retributive justice” and that even if your present movement succeeds (which goodness forbid) in ousting the British and establishing independence, it will not be worth an hour’s purchase?
('21', 500, 8, 18, 1165945) For as our revered poet laureate Dr. Tagore says in his book on “Nationalism”, “no enduring political freedom can be built in this country on the quicksands of social slavery”, and further, “the real problem in this country is social and not political”.
('21', 500, 8, 19, 1166199) I know you too were of this opinion some time ago.
('21', 500, 8, 20, 1166250) I distinctly remember to have read in one of
('21', 500, 9, 21, 1166295) 1 Entitled “ ‘Depressed’ Classes”
('21', 501, 0, 1, 1166329) 502 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 501, 1, 2, 1166371) your speeches in the early days of your work here, that if only we Indians remove our internal evils and social handicaps, self government will come to us without our seeking or asking for it.
('21', 501, 1, 3, 1166564) I am profoundly sorry that you have changed your opinion since then.
('21', 501, 1, 4, 1166633) I regard it as nothing short of a national calamity.
('21', 501, 1, 5, 1166686) But I pray you not to misunderstand those of us who still hold the same view.
('21', 501, 1, 6, 1166764) It is because they still sincerely hold this view that the suppressed millions and the non Brahmins of Madras and the Deccan, who represent the masses of the people in these parts, have so resolutely set their faces against your political non co operation move ment which, in their judgment, is like putting the cart before the horse.
('21', 501, 1, 7, 1167099) They are not traitors to the country of their birth as you seem to think.
('21', 501, 1, 8, 1167173) Knowing them in a way in which you do not know them, I may assure you that they are no less sincere and patriotic than you yourself.
('21', 501, 1, 9, 1167306) They fervently believe that on the whole the British raj is the best for the time being, and that even if you succeed in establishing Indian independence tomorrow, it will be lost in no time to the Afghans or the Japanese, if it is not wrecked and broken to pieces on the rock of caste as it has been more than once in our long and chequered history.
('21', 501, 1, 10, 1167657) They, therefore, intend to make democracy safe for India before India achieves democracy—safe from internal enemies as well as external foes.
('21', 501, 1, 11, 1167799) That is why they, while thanking you for inviting them to join your movement, will thank you still more if you give it up and join them in their noble endeavours of making India a fit and lasting home for democracy.
('21', 501, 1, 12, 1168015) Phrases as “slaves of slaves” and “the greater includes the less” are, no doubt, admirable dialectics which might conceivably deceive the shallow, superficial reader, but they sound hollow in the ears of all practical minded folk.
('21', 501, 1, 13, 1168246) And it is neither correct nor fair to say, that the Government will be a hindrance in your way if you decide to work for the uplift of the suppressed millions.
('21', 501, 1, 14, 1168406) Why, they no less than we would thank you for it!
('21', 501, 1, 15, 1168456) It is too much to hope you will see your “error of judgment” yet and turn attention to the task of social amelioration which, to quote from your old speeches, is the surest and the best way of winning swaraj for India?
('21', 501, 2, 16, 1168675) Yours truly,
('21', 501, 3, 17, 1168688) 4 11 ’20 S. M. MICHAEL I gladly publish this reply.
('21', 501, 3, 18, 1168740) Evidently Mr. Michael is not a regular or careful student of Young India.

('21', 501, 3, 20, 1168898) He will find when swaraj is established by the method of non co operation, that there will be no Pariah or non Brahmin problem left to be solved.
('21', 501, 3, 21, 1169044) I adhere to my statement that amelioration of radical social evils meant an attainment of swaraj, but I did not then realize that the British Government was the greatest of all the social evils with which society was cursed.

('21', 503, 1, 2, 1171373) 286. LETTER TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE” 1
('21', 503, 2, 3, 1171413) BOMBAY, November 19, 1920
('21', 503, 3, 4, 1171439) SIR, I have just read the Express extract reproduced by you, attributing to me the opinion that Urdu should be the national script.
('21', 503, 3, 5, 1171571) Somebody has evidently perpetrated a joke at my expense, for I have never entertained any such opinion.
('21', 503, 3, 6, 1171675) What I have said to my friend and fellow worker Hasrat Mohani 2 is that in any scheme of national seducation Devnagri anal Urdu scripts should be compulsory.
('21', 503, 3, 7, 1171833) My opinion is that Devnagri is the most scientific and perfect script in the world and is therefore from that standpoint the most suitable national script.
('21', 503, 3, 8, 1171989) But I see no way out of the difficulty of Mussulmans in accepting it at the present moment.
('21', 503, 3, 9, 1172081) I therefore feel that the educated classes should know either script equally well.
('21', 503, 3, 10, 1172164) That which has greater vitality and is easier will then become the national script, especially when Hindus and Mussulmans as well as the [other] classes have ceased altogether to distrust one another and have learnt to decide non religious questions on purely national lines.
('21', 503, 4, 11, 1172440) From a photostat: S.N. 7344
('21', 503, 5, 12, 1172468) 287. LETTER TO RANGASWAMI IYENGAR

('21', 504, 6, 9, 1173710) It is perhaps impertinent for me to express my sympathy with you when I am the direct or indirect cause of distress to you.

('21', 505, 3, 10, 1175477) If he comes over to the Ashram, by all means have him, otherwise he may go to the [National] University hostels.

('21', 505, 3, 13, 1175724) Keep him company and see that he does not feel ill at ease in the Ashram.
('21', 505, 3, 14, 1175798) Get to know Velabehn.
('21', 505, 3, 15, 1175820) She has made an excellent impression on me.
('21', 505, 3, 16, 1175864) She seems to be an upright and virtuous woman.
('21', 505, 3, 17, 1175911) Her children, too, seemed to be well behaved, but you will be able to observe these things more carefully.
('21', 505, 3, 18, 1176018) Though I would not like to put too heavy a burden on them; I might do so without knowing it.

('21', 505, 3, 20, 1176233) When speaking, one doesn’t knowingly commit errors; actually, if errors are pointed out from time to time, one learns to avoid them.
