('21', 509, 3, 9, 1183891) NAVAJIVAN, 21 11 1920
('21', 509, 4, 10, 1183913) 295. CONDITIONS FOR SWARAJ AND PRACTICE OF UNTOUCHABILITY
('21', 509, 5, 11, 1183971) An innocent resolution of the Gujarat Vidyapith has created a commotion in Ahmedabad, Bombay and elsewhere.
('21', 509, 5, 12, 1184079) 1 The resolution is to the effect that no school which excludes Antyajas 2 will be recognized.
('21', 509, 5, 13, 1184174) It is but a corollary of a principle adopted by the Vidyapith, but it has hurt many Hindus and some have been telling me that I should not have raised the issue for discussion.
('21', 509, 5, 14, 1184351) There are some who argue that my views on the practice of untouchability are a blot on my Hinduism.
('21', 509, 5, 15, 1184451) Some others question my claim to be a Sanatani 3 Hindu on the score of these views.
('21', 509, 5, 16, 1184535) My reasons for believing that I am one, I shall examine some other time.
('21', 509, 5, 17, 1184608) At the moment I merely wish to show that the Vidyapith has not adopted a new policy by passing the resolution it did.
('21', 509, 5, 18, 1184726) It would have been a new policy had it resolved otherwise.
('21', 509, 5, 19, 1184785) The Antyajas attend Government schools at present.
('21', 509, 5, 20, 1184836) There are many such students in Bombay schools.
('21', 509, 5, 21, 1184884) There are some in the high schools in Gujarat, too.
('21', 509, 6, 22, 1184936) 1 The Gujarat Vidyapith had been established as a national university without a Government charter.
('21', 509, 6, 23, 1185036) At a meeting of its senate on October 31, 1920, under the presidentship of Gandhiji, it was resolved that the so called untouchables would not be excluded from any schools approved by the Vidyapith.
('21', 509, 6, 24, 1185235) 2 The lowest caste among Hindus, traditionally regarded as untouchables 3 One who accepts the essentials of Hinduism as unalterable
('21', 510, 0, 1, 1185367) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 511
('21', 510, 1, 2, 1185412) If we have been sending Vaishnava 1 children to such schools till now, shall we adopt a new policy and exclude Antyaja children from national schools?
('21', 510, 1, 3, 1185563) Do we hope to win swaraj while reviving the practice of untouchability at the same time?
('21', 510, 1, 4, 1185652) We do not mind what happens in trains, hotels, courts and mills; shall we, then, perpetuate the practice in schools alone where, all the time under teachers, eyes, pupils can attend only if they observe the ordinary rules of cleanliness ?
('21', 510, 1, 5, 1185891) We do not treat Muslims, Parsis, Christians and Jews as untouchables; if we do, we cannot hope to make them our brethren; shall we, then, treat the Antyajas, who are a limb of Hindu society, as untouchables even in schools which pupils belonging to non Hindu communities can attend?
('21', 510, 1, 6, 1186174) It has been charged against me that, by getting the Vidyapith to pass the resolution in question, I too have, by this means, used coercion on Hindu society in the same manner that the Government does.
('21', 510, 1, 7, 1186375) I would humbly remind those who level this charge that I do not prevent them from running schools according to their ideas, and I request them not to prevent me.
('21', 510, 1, 8, 1186537) Where is coercion in this?
('21', 510, 1, 9, 1186564) In fact, it is they who employ coercion on me by standing in my way.
('21', 510, 1, 10, 1186633) Is it right for them to prevent those who believe that the practice of untouchability hampers our efforts to create a national consciousness from working for its removal?
('21', 510, 1, 11, 1186804) No one will hamper them if they try to set up vidyapiths with other ideals, which recognize this practice as part of dharma.
('21', 510, 1, 12, 1186929) That you may be prevented by the impossibility of succeeding in the attempt is a different matter.
('21', 510, 1, 13, 1187028) I am firm in my view that the practice of untouchability is contrary to dharma.
('21', 510, 1, 14, 1187108) It is an instance of the evil extremism in Hinduism.
('21', 510, 1, 15, 1187161) To keep alive extremism is duragraha 2 and to try to eliminate it through tapashcharya is satyagraha.
('21', 510, 1, 16, 1187263) Firmness in seeking and upholding truth—this is dharma.
('21', 510, 1, 17, 1187319) Firmness in holding on to an evil practice sanctioned by custom is adharma.
('21', 510, 2, 18, 1187395) Non co operation is a science of purification.
('21', 510, 2, 19, 1187442) Unless we have purified ourselves, we cannot employ it.
('21', 510, 2, 20, 1187498) So long as we regard one of our own limbs as untouchable, we ourselves, Hindus, and our
('21', 510, 3, 21, 1187586) 1 Vaishnavas are devotees of Vishnu, one of the Hindu Trinity, and his incarnation, Krishna 2 Pursuit of a wrong cause, or of the right cause in an unworthy manner 3 The opposite of dharma
('21', 511, 0, 1, 1187775) 512 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 511, 1, 2, 1187817) neighbours, the Muslims and others, will remain the untouchables that we have become.
('21', 511, 1, 3, 1187903) I am convinced that the Hindu society has fallenbecause of the evil of untouchability.
('21', 511, 1, 4, 1187990) Thanks to our sin, we ourselves have become untouchables.
('21', 511, 1, 5, 1188048) We looked upon the Antyajas as untouchables in the name of religion; the Government, too, has reduced us to the position of untouchables in the sincere belief that it was doing its duty in this.
('21', 511, 1, 6, 1188243) Like the Antyajas, we too have accepted as natural and carry the stigma, branded by foreigners, of being untouchables.
('21', 511, 1, 7, 1188362) Besides, just as we argue that the Antyajas themselves do not consider it an insult to be treated as untouchables, the Government too argues that we accept our inferior status as natural and that it is a few revolutionaries like Gandhi who, misleading the people, describe their natural state as degradation.
('21', 511, 1, 8, 1188671) I entreat the Hindus of Gujarat not to stop, because of thepresent commotion, the great effort they are making in the non co operation movement.
('21', 511, 1, 9, 1188816) If they look upon the practice of untouchability as a part of dharma, they may be sure they will never get swaraj.
('21', 511, 1, 10, 1188931) Perhaps they will argue that, in that case, they will prefer the present Government, Satanic as it is.
('21', 511, 1, 11, 1189034) The reply to this is that, even under its rule, they will not be able to go on treating as untouchables those whom they look upon as such; not only this, but our present pitiable condition in which we find that all of us have become Antyajas will become ever more so.
('21', 511, 1, 12, 1189302) Let us not forget this self evident truth.
('21', 511, 1, 13, 1189345) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 21 11 1920
('21', 511, 2, 14, 1189383) 296. TRIUMPH OF NON VIOLENCE
('21', 511, 3, 15, 1189412) Whether you speak of renunciation of the sword, or compassion or peace or non violence, the meaning is the same.
('21', 511, 3, 16, 1189525) The Government’s latest resolution 1 is a triumph of this principle.
('21', 511, 3, 17, 1189594) The Government has
('21', 511, 4, 18, 1189613) 1 This resolution, released early in November 1920, stated, among other things, “ .
('21', 511, 4, 19, 1189697) the Government have hitherto refrained from instituting criminal proceedings, or taking any other action against those .
('21', 511, 4, 20, 1189818) who have advocated simultaneously with non co operation abstention from violence, and they have instructed local Governments to take action against those persons only who .
('21', 511, 4, 21, 1189991) have by speech or writing openly incited the public to violence .
('21', 511, 4, 22, 1190057) [The Government] have been reluctant to interfere with the liberty of speech and the freedom of the Press .
('21', 511, 4, 23, 1190165) .” India in 1920.
('21', 512, 0, 1, 1190183) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 513
('21', 512, 1, 2, 1190228) given up, for the present, its intention of arresting the Ali Brothers 1
('21', 512, 2, 3, 1190301) and me and has decided to try, instead, todefeat non co operation with the force of reason, that is, with the help of the Moderates.
('21', 512, 2, 4, 1190434) For this decision, the Government and the people may compliment each other.
('21', 512, 2, 5, 1190510) I look upon it as a triumph of peaceful war, that is, of non violence.
('21', 512, 2, 6, 1190581) Had we decided to carry on the struggle through secret or open assassinations or by burning down buildings or removing railway tracks, we would not have succeeded in educating public opinion and would not have acquired the strength to speak out the truth courageously; that is, we would not have been ready or fit for swaraj.
('21', 512, 2, 7, 1190907) Even as late as a year ago, we could not express our ideas as freely as we do today.
('21', 512, 2, 8, 1190992) By taking care that the Government should have nothing to fear from us, we ourselves have acquired courage.
('21', 512, 2, 9, 1191100) We have come to have the confidence that, since we ourselves have no guilty thought in us, others can do us no harm.
('21', 512, 2, 10, 1191217) We have an instinctive feeling that, as we do not intend violence to anyone, no one will use violence against us either.
('21', 512, 2, 11, 1191338) In this way the atmosphere has become clean.
('21', 512, 2, 12, 1191383) We want to win swaraj by changing people’s ideas through the force of love and reason, and this has obliged the Government also to rely on reason.
('21', 512, 2, 13, 1191530) It is only when, afraid of our opponent, we employ unclean strength like his that we learn unclean ways and so become weak.
('21', 512, 2, 14, 1191654) In the result, both sides become weak.
('21', 512, 2, 15, 1191693) If we meet uncleanliness with cleanliness, the total result would be less of uncleanliness and the people, the world, would be the happier for this.
('21', 512, 2, 16, 1191842) Thus, peace—non violence—is ever victorious.
('21', 512, 2, 17, 1191887) The Government’s resolution is a notable instance of such victory.
('21', 512, 2, 18, 1191954) We still do not have the spirit of perfect peace among us.
('21', 512, 2, 19, 1192013) The tongue has not yet become clean, the heart is not pure.
('21', 512, 2, 20, 1192073) We have anger in us.
('21', 512, 2, 21, 1192094) Because of this, our remaining peaceful does not produce the effect it should.
('21', 512, 2, 22, 1192173) We shall have swaraj the day our struggle is free from all bitterness and the workers are perfectly sincere.
('21', 512, 2, 23, 1192282) The common people will do what we do.
('21', 512, 2, 24, 1192320) The path taken by the eminent is followed by the rest.
('21', 512, 3, 25, 1192375) 1 Mahomed Ali (1871 1931) and Shaukat Ali (1873 1938).
('21', 512, 3, 26, 1192430) Both the brothers were nationalist Muslim politicians and took a leading part in the Khilafat movement.
('21', 512, 3, 27, 1192534) Mahomed Ali, orator and journalist, led the Khilafat delegation to England in 1920 and was president of the Indian National Congress in 1923. 2 An allusion to the Bhagavad Gita, iii, 21
('21', 513, 0, 1, 1192720) 514 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 513, 1, 2, 1192762) The Government resolution has a sting in it’s tail, since in our attitude, too, there is a similar sting in the tail.
('21', 513, 1, 3, 1192880) How many of us accept non violence as a matter of principle, as I do?
('21', 513, 1, 4, 1192950) My friend Shaukat Ali does not believe in non violence as a principle valid for all time; he believes in it only as a temporary expedient.
('21', 513, 1, 5, 1193089) He accepts non violence as a policy.
('21', 513, 1, 6, 1193126) If all of us accord primacy to non violence and accept it as our chosen means, we can have swaraj this very day.
('21', 513, 1, 7, 1193239) It is because I believe that we shall do this before long that I say we may get swaraj within a year.
('21', 513, 1, 8, 1193341) Of what value is swaraj without non violence?
('21', 513, 1, 9, 1193387) The way to destroy adharma is to establish dharma.
('21', 513, 1, 10, 1193438) The moment we declare solemnly that this regime is an enemy of dharma, we must learn to abide by dharma.
('21', 513, 1, 11, 1193543) How can a person who has no regard for dharma point an accusing finger at another for being like him?
('21', 513, 1, 12, 1193645) What right has the kettle to call the pot black?
('21', 513, 1, 13, 1193694) Adharma can be destroyed only through dharma.
('21', 513, 1, 14, 1193740) If there is none to submit to oppression, there can be no oppression.
('21', 513, 1, 15, 1193810) Since we have not become wholly truthful, the Government’s resolution is full of falsehood and hypocrisy.
('21', 513, 1, 16, 1193916) It says that, because our campaign is non violent, the curbs on newspapers have been removed.
('21', 513, 1, 17, 1194010) This is not quite true.
('21', 513, 1, 18, 1194034) Some newspapers are still harassed.
('21', 513, 1, 19, 1194070) As for people who have been imprisoned, the reason given is that they had incited people to violence.
('21', 513, 1, 20, 1194172) This also is not correct.
('21', 513, 1, 21, 1194198) These persons may not have been quite innocent in their language, but they certainly did not incite the people to violence; even if it is a fact that they did so, the Government has not succeeded in establishing their guilt.
('21', 513, 1, 22, 1194423) The law is that even if a man is, in fact, guilty, he cannot be punished unless his guilt is proved.
('21', 513, 1, 23, 1194524) In trying to discredit non co operation, the Government has had recourse to much hypocrisy.
('21', 513, 1, 24, 1194616) It says that non co operation will spread anarchy.
('21', 513, 1, 25, 1194667) It knows, however, that simultaneously with non co operation, a new order is taking shape.
('21', 513, 1, 26, 1194758) Keeping away from the education provided by the Government does not mean anarchy in education but means receiving education for freedom in place of the present education for slavery; keeping away from the Government’s courts does not mean increase in crime but settlement of disputes panchas 1; boycott of councils does not mean rejection of laws—of restraint—but voluntary obedience to laws in the nature of self imposed restraints instead of to arbitrary laws;
('21', 513, 2, 27, 1195221) 1 Literally, panch means “the five”, a board of arbitrators; an arbitrator or board of arbitrators in general
('21', 514, 0, 1, 1195331) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 515
('21', 514, 1, 2, 1195376) refraining from the use of foreign cloth does not mean going naked, but means the hallowed use, for protection of the body, of sacred cloth produced by the people with what art they possess; refusing to join as policemen in the Government’s service means enabling the people to protect themselves; thus, non co operation with the \the Government means perfect co operation by the people among themselves.
('21', 514, 1, 3, 1195781) If there is no limit to the Government’s hypocrisy, there is no limit to its arrogance either.
('21', 514, 1, 4, 1195876) To hold out false threats is to be arrogant.
('21', 514, 1, 5, 1195921) To make impossible claims is to be arrogant.
('21', 514, 1, 6, 1195966) The Government claims that it protects the country against external aggression and says that, were non co operation to succeed, that is, were the Government to withdraw, the country would be wholly defenceless, like a child, and an easy prey to invasion by any nation.
('21', 514, 1, 7, 1196235) The truth of the matter is that, if co operation prevails among us, if we Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs, Christians and Parsis believe ourselves to be one nation and be ever fearless and self reliant, if the people produce their requirements—of food, clothing, etc.—in the country itself, no one will dare cast covetous eyes on India.
('21', 514, 1, 8, 1196563) Non violence—peacefulness—does not mean cowardice.
('21', 514, 1, 9, 1196614) It means the spirit of manliness in its perfection.
('21', 514, 1, 10, 1196666) Should India be ever invaded in this manner, it should defeat the enemy by its perfect non violence or, if it cannot thus endure the enemy’s pride, the Kshatriya communities in the country—Sikhs, Muslims and others— should give the aggressor his due.
('21', 514, 1, 11, 1196917) Non violence—peace— does not mean submission to others, does not mean weakness.
('21', 514, 1, 12, 1196997) He alone can forgive who is brave.
('21', 514, 1, 13, 1197032) When the hour comes for bidding good bye to the Government, India will not be lustreless as she is today but will be radiating light in all directions.
('21', 514, 1, 14, 1197184) If anyone asks whether it is possible that we should see this day within a year, the only reply to such a sceptic can be that, unless such a day comes, India will not be fit for swaraj at all.
('21', 514, 1, 15, 1197377) If, moreover, such a happy day is to come, it will come only through non violent non co operation.
('21', 514, 1, 16, 1197476) I for one see the day approaching nearer.
('21', 514, 2, 17, 1197518) In all humility I entreat our elders among the Moderates to see the Government’s insincerity and not to walk into the snare laid by it.
('21', 514, 2, 18, 1197654) I do not go into the Government’s charges relating to education.
('21', 514, 2, 19, 1197719) If there had been no co operation from parents, the
('21', 515, 0, 1, 1197771) 516 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 515, 1, 2, 1197813) movement would not have progressed so far as it has done.
('21', 515, 1, 3, 1197871) I have advised sons to disobey parents, respectfully, only when the latter are without faith and the sons themselves possess soul force.
('21', 515, 1, 4, 1198008) This advice is not immoral, or thoughtless or unmannerly.
('21', 515, 1, 5, 1198066) All Shastras give the young the right to think for themselves.
('21', 515, 1, 6, 1198129) The lesson to be drawn from the Government’s resolution is that, just as we have almost succeeded in overcoming its armedmight by our renunciation of arms, so also we should slash its snare of hypocrisy and duplicity with the golden knife of fearless truthfulness and not ignorantly walk into it.
('21', 515, 1, 7, 1198426) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 21 11 1920
('21', 515, 2, 8, 1198464) 297. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('21', 515, 3, 9, 1198508) DELHI, November 21, 1920
('21', 515, 4, 10, 1198533) Asked whether he thought he would be able to run all the educational institutions in this country without taking any financial aid from the Government, Mr. Gandhi replied: Yes, if I can carry the country with me, I think it is quit.
('21', 515, 4, 11, 1198766) possible to run all the present institutions without any Government aid.
('21', 515, 5, 12, 1198839) In reply to the enquiry whether the success hitherto achieved by non co operation made him confident of its ultimate triumph, Mr. Gandhi said: Yes, certainly.
('21', 515, 6, 13, 1198998) To the question, “Are the non co operation and the Khilafat agitation really two separate movements or have they been merged into one another for the realization of any particular object”, Mr. Gandhi said: Non co operation has been adopted by the country as a means to an end.
('21', 515, 6, 14, 1199275) It has been adopted for the rectification of the Khilafat wrongs, the Punjab wrongs and the attainment of swaraj.
('21', 515, 7, 15, 1199389) When Mr. Gandhi was asked if, in spite of all that was happening, he was still as sanguine as ever in the belief that India would attain self government within a year or so, he said: I still consider it possible to attain swaraj in India within one year if India responds sufficiently, but whilst I think that the response is not quite as adequate as it might have been, it is adequate enough to make me not to despair of more in the near future.

('21', 516, 2, 3, 1199914) APPENDIX I
('21', 516, 3, 4, 1199925) V. J. PATEL’S NOTE ON DRAFT INSTRUCTIONS
('21', 516, 4, 5, 1199966) BOMBAY, September 22, 1920
('21', 516, 5, 6, 1199993) While I agree, generally speaking, with most part of the draft instructions
('21', 516, 6, 7, 1200069) contained in the report I feel I should be failing in my duties as a member of the
('21', 516, 7, 8, 1200152) Sub committee were I to endorse them wholesale in solemn silence.
('21', 516, 7, 9, 1200218) I therefore
('21', 516, 8, 10, 1200230) write this separate note explaining my views on some of the points dealt with in
('21', 516, 9, 11, 1200311) the report.
('21', 516, 10, 12, 1200323) 1. I regret, I cannot see my way to accept the suggestion contained in the report that the Congress has approved of Mr. Gandhi’s full programme of non co operation and that having adopted the first stage for immediate application it has merely to determine later on the pace for the remaining three stages.
('21', 516, 10, 13, 1200630) My reasons briefly are : (1) The Congress did not as a matter of fact discuss the merits or demerits of the remaining three stages of Mr. Gandhi’s programme.
('21', 516, 10, 14, 1200788) The issue was not directly raised, debated and determined upon.
('21', 516, 10, 15, 1200852) (2) In my opinion approval by the Congress of all stages of Mr. Gandhi’s programme would offend against the first article of the Congress constitution which restricts the Congress to the use of all “constitutional means” for attainment of self government.
('21', 516, 10, 16, 1201108) The stage which involves resignation of Government employees particularly those in the Military department can hardly be deemed “constitutional”.
('21', 516, 10, 17, 1201254) I should be perfectly prepared to support any proposal for the substitution of the word “peaceful” for the word “constitutional” in the first article.
('21', 516, 10, 18, 1201405) But unless the necessary change is made in the “constitution” Congress cannot approve all the stages of Mr. Gandhi’s programme.
('21', 516, 11, 19, 1201533) I therefore respectfully submit that All India Congress Committee should delete the paragraph in the report which contains the suggestions in question
('21', 516, 12, 20, 1201684) 2. Boycott of Government functions, etc.
('21', 516, 13, 21, 1201725) Perhaps the omission of instructions in the report on this is due to inadver tence.
('21', 516, 13, 22, 1201809) The following are the lines on which instructions under this item should be prepared :
('21', 516, 14, 23, 1201896) (1) Deputations and public meetings to ask Durbaris to have their names removed from the list.
('21', 516, 14, 24, 1201991) (2) Deputations and public meetings to be organized on the occasion of a Levy, Durbar or such other functions in order to urge upon persons likely to attend them, the necessity of abandoning the idea organized by
('21', 517, 0, 1, 1202204) 518 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 517, 1, 2, 1202246) Government, local body, association, or any private individual in honour of an officer of Government, similar steps should be taken to induce people not to attend such function.[sic] Deputations and public meetings should also be organized to request local bodies, associations, or private individuals not to give any address to any officer of Government or hold or organize any function in his honour.
('21', 517, 2, 3, 1202649) 3. Gradual boycott of Government schools and colleges.
('21', 517, 3, 4, 1202704) I cannot accept the interpretation in the report of the adjective “Gradual” in this clause.
('21', 517, 3, 5, 1202796) I fail to understand how the All India Congress Committee can advise immediate withdrawal of boys and girls from schools and colleges in face of the introduction of the adjective “Gradual” by the Congress, an adjective which did not find place in the clause as originally proposed by Mr. Gandhi.
('21', 517, 3, 6, 1203092) In my opinion the the All India Congress Committee could only adopt one of the two courses mentioned below in order to give effect to this part of the Congress Resolution : (1) An All India propaganda for the withdrawal of boys and girls from schools and colleges pari passu with the establishment of national institutions.
('21', 517, 3, 7, 1203416) Such a propaganda must necessarily require huge funds and call for incessant activites and yet it will not be possible, I am afraid, to show any tangible results for a long time to come.
('21', 517, 3, 8, 1203603) (2) Concentration of all our efforts in making an experiment of the establishment of national education and simultaneous withdrawal of boys and girls from schools and colleges in some select area e.g., Gujarat in the Bombay Presidency.
('21', 517, 3, 9, 1203839) Under such a scheme, it is possible to show definite results within reasonable time and if the experiment is found successful, other parts of India will soon follow the example.
('21', 517, 4, 10, 1204017) 4. Boycott of British courts.
('21', 517, 5, 11, 1204047) Here too I cannot accept the meaning given to the word “Gradual” in the report.
('21', 517, 5, 12, 1204127) Vigorous propaganda through the country preaching to the masses the desirability of referring their dispute to arbitration simultanesouly with the establishment of arbitration courts will yield results better than any propaganda for immediate withdrawal of lawyers from British courts would do.
('21', 517, 5, 13, 1204422) Better still I would recommend the concentration of our efforts in this direction in some select areas and making the experiments as thoroughly as possible.
('21', 517, 5, 14, 1204579) In the meantime lawyers all over the country should be asked to contribute a quota of their income to the National Fund.
('21', 517, 5, 15, 1204700) From this Fund, lawyers who desire to suspend their practice and devote their full time to public affairs may be maintained.
('21', 517, 6, 16, 1204825) 5. Boycott of councils.
('21', 517, 7, 17, 1204849) I am of opinion that for some time to come at any rate we must concentrate all our energies and efforts in making the boycott of councils as complete as possible.
('21', 517, 7, 18, 1205012) We must create an impression and this we can do by concentrating on any one of the items of our programme.
('21', 517, 7, 19, 1205119) In order that the non co operation movement may take root, grow, develop and ultimately succeed, we must act in such a way as to show some tangible results of our activities in the near future.
('21', 517, 7, 20, 1205313) This can be best done by taking up in initial stages only one item and working it up as thorough as we can.
('21', 518, 0, 1, 1205421) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 519
('21', 518, 1, 2, 1205466) This being my view, I have suggested above that the work in connection with the boycott of schools and courts be localized to select areas in order that we might be able to put forth sufficient efforts to make the boycott of councils as complete as possible.
('21', 518, 1, 3, 1205725) I would therefore like to supplement the instructions contained in the report on this item by following suggestions : (1) Public meetings should be held immediately in all constituencies and resolutions passed asking candidates to withdraw.
('21', 518, 1, 4, 1205966) (2) Even after elections are over continuous propaganda by way of deputations and public meetings in order to bring pressure to bear on the candidates to resign their seats.
('21', 518, 1, 5, 1206140) (3) Voters with whose votes a constituency has returned a member should be repeatedly approached and asked to influence the members to resign.
('21', 518, 2, 6, 1206283) 6. In the form embodied in the report to be signed by the voters I would suggest one alteration.
('21', 518, 2, 7, 1206380) The last sentence should be dropped and the following words substituted.
('21', 518, 2, 8, 1206453) “We do hereby declare further that we do not desire do be represented on any legislative bodies unless they are established under a constitution for full “swaraj” that is complete responsible Government in order to enable us to secure justice in the matters of the “khilafat”, “the Punjab” and the like.
('21', 518, 3, 9, 1206757) 7. Boycott of foreign goods.
('21', 518, 4, 10, 1206786) I cannot endorse the view that this is an unfortunate interpolation due to a misapprehension.
('21', 518, 4, 11, 1206880) No doubt the phraseology of the clause is too sweeping and will in all probability be devised at the next Congress.
('21', 518, 4, 12, 1206996) In the meantime, it is the duty of every non co operator to give effect to the recommendation as far as practicable.
('21', 518, 4, 13, 1207113) Perhaps the All India Congress Committee might give instructions recommending the boycott of certain specified goods of British origin to start with.
('21', 518, 5, 14, 1207263) 8. Publicity Boards.
('21', 518, 6, 15, 1207284) I strongly feel that in our struggle for freedom full pubicity of our activities from time to time not only in United Kingdom, but also in America is absolutely essential.
('21', 518, 6, 16, 1207456) This was the opinion of Lokamanya and it is also the opinion of Lala Lajpat Rai.
('21', 518, 6, 17, 1207537) One noticeable feature of the Egyptian Nationalist Movement was its extensive foreign propaganda.
('21', 518, 6, 18, 1207635) My interviews with the Irish and Egyptian Nationalists during my stay in England this year have convinced me that without simultaneous publicity in foreign countries [our efforts] will not yield results they otherwise would.
('21', 518, 6, 19, 1207860) I therefore unhesitatingly recommend that simultaneously with our activities in the field of non co operation in this country two strong Publicity Boards should be immediately established, one to be located in London and the other in New York.
('21', 518, 6, 20, 1208104) I append herewith a copy of the issue of the Egyptian Circular dated November 15th, 1919, to give to the members of the All India Congress Committee some idea of the kind of publicity work carried on by the Egyptian Nationalists.
('21', 518, 7, 21, 1208334) Finally I should like to say a word or two which I should have said in the earlier part of this note.
('21', 518, 7, 22, 1208436) On the question of boycott of titles, etc., the draft instructions contained in the report are all right so far as they go.
('21', 518, 7, 23, 1208560) But they should in
('21', 519, 0, 1, 1208579) 520 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('21', 519, 1, 2, 1208621) my opinion be supplemented on the following lines :
('21', 519, 2, 3, 1208673) (1) All Indian newspapers should in future in all their writings drop all references to titles and the title holders should be addressed or referred to as Mr. or Esquire.
('21', 519, 3, 4, 1208844) (2) No Indian newspaper should in future publish in their columns any Honours’ list or any nominations by Government.
('21', 519, 4, 5, 1208962) (3) Indian Public in addressing title holders should drop all references as in the case of newspapers.
('21', 519, 5, 6, 1209065) V. J. PATEL

('21', 519, 8, 9, 1209118) MAHADEV DESAI’S NOTES OF GANDHIJI’S SPEECH AT LAHORE
('21', 519, 9, 10, 1209171) The following is an English rendering of brief notes of Mr. Gandhi’s Lahore speech1 contributed by Mr. Mahadev Desai to Navajivan of the 4th instant :
('21', 519, 10, 11, 1209322) Mr. Gandhi referred mainly to the imprisonment of Moulvi Zafar Ali Khan in his speech.
('21', 519, 10, 12, 1209409) He said that the Moulvi had already secured his liberty by going to jail, while we were still slaves.
('21', 519, 10, 13, 1209511) He repeated with special stress the words of the Moulvi that this Empire would collapse, and added that the Government was sure to be uprooted if it did not give us justce in the Punjab and khilafat matters; and that it was the duty of all Indians to do their might towards its overthrow, keeping themselves within the paths of truth and justice; because to destroy this oppressive Government was to obey the word of God.
('21', 519, 11, 14, 1209933) He further said that “there are two ways by which we can see Moulvi Zafar Ali Khan.
('21', 519, 11, 15, 1210017) One is that he should apologize for his words and be acquitted; but that he will never do.
('21', 519, 11, 16, 1210108) The second is that we should enter the jail.
('21', 519, 11, 17, 1210153) Sikhs, Hindus, Mohammedans, whoever have the strength to do what he did, can secure his acquittal by entering the jail.
('21', 519, 11, 18, 1210273) But those who will request the Governement to set him at liberty will thereby commit a national crime.
('21', 519, 11, 19, 1210376) I called the Sikhs brave.
('21', 519, 11, 20, 1210402) They have shed their own blood for the sake of this Government.
('21', 519, 11, 21, 1210466) Other races are brought into submission with their help.
('21', 519, 11, 22, 1210523) It is due to them that hundreds of Arabs and Egyptians have been cut down.
('21', 519, 11, 23, 1210598) And today how are the Sikhs rewarded for all their bravery?
('21', 519, 11, 24, 1210658) Ask that of Sardar Goharsingh of Shekhupur.
('21', 519, 11, 25, 1210702) If the Sikhs would do their duty by their Hindu and Mohammedan brethren, they would surely bring about the release of Moulvi Zafar Ali Khan and also swaraj.”
('21', 519, 12, 26, 1210860) Mr. Gandhi further said that he was deeply pained by the remark of a fakir during the speech of Maulana Mahomed Ali, that so long as materials are not ready for
('21', 519, 13, 27, 1211021) 1 Vide “Speech on Non co operation, Lahore”, 19 10 1920.
('21', 520, 0, 1, 1211078) VOL. 21 : 1 JULY, 1920 21 NOVEMBER, 1920 521
('21', 520, 1, 2, 1211123) the use of the sword, we can do nothing but harm ourselves by resorting to the sword.
('21', 520, 1, 3, 1211209) He was altogether opposed to the use of the sword and expected that the Maulana would agree with him in the end.
('21', 520, 1, 4, 1211322) Murder of one Englishman would result not in our independence but in thousands of Jallianwalas.
('21', 520, 1, 5, 1211418) Even an encounter with arms would necessitate training and sacrifice.
('21', 520, 1, 6, 1211488) He then dilated upon the necessity of self control with special stress upon the conquest of the senses, and in conclusion advised the audience to demand justice from the Government in the Punjab and khilafat matters, and failing to receive that to paralyse the Government by renouncing all connection with it.
('21', 520, 1, 7, 1211798) They should either get Zafar Ali Khan released or enter the jails themselves.
('21', 520, 2, 8, 1211876) Young India, 24 11 1920
